I believe commissioner Katainen will push for the implementation of the package and ensure the growth, jobs and investment most EU citizens expect since the crisis began in 2009. The EPP Central Committee meeting in Riga presented five pillars for growth and jobs: stability, access to capital for SMEs, the European single market, smart investments and strengthening industry in connected Europe. I believe that the combination of these packages of measures will have a positive impact on growth and the 2016 revision of the MFF will put the focus on further targeting the budget towards jobs, growth and competitiveness.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – I congratulate the Commission on the presentation of the Investment Plan. Europe now needs investment to ensure long-term and stable prosperity. More positive to say about the plan presented is difficult. It does not balance financial flows with basics, it is unclear how the eur 315 billion is planned to be invested. Euro. The so-called innovative financial engineering instruments, which have to increase the value of EU investment by as much as 15 times over 7 years, look more like securities speculation in optimistic emerging markets than in long-term investment in regional growth. I would also like to point out that such plans are being published at a time when the EU budget does not find the funds to offset the Union's commitments for projects for the period 2007-2013. Ideas can be drawn from a green investment plan based on the real potential mobilisation of public sector funds. We are realistic, so we do not believe that one euro of public expenditure will attract more than two from the private sector. The impact of the measures we propose will be much more sustainable – a cleaner environment, reduced pollution, a more sustainable and resource-efficient economy. The Greens propose a fundamental reorientation of the economy and the promotion of social and environmentally friendly innovations, and the creation of an effective, externally independent and energy union. This ensures the use of the plan to address social exclusion, poverty problems, and create dignified living conditions for all citizens.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: napisan. – I support the roadmap put forward by the European Commission, which is a good incentive to kick-start growth. Europe must become more attractive to investors, and this investment plan will contribute to improving our competitiveness. The return on private investment is always higher and it is therefore good that this project has the ambition to mobilise private investment in particular.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The Investment Plan for Growth and Development in the European Union, presented by European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, is a great encouragement after the global economic crisis to which neither the EU remained immune. The recession did not bypass Croatia either, resulting in the departure of a large number of young people from Croatia, as well as high unemployment, especially for young people.  I welcome the announced cooperation with the European Investment Bank, which should provide €5 billion, while the EU budget will provide €16 billion, as we can achieve economic growth and jobs through coordinated action alone. According to the Commission President's announcements, the new plan will finance strategic projects related to education, research, innovation, investment in renewable energy sources, modernisation of the transport sector and more. This strategic planning raises the optimism of croatian residents regarding new jobs and economic growth and additional optimism of the inhabitants of the Croatian south regarding transport connections with the rest of the EU.  Given the strategic nature of this plan, and as a deputy member of the Transport and Tourism Committee and given that there is a part of the Union that is not yet road-related to the rest of the EU, I expect the Commission to recognise the project of continuing to build the Pelješac bridge as strategic, as it would ensure the continuity of not only Croatian territory but also the territory of the EU.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Having swapped austerity for investment, we are taking a step in the right direction, but far from the giant step we are entitled to expect. We will not be allies of the Commission if it only proposes smokescreens. Investing, and investing well: it's essential! If Europe remains timid, it will lose any chance of prosperity and recovery of European employment. We will be there to constantly remind President Juncker that Europe must have ambition, that missteps are forbidden and that a fairer Europe is not an option but an imperative. Many observers question this multiplier effect of 15, which you take Mr Juncker for granted. Even in times of fat cows, we've never seen such leverage, it's really amazing. I hope that it is not the pope's visit yesterday that makes you think that the "multiplication of breads" or "financial miracles" are easy things to achieve.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. – After years of imposing a strict austerity policy on the Member States on the Member States, I am pleased that the new Commission has recognised the need for investment to lift Europe out of the crisis. With only hard savings, we can't do that. This investment plan is therefore a break with the past and therefore welcomes it. However, the plan is not ambitious enough.  It should have gone much further, both in terms of the amount that will be invested and the origin of those funds and the priorities that are being put forward. The amount being made available to enable public investment is limited and is also mainly a reorientation of existing budget lines. That's disappointing. Moreover, the proposed leverage effects appear to be unrealistically large.  But also in terms of substantive priorities, the plan could be a lot more ambitious for me! In order to prepare the European Union for the future, the transition to a sustainable economy must be radically chosen. Investments in energy efficiency, tackling climate change, sustainable transport, the digital economy and human capital (education and training) are priorities. With the vague priorities put forward in the investment plan, this sustainable transition will not be implemented.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – The European Investment Plan announced by European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker on 26/11/2014 is an air number. It is fundamentally wrong. The lack of investment is not the cause, but the consequence of the crisis in the Monetary and Economic Union. Investors are not investing because the crisis states in particular have lost their competitiveness because of the overpriced euro. That is the fundamental problem in the eurozone. And the failure to recognise this fact is the fundamental problem in trying to resolve the crisis. But something else is strange: it is a deliberate misinformation to the public that the size of the investment programme is eur 315 billion. The announced 'mobilisation of finance for investments without public debt' means nothing more than the redeployment of existing EU programmes. In fact, only EUR 21 billion is available for 'strategic investments'. Some of these come from european investment bank funds, but more of them mainly from existing EU funds, which would have been invested anyway. These are now simply transferred from EU-Fond XY to the new Juncker's Magic Fund. Mr Juncker's magic formula is 'factor 15'. According to Juncker, every state euro from Junker's magic fund mobilizes 15 private euros. 21 by 15- makes 315. Abrakadabra.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The so-called "investment package", with the creation of an investment-managed fund presented today to the plenary of the European Parliament by Commission President Z.K. Younger, seeks to provide additional capital to business groups in order to make investments, with state funding, to increase their profitability . This funding will come from the even greater plundering of labour income. As a whole, the civil political staff, aligned with the requirements of the capital, demanded the continuation of the "structural reforms", i.e. to continue to bleed the working people in order to create an "attractive environment" for monopolies, with cheap labour force, without labour and social security rights. In the same wheel of capitalist management, SYRIZA, during the debate, after exasying the "development" policy of the Federal Reserve, complained that the money to "healthy entrepreneurs" is few, demanding more "fresh" money for profitable investments of monopolies.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the 2014 UNITED NATIONS Conference on Climate Change - COP 20, Lima, Peru (1 - 12 December 2014) (2014/2777(RSP)) . Before giving the floor to the Council, I would like to inform all those who will speak that I will be forced to strictly respect the deadlines allocated and I will not be able to authorise 'blue card' applications because at 12.00 p.m. there is the award of the Sakharov Prize. Therefore, since there are a great many speakers, there is an hour and a half of debate and I absolutely must ensure that the timetable is respected. I call on all of you, the Council and the Commission to keep to the timetable.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very grateful to you for this opportunity to address the key issues before us, in view of the Lima Conference to be held next week, a conference in which, as has been the case for years, of course, representatives of the European Parliament will participate in the European Union delegation. Lima, as you know, is the last major event this year before the Paris Conference, at which we want and aim to have a global climate agreement in the post-2020 period. To begin with, I would like to remind you of the reasons why these commitments are so important. We all know that in order to prevent advancing climate change and its devastating consequences, the rise in world temperatures must remain below 2 degrees centigrade below pre-industrial levels. To achieve this, global emissions must be reduced by 40 to 70% by 2050 compared to 2010. The same emissions must reach levels close to zero or lower in 2100. In order to provide ourselves with an instrument suitable for the post-2020 period, we agreed in Durban to develop a new legal instrument within the framework of the existing UN Convention.  I would now like to mention here the most important tasks that we will have to carry out at the Lima Conference, in order to make this a success and, above all, to prepare well for the Global Conference in Paris next year: to identify, of course, the main elements on which we can agree in the run-up to 2015; agree on the essential requirements regarding the initial information, the process of communicating it and subsequent examinations and analyses of the various planned contributions established at national level; appropriately address the issue of our mitigation ambitions for 2020. First of all, in Lima we must agree on the essential elements of the 2015 agreement, as I said: mitigation (which also includes the cycle of commitments), adaptation, market use, financing, technologies, capacity building and transparency. In this way, we will be able to present, by May next year, a comprehensive draft negotiating text to start negotiations on the real agreement, well in advance of the Paris Conference. The second point relates to the planned contributions established at national level, the so-called INDCs. The 2015 agreement should include legally binding mitigation commitments for all parties. However, the level of ambition and the type of commitment will vary. INDCs should therefore allow each party to choose its own type of contribution and to define its own level of ambition according to their national situations and capacities. The possibility of making different choices implies that the parties will have to provide sufficient information for their commitments to be understood and analysed to verify their compliance with the 2 degrees centigrade objective. The Lima Conference must therefore provide guidance to the parties on the initial information to accompany the INDCs and on the process of examining and analysing these data next year. As you know, the agreement on the Horizon 2030 climate and energy policy framework, reached by the European Council last month, is very significant. It was a high priority of our six months: we absolutely wanted to reach an important and ambitious agreement on the fight against climate change as the European Union, we wanted to confirm the role played by the European Union in international climate negotiations. We set ourselves the goal of reducing our emissions by 40% in 2030 compared to 1990, in line with the longer-term goal of reducing emissions by 80-95% by 2050. Perhaps we realised and perhaps european public opinion only realised the importance of this agreement a few days later, when much more media attention was given to the decision and announcement of China and the United States when they announced their INDCs. Without knowing all the details, assessing them correctly is rather difficult, but the announcement itself at this early stage and a few weeks after the European Union's announcement is in itself a very positive development in the run-up to the Paris Conference. The two main emissions producers have sent a clear signal of their willingness to engage and reach an agreement in Paris. Thirdly – and I will end, Mr President – the Lima Conference should send out a clear signal, building on the momentum given by the climate summit called by the Secretary-General of the United Nations in September, with a view to stepping up the sectors with high mitigation potential with positive consequences in terms of development, growth and innovation.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, let me first thank you for the draft resolution on the Lima Conference and for your work and support for international climate negotiations. Lima will be a milestone. Progress in Lima will be crucial to success in Paris at COP 21, where we will adopt an internationally legally-binding agreement applicable to all Parties. In that context Lima must deliver three key outcomes. Firstly, we should have a good understanding of the elements of a draft negotiating text of the 2015 agreement. Secondly, we need to agree on the requirements for the way in which all Parties are to present, early next year, their Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) to the new agreement. These contributions will express each Party’s intended emission reduction effort, and they must be transparent, quantifiable and comparable. Lima should also provide for an international process to consider and analyse the adequacy and ambition of INDCs before Paris. That process should aim to ensure that finalised emissions reductions commitments in the 2015 agreement are collectively sufficient to keep global average temperature increase below 2oC, and individually fair. And thirdly, we need to make progress on enhancing mitigation ambition also before 2020, so we remain on track to achieve the ‘below 2o C’ objective, which is crucial given that the 2015 agreement will not enter into force until 2020. The Commission has been very active in driving European Union action to make Lima a success. My predecessor, Connie Hedegaard, has done a tremendous job reaching out to our key strategic partners through visits – to the United States, China and India – and through her engagement in plurilateral forums such as the Major Economies Forum or the Cartagena Dialogue of progressive countries. I am personally committed to furthering and strengthening these dialogues and alliances. The European Union has also actively engaged in climate-related outreach through the EEAS and the Member States’ embassies, and through putting climate on the agenda of summits and forums such as the G20. In the next thirteen months these efforts will continue and grow in importance. On 24 October the European Council agreed on the 2030 targets of 40% greenhouse gas reductions. This puts the European Union ahead of the curve and means we will be in a position to come forward with our INDC by the first quarter of 2015. However, the European Union only accounts for 10% of global emissions today. At least all the major and emerging economies must also come forward by the first quarter of 2015. The United States and China announcement earlier this month should show that the European Union call is being answered by key players and hopefully will incite others to follow suit. There is also an urgent need to step up global ambition to cut greenhouse gas emissions before 2020 – to address the gap between current emission pledges and the reductions needed to keep global warming below 2oC. We need to promote strengthened collective efforts in the UNFCCC and other relevant forums such as the Montreal Protocol, the International Maritime Organisation and the International Civil Aviation Organisation. The European Union is on track to achieve emission reductions well beyond the current 20% target. We have also confirmed our conditional pledge to move to a 30% reduction, provided that other major emitting countries commit to comparable reduction targets. I look forward to working with my fellow Commissioners, including Vice-President Mogherini and Vice-President Šefčovič, to ensure climate change is a top priority for all our external dialogue in the coming important months. This brings me to the issue of climate finance. The Members of this House attach great importance to the question of scaling up climate finance to the USD 100 billion goal. I do too. Let me underline that the European Union and the Member States have taken numerous initiatives to that end. Finance to developing countries from the European Union budget and the European Development Fund has steadily increased, achieving EUR 900 million in 2013. This adds to the EUR 8.7 billion of climate finance provided by the Member States in 2013, which brings the total climate finance contribution by the European Union and its Member States to EUR 9.6 billion in 2013. Looking to the future, the multiannual financial framework, together with the European Development Fund, will provide EUR 14 billion to support climate-relevant actions in developing countries in the period 2014 to 2020. This represents a significant effort from the European Union. In relation to the Green Climate Fund, the EU Member States are major contributors. They have pledged over USD 3.8 billion to this Fund, around 40% of the total pledges so far. Finally, let me underline the important role the European Parliament plays as we move towards Paris. In Lima I intend to make sure that the delegation of the European Parliament is fully informed on the progress of the negotiations. Speaking with one voice as the European Union also means that Parliament’s support for an ambitious agreement is crucial. I would like to thank you again for your interest in this question and look forward to a lively debate.

name: Karl-Heinz FLORENZ
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I am pleased that today, for the first time, we have had the opportunity to exchange views here in Parliament. I've been there for many years, I was in Rio for the first time in 1992. Since then, I have witnessed many gloomy climate conferences. Now, however, I am relatively hopeful that we are on a good track towards Paris. This has to do not only with the fact that the European Union has presented a good result, but also with the fact that the Americans and the Chinese announced a turnaround at the Ban Ki-moon summit in New York. They have not yet done so, as we know. But we have never experienced such a mood. I am thinking of Copenhagen, which was the darkest thing we have ever met. I think we have a good chance of being hopeful. This is partly due to the fact that the moderate and sustainable industry has long been on the path to working in this direction as well. This helps, and we also know that American industry has long understood that money can be made in low-carbon farming. But, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming months, the moment of truth will come. Just going to Lima and saying we are reducing it by 40%, that is not enough. However, all our Member States will soon have to put binding figures on the table, and the perpetrators in particular must understand that a figure must now be put on the table – as the Commissioner has just mentioned – so that we can then verify this figure in Europe as well. In the end, we have to reach the 2-degree target, if we don't get there, the numbers are of no use. So it will be difficult negotiations after Lima. But that is the precondition that we will get a good result in Paris. We are hopeful, Mr President, because we have presented a good result.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, Kyoto was a great decision to ensure that humanity's future is at risk from climate change.  But the effects that should have been achieved with the full implementation of the Kyoto Protocol have been hated by two wrong decisions, by two misguided approaches: that of developed countries, which believed that sustainability policies and the fight against climate change, and that of countries emerging from underdevelopment, had to be abandoned , because they have believed that growth is not compatible with environmental respect. During this time, however, evidence of climate change has continued to grow. Crises are becoming more frequent. Lima must be the pre-step to retake Kyoto's great ambition, and Paris must be consolidating that ambition. There are positive signs. The European Union has made commitments. It is true that Parliament wanted more. More than the Commission and the Commission more than the Council. But we've made commitments. China and the United States are doing it. And the G77 is doing it. It is time for these commitments to be precise objectives, concrete actions, new funding, support and solidarity for developing countries. Lima must be the place to prepare for the recovery of a great ambition that, to some extent, has been lost along the way.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, cosmologist Carl Sagan said it is far better to grasp the universe as it really is than to persist in delusion, however satisfying and reassuring. 26 years later, climatologist James Hansen put it more bluntly: it is time to stop waffling. As a planet we have made slow and halting progress since we first began to appreciate our challenge. If I may, in an aside, say, as we approach the Lima gathering: it is a particularly unfortunate moment to dispense with the services of the European Union’s Chief Scientific Adviser. Right now more than ever, we need science at the heart of the decisions we take. The Scottish Professor Anne Glover has served well in this capacity, and I had every hope that her successor would do the same. I therefore call for Mr Juncker to reverse this decision and reverse it now. The gathering in Lima will present a number of challenges, notably the question of burden-sharing. I am pleased to note that the UK will contribute GBP 720 million pounds to the Green Climate Fund. This is important. Equally important will be the funds contributed by others. It is this particular fund which will help us ensure that we meet the targets to ensure that the two-degree reduction is made. Equally important, as we head towards the Paris COP meeting, will be the setting of clear and ambitious national contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. The headline agreement by EU leaders of a binding target to reduce headline emissions by 40% from 1990 levels is important, as is the statement by the British Prime Minister that this must represent a floor, not a ceiling. For much of the last decade we have been at the forefront of efforts to decarbonise the globe, and it has been a lonely place. With the recent climate change commitments of the US and China, we are no longer alone. Now is the time to find a truly global solution to a truly global problem. As we say in Scotland, it is now time to grasp the thistle.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Let me start positively: Europe is going to meet the 2020 targets, but in a world where more CO2 is emitted every day than the day before. And the year 2014 will also yield another record in CO2 emissions. Never before has the CO2 concentration been as high as it is today. We see the evidence of climate change almost every day. In the first decade of this century, we saw three times as many natural disasters as a few years before. In any case, this means that the sense of urgency seems to be finally increasing. I therefore welcome the decision of China and the United States to jointly tackle climate change. Although, of course, the reaction on Capitol Hill makes you believe the worst. Let us not underestimate the Chinese promise. Twenty percent zero emission energy by 2030 means an additional 800 to 1,000 gigawatts of capacity, which is almost the entire current electricity generation in the United States. So let us not say that we do a lot in Europe and the rest of the world does not. There does indeed seem to be momentum coming back. But we must be careful, because the bottom-up approach we have taken since the Copenhagen Échec is absolutely no guarantee of success. The intended nationally determined contributions - it all sounds wonderful - should not become noncommittal intentions. And it is therefore the job of Mr Arias Cañete to fight hard for it. In addition to the Lima-Paris route, let us remain very honest: even in the most rosy Lima-Paris scenario, we will not do enough and we will not fall below that two-degree limit. My question to the Commission is therefore: do you also have a multi-track policy in addition to this UN policy? Should we not, above all, discourage investment in polluting fuels as much as possible, for example through a very well-functioning fuel quality directive? I would also like a response from the Commission on this.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, whenever we talk about climate negotiations, the mood varies from hope to desolation. The global climate crisis must be our priority in this House, but clearly we are afraid. We fear the logic of market capitalism, which always shifts production to where it is cheapest and regulation is lowest.  I am not the only one who has come to think that the climate crisis is not about coal or carbon dioxide at all, but about pure market capitalism. In order to combat climate change, we should get out of the market economy's race towards destruction. We know what needs to be done, but we are only taking very small steps forward. The mere 'signals' are not enough about Lima, we need a proper mega leap in ambition and a sincere commitment for our environment. I very much hope that the Commission and the entire EU delegation will be as constructive and forward-looking as possible in Lima, because a binding global climate agreement in Paris next year will be a necessity for the whole world. Our credibility depends on the ambition of our own actions. As transport coordinator, I invite all my transport colleagues to jointly build an ambitious action plan for the EU, which will also make the European transport system truly energy-green and sustainable. With sustainable growth, a healthy policy, we can safeguard both the environment and create much-needed new jobs throughout Europe.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome Mr Cañete to the plenary for his first address to the plenary, on the very important climate conference in Lima. I think we can see now that the world is starting to move. We are now looking at the US and China which are doing things, and I think we have to welcome that. We have to see that this is a good step towards Paris. But there are, of course, questions as to what Europe is doing. We have always claimed that we are leading the world. I think that tone has become very irritating for the rest of the world, because if you really look at what the EU is doing, it is not that impressive. I think just one clear question – and I think it is important Mr Cañete address it – is: Europe – what is Europe going to do with its coal-fired power plants until 2030? We know that in the US they are going to handle them, in China they are going to handle them, but the Council conclusions still give a feeling that Europe might give subsidies to coal-fired power plants until 2030. It would be very important, Mr Cañete, for you to make it very clear here that when we are talking about funds for the modernisation of our energy system, we are not talking about subsidies for coal-fired power plants at all. I think you have to clarify that very clearly. And if we make a link to the investment plan – because everyone is making the point that this is very important – unfortunately there are not so many Commissioners left any more, while we were discussing an investment plan. I think there is one important issue here: if you want to have clarity for investors, you also need to have clear policies, and one of the clearest policies you can provide investors with is a binding energy-efficiency target. That would really make it clear to investors what to do. I think that there, too, you can also provide investors with some clarity that the Commission will indeed come forward with those proposals. A final remark to the Council: regarding the funds, the Green Climate Fund. Is the Council able, for next year, to really make sure that, on time, Europe as a whole can provide money for that Climate Fund in a new additional way that is transparent and also predictable, so that the developing countries really know that the Council of the European Union is serious about climate change and helping developing countries in that?

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – The Lima Conference must become an intermediate stop in the run-up to a legally binding, ambitious international agreement in Paris in 2015. Not only for the European Union, but also for the rest of the world to start taking global warming seriously, not to keep its head in the sand. The risks posed by climate change are very serious and have negative consequences for long-term economic growth and pose a real threat to the existence of mankind. The European Union's efforts in this area alone are not enough, and there is a risk that the safe climate threshold may be exceeded after 2020. It is therefore necessary to agree on global action against climate warming following the expiry of the Kyoto Protocol. The carbon-based development strategy is fully compatible with economic growth. All countries must do their homework and achieve their intended objectives. Action plans must be drawn up, providing for specific commitments from states and ensuring clarity and transparency of actions at national level. In order to achieve an ambitious global climate change policy, we need to work together to promote joint action, particularly between states, businesses, financial institutions, industry, society, and to look together for all possible sources of funding, which is extremely important.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the European Mr Thank you for the floor. The fundamental stakes of the forthcoming conferences are whether the United States and China, the two biggest polluters, can be persuurged to make real commitments and deliver. If it's just the mood, it's not going to do us any good.  The EU is at the forefront of reducing CO2 emissions. He's setting an example, that's right. But it's like, un. ambitious targets, which are in fact unrealistic and do not lead to results. Climate change is a global problem. This means that it cannot be solved at the local level. The European Union is responsible for 10-12% of emissions, which will fall to 4-5% by 2030. So, in fact, progress can only be made on a global scale. It should be noted that member states' commitments also mean that they determine their energy mix.  For example, there are countries that prioritise nuclear energy as clean energy. Of course, it would be good to have more green, renewable energies, but we cannot turn a blind eye to costs. Yes, those of us who say that we represent the interests of the European population never talk here about energy poverty, that the cost of energy is a huge item for many families in Europe, so it is not possible to take costs out of this issue. Thank you so much for listening.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Undersecretary, in Lima we will be faced with a major political challenge, namely to convince all the parties involved of the need to invest in an ambitious climate policy, in order to safeguard the environment and at the same time create jobs by encouraging the development of sustainable technologies. Our overall objective is to strengthen the commitment of the entire international community to sustainable development, because it will, I believe, be the real element through which we can build sustainable growth. Considerable progress has been made towards achieving the Eu ropean Union's targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, renewable energies and energy efficiency, and the same must be done at international level. In this respect, the recent plan announced by the United States and China is an important step in the right direction, but it remains only a start in achieving much more ambitious targets. As Pope Francis recalled yesterday, during his speech, we have a duty if not an obligation to preserve the planet for future generations and as Europe we intend to play a fundamental role in the forthcoming negotiations to try to reach a truly ambitious agreement in Paris in 2015. I would also like to stress the importance of funding in this area, and I would remind you of the commitment made by the European Union and its Member States to progressively increase the mobilisation of climate finance that is essential for investing in research and sustainable development. To close, I call – as the Commissioner announced in his speech, but I also ask the Presidency of the Council – to ensure that during the negotiations in Lima the European Parliament delegation can participate daily in the updates on the negotiations so that they can contribute with their work there to achieving even more ambitious objectives.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I would like to remind Members that there is no blue card today because of the awarding of the Sakharov Prize 2014 at 12 o'clock.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Welcome, Commissioner, in your first debate, which will be a debate for years to come and, of course, for the next few weeks. It looks - if we look at the calculations of the past centuries - that 2014 is going to be the warmest year in the world. And that may be an anecdote for some, but it is an important fact in addition to the scientific facts we know: climate change is in progress, the consequences are already piling up. In this light, the 20th climate conference in Lima will be important. I want to be optimistic. Optimism is a moral duty, also for this important issue. Internationally, things are happening, the US/China agreement, there is a paragraph in the final conclusions of the G20, so initiatives are taking place on the world stage as well. This must give us energy to take on our own responsibility. I was not very satisfied with the Council's conclusions, I did not think they were too ambitious. We can put that right in Parliament, we approved important commitments in this Parliament at the beginning of this year. I repeat them again: 40% emissions for greenhouse gases, 40% for energy efficiency, 30% for renewable energy. Let us confirm this in the vote and go to Lima with that strong commitment and then reach a good agreement in Paris.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The European Union's climate strategy is based on several very dubious assumptions. Firstly, it is based on the assumption that there is consensus in the scientific world on the direction and impact of climate change on human activities. In other words, the opinions expressed in the reports of the International Panel on Climate Change are to be the only ones present in the scientific debate, which is obviously not true. Dissenting opinions are simply silent. The consensus ends with the statement that the climate is changing, just as it has always changed. But even if the panel's opinions were correct, the second questionable assumption is that other global players will agree to make significant concessions about their economic policies. The third dubious assumption concerns the role of the European Union. We can set an example of environmental and climate concern for others, but apparently no one is going to change their policy because of this, and with the Union's shrinking participation in global emissions, the importance of unilateral action is steadily diminishing. However, the threat of loss of competitiveness is increasing. Let me remind you once again that by 2030 we will be responsible for 4% of global emissions. So we will not do anything ourselves, but at the same time we will deeply jeopardise the plans to restore the significant role of our industry, which we so badly need.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Somehow it feels like, during the financial crisis, Europe has lost faith in what we actually have to do in front of us. It is as if we believe that we can hide the future costs of climate change. It is as if you believe that not taking climate action costs is costs. We know that the costs that we currently pay in life – of people dying prematurely from pollution – are costs that companies do not have to pay because they put it on society. It is our hospitals and our communities that pay these costs instead. Nevertheless, we know that it will cost us an incredible amount on the day that land values will be destroyed because the sea level is rising. We know that it will cost a lot in the flow of refugees and in human suffering on the day we are driven from our coastal areas because we have to move further inland. Europe has every opportunity to be a driving force in this. The US and China are finally presenting concrete figures. At the same time, they are far too low. I can see from the list of speakers here that one after the other will soon say that it is not possible to combat the climate problem without driving businesses out of Europe. This is not true. We can see from a Swedish perspective that we have had growing growth for 20 years, while we have had decreasing climate emissions. But in order to achieve this, one must dare to believe in the future, in technology, in development and setting clear goals under Paris. But it has to be taken a big step now for us to get somewhere.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Indeed, the Lima conference should pave the way for a global climate agreement in Paris 2015 to keep global warming below 2°C.   However, when creating a global agreement, we should not only focus on reducing specific numbers in reducing CO2 emissions, but pay attention to investments in future technologies that will enable emissions to be reduced while being affordable.  We cannot allow the fight against climate change to turn into a fight for jobs in a failing industry. The development of technologies conducive to climate change is also important from the perspective of the developing world. The developed world needs to help the third world by transferring technology in its efforts to reduce CO2 emissions.   I want to appeal to our sanity. The ideologically blind view in the climate change debate often overshadows the most economically affordable ways to truly reduce CO2 emissions.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since the first COP in Berlin, via Kyoto and to date, 20 years of continuing exhausting climate negotiations have passed. Taken together, however, the European Union, China and the United States are responsible for 50% of global emissions. Yet the US President and the Chinese President have only today declared their intention to stop emissions growth by 2030. Then who knows when they will decide to declare their intention to reduce emissions as well. But we in the European Union do no better. We persist in pulling new percentages out of the cylinder: 40% of emissions, 27% of renewables, 30% of energy efficiency, etc.; but then we continue to extract oil and burn coal all over the territory. We need to understand that to really combat climate change it only takes 100% of the change of mentality.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr. President! We Europeans must, of course, also make our contribution to combating global climate change. But our approach must also be globally coordinated. Above all, as far as the distribution of the costs of this trade is concerned, there must be a fair distribution of the burden satisinly throughout the world. According to a study by Johannes Kepler University in Linz in Austria, the reduction of CO2 emissions by a further 40% by 2030 threatens around 61,000 jobs in Austria alone. Industry has already made its contribution to the fight against climate change in many European Member States on emissions trading. But what about the rest of the industrialised nations outside the EU? The US has more or less distanced itself from the Kyoto agreement, and Turkey has increased its emissions by 115% in the last 20 years. It is indeed nice to hear announcements from China and the United States – on our own, judging by the facts, by the actual deeds, and I am very sceptical about that. That is why we must also increase the pressure on our economic partners. We should stop constantly depriving domestic industry of its competitiveness by new requirements.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we must consider that this Lima conference will be a springboard conference, as it is to prepare for the great Paris conference in 2015, at which we will have to get a binding agreement which is widely supported by our international partners. Therefore, in Lima, we will have to work towards a result for the planet, not just for the European Union, because the European Union accounts for only 10% of CO2 emissions. This forces us to address the climate problem in a comprehensive way. At the same time, we cannot sit idly by for other countries to act to move forward.  The European Union must be at the heart of the negotiations to send a clear message. It must affirm the interest that everyone has in committing, without delay, to the reduction of CO2 emissions. Developing countries that fear that reducing emissions will penalize them in their growth have an interest in this because they will be the first to suffer the consequences of climate change. We must therefore pay particular attention to their concerns. Developed countries also have an interest in this because reducing CO2 emissions can be achieved by further innovating and creating jobs. There are encouraging signs, although caution should be required. Internationally, we see that with the agreement between China and the United States, but we must not have a simple catalogue of good intentions. I therefore trust our Commissioner, Mr Arias Caete, to carry this message and promote the spirit of dialogue with which the European Union must go to Lima. I will end by quoting an English writer, Samuel Johnson, who said: "It is not strength but perseverance that makes great works". I hope that is what we will get in Lima.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Mr President, Mr Gozi, Commissioner, I would like to thank mr Gozi for his work and for his work. I have several questions. When it comes to climate protection, there is no G20, there is no G8, there seems to be a G2: the US and China. In Copenhagen, both blocked. Now there is an opening for Paris, but we know that this is far from enough to reach the 2-degree Celsius target. My question is this: what coalitions does the EU intend to forge in Lima and Paris, so that we are not at the cat table, but are a front-row player and really achieve an ambitious result? Secondly, the financing of climate protection. It is good that we have EUR 10 billion together. However, we have pledged EUR 100 billion a year. There must be a new concept, new ideas. Does the Commission have any new ideas on how we can get from 10 billion to 100 billion? Thirdly, I hear that a 'Paris Alliance' is being discussed for Paris, not a legally binding treaty or instrument, but a global deal where everyone puts something on the table. As the EU, do we still maintain a legal instrument, which also brings commitments? Fourthly, with the Ban Ki-moon Summit, we have learned that there are other actors, especially cities, municipalities, but also advanced industry. What is the EU's strategy of involving these actors?  Ultimately, I believe that Lima and Paris are test cases for European diplomacy, not by the side, but at the centre.

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: Mr President! Following this decision, the EU will have a leading role at the Lima Conference in December and in reaching a global agreement on climate change in Paris next year. I welcome the recent agreement reached at the October European Council on 2030 climate and energy policy. But for the EU to be credible, we must be fair. Implementing these objectives is key. Member States of the European Union must contribute in the same and fair way. If the EU wants to be a world leader in combating climate change, it needs a fair burden-sharing among member states. We also need to increase investment in research and development because eu spending in this area is too low compared to the countries we have to compete with in the future. For the agreement to be effective, it must also be accepted by all countries, including China and the new industrialised countries. If that does not happen, the EUROPEAN Union risks losing its growth, its prosperity in the future, and the growth package presented by Juncker today will then be wasted.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Mr President, we need to develop an ecologically sustainable economic model, which, in my opinion, means laying the groundwork for a real and credible transition towards an ecological economic model, as a means, of course, to achieve real inclusive progress for all people, and I certainly am not just talking about the European level. When we talk about the fight against climate change, we talk about transforming the current model; we are talking about social, economic and environmental justice, that is, an alternative model very different from the current one, a model that must integrate, in turn, mobility and energy policies with public planning, policies of territorial planning, consumption and production processes, waste management, a new model of taxation on environmental bases. Finally, we are talking about transforming the economic cycle at the root. As Merja Kyll'nen has pointed out, we need a comprehensive action plan and more ambitious steps.

name: Roger HELMER
text: Mr President, the reason we need a EUR 300 billion investment package in the EU is because private sector investment is too low. The key reason for that is the eye-watering energy prices in Europe, which are a huge disincentive to investment. These high energy prices, Mr President, are not an act of God or of world markets; they are the direct results of policy decisions which we have taken here in this House. Our green policies are forcing energy-intensive business out of Europe altogether, taking their jobs and their investment with them. Often they go to jurisdictions with lower environmental standards, so arguably we could be increasing global emissions at the same time. Our objectives in Lima will make matters worse. We are proposing a USD 10 billion fund to assist developing countries on climate issues, but my constituents in the UK are already facing eye-watering energy prices, plant closures and job losses for your green policies. They will be appalled that we are asking them to sacrifice even more on the altar of climate alarmism.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: Mr President, if one wants to combat climate change, then I propose fighting global warming in spring and global cooling in the autumn. That makes just as much sense. Global warming is a cyclical process, only its cycle is longer. By the way, the Earth needs more carbon dioxide and more warmth for plants to grow and make the Earth greener. Is combating global warming nonsense? No, because the real aim of its proponents is to stop economic growth. You should read about the zero-growth theory. They believe in it and they are achieving their goal. The development of Europe is zero. When Europe is liberated from the occupation of the European Union, I hope that those people will be unmasked, persecuted and duly sentenced. Moreover, I think that, if Europe is to survive, the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we all believe that we must reach a binding global agreement here, as Mrs Grossetête said, because otherwise the climate will not benefit either, we will only have costs. It has already been mentioned that we produce about 10% of THE CO2 to date, but not global, of the planet, because 10% of CO2 is produced by human activity, which we know is already a very small share compared to the entire natural emission of the planet of CO2.  So if Europe were to wipe out or come close to zero CO2, as Mr Gozi dreams, we would not achieve any benefit to the environment, because we would only achieve a relocation of our productions, which would produce somewhere else and emit even more than they emit in Europe. We must therefore be aware that we are going to very, very tough negotiations, as Mr Florenz said, because we applaud what the USA and China are doing, but they are very small objectives in relation to the objectives that we have set ourselves.  We talked this morning about growth, work and investment, we have the goal of reindustrialization at 20% of Europe by 2020, but the cost paid by our traditional industries is a salty cost and we will continue like this: aluminum, the paper sector, cement works, ceramics... We are talking about steel, we have seen the question of Terni in recent days. Well, we will only be able to bear these costs within a binding global agreement, so that there are fair situations for everyone.

name: Matthias GROOTE
text: Mr. President! Every year in November we discuss the COP resolution and also the upcoming COP conference. I note, again every year: the Spirit is willing, but at the end of the day the flesh is weak. Because when it comes to concrete measures, Parliament sometimes pushes back, but also the Commission. I would like to take this as an example: internally, we can certainly get things going in Europe. Parliament has done it, in percentage terms: 40% CO2 reduction in 2030, 40% increase in efficiency and then the 30% renewable energy target. But that our legislation – and by this I mean the Fuel Quality Directive – ensures that the dirtiest form of fuel comes to Europe in the end, namely tar sands – an entire province is ploughed in Alberta – we should think again about whether this is the right way to go. That is why the litmus test will come next week in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy by voting on an objection that we are not adopting the Fuel Quality Directive in its form, stopping the whole thing, so that Mr Caete and the Commission have time to think again about whether this is the right way to go and to revise the whole thing again.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! In the European Union, we are responsible for around 10% of global CO2 emissions. 40% of this is now to be saved, i.e. about 4% of global CO2 emissions. That is what we can decide here in the European Union. We have tried several times to reach agreement with the major CO2 emitters, with the USA, China, Russia and also India. In the end, Kyoto was not worth the paper on which it was written, and in Copenhagen the European Union really let itself be demonstrated, as it rarely happened. In Germany, meanwhile, we have a fine example of how CO2 climate policy cannot work: the hasty phase-out of nuclear energy. At the same time, we are continuing with lignite and hard coal, wind energy with a dubious climate balance and, finally, emissions trading, which has proved to be completely superfluous. Tell the people who have to pay for this energy transition, that they are, the citizens, with their jobs and, ultimately, with energy prices!

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: Mr President, the European Union is presenting itself as a leader at the Climate Change Summit, but the reality is not so accurate. For example, in Spain there has been an increase in emissions of 5.2% for the electricity generation sector, even during the crisis, according to data from the National Statistical Institute. We still have an economy addicted to oil and coal. We continue, from the European Union, to support electricity, which use the most expensive and polluting energy sources , such as coal and gas – by boosting the electricity bill while increasing energy poverty. Outside the photo are emissions imported by international trade, including the failed European emissions trading system, hot air purchases, etc. If we take the European Union as a whole, the carbon footprint increases by 25% by including imports. The allocation of emission quotas is outrageous. The polluters have "lined up" at the expense of emissions trading and their use has become a source of surplus for the companies themselves. Isn't it time to start thinking that solutions go through binding laws and not so much for money, money and money?

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, next week we will begin the crucial stage in the run-up to COP-21 in Paris, which has expectations similar to those we had in 2009 on the eve of COP-15 in Copenhagen. At that meeting, the European Union presented itself with a unilateral and demanding legislative package, hoping that this would stimulate other countries to sign concrete commitments. Nevertheless, the results were very disappointing.  Today, the European Union has no new reference models to present to the international community, but that does not mean that something more and more concrete cannot be done yet. We believe, for example, that binding targets for energy saving and efficiency could be agreed, two areas that allow the best optimisation of investments. The energy saved is the one that costs the least. Investments pay off within three to four years, and the involvement of energy service companies could trigger a virtuous mechanism. In this case, finance intervenes upstream of investments and pays off only if the reduction in consumption is effective, unlike the bankrupt ETS market where the only advantages are made by financial speculators. What steps does the Commission intend to take to fill this obvious and unjustified regulatory vacuum?

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the European Union is making meritorious efforts to combat climate change. It applies the Kyoto Protocol and the Doha amendment. Today, it is aiming to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 40% by 2030 and 80% by 2050.  Undoubtedly, it will try to persuade the world, at the Lima conference next December, to meet the goal set by the Durban agreement, namely the adoption, at the end of 2015 in Paris, of a binding treaty to contain global warming to a maximum of two degrees by the end of the century.  Unfortunately, the failure is predictable because China and the United States, which are the two biggest polluters, do not want to make an effort. I want to prove that these two countries have just reached an agreement on 12 November by which they bury the Durban process. I draw two conclusions from that. Firstly, the European Union has failed in this area as in others. Secondly, European states must be prepared to deal with the consequences of this failure, which the IPCC announced in its March 2014 report: food insecurity, water scarcity, massive population displacement and the risk of conflict.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Mr President, colleagues, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur, We are actually a very big challenge. On the one hand, not only in Europe, but worldwide, we need to reduce CO2 emissions in order to combat global warming, on the other hand, it is important for us, especially in Europe, to preserve jobs and promote economic development.  And, in fact, there are two ways in which these CO2 emissions could be reduced, which will have different effects directly on our economy. The first way is to ask the industry to reduce CO2 emissions in Europe more and more, in our own union, which will result in some industries moving out of the EU to countries such as China, where there are no caps on these CO2 emission allowances, and it could be said that CO2 emissions would decrease in Europe, but this would not happen globally, as they would continue to continue in China, perhaps even more, because there are no restrictions. The second way to do the same is to achieve at the Lima Conference that it is nevertheless an international agreement: reducing CO2 emissions not only in Europe, but also in the rest of the world and in China. In this way, the industry will not have the need or ability to flee Europe in order to continue to pollute air from elsewhere, to stay in Europe, to invest in modern technologies. In short, there is an international agreement so that the industry does not leave the European Union.

name: Seb DANCE
text: Mr President, slowly but surely we are seeing a consensus emerging in the world that human activity is responsible for climate change, in spite of some of the oddball conspiracy theories we have heard this morning. If the EU is to demonstrate what it does at its most effective, which is working together with cross-linkages and having different countries work together for their common interest, then it must do all it can do combine different areas of policy. That includes when we work on air quality, linking that to climate policy and linking development policy very clearly to climate policy as well. We know that the effects of climate change will have a disproportionate effect on developing countries, because their infrastructures are far less able to cope with its effects. Therefore, I welcome the money that the Commission has announced that it will be supporting at Lima. We must have a deal in Paris that provides support for developing countries for sustainable growth so that new areas of economic growth are not dependent on mechanisms that degrade the environment.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: Mr President, sometimes it feels a little bit like ‘Groundhog Day’ when we stand in this Chamber. When we are talking about these COP resolutions, one comes after another with monotonous regularity, but I really do believe that we have reached a key stage here in our pursuit of a new global deal to arrest climate change. With the recent European Council conclusions on the 2030 package, the EU is now in a strong position to push for a truly international and binding agreement. I would like to say: let us concentrate on achieving that end, particularly agreeing the draft elements of our text, and agreeing the steps to strengthen the UN climate regime covering rules, mechanisms, reporting and implementation. The time has come for detail, for getting that detail right, and for Europe to lead the way forward. It is not the time for grandstanding about whether we do or do not believe – it really does not matter; we are at the stage where we are moving forward. Let us not squabble, let us do it together, and let us make sure that Europe’s voice counts.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: Next week, another 15,000 civil servants, politicians and environmentalists will go to Lima. Business class flying and leaving tens of thousands of tons of CO2 behind. And why? To put together a draft text. Mr President, you can also do so by email. And at least it won't cost taxpayers $60 million.  Because there is good news to report! We can report that the North Pole was growing. Now, last month, NASA announced that the South Pole has grown 17,000 km2 a year over the past 40 years. The crazy thing with good news is - if my kids bring good news from school, good grades, then I'm happy, then the teachers are happy and my kids are happy! If there is good news about the economy, then the economists are happy, the producers and the consumers. But if there is good news about the environment, I don't hear the environmentalists. It seems like they only benefit from bad news, because bad news makes money. The summit in Lima takes place under the worst staring you can imagine. Obama can't do anything with the Republican majority, China and Russia, we know enough about that, the EU is divided and even put the climate scientist Glover aside because she didn't want to go along with climate hysteria. In Lima, the only change in temperature will be due to the heated scenes in the local brothels and the chambreing of thousands of bottles of luxury wine, which are immediately clocked away by the people who are so concerned with our environment. I call for a boycott of this climate summit; the money spent on this should be returned directly to the countries where it comes from.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: Mr President, I am very glad to see the Commissioner in the place where he is sitting now, but it is a pity, Mr Commissioner, that you cannot sit together with us. I am quite sure that we have the same approach, because we spent some time in this Parliament together. It is a global threat, this means that we should have a global answer. That is why we have been ringing the alarm bells for global climate action since 1992. The ringing is getting louder and louder, and we know that in Paris 2015 it will probably be the last chance. And it is in Lima that we should finalise the preliminary deal. First, and most important: intended nationally-determined contributions – to present our assessment phase, a road map to Paris, a bottom-up approach. Secondly: how to make the best use of the Green Climate Fund and other funds and how to strengthen them. And thirdly: the sharing of new energy technologies. Very important, all three of them. We cannot, as the European Union, be the lone runner; we would endanger our industries, our SMEs, our energy sector and we would deprive ourselves of an important exit strategy from the crisis. This would be reckless and irresponsible. If we fail to reach a global deal, we may have to consider the principles of our own European deal. This is what is at stake in Lima and Paris, and this is why we must make the best of these conferences, and we ask you for close cooperation, Mr Commissioner, between our delegation – I am a member of our delegation to Lima – and yourself, the European Commission representative.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for far too long we have underestimated the seriousness of climate change. What still needs to happen to open your eyes? We see the floods, the droughts, the dead. We count the hundreds of millions of damages. Of course, it is not just up to Europe. Of course, there is a problem with industrial production. But if Europe stops, if Europe is less ambitious, it will be more difficult to build a broad agreement first in Lima and then in Paris.  So, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot stop now, and now we cannot go backwards. The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy voted for a resolution by a very large majority, which is precise. It is important that this resolution is adopted by this Parliament. There are specific and concrete commitments and the issue of financing is also addressed by committing the money we earn from the CO2 market.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, in the European Union we have made countless efforts in the fight against climate change, both in the conferences of the parties and in our internal policies. And we're only responsible for 11% of emissions. We are on our way to meeting the commitment to reduce emissions by 20% by 2020 and that is thanks to research, new technologies, the promotion of renewable energy, new car emission standards and the replacement of energies with less polluting energies. We have the best guarantee to go to a new international negotiation in which the European Union must not only make offers to its partners, but must make demands. Because meeting our goal by 2020 comes at a cost that is being borne by families and businesses. We need an international agreement to unify the environmental conditions under which industrial activity, agriculture, power generation and transport are developed around the world. European citizens and businesses cannot continue to bear the cost of a fight against climate change. The Commission and the Member States must use all springs to reach a balanced agreement for next year, where everyone is equally committed to combating climate change, as the European Union is committing itself.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I congratulate you, Mr Caete, on your victory, the victory of Europe, at the Paris meeting on 20 November last meeting of the parties to the Montreal Protocol on ozone-depleting substances.  This is a victory because it is the proposals, your proposals, those of the European Union, that have been validated to combat hydrofluorocarbons and hydrochlorocarbons whose impact on the destruction of the ozone layer and, therefore, on climate change and warming is, it must be known, twenty-three thousand times greater than that of CO2.  A question about this, Mr Caete: how will these proposals be implemented in the coming weeks, especially on the occasion of Lima? The second point, which was also discussed at the Berlin Conference on 20 November, relates to the Green Climate Fund: again, we need clarification on how the Lima Conference will define how the Fund will be allocated.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to join the previous speakers in pointing out once again that it is essential for the European Union to secure and defend its pioneering role in international climate protection in the climate talks. In the face of all these important challenges, which still urgently need to be addressed, we have achieved a great deal in recent years. We have been able to reduce European emissions, which have been agreed under the Kyoto Protocol, by 19%, but we have nevertheless increased gross domestic product by more than 45%. The intensity of our greenhouse gas emissions has fallen by almost half and per capita emissions have fallen by 25%. So we can really accept the challenge of keeping global warming below 2 degrees with combined forces. Now that the signs are really being confirmed that China and the US are finally abandoning their blockades, we also see that our path in recent years has been the right one. Our commitment to reducing CO2 emissions, promoting renewable energies and increasing energy efficiency has borne fruit. Lima is now the last stage on the way to Paris and thus also the last opportunity to convince others that it is not too late. Let us ensure that Copenhagen does not repeat itself in Paris and that a joint international agreement on climate protection really becomes a reality.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his I wish that those most affected by climate change also had the greatest megaphones and the best opportunities to influence politics. Unfortunately, it doesn't look like it. Many times, the most vulnerable are also those who lack power. It places a lot of responsibility on us politicians.  My group and I will defend the European Parliament's position to have three ambitious and binding targets for renewable energy, reducing climate emissions and energy efficiency. Instead, the EPP Group in Parliament wants to delete these objectives. I think that's serious. It is a weak policy for Europe's environment, for the world and for jobs, which does not take responsibility for the most vulnerable in the world. The lima meeting is important for the climate. Paris must not become a new Copenhagen. The latest US and China initiatives are important. Now is the time for europe to take the leadership as well.

name: Ivo BELET
text: The Juncker Commission's investment plan, which we discussed here this morning, can perfectly go hand in hand with what we are all advocating here, such as energy efficiency, renewable energy and also the restrictions on harmful emissions. We need to do two things in the short term: firstly, and this is very topical, the reform of our emissions trading system. The first step to this - Commissioner, you agree with us - is the introduction of a market stability reform mechanism. This will prevent the carbon price from collapsing further and the entire ETS system from collapsing. We are counting on broad support in this House to achieve this in the coming weeks and months, and of course we are counting on the Council to support this.  Secondly, we need a forward-looking, smart strategy for our energy-intensive industry. We must reward investments in energy efficiency and also investment in low emissions by providing incentives. With such a balanced package, both ets reform and positive measures for the energy-intensive industry, we can secure and uphold our industrial ambitions while at the same time going to the crucial summits in Lima and in Paris with an ambitious climate package.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Mr President, it is not the fight against climate change that falls on the backs of citizens at their costs. It is the policy change of some governments, as is the case in Spain, which has stopped betting on renewable energy and that has been a blow to those families who had invested in it. But let's talk about the Lima Conference. Amendment No 9 of the European People's Party breaks with a traditional ambition of this Parliament. It is a step backwards that they want to impose on us, eliminating binding targets in efficiency and renewables. It's a sign of what this legislature is waiting for us. It is a nod to certain interests supported by some countries. And I would like to know whether this is also the position of the European Commission. Today you want us to give up claiming binding targets. They say in their amendment that what happens is that there are different views on the role we must play. Don't confuse us. This Parliament has always had a vocation to combat climate change and we cannot take a step back.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Mr. President, in Kyoto we decided on our goals when we realized that we were all endangered, not only the human race but all other living things. But from Kyoto through Copenhagen, Durban, Doha, Lima and Paris we really thought we had done a lot, however, we definitely need one global deal. This is the key moment. You know that Parliament wanted more from the Commission, that the Commission wanted more from the Council and that finally in October the Council adopted binding targets and this resolution.  Given that the European Union only participates with 10 to 11% of emissions, and America and China with 50%, this does not need to discourage us from being at the fore in this fight against climate change. However, we should ask ourselves where Russia is, where India is. It is good that America and China have stepped in, however, their goals are very modest as far as they can conclude.  But all of this should not discourage us. Where are the developing countries? We have to help them. We have heard from Commissioner Cañete that €9.6 billion has been invested in this fund. In any case, binding targets are important for us, we must adhere to them. We want to be compatible with Mr Juncker's programme which outlined it this morning. We must take into account growth and development at the same time and for us remains a binding target of 2 degrees Celsius reduction. It is also a binding target by 2030 of 30% reduction in emissions and by 2050 50%. In the end, I have to use the Indian one, we borrowed this land from our descendants, and we have to take care of it.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Mr President! "I love deadlines! I absolutely love the rushing sound they make when they fly past me!"" That's what the English writer Douglas Adams said. I always think of the quote when I think of the climate fight. We have set ourselves a number of deadlines. We have a 2°C target. We have a watered-down 2030 climate package. We seem to have been adamant that something will not happen until next year's Paris summit. In short: with the current level of ambition, we can start preparing for the sound of the 2°C target to whizz past us.  Dear Commission, act now! Go to Lima with a promise of actions, concrete actions, and ambition. Promise that the EU will get a grip on our grid so that we can transport renewable energy across the EU. Promise that Juncker's investment plan will be targeted at green investments and promise that we will not just have an energy union, but that we will have a green energy union.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues! A report for the Pentagon identified climate change as a threat to US national security. I think these are clear words, and the Pentagon is really not a green institution. This shows the scale of the challenge. That is why I believe that it is a good thing that the European Council has presented a very ambitious target, at least in the case of the CO2 reduction targets. Angela Merkel said in the government statement to the German Bundestag on 16 October that, in the context of the negotiations on the global agreement, we must be prepared to go beyond the 40% proposed by the Commission. I think it is a very gratifying development that the European Council has agreed to this position. Personally, I am not entirely satisfied with what the summit decided on in terms of renewable energy and energy efficiency. But this 40% target is crucial for the international negotiations. I would like to point out to the previous speaker from the Socialist Group that we should not be arguing here today on the issue of binding targets for energy efficiency and renewable energy. I believe that Parliament has decided on something wise, but that does not belong in Lima. These are our internal discussions, which we must prepare well and which this Parliament will, of course, give its opinion on at some point. But I do not believe that this is part of this resolution. That is why we do not support this amendment at this point. This does not mean that we are opposed to binding targets.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Lima objective is a global agreement to reduce pollutant emissions and prevent dangerous interference with these changes. There is no longer any doubt about the disastrous effects of climate change, and Europe must come to this meeting without hesitation and as a leading player. It is no longer time to think, as I have heard from many, of environmental policies as a brake on development. But we need to rethink the growth model pursued so far, a new deal that has great potential, including for the creation of new jobs in research, innovation, renewable sources, energy efficiency, air quality and adaptation to climate change.  May I remind you that the floods that have hit Europe in recent years are already an effect of these changes and pose the need to work for prevention, reducing global emissions and warming on the one hand and investing in risk reduction works and actions, among other things, creating new skilled jobs to save us resources.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, on the way to Paris and Lima, three good news is before us.  Firstly, the agreement reached at the European Council, which includes a binding target and two optional objectives, should be welcomed. Second, the agreement between China and the United States should be hailed as a common decision to reduce their emissions. Finally, the Meeting on the capitalization of the Green Fund should also be welcomed. However, as Europeans, it seems to me that we cannot leave it at that and that, even going to Lima, we must continue to mobilise on the basis of the European Parliament's positions in favour of a three-pronged three-pronged target that would add to the objectives accepted by the European Council those of energy efficiency and renewable energy. Finally, when we discuss the 300 billion investment plan, it is also necessary, in a coherent way, that the issue of ecological transition should be the main theme of mobilising these new investment capacities in the European Union.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: One of the most important achievements of the European Union so far is a significant reduction in the carbon intensity of the European economy. I therefore welcome the member states' commitments made by the Council in October to reduce member countries' emissions by 40% by 2030.  However, we must be equally ambitious at global level.  Our main goal must be that the average global temperature does not rise by more than 2°C.  We must therefore reach an agreement in Paris to ensure that we fulfil it. We will not achieve this without cooperation with the United States, China, and other major emitters of greenhouse gases. I therefore welcome the recent statements made by the representatives of both these countries in the fight against climate change. It is not possible for China's emissions to increase for another 15 years.  We must fight not only climate change itself, but also the demagoguery and propaganda of opponents of climate change. Our struggle cannot be perceived through the prism of forced costs. Together, we are investing in a new economy, a system that creates new jobs and promotes sustainable development.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: Mr President, I want to talk about the development aspects of climate change.
