Commissioner and Mr Gozi, I have a question for you, which is that we all know that climate change is already a problem for developing countries – I am very pleased we had the meeting in Berlin last week where we made progress on climate finance – and we have all talked about COP 2021 this morning, but before we get to Paris – between now and Lima and Paris – we have got the SDG meeting at the UN General Assembly next September, and climate and sustainability will be a big part of that agenda as well. Yesterday we adopted Mr Stier’s excellent report here in this Parliament about the SDG and the post-2015 process. I want to know how you in the Commission are working together on the SDGs because – as you know, Commissioner – these two processes are going to be linked at the United Nations. The SDGs are also going to be universal. They are not just going to be like the old MDGs applying to developing countries; they are going to apply to us as well. So how are you working inside the new Commission to link those things together? I wonder, too, how the Council is dealing with this. What process has it set in place to make sure the two things make sense, are linked together and really deliver something on climate change?

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, today, all over Europe and around the world, citizens have become aware of the reality of climate change. Companies have adopted pro-climate investment strategies. Cities, municipalities and regions have committed to climate plans. So we have a moving society that is ready and a pro-climate economy that is already in operation.  Now, Commissioner, it is up to you to take initiatives. The Commission has the power to drain the carbon market, end fossil fuel subsidies and strengthen energy efficiency and renewable energy targets. That is how we will be less dependent on Russia, we will create SMEs in all territories to respond to Mr Juncker's speech, and that is how we will create jobs. Let us demonstrate that we will live better in a society that fights climate change.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Due to the need to meet the deadlines for the award of the Sakharov Prize and for all the ceremonies that will follow the award, I cannot grant catch the eye. Under Rule 162(12) of the Rules of Procedure, Members who have not been able to take the floor, and I apologise for that, may make a written statement which does not exceed 200 words and which will be annexed to the Verbatim Report of Proceedings.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, thank you very much for this debate. I was happy to hear support from different sides of the hemicycle for a strong European Union negotiating position in Lima and Paris. To be an effective negotiating partner, we need three things. First, we need to show leadership through our domestic policies. With the 2013 framework adopted, the European Union is in an excellent position not only to be a strong international voice but also to address the European climate and energy challenges. I have listened with great attention to all your concerns in this regard. Second, we need to deliver on our previous commitments. We will continue scaling up climate finance, as we have done so far, and I hope we will also be able to adopt the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol shortly. I have been asked a very specific question about the Green Climate Fund (GCF) by Mr Eickhout. As you know, clearly the European Union does not have a seat on the board of the GCF due to the position of Russia and the United States at the time of its establishment. It will not therefore be possible to contribute to it from the European Union budget for accountability reasons, because European Union spending from the European Union budget cannot be undertaken if the European Union is not involved in decisions made by the Green Climate Fund. However, the Commission is ready to explore co-financing projects with the GCF at country level, for example via the European Union regional investment facilities, with which we currently already blend grants in the European Union budget and loans from the Development Bank. Finally, to be an effective negotiating partner, we have to be united. The European Union is a strong unit that speaks with one voice. Only in this way can we continue to strengthen our existing alliance and to build bridges, with the perseverance Mrs Grossetête claims and without changing strategies. This is not the time to change a global strategy that we have lived with for many years. We are aiming for a globally-binding agreement, and we cannot change that strategy. It takes time. It is difficult. The United Nations procedures are slow, but we must proceed with the aim of having a binding agreement in Paris. You can count on my engagement, both in Lima and also next year, to work on all these three elements. My hope and ambition is that, by the time we have a similar debate next year, the outline of the future agreement will be clear. It must be an agreement that keeps us on track for the below 2° C target and that is applicable to all. It is something we owe to future generations. Delivering the 2015 Agreement in Paris needs commitment from all countries in order to effectively combat dangerous climate change. However, Paris will not be the end of the process, because implementation, monitoring and review will always be needed beyond Paris to verify that the international ambition of all countries will be delivered to the levels required by science. If need be, a regional intervention action will have to be identified.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very encouraged by the outcome of this debate. You said it: the world is beginning to move; it must do so with perseverance more than forcefully, as Mrs Grossetête said. Jo Leinen referred to a very important point. It is true that we are far from Copenhagen, we must stay away from Copenhagen even when we move on from Lima, which is really far from Copenhagen, to Paris, which is a little closer, but only geographically. We must certainly maintain the level of our ambitions. That is why you have stressed in various countries the importance of the announcement by the United States and China: they are responsible for 43% of global emissions and have jointly announced a commitment for the first time long before the Paris Summit. It is clear that we need more information to assess the commitments and also to prepare for the right coalitions and alliances to make Paris a success. Mrs McAvan asked how much we would take account of the work that is being done for the developing countries. I would remind you – as I said in my introduction – that the contributions planned and established at national level, the so-called INDCs, must allow each party to choose its own type of contribution and to define its own level of ambition according to their national situations and capacities. Of course, as you have said, in Lima we must achieve a result not only for the European Union, but a result for the whole planet, and as on previous occasions we will take full account of your support and, above all, of the awareness-raising work that, as in the past, you have done and can do with regard to our partners at world level. It is an essential element of the leading role that the European Union has played in the past and your contribution has also been and will, I am sure, also be in Lima and in view of Paris, which is highly appreciated. We want to work closely with you in the immediate preparation of the Lima Conference, and you will also be part of the European Union delegations at the Lima Conference. It is essential that we achieve the best possible results in Lima in the run-up to next year's decisive Paris Conference. A Paris Conference which, in the Council's hopes, will have to take up the spirit and ambitions of Kyoto.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I have received one motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Wednesday, 26 November 2014, at 12.30 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. – If only the most alarmist climate predictions are taken into account, then action will be taken on short-term measures without a proper consideration of the future. This is, I believe, what is happening at present. But imagine that we developed renewables technology to a point where it became economically competitive first. People would not be in fuel poverty today, and when such technology becomes viable the advantages will see it taken up worldwide. Short-term targets lead to the development of the wrong forms of energy. Wind energy may well hit a target, but wind is intermittent and unpredictable and requires significant conventional backup. Investment in research now, and implementation when that research yields benefits, would benefit both the economy and the environment.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: in writing. – I welcome this resolution and am delighted that Parliament is sending a delegation to the Lima COP and is putting in so much effort, together with the Commission, to ensure that a truly global legally-binding agreement is achieved in Paris at the end of 2015. It is imperative to limit global temperature rise to below 2°C, the impact of climate change is real, not only on humans but also on the planetʼs fragile biodiversity. Just last year the south of the UK was severely affected by flooding, costing the country an estimated GBP 1 billion. Today the UK Environment Agency estimates that one sixth of houses in England are at risk of flooding. But right across the world, not only in the UK, many nations are struggling to cope with the effects of climate change. This is why I welcome the fact that this resolution reiterates the EUʼs and Member Statesʼ commitment to funding the UN Green Climate Fund by 2020. Such a fund will help developing countries adapt to and mitigate the effects of climate change. Finally I would like to wish Parliamentʼs delegation all the best at the COP in Lima and truly hope that significant international progress can be achieved.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. The fight against climate change is an issue that is particularly close to my heart. Since 2000, Europe has reduced its CO2 emissions by almost 10%, but global emissions have increased by 36% over the same period. It is therefore particularly important that our negotiators, at the UN climate conference in Lima at the beginning of December, commit themselves to continuing global efforts to combat climate change. I hope that a negotiating text with new binding climate change targets for the post-2020 period can be drawn up in Lima, which will then be decided at the climate conference in Paris in December 2015. Unlike the Kyoto Protocol, which only obliges the industrialised countries, the new agreement is intended to apply to all countries.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – Greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions are a global problem but let us be honest: developed nations caused the majority of global warming by fuelling our industrial development over the centuries. It is now our role to take the lead in reversing this process. I am very proud that the EU has set the prevention of dangerous climate change as a strategic priority. In the past five years, the EU has been working hard to transform Europe into a highly energy-efficient low carbon economy, while encouraging other nations and regions to do likewise. And now, we are starting to ʽsee some light at the end of the tunnelʼ. Just 10 days ago, US and Chinese leaders unveiled new pledges on GHG emissions. In addition, a week ago 30 nations pledged USD 9.3 billion for the Green Climate Fund in order to help developing nations cut emissions and prepare for climate change. These latest moves send very powerful signals and give a strong boost to our efforts to secure a global deal on reducing emissions after 2020. Therefore, let us set ambitious EU goals for the negotiations in Lima and aim for a strong agreement in a well-framed framework, with maximum transparency.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. In line with my position in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I voted against the motion for a resolution which turns out to be built on vague ideas and imprecise objectives, with some policies projected on deadlines too far away to be realistic. In addition, the text paves the way for legally binding provisions for states and proposes releases of large financial masses without specifying the objectives and means of controlling this expenditure. It is therefore not acceptable to support such undertakings, which are otherwise based on ideologically marked work. Finally, this draft resolution presents aberrations that fall within communist planning where it is assumed that objectives achieved are synonymous with unambitious objectives. These policies are leaks forward that no longer have any contact with reality.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. – The catastrophic results of climate change – extreme weather, rising sea levels, and the growing number of environmental refugees – are undeniable. This underlines the need for an ambitious and sustainable strategy in the fight against global warming. The Climate Change Conference, to be held in December, is intended to enable the 194 member states of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change to adopt an international binding agreement in the fight against climate change in Paris next year. The European Union must lead the way in this regard when it comes to climate protection with a united voice. The turnaround announced by the US and China shows that increased cooperation is being sought with both developed and emerging and developing countries. Consequently, it is essential that EU Member States present ambitious national strategies that reflect their willingness and will to stop climate change. Only through a coordinated approach can we get to grips with global warming. The 20th United Nations Climate Change Conference in Lima must take the first steps to the 21st United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris in 2015. This will provide the necessary basis for an ambitious agreement in the fight against climate change.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. The European Parliament is preparing to send an authoritative and ambitious message with a view to the United Nations Conference in Lima. This is no longer the time for compromise agreements: the new framework that we will prepare in Lima and that will spring up in COP21 in Paris 2015 must aim for important targets, up to a 50% reduction in emissions by 2050. Our delegation in Lima will pursue a position which will, of course, be very attentive to the impact that reducing emissions will have on the competitiveness of Europe's manufacturing, industrial and chemical sectors. In this context, it is crucial to reach a common agreement covering all productive areas of the world, including developing countries. The contribution that Europe can make to these countries in terms of technology transfer and capacity reduction capacity will therefore be truly decisive, including through an increase in the allocations of the United Nations Green Climate Fund: the latter, in fact, is the best investment that European countries can make to promote the energy transition and a fairer competitive condition at global level.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I can agree with the statements made in the resolution that climate change requires an urgent response. The only question is which one? I do not agree that it is mainly human activity that causes the climate to warm and that without a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by the end of the century, the temperature will rise by 5oC. This is a bare-word statement, based on the belief that the IPCC hypothesis has been proven. Such an unproven claim cannot be used to simulate future climate effects by extrapolation. This is an extremely primitive, unsuspecting simplification.  What should be the international response to global warming? Firstly, it is necessary to determine quickly and unequivocally whether the causes of these changes are natural or anthropogenic. Secondly, if it turns out that these are anthropogenic causes, it is necessary to determine whether they are greenhouse gases or dust, or deforestation or other factors. Thirdly, more attention needs to be paid to the effects of global warming , which vary from country to country, as over-concentrating economies on reducing CO2 emissions is extremely costly and can delay or even prevent the equally costly, extremely urgent need for countries to adapt to climate change. Fourthly, there needs to be a broad discussion about climate change, its causes and local and global impacts, and this is not guaranteed by the IPCC and the belief in the inability of this unfortunately quasi-scientific group.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – Climate change is affecting the world, not just Europe. As an elected Member, I have a responsibility to present the views of the citizens I represent. And the citizens seem to me to have been removed from the programme that you have presented, Commissioner. Some citizens do not perceive climate change correctly, while others (most) say that nothing coherent is being done to improve the situation. Why is that? Because they see how money is spent with minimal effects, they see how emissions move from one country to another by walking waste, old cars, old technologies from one country to another. They see how governments accept the cutting of forests. Today I heard several times "must", but I did not hear "HOW"! That is why I believe that both the European Commission and the Council must present integrated projects in and between EU countries, but also between the EU and the rest of the world. I think there is a need for better mandatory regulation, not voluntary regulation, because everything that is done wrong in a country affects the rest of the world. The Council and the Commission have an obligation to find solutions that bring concrete results so that 'climate change' does not remain just a slogan.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – In 2009, the European Union unilaterally committed to a 20% reduction in greenhouse gases by 2020 compared to 1990 levels. The European Council of 23 and 24 October 2014 committed to reducing emissions within the EU by at least 40% by 2030 compared to 1990. For the first time since the announcement by the United States and China in November 2014, I see hope that we can effectively combat climate change through effective international cooperation. Although the target dates undertaken by our partners are far away (2025 and 2030) and their performance can only be measured after years, there is a chance that the European Union has not pioneered the initiative in vain. This does not mean, of course, that Europe can also bring about a competitive disadvantage. Regardless of these commitments, energy prices in the United States are expected to remain well below the European average for decades to date. In China, we have a very different competitive advantage, where the price of human resources is much more favourable. I am confident that, as a result of the TTIP negotiations, Europe's leadership in green technologies can be further achieved than it is now, and that European investors can achieve significant success in the US market.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. According to european commission data, the European Union is responsible for 11% of global greenhouse gas emissions and is on track to meet its own reduction commitments. With its illustriised certificate and the recently sanctioned 2030 climate and energy framework targets, Europe can once again sit confidently at the negotiating table at the UN climate conference in December. But will there be other good students in Lima or will the EU once again be left alone in the international community?  The fight against climate change can only be effective in the future if other developed countries and the major emitters currently developing make ambitious commitments comparable to the EU before the 2015 Paris Conference. The new international convention should be applicable, stimulating, fair and legally binding to both developed and developing countries. The EU cannot solve the global emissions reduction deficit on its own.  Moreover, even if you achieve your zealous goals, you cannot hurt your own industry indefinitely. We're going to have to look back for a second and wait for the others. In the wake of the historic announcement by the United States and China, it is hoped that europe's followers will soon be within sight.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. "Harmful emissions in the climate are increasing cumulatively. In order for global warming to remain below 2 degrees during the current century, urgent measures are needed to reduce greenhouse gases. The further we stretch the decision to significantly reduce emissions, the more expensive it will be to stay below 2 degrees. Parliament's line on international climate negotiations is good and ambitious. According to this week's policy, internationally binding emission targets are needed to take global CO2 emissions and the use of fossil fuels to zero by 2050. The countries of the world will next be at the negotiating table in December in Lima and next year in Paris. The European Union is committed to reducing its greenhouse gases by 40% by 2030. Climate action also requires the biggest polluters – China and the United States produce 45% of global greenhouse gas emissions. What is promising for the success of next year's negotiations is that these countries are committed to reducing their own emissions. Politically, these commitments are significant but insufficient to mitigate climate change.

name: Pavel POC
text: climate change is a reality of today's world. Twenty years on, and after 20 climate conferences, we're getting to the point where we're going to decide what's going to happen to our planet. The IPCC's fifth assessment report is very clear in this regard: our planet could warm by up to 4.8°C by 2100.  To those who do not see this as a problem at first glance, I highly recommend reading the World Bank's report entitled 'Lower the temperature: why cannot a world with a temperature of 4 °C be allowed'. We simply must not allow such warming. Of course, the international community is aware of this, and it has long since agreed that global temperatures must not rise by more than 2°C in order to avoid potential worst impacts on the biosphere, food and water availability and supply, health, livelihoods, and economic development worldwide. And it's no wonder. An October 2014 Pentagon study stated that climate change poses a current threat to national security with an increased risk of terrorism, a threat to food supplies, and an increase in infectious diseases among the population. Unless the necessary conditions are created at the Lima Conference for the successful adoption of a binding global climate agreement in 2015 in Paris, the aforementioned disastrous scenarios will become our future.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: Written. – I welcome the steps taken by the European institutions with regard to their concern for climate change. I believe that, if action is taken now, the costs of food production and environmental protection costs for the global, European and national economies will be able to be lower in the future. All the countries of the world must take appropriate measures to establish globally coordinated regional and macro-regional plans capable not only of reacting to climate change, but more, of preventing its effects, in order to protect the society in which we live and its citizens.  Every month, every year that passes without having made firm decisions about the risks of climate change means not thinking about our living conditions, but more over that means not caring about the planet we leave to our children. The invitation to all actors (governments, international organisations, non-governmental organisations and operators at sub-national level) must have an answer, and the answer can only be better concrete international cooperation against climate change. We must not forget that food safety and security, especially for vulnerable people, is affected by the effects of climate change.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, It is a great honour for me to welcome this year's Sakharov Prize winner Dr Denis Mukwege and his wife, Mrs Madelaine Mapendo Kaboyi from the Democratic Republic of Congo to the European Parliament. (Applause) Cher Docteur Mukwege, Madame, soyez les bienvenus au Parlement Européen! Before I acknowledge your extraordinary commitment to welcoming a number of other guests who have made a living for freedom and human rights, please allow me, Dr Mukwege. Among you the representative of the Ukrainian Euromajdan movement, Elisaveta Shcheltyylnykova, who is with us today and whom I warmly welcome on behalf of the Euromajdan movement. (Applause) You, Mrs Shcheletylnykova, and your colleagues, your friends, have shown enormous courage and you have fought for the good future of your country at the risk of your life. They have taken to the streets to live in a free and democratic Ukraine. We assure you of our full support and solidarity for this. I would also like to welcome Dinara Yunus. You, Mrs Yunus, have come to Strasbourg today to represent her mother, Leyla Yunus, who cannot be with us because she is still in prison. Welcome, Dear Mrs Yunus! (Applause) Mrs Yunus has been nominated for the Sakharov Prize here in Parliament because, as the founder of the Institute for Peace and Democracy, she courageously defended and defended human rights in Azerbaijan. The European Parliament calls on the government in Azerbaijan to release immediately this innocent woman, whose health is deteriorating dramatically. I would like to add here that we have tried to send a parliamentary delegation to Azerbaijan to visit Mrs Yunus. We have not been able to do that so far. That is why I am protesting explicitly here against our fellow Members being denied access to Mrs Yunus by the Azerbaijani authorities to this day. This is unacceptable. That is why the fact that her daughter is here today is a symbolic act. (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen! Much better than I could describe it, says about the work of Dr. Mukwege a short film, which we want to show you before I continue. (A short film about the work of Dr. Mukwege is recorded.) These impressive and also stirring scenes say a lot about you, Dr. Mukwege. A fascinating personality and at the same time a humble man who dedicated his life to the fight for peace and justice, a doctor who cares tirelessly for his patients and does everything in the most adverse circumstances to alleviate their terrible suffering. And yet we can hardly imagine the pain and misery you encounter every day of your work in the Panzi hospital you founded. On behalf of my fellow Members, I would like to express our admiration and deep respect for what you do every day. Instead of looking away and turning away, you have become a fearless man in the face of cruel violence. A man who cares for the most neglected victims of the war, women and girls who have been victims of sexual violence. They have alleviated the suffering of countless women and girls. They have offered refuge to the survivors and given them a helping hand to heal their wounded bodies and broken souls. You tirelessly denounce the systematic use of rape as a weapon in the war against the innocent and that these atrocities are not just acts of violence, but, as you said, part of a strategy. Rape is always inhumane and brutal, and we condemn it. But we must also turn words into deeds. In other words, ladies and gentlemen, the de facto impunity for rape in armed conflicts must be brought to an end. (Applause) When rape is ordered by commanders, it is a war crime. And then these war crimes must also be punished like war crimes. (Applause) Mass rapes are still taking place in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Countless women have suffered the same fate in Syria, Iraq, Rwanda, Bosnia and Herzegovina and other armed conflicts. Almost all of these crimes went unpunished. The European Parliament calls on the Government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, as well as the governments in other countries concerned, to assume their responsibilities and to do everything possible to stop the rapes immediately, to do everything possible to end impunity for rapists, and to do everything possible to give women a single voice. free access to the legal system. Dear Dr. Mukwege! With the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought, the European Parliament honours your admirable work, her work as a doctor and as a fighter for the dignity of women, for justice and peace in your country. I hope that together we will be able to raise awareness that rape is being systematically used as a weapon of war – a heinous crime that we must fight and eradicate together with all our strength. Yesterday, Dr Mukwege, in the European Parliament, you said a sentence which impressed me greatly: ' En m'attribuant ce prix, vous reconnaissez toutes ces femmes et toutes ces filles, dans mon pays ou dans d'autres régions du monde, leurs statuts de victimes auxquelles nous devons. I am proud, ladies and gentlemen, to present this year's Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought to Dr Denis Mukwege from Congo. (Members of Parliament rose and applauded the laureate)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: winner of the Sakharov Prize. Mr President of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, representatives of the peoples of the European Union, distinguished guests to your titles and qualities, it is with great humility and hope that I receive today the prestigious Sakharov Prize for freedom of thought. This year, you commemorated the 100th anniversary of the First World War. Europe thought that this was the last and that civilization would triumph. No, alas, thirty years later, human folly was back on the agenda. Since then, you have made the choice of peace and living together in a society oriented towards freedom and prosperity. In an increasingly unstable security environment where crisis centres are multiplying, especially in the direct vicinity of the European Union, I would like above all to thank the elected representatives of the European peoples for highlighting the human tragedies experienced by women victims of rape and sexual violence in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. In a world of inversion of values where violence is trivialized in always abominable forms, to refuse violence is to be dissenting. By drawing the world's attention to the need to protect women in times of armed conflict, you have refused indifference to one of the greatest humanitarian disasters of modern times. You reaffirmed that the resolution of conflicts in the Great Lakes and the promotion of human rights and democracy are and remain priorities of the European Union's foreign policy.  With this award, you have decided to increase the visibility of the struggle waged by Congolese women for more than 15 years and to recognize their suffering, but also their dignity and the courage they embody.  (Applause) Mr President, the region where I live is one of the richest on the planet; yet the overwhelming majority of its inhabitants live in extreme poverty due to insecurity and poor governance.  Women's bodies have become a real battlefield and rape is used as a weapon of war.  The consequences are manifold and affect society as a whole. The family unit is disintegrated, the social fabric is destroyed, populations are enslaved or simply driven into exile in a largely militarized economy where the law of warlords continues to prevail in the absence of a rule of law. So we are facing a dreadfully effective war strategy. The authority of the Congolese state and its institutions remain fragile and are not yet able to protect the population or meet its basic needs.  Mr President, there are few days when the news in my region does not reveal a new human tragedy. Last week, more than 50 people were massacred with machetes in the territory of Beni in North Kivu: pregnant women are gutted and babies mutilated. In the space of a month and a half, two hundred people were brutally killed. Like any human being, I would so much like to stop mentioning these heinous crimes against my fellow human beings. But how can I be silenced when, for more than fifteen years, we see what even a surgeon's eye can't get used to seeing? How can I be silent when we know that these crimes against humanity are planned with a low economic motive? How can I be silenced when these same economic reasons have led to the use of rape as a strategy of war? Every woman raped, I identify her with my wife. (Applause) Every mother raped, I identify her with my mother and every child raped, I identify her with my children. How can we keep quiet? What is this conscious human being who would be silent when a six-month-old baby whose vagina was destroyed either by the brutal penetration of an adult, by blunt objects or by chemicals? Already, only one case of rape is serious and requires action by all. In my country, there are hundreds of thousands of women raped and thousands more children from rape, in addition to the millions of human beings who died as a result of conflict.  In the rest of the world, everyone would rise with indignation, but in Congolese society, which is losing its bearings, mass atrocities pass into the news as mere miscellaneous facts, a desolate sign of a society traumatized by too much violence, a society where there is a lack of political responsibility, and a simply denial of our common humanity. Mr President, we have taken too much time and energy to repair the consequences of violence. It is time to address the causes. Thousands of testimonies from victims show that the Congolese people crave justice, peace and yearn for change. There are a urgency to act. Solutions exist and require real political will. We are at a critical moment. The Framework Agreement for Peace, Security and Cooperation, signed in Addis Ababa in 2013, cannot remain a single piece of paper. We call on the European Union - and its Member States - as a historic partner and the main contributor of aid, to revitalise the implementation of this agreement, which we gladly call the 'agreement of hope', and to use all the levers, economic, financial, but also political and diplomatic, to contribute once and for all to the resolution of conflicts in the Great Lakes. (Applause) In the Democratic Republic of Congo, the consolidation of the state and the restoration of security in the east are the priorities. Security sector reform is one of the most important institutional reforms and is at the heart of efforts to implement the Congolese state's primary responsibility to protect civilians. Justice must also be placed at the heart of the peace process, and the fight against impunity for the most serious crimes, including crimes of sexual violence, must be strengthened.  There will be no peace, economic and social development without respect for human rights, (applause) without reparation for rape survivors and victims, without remediation of the civil service, including a vetting of the security forces, and without a truth-finding mechanism to promote reconciliation. Mr President, human rights are not only one of the fundamental values of the European Union but also one of the objectives that inspire its external relations with the promotion of peace and development and the strengthening of democracy and the rule of law.  In our humble opinion and esteem, this is the real added value of the Union compared to other international partners. But realpolitik often illustrates that geostrategic and economic interests take precedence over respect for the protection of human rights. The Commission's draft European regulation for responsible mineral supply, which is to be discussed in this House, should have a binding dimension and target both finished products here in the West and raw materials in the raw state in Africa.  (Applause) We express here the hope that everyone will ensure that economic policies and respect for human rights are more coherent, and that human dignity is at the centre of economic and financial concerns. Our country is full of potential and, with more responsible and transparent trade, Congo has the capacity for endogenous development thanks to its natural resources but, above all, thanks to its human resources, which today cannot be exploited for the benefit of all in a context of "neither peace nor war".  Mr President, this award will only mean meaningful to women who are victims of sexual violence if you accompany us on the road to peace, justice and democracy. We therefore dedicate it to all survivors of sexual violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo and around the world. We are convinced that change will come through these courageous, determined and dignified women who are our daily inspiration. We also dedicate this award to all human rights defenders who campaign day after day, often under difficult conditions and away from the spotlight, to foster a culture of peace, to help victims claim their rights and to make their institutions more accountable.  Finally, we would like to acknowledge the professionalism and dedication of all Panzi staff and all our partners who have helped us to carry out our work. I am thinking in particular of the European humanitarian agency ECHO, which has been supporting us for 10 years. Without you, we wouldn't be here today. Together, policy makers, civil society actors and citizens, men and women, we must draw a red line against the use of rape as a weapon of war and build a better future to provide our children and grandchildren with a framework for their development, and to enable all those who have suffered too much to look to the future in greater freedom. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me conclude by addressing the citizens of my country, who, in large numbers, have been willing to accompany me.  Dear compatriots, our nation, the Democratic Republic of Congo, belongs to us. Its natural and human resources, its institutions, its destiny, are all our responsibility.  It is up to us, the Congolese people, to shape our our laws, our justice and our government to serve our interests for all, not just those of some. (Applause) The Sakharov Prize we receive from the European Parliament is yours, and it is the symbol of freedom of thought: a right that has been taken away from us, a right which, because of terror and oppression, we sometimes seem to have renounced. This right is vested in us and the Peoples of Europe, through their representatives, are reaching out to us today to recover it. They want to support us in our struggle for freedom, peace, justice and progress. Today, aloud and in front of the whole world, Europe expresses its solidarity with us. She wants to walk with us in our quest to restore a dignified Congolese life. Let us unite and walk with it, so that, once and for all, peace and justice will be restored in Congo and that we can aspire to a better future. Our country is sick, but together with our friends around the world, we can and will heal it. Thank you. (Applause) (The Assembly, standing, applauds the laureate)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Neena GILL
text: Madam President, I voted in favour of the Gualtieri Report and would like to congratulate the rapporteur, because it is vital that we have clear rules that are adopted on the ECB’s ability to circulate statistical information among the European system of central banks and to relevant Member States and national institutions. I also believe it is crucial that regional variations are included in the statistics that are taken on board by the ECB. It is crucial also that organisations on the receiving end should take all the necessary regulatory, technical, administrative and organisational measures to ensure the physical and logical protection of confidential statistical information. I welcome the inclusion in the report of a call for increased transparency on the exemption of reporting agents and protection of confidential data used by the ECB under its new supervisory task.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: I want to say that I was pleased to support the draft legislative resolution on the Council regulation on the collection of statistical information by the ECB.  Although this regulation seems to bring additional bureaucracy and administration, this is not the case. The new rules on the use of confidential statistical information reduce the reporting burden to a minimum and make it an effort to ensure that the same data is collected only once.  On Monday, we discussed the Commission's guidelines on the impact assessment of legislation. I think that this regulation shows the right way to reduce bureaucracy, administration, which is why I want to explicitly highlight them and say that I was happy to support them.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. I voted today in favour of the report on the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank because I believe that Regulation 2533 of 1998 undoubtedly needs to be amended in view of the extension of the ECB's powers. The granting of new supervisory tasks to this institution is a consequence of the changes that have taken place in the euro area as a result of the collapse of the global and European economies. The irresponsible behaviour of some financial institutions has led to a deepening of poverty and social exclusion in Europe. It is therefore good that the ECB will be able to control and verify the data it receives. In this area, an amendment seems appropriate to give the bank the power to collect and analyse so-called raw data not processed by the audited institutions. This will create better conditions for knowing their real situation, will allow to differentiate the importance of individual actions, and thus the responsibility and potential consequences. I also fully agree with the provisions that the extension of the obligation on credit institutions to provide data must be balanced by strengthening the requirements necessary to protect their confidentiality. Indeed, we must bear in mind that supervised entities are very sensitive to any manipulation activities, and the leakage of confidential information can weaken their position in the market. Thank you.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Madam President, when I was a teenager travelling in the Warsaw Pact countries in the 1980s, I came across a very eerie phrase that people used to use and which some colleagues from those countries may remember. It was ‘the gap between what is said and what is’. We used to think it a characteristic of totalitarian regimes, but what a wonderful description it is of the whole lamentable euro project also. The thing was built on a fraud in the first place, as countries falsified their statistics in order to qualify, and it was then sold to the people in an act of even greater fraud, as we were told that it would add 1% to the GDP of all participating states every year in perpetuity. The worse of it is that the lies are continuing. Even now, in this Chamber we are assured, over and over again, that the debt crisis had nothing to do with the euro and that the economic crisis is unrelated to monetary union. The new President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, stood in front of us at a recent session and said that the euro had been a shelter in the economic storm. My friends, unless we get the diagnosis right, we will never get the prescription right. We are not only deceiving our constituents; much more seriously, we are deceiving ourselves.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President! Before the financial crisis, we believed that banks were living up to their social responsibility. Unfortunately, we had to recognise that this is not the case. That is why I have to say that politics always starts with looking at reality, and the reality is statistics – especially in banking. If we want to equip the European Central Bank with the competence, if we want to establish the European Central Bank as the guardian of our financial relations, then we simply have to have the necessary statistical data. That is why I voted in favour of the report because it is a prerequisite for grasping and reflecting reality.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the ECB fully assumed its single supervisory duties on 4 November 2014. Consequently, I agree with the rapporteur on the need to amend the regulation we are debating today, as these amendments are in line with the objectives of taking account of the new tasks of prudential supervision for credit institutions. I am convinced that in a centralised system the ECB can make use of confidential statistical information for the performance of its supervisory tasks, in the same way as central banks, ensuring that it is used directly for the activities to be carried out. I am of the opinion that the authorisation of the Transmission of Confidential Statistical Information by the European System of Central Banks to the authorities or bodies of the Member States means authorising an important flow of information which, if collected in the wrong hands, can destabilise information flows and markets. Consequently, I agree with the rapporteur that the receiving authorities must take all necessary regulatory, administrative, technical and operational measures to ensure the physical and logical protection of the confidential statistical information in question.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, ar dtús ba mhaith liom a rá go raibh mé sásta tacaíocht a thabhairt do mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir; agus glacadh leo uile. Freisin, tá moladh ag dul don rapóirtéir, Kay Swinburne, as ucht an jab maith a rinne sí san ábhar casta seo.  Dar ndóigh tá dul chun cinn iontach déanta ag an mbanc seo le blianta beaga anuas, go háirithe ó tháinig an tUachtarán Draghi isteach agus tá moladh ag dul dó faoi sin.  It is good that the Bank has more powers, but also more responsibilities. This revised mechanism should help ensure that we learn from the mistakes that were made at the time of the recession. But in relation to Ireland, we are having a banking inquiry at central level shortly, and it has been requested that the European Central Bank cooperate in that inquiry. That may take one form or another, but I think it is important that they will be seen to give as much information as possible according to their remit, so that the Irish people can see exactly what happened and learn the lessons of the recession and the crisis.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted against this report approving the draft contained in the recommendation of the European Central Bank as amended in relation to the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank, as one of the new powers granted to this entity. From the outing point of view, my group has criticised most elements of the banking union, including those relating to increasing the ECB's power. That's why I voted against it.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. - The aim of this text is to allow the European Central Bank to use confidential statistical data in the context of its new tasks in the field of banking supervision, similar to that for national central banks. The ame is to reduce the reporting burden, as the same data only needs to be collected once.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - Whilst the majority of this text refers to euro area countries, there is still potentially some impact of the new proposed ECB powers in terms of the UK. Consequently, I voted against the adoption of this report.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to take account of the Recommendation of the European Central Bank to amend Regulation (EC) No 2533/1998 in order to take account of the new ecb supervisory tasks relating to the policy on prudential supervision of credit institutions. The proposal states that the ECB may use confidential statistical information in the performance of its new supervisory tasks. I agree with the rapporteur's proposal to limit these new powers to the transfer of only confidential data necessary for the ECB's new supervisory tasks under the SSM Regulation. In addition, the European System of Central Banks must allow the transmission of confidential statistical information to the Member States and eu authorities responsible for the stability of financial institutions, markets and infrastructure and to the European Stability Mechanism in such completeness as is necessary for the performance of their respective tasks. I agree with the rapporteur's proposal that such an important mandate be given by requiring the receiving authorities to take all necessary regulatory, administrative, technical and organisational measures to ensure the protection of relevant confidential statistical information.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. — At first glance, there is an attempt to support this collection of statistical information by the ECB, except that this amounts to the divesting the national authorities of the necessary control of the banking system. I therefore voted against granting these new missions to the ECB.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the draft Regulation because I share the ECB's recommendation that Regulation (EC) No 2533/1998 be amended in order to adapt it to the ECB's new supervisory functions in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013. These modifications will allow you to use sensitive statistical information to serve as supervisor. In addition, the transmission of this information to the European System of Central Banks, authorities and bodies of the Member States and of the Union responsible for the supervision for the exercise of their respective functions shall be permitted.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report, which aims at the collection of statistical information by the ECB, makes it possible to use confidential statistical information as part of the exercise of the new supervisory functions.  The amendment to the regulation is part of a clear divestiture of national banking authorities in favour of supervision of the ECB, even though national banks will be able to benefit from the information received.  This text, in the context of the Banking Union, obviously implies a strengthening of communication obligations and to the extent that it wants to ensure more transparency within the world of finance could only garner a favourable opinion in order to avoid any excesses. Nevertheless, given the ECB's power in this area instead of national banks, I abstained.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - (IT) In view of the disastrous results of the ECB's monetary policy, although this measure is purely technical in nature, I have nevertheless chosen to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - The financial crisis highlighted the need to improve the regulation and supervision of the financial sector in the EU, so I voted in favour of the ECB being able to use confidential statistical information for the performance of its new supervisory functions and for its transmission within the European System of Central Banks to national and EU authorities and bodies responsible for the supervision and stability of institutions , markets and financial infrastructures in accordance with the European Stability Mechanism and current legislation. A rule that we compensate for the requirement that the authorities receiving the information take all necessary regulatory, administrative, technical and organizational measures to ensure the physical and computer protection of their confidentiality.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which replaces the Recommendation of the European Central Bank (ECB) on statistical information. The amendments to the Recommendation proposed by the European Central Bank state that the ECB may use confidential statistical information in the performance of its new supervisory tasks, similar to the national central banks, which are entrusted with specific prudential supervisory functions and which, as a result, may use confidential statistical information for prudential supervisory purposes under the current Regulation. The European Parliament proposes a new mandate to limit the transfer of confidential data necessary for the ECB's new supervisory tasks under the Credit Institutions Supervisory Policy Regulation. After all, that Regulation receives new powers from the ECB, not the European System of Central Banks. The European Parliament therefore considers that such an important power to transmit confidential data to certain authorities must be offset by the requirement that the receiving authorities take all necessary regulatory, administrative, technical and organisational measures to ensure the physical and logical protection of the relevant confidential statistical information.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the draft Regulation of the Council amending Regulation (EC) 2533/98 concerning the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank (ECB). If the text increases the powers of statistical collection, not only for the benefit of the ECB, but also for the national authorities, I can only regret that the sanctions, dating back to 1998, have not been revised upwards.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that a collection of statistical data from the European Central Bank can only be positive for the European economy.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. - Regulation 2533/98 of 23 November 1998 sets out procedures governing the collection of statistical information by the ECB from EU banks or the like. The purpose of collecting statistical information is to enable the creation of macroeconomic data essential to the ECB's management of monetary policy. The amendment to the 1998 Regulation allows the ECB to use confidential statistical information for the exercise of its new supervisory functions. If, in principle, we can welcome the strengthening of transparency obligations for banks, we cannot guarantee that it should be for the benefit of the ECB, whose legitimacy we question in monetary governance. That is why I abstained on this vote.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. I abstained. The measure itself does not involve any particular problems, but is instrumental in the exercise of functions that would increase the powers of an institute that is not a solution but part of the problem to be solved.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The European Central Bank's new role in supervising credit institutions is a significant step forward in the establishment of the Banking Union. In order for its supervisory mission to be as effective and coordinated as possible, the ECB must have confidential statistical data on the agencies under its supervision. This report makes it possible to adapt the current legislation on the ECB's prerogatives regarding the use of confidential statistical data to its new supervisory function. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree with making the supervision of the financial system more effective. This can only be done by strengthening coordination between national supervisory authorities and at the same time improving supervision on a European scale. This will make it possible to manage risks and issues with cross-border implications under the ultimate guidance of the ECB.  I believe that the two levels of supervision are complementary and essential to safeguard financial stability in Europe.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — With the increase in the powers of the European Central Bank, it should be able to rely on more complex and more precise indicators to guide its decisions. This draft regulation mainly calls for this, and is therefore broadly acceptable. That is why I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - After the worst moment of the economic crisis, what is urgent now is to finance the economic growth that generates jobs. And to ensure that the mistakes of the past in deregulation and financial speculation are not repeated. The ECB now has greater supervisory responsibilities. The proposed amendments to Regulation No 2533/1998 on the circulation and use of confidential statistical information in the context of prudential supervision are therefore fully justified, ensuring that the same data only needs to be collected once.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this report, which aims to strengthen the functions of the ECB in the context of prudential supervision of credit institutions, through the use of confidential statistical information. I agree with the idea of allowing the Transmission of Confidential Statistical Information by the European System of Central Banks to national authorities or bodies, as well as regulatory measures in favour of the protection of information. It is, in fact, confidential and important information to be protected for the protection of the market and the entire institutional structure. The ECB has recently assumed the single supervisory functions and these changes adopted will strengthen its role for the benefit of the entire European system.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report in view of the new supervisory task of the ECB related to prudential supervision of credit institutions with the intention to minimise the reporting burden and to ensure the same data only need to be collected once. Physical and logical protection of the confidential statistical information concerned will be ensured.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. I am voting against this resolution as it concerns certain amendments to be included in the regulations as a result of new powers conferred on the ECB also by virtue of the entry into operation, from November 2014, of the Single Supervisory Mechanism. This is a review of statistical information collection methodologies which should allow for a better effectiveness of the entire supervisory mechanism. My unfavourable vote also stems from the highly critical assessment of the ecb's actions and management.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted against this report approving the draft contained in the recommendation of the European Central Bank as amended in relation to the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank, as one of the new powers granted to this entity. From the outing point of view, my group has criticised most elements of the banking union, including those relating to increasing the ECB's power. That's why I voted against it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it is intended to minimise the reporting burden and ensure that the same data need only be collected once.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. During the previous mandate, I and my colleagues contributed to the reform of the banking and financial system, whose crisis has hit European citizens hard. Today, with the vote in favour of this text, I continue this momentum. The amendment of the regulation on the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank (ECB) will enable the ECB to assume, with the necessary means, its new supervisory functions provided by the Single Supervisory Mechanism.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. I considered, given the new supervisory tasks conferred on the ECB, to vote in favour of this report. In this way, the ECB will be able to make use of confidential statistical information for the performance of its new supervisory tasks within the SSM Regulation. At the same time, this power will be counter-balanced in order to ensure the physical and logical protection of the confidential statistical information in question.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — While the requirement for transparency is essential to the consolidation of the banking sector, the proposed report does not increase the amount of penalties provided by the previous regulation for data fraud, even though the balance sheets of the institutions concerned are important. I have therefore decided to abstain on the vote of this incomplete text.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted against it as the report is part of the new banking union which they want to establish by giving more power to the ECB. The ECB's monitoring and at the same time dictating the monetary policy of the countries of the European Union creates a conflict of interest that we must keep in mind when analysing what the establishment of a European banking union will entail. Because at a certain point monetary policy decisions (such as interest rate variation) may conflict with the objective of financial stability. Thus, if monitoring detects a stability problem, the solution may require a change in interest rates in the opposite direction.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - With regard to the amendment of Regulation 2533/98 as regards the ECB's ability to collect financial information from "reporting agencies", financial institutions, markets and infrastructure, we are voting against, because this regulation grants too many privileges and possibilities to the ECB and undermines the ability of any national government in the future to pursue an independent national economic policy.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. - I supported the proposal to amend EC Regulation 2533/98 on the collection of statistics by the European Central Bank (ECB) as the ECON Commission had succeeded in substantially improving this rule, thanks in part to amendments promoted by my group, that of the Socialists and Democrats, including some contributions from me. Therefore, a more transparent, coherent and consistent standard has been achieved internally, which has required going beyond the articles recommended changing the ECB. It is worth noting at least three improvements. First, any exemption from the obligation to provide statistics will have to be reasoned and public. Second, there is a distinction between incorrect and manipulated statistical information, which will allow for the graduation of possible sanctions. Thirdly, the ECB's inspectorate work is strengthened, giving it the power to access unprocessed data from entities subject to obligations to provide statistical information. However, it should be noted that a majority has not been achieved in favour of updating the amount of sanctions, which are not entirely proportional to the various conducts, in addition to being sparsely dissuasive.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - These changes are used to allow the ECB to use confidential statistical data information in the performance of its new banking supervision tasks. Furthermore, amendments are being proposed to transmit the same statistical information within the ESCB within the ESCB as has been collected by the ECB in the context of its new tasks, and only the ESCB will be able to collect it. The authorities or bodies of the Member States and the EU responsible for the supervision of financial institutions, markets and infrastructures or for the stability of the financial system may have access to this information only when transmitted by the ESCB to it.  This report only adds to the concern with the physical and electronic protection of information, which should be ensured with technical, administrative and regulatory measures. Once again they serve the amendments tabled to empty the supervisory powers of national institutions, and to make confidential and important information pass through the ECB's first sieve after the ESCB and only then by the national institutions, all so that important information for markets is protected.  This proposal follows the deepening of the ECB's role and the loss of state sovereignty in this strategic sector in areas such as supervision and control.  We voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. - The regulation in question aims to take account of the new supervisory powers of the European Central Bank under Regulation (EC) No 1024/2013. With this particular regulation, the European Central Bank has been given new powers in the area of supervision of credit institutions. Some important changes have been incorporated into the final text of the proposal in question, which will ensure the protection of private and trustworthy data that the European Central Bank will use in the performance of its new supervisory tasks.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — This measure is intended to adapt the rules on the collection of statistical data by the ECB. The measure is functional to the exercise of functions that do not fully support us precisely because of the results that the exercise of these powers by the ECB is giving in Europe. That is why I will not support the report and will abstain.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the report on the draft Council Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This regulation grants too many privileges and possibilities to the ECB and undermines the ability of any national government in the future to pursue an independent national economic policy.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. — The report on ECB Statistical Data Collection allows the ECB to perform its new tasks for the prudential supervision of credit institutions (Single Supervisory Mechanism).  The report establishes that any exemption of reporting agents must be justified and made public. By doing so it increases the level of transparency. The report also amplifies the typology of collected data and adds the fundamental principle of proportionality in the definition and imposition of statistical reporting requirements: the ECB, when imposing sanctions, will have to distinguish between types of misconduct and whether infringement is intentional or negligent.  Our Group has managed to include amendments that ensure greater transparency on exemption of reporting agents and protection of confidential data used by ECB when performing its new supervisory tasks. I congratulate the rapporteur Roberto Gualtieri not only for excellent work but for being able to achieve a large consensus in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs as well. I support the adoption of the report as it strengthens the ECB’s power in the exercise of its supervisory tasks, with the ultimate goal of better controlling and regulating the European Banking System.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. - Using the ECB's statistical expertise, significant support should continue to be provided for risk monitoring and risk analysis work through its macroprudential overview, which provides detailed statistical information on the various projections of systemic risks to national and European Union financial systems. In order to address the challenges arising from the changing nature of risks in the EU financial sector, the ECB should continue to participate in the review and further development of the European SystemIc Body's risk signalling system. By providing statistical information on the risks and vulnerabilities of the financial system, the risk signalling system is a key communication tool and an important element in meeting public accountability requirements. I also consider precise exchange of information and effective cooperation between the authorities to be essential, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council regulation concerning the collection of the statistical information by the European Central Bank. I believe that the statistical information has to be exchanged within the European System of Central Banks in order to be able to supervise and to ensure a stable financial sector.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. — We voted against it as the report is part of the new banking union which they want to establish by giving more power to the ECB. The ECB's monitoring and at the same time dictating the monetary policy of the countries of the European Union creates a conflict of interest that we must keep in mind when analysing what the establishment of a European banking union will entail. Because at a certain point monetary policy decisions (such as interest rate variation) may conflict with the objective of financial stability. Thus, if monitoring detects a stability problem, the solution may require a change in interest rates in the opposite direction.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for the draft EP resolution on the draft Council regulation amending the Regulation on statistical collection by the European Central Bank, thus aligning the ECB's new supervisory obligations towards credit institutions. In addition, in order to simplify and reduce reporting procedures, the proposed amendments provide for the ECB's ability to use confidential statistics for the purpose of carrying out its new duties. However, since the ECB amendments allow confidential information to be transferred to the various authorities and bodies of the Member States and the European Union, I believe that the latter should provide the necessary measures to protect that information adequately.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. —I voted in favour of my colleague Roberto Gualtieri's report on the european Central Bank's draft regulation on the collection of statistics. This text aims to update the powers of the European Central Bank, whose scope has been extended to strengthen supervision of credit institutions. To this end, the Central Bank will be able to impose the transmission of statistics, in accordance with the principle of proportionality, in order to be able to adapt the type and extent of possible sanctions. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report to amend the regulation on the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank. This amendment is intended to take into account the european Central Bank's new supervisory missions and to allow the transmission and use of statistical information collected by the European central bank system, between its members and the relevant authorities. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. — The amendments proposed in this report are in the correct line; however, we should not underestimate the importance of non-delivery of accurate information from the banks. We should underscore, though, that non-compliance with the delivery of data may be either inadvertent or deliberate. Deliberate misinformation or deliberate delay of information must be treated with severe retaliation from the regulatory authorities.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. - This draft Commission provides that the ECB may use confidential statistical information in its new supervisory role, similar to what national central banks do in their review activities. This is intended to simplify reporting and to prevent additional administrative burdens in data collection. Within the European Central Bank system, confidential statistical information collected in the course of monitoring activities should be exchanged. The amendment to Regulation (EC) No 2533/98, with reference to the ECB's new supervisory tasks, set out in Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013, to strengthen supervision of banks and credit institutions, is necessary, especially if the course of the financial crisis is being monitored. I therefore support the Commission's proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. – I welcome the amendments introduced by my Group ensuring more transparency on exemption of reporting agents and protection of confidential data used by the European Central Bank under its new supervisory tasks. I therefore supported the report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Roberto Gualteri on the need to amend Regulation (EC) No 2533/1998 in order to formalise its new supervisory tasks. I also believe that the European Central Bank should be able to use statistical information to fulfil its control prerogatives.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I supported this report in order to try to make this regulation more consistent and consistent. Progress has been made in the differentiation between incorrect and manipulated information and, for the purposes of sanctions, it has been specified that the ECB has the power to request raw data from financial institutions, as well as the need to justify in writing any exemption to entities providing statistical information. However, an update of the fines, which date back to 1998 and are now outdated, has not been achieved.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted against this report approving the draft contained in the recommendation of the European Central Bank as amended in relation to the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank, as one of the new powers granted to this entity. From the outing point of view, my group has criticised most elements of the banking union, including those relating to increasing the ECB's power. That's why I voted against it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the Gualtieri report, because I believe that the European Central Bank should be aware of the statistics necessary for the performance of its tasks.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. — This text was not very important and had few consequences: the ECB is increasing its powers to collect statistics, which it can do under the Single Supervisory Mechanism, but forces banks to submit to more transparency, which is positive. We have chosen to abstain.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the report on the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank, as this text is Parliament's response to the recommendations of the European Central Bank to amend the Regulation in order to take account of new ecb supervisory tasks with regard to policies relating to prudential supervision (SSM Regulation - Single Supervisory Mechanism). The report focuses mainly on the use and transmission of confidential statistical information for the performance of new supervisory tasks. The ECB will have to respect the principle of proportionality in the definition and imposition of statistical reporting obligations.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) I agree with Mr Gualtieri that the Recommendation of the European Central Bank on the need to amend Regulation (EC) No 2533/1998 should be adopted so that its new supervisory tasks can be formalised. I particularly agree that the ECB should be able to use confidential statistical information to fulfil its new control prerogatives.  On the basis of previous considerations, I felt it necessary to express my agreement with the report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — The competences of the ever-growing European financial market need to be improved in order for full control to take place. The Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) has strengthened the powers of the European Central Bank. However, I find it very drastic that a national managing authority should not have the right to impose sanctions on a bank that is under the direct supervision of the ECB. In addition, the ECB may provide banks with invoices for its supervisory activities. I think this approach is difficult to criticise, because the ECB can enrich itself by being able to impose its supervision on banks. I do not agree with this approach, which is why I abstained.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. - Following the adoption of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (MSU Regulation), the aim here is to amend Regulation (EC) 2533/98 to take into account the ECB's new missions in terms of prudential supervision of credit institutions. The recommendation put forward by the European Central Bank (ECB) aims to give it access to confidential statistical information. The aim is to enable the identification of the reporting officer for the performance of his supervisory duties and to authorise the transmission of this data to the European Stability Mechanism (ESM). Parliament's report endorses these recommendations. It specifies a few points such as the obligation to take the necessary regulatory, administrative, technical and organisational measures to ensure the physical and logical protection of the relevant confidential statistical information. Nevertheless, under a technical guise, this is a transfer of sovereignty allowing the ECB to obtain statistics before national central banks. Being opposed to the independent power of the central bank, I vote against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — In order to make the ecb's new prudential supervision mechanism effective, it may use confidential statistical data that can assist it in its new supervisory responsibilities. This is very important, in view of the various cases of supervisory failures that have occurred, a little across Europe. Hence my vote in favour.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I welcome the recommendation of the European Central Bank to amend Regulation (EC) No 2533/1998 with a view to taking into account the ECB’s new supervisory tasks under Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013 conferring specific tasks on the European Central Bank concerning policies relating to the prudential supervision of credit institutions (SSM Regulation). The ECB will take up its full supervisory tasks in accordance with the latter Regulation on 4 November 2014.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of this report, which will focus on maximising the effectiveness and security of the European Central Bank’s data collection operations. This report discusses the exchange of data between the ECB and the relevant authorities of Member States and the Union. While the European Central Bank is responsible for the collection of data for law enforcement, government and other such authorities, in utilising the ECB in collecting statistical information we must ensure the protection of this data.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank, which takes into account the ECB’s new supervisory tasks relating to the prudential supervision of credit institutions.

name: Bernard MONOT
