text: In writing. - The new supervisory tasks entrusted to the ECB within the framework of the Banking Union imply, quite logically, a strengthening of the obligations to communicate statistical data provided by credit institutions. To the extent that this text tends to increase the transparency, even in part, of the players in the world of finance who prosper all the more so because they are in secret, it could be supported.   However, even if the national central banks would also benefit from the information received, this text is in line with the logic of divestment of the national authorities of the banking supervisory missions, on which it is necessary to remain firmly opposed.  The abstention is therefore justified in this case.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The procedures governing the collection of statistical information by the ECB and the banking or related institutions of the European Union are defined by Regulation 2533/98 of 23 November 1998. The collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank allows the collection and analysis of macroeconomic data. The latter are therefore used for monetary policy adjustments decided by the ECB. However, the amendment to the regulation proposed here gives the ECB an increased right of supervision with access to confidential statistical information. If, in principle, we can accept the need for more transparency for the proper functioning of banking institutions in general, we consider that this should not be done for the benefit of the European Central Bank, whose monetary governance guidelines we reject and ultraliberal dogmatism. That is why I abstained.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this report. Indeed, in the same logic as the vote on the Swinburne report, the ECB should be given the appropriate instruments to carry out the new tasks entrusted to it.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. "I have spoken in favour of this text, which strengthens and clarifies the ECB's powers of sanction. The absence of credible sanctions has fostered deviant banking behaviour, and this text is helping to establish a new system of supervision and control.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — I have received my support for the supplementary report 'The collection of statistical data by the European Central Bank' and its objectives. In future, the information should no longer be received by the respective national central banks, but should go directly to the ECB. In doing so, the reporting burden on companies should be kept to a minimum and data should only have to be collected once. The information is then available for the supervision of e.B financial institutions for all competent eutoeusto-state bodies.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This technical report aims to enable the European Central Bank to collect and store statistical information to avoid the proliferation of requests for information from the ECB. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - I supported the draft amending the Regulation on the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank. I am of the opinion that collecting information simply for the purpose of collecting information is not reasonable and increases the financial and labour burden. Bureaucracy must be reduced as much as possible in order to be effective. I therefore consider it important that the principle of proportionality must be respected in the future when defining and imposing data requirements.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. The amendments proposed by the ECB aim to strengthen the prudential supervision functions of credit institutions through the use of confidential statistical information. This confidential information will be transmitted by the ESCB to the bodies responsible for carrying out its duties. I believe it is important to counterbalance the transmission of confidential information by introducing conditions which impose regulatory measures on the receiving authorities in favour of the physical and logical protection of statistical information. I would therefore like to vote in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — It is always desirable to subject banks to transparency obligations, which is the purpose of this measure. But what good is transparency if it is for the benefit of the ECB, which does not care in the least about financing a genuine re-industrialisation of Europe? Refusing to allow this institution to increase its power of nuisance but aware that banks must submit more to transparency obligations, I abstain.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Report of the Chair of the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee, Robert Gualtieri, on the collection of statistics by the European Central Bank. EC Regulation 2533/98 is a key component of legal frameworks supporting the collection of statistical information at the European Central Bank backed by national central banks.  I would point out that the ECB has consistently insisted on regulations to carry out and monitor the coordinated collection of statistical information necessary to carry out the tasks of the European System of Central Banks, including tasks that contribute to the implementation of the policy of monetary supervision of credit institutions and the stability of the financial system.  I welcome amendments by the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee aimed at clarifying the issues. It is important to point out that liability in the transfer of confidential data and careful handling of all necessary regulations, administrative, technical and organisational measures to ensure the security of confidential statistics.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the draft Council regulation amending the regulation on the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank, because this takes account of the new tasks given to the ECB in the field of supervision (prudential supervision of credit institutions). As can be seen, the authorities in this sector are given an important power to authorise the transmission of confidential information, but this is offset by the condition that it requires the receiving authorities to take all those regulatory, administrative and technical measures that guarantee protection in all aspects of confidential statistical information in the specific case.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — By ordering the ECB to supervise systemically important banks, the European Union has created a problematic situation. In the future, the ECB will have to both provide price stability and perform financial tasks. In doing so, however, it is losing the independence that would be so desperately needed in today's crisis. For these reasons, I cannot agree with any proposal which is likely to further promote the situation described.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — I am voting in favour of a regulation to take account of the changing prerogatives of the European Central Bank. The latter must be able to fulfil its role as prudential controller. The collection of statistical information must therefore be possible, while respecting the principle of proportionality.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the draft Council Regulation amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2533/98 on the compilation of statistical information by the European Central Bank, as it considers that, in view of the ecb's new prudential supervision tasks of banking institutions undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB), these changes in the use and transmission of confidential statistical information are justified. It is important, however, to ensure that the ECB, when defining and imposing statistical reporting requirements, will comply with the principle of proportionality. Similarly, it is curial that the authorities or bodies of the Member States and the EU to which confidential statistical information is transmitted take all the regulatory, administrative, technical and organisational measures necessary to ensure the physical and electronic protection of the data concerned.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — The financial crisis highlighted the need to improve regulation and supervision of the financial sector in the EU, so I voted in favour of the ECB being able to use confidential statistical information for the performance of its new supervisory functions and for its transmission within the European System of Central Banks to national and EU authorities and bodies responsible for the supervision and stability of institutions , markets and financial infrastructures in accordance with the European Stability Mechanism and current legislation. We compensate for the rule with the requirement that the authorities receiving the information take all necessary regulatory, administrative, technical and organizational measures to ensure the physical and computer protection of their confidentiality.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — Taking into account the new specific supervisory tasks that Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013 assigns to the European Central Bank (ECB) within the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), it seems clear to me the need for an update of the ECB's powers with regard to policies allocated to the prudential supervision of European banking institutions.  To this end, the proposed amendments allow the ECB to use confidential statistical information in the performance of its new supervisory tasks, and also give it a new power to transmit confidential statistical information, collected in accordance with Article 5 of the ECB's statutes within the European System of Central Banks and also to the authorities of the Member States and the European Union responsible for the supervision and stability of financial institutions, markets and infrastructures. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to abstain because this measure is functional to the exercise of the power of sanctions and supervision that has been conferred on the ECB and on which I have several concerns given the results it has given so far.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - I voted against it, as the report is part of the new banking union they want to establish, thus giving the ECB more power. For the ECB to oversee and, at the same time, to dictate the monetary policy of the countries of the European Union creates a conflict of interest that we must keep in mind when analysing what the establishment of a European banking union will entail. Because, at a certain point, monetary policy decisions (such as interest rate variation) may conflict with the objective of financial stability. Thus, if monitoring detects a stability problem, the solution may require a change in interest rates in the opposite direction.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — I voted against this report approving the draft contained in the recommendation of the European Central Bank as amended in relation to the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank, as one of the new powers granted to this entity. From the outing point of view, my group has criticised most elements of the banking union, including those relating to increasing the ECB's power. That's why I voted against it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of the ECB’s proposed amendments specifying that the ECB may use confidential statistical information for the performance of its new supervisory functions. The amendments are intended to minimise the reporting burden and to ensure that the same data will only need to be collected once. In addition, the proposed amendment allows for the transmission of confidential statistical information within the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) for the performance of tasks in the field of prudential supervision.  The ECB will be permitted by the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) to transmit confidential statistical information to authorities and bodies of the Member States and the Union responsible for the supervision of financial institutions, markets and infrastructures. Due to the confidential nature of the data being transmitted to the various authorities, it is vital that the receiving authorities take all necessary regulatory, administrative, technical and organisational measures to ensure the physical and logical protection of the confidential statistical information concerned.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I supported the supplementary report on the Regulation with a view to further improving and complementing the regulations.  The European Central Bank is responsible for certain tasks concerning prudential supervision of credit institutions based in the participating Member States. It carries out these tasks under the Single Supervisory Mechanism, composed of the ECB and the NCAs. With this complement, the European Central Bank wants to set new tasks concerning prudential supervision of credit institutions. Prudential supervision of banks is important because of the improvement of their business and that banks, with their operations, countries and their economies would help get out of the crisis.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I supported the proposed amendments because they contribute to more efficient data collection. Amendments proposed by the ECD specify that the ECB can use confidential statistical information for the purpose of monitoring functions, similar to national central banks in the field of prudential supervision. This was done to reduce the burden of the report and to collect the same data only once. In addition, the proposed amendment allows the transmission of confidential information within the European System of Central Banks (ESCB). The rapporteur proposes to limit to sending only the data necessary for the effectiveness of the new ECB tasks to be regulated by the SSM Supervisor Singley Mechanism. Now these powers are given to the ECB, not escb.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. - I support the proposal because it contributes to a more efficient collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank. Several provisions of the proposal also limit the possibilities of falsifying statistics or providing misleading statistical information. This was one of the reasons for the current debt crisis, as we could see, for example, in the case of Greece.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — This regulation grants too many privileges and opportunities to the ECB and undermines the ability of any national government in the future to pursue an independent national economic policy.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the amendment, as the Single Supervisory Mechanism Regulation entrusts the ECB with specific tasks relating to policies on prudential supervision of credit institutions, which these amendments are essential for the performance of. However, it should also be underlined that the European Union should minimise the continuation of parallel activities while maximising transparency. European citizens have a legitimate expectation that both the Member States and the EU institutions should strive for cost-effectiveness and reduction of red tape. A good example of this is that, under this amendment, the same data will only have to be collected once. It should be noted, however, that the transfer of confidential data will have to be adequately protected at all levels, such as the receiving authorities.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I supported this legislative regulation on the collection of statistics by the ECB, as I think it clearly shows the ECB's obligations and capabilities in relation to the collection of statistics.  In order for the statistical collection system to be effective, I agree with the notion that the ECB should also have access to raw business book data and records of reporting units, as it is of u essence to stress that in addition to sanctions for inaccurate, incomplete or non-requested data, there should also be sanctions for the provision of falsified or distorted statistics.  I hold a very important amendment obliging the competent authorities of the Member States and union authorities to take all necessary regulatory, administrative, technical and organisational measures to ensure the physical and logical protection of confidential statistics.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I believe that it is important to have clear rules on the information that circulates within the European Central Bank, but more importantly it is to ensure that the recipient countries ensure an adequate legal framework, technical preparation, administrative and organisational issues, in order to ensure the protection of sensitive and confidential information. I believe that these new rules can also serve to reduce the administrative burden, since it is envisaged that the same data will need to be collected only once.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — I voted against this report approving the draft contained in the recommendation of the European Central Bank as amended in relation to the collection of statistical information by the European Central Bank, as one of the new powers granted to this entity. From the outing point of view, my group has criticised most elements of the banking union, including those relating to increasing the ECB's power. That's why I voted against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - These changes serve to allow the ECB to use confidential statistical data information in the performance of its new banking supervision tasks. Amendments are also proposed to have the same statistical information collected by the ECB in the context of its new tasks, and only the ESCB will be able to collect it.  The authorities or bodies of the Member States and the EU responsible for supervising the institutions may only have access to this information, and only when transmitted by the ESCB to the ESCB. This report only adds to the concern for the physical and electronic protection of information to be ensured with technical, administrative and regulatory measures. We believe that these changes only serve to deflate the supervisory powers of the national institutions and to make confidential and important information pass through the ECB's first sieve after the ESCB and only then by the national institutions, all so that the information important to the markets is protected.  We voted against it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — (DE) The report on the collection of statistical data by the European Central Bank has potential for me, since in future the information will go directly to the ECB and not to the respective national banks. Above all, it is important that companies are significantly relieved by the reporting burden and that the information is available to the competent authorities. I have therefore voted in favour of this supplementary report.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — These changes serve to allow the ECB to use confidential statistical data information in the performance of its new banking supervision tasks. Furthermore, amendments are proposed to have the same statistical information collected by the ECB within the ESCB available within the ESCB under the new functions, and only the ESCB will be able to collect it. MS and EU authorities or bodies responsible for the supervision of financial institutions, markets and infrastructure sands or the stability of the financial system may only have access to this information when transmitted by the ESCB to it.  This report only adds to the concern for the physical and electronic protection of information to be ensured with technical, administrative and regulatory measures. Once again they serve the amendments tabled to empty the supervisory powers of the national institutions, and to make confidential and important information pass through the ECB's first sieve, after the ESCB and only then by the national institutions. It follows the path of deepening the central role of the ECB and all the consequences of the loss of sovereignty in the banking sector, its supervision and control, which can lead to poor action by these institutions.  We voted against it.

name: Neena GILL
text: Madam President, I had to abstain on the Swinburne report. Although there has been some progress in terms of the transparency of the sanctions from the ECB, we should have gone further. Indeed, I believe that the call for publishing sanctions only when all legal means of appeal against such a decision have been exhausted means that the door will be open for indefinite periods of stalling, during which the ECB cannot publish the fact that it has to impose sanctions on particular banks. So, full transparency is a key issue for me. We should avoid repeating the bottlenecks we had in the past. It is also important that markets know when banks have transgressed, and that sanctions have been put on them, as soon as possible.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: Madam President, at a meeting last week of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Mario Draghi informed Members that the ECB would not in fact be participating in an inquiry into the banking crisis in Ireland, which is currently ongoing in the Oireachtas – the Irish Houses of Parliament. We in Ireland know too well the disregard that the ECB has for ordinary families and local communities, not to mention our domestic economy. That was very evident as a result of the Troika-imposed austerity measures that have resulted in mass emigration and increased levels of poverty. That the ECB has now put on the record that it also intends to disregard an elected Parliament of a Member State is simply unacceptable. Reading the title of this report ‘The power of the ECB to impose sanctions’, I could not help but wonder: who has the power to impose sanctions on the ECB? Because the ECB’s role in exacerbating the Irish financial and banking crisis and its failure now to even engage in a Parliamentary inquiry into those events is unacceptable and should be challenged by Members of this House.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Madam President, the way to deal with wrongdoing in banks is not to sanction them with fines that they will pass on to their customers. It is to make the directors of the Bank personally liable. They would then have more incentive than anybody to prevent a meltdown which would leave them with nothing except personal debt. It is a funny thing about sanctions, the way they create perverse incentives. When the euro was being launched, there was a mechanism to sanction countries that breached the Stability Pact and thereby played some part in triggering the financial crisis. It was never used. France and Germany were among the infracting states. It was never triggered, and yet we have in practice a fine against those countries which performed better than expected – including the UK, because we did not join the single currency. In practice, this GBP 1.7 billion that has been levied on us in a surcharge for prosperity is what we got for having kept the Pound. You know, it is a funny thing, but if you start taxing countries for doing the right thing in order to pay countries for doing the wrong thing, you are going to end up with fewer of the former and more of the latter.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President! Money is a matter of trust, and financial and monetary stability are the foundations for stable social and democratic development. Of course, one could say that if you agree on rules of the game, you will also stick to them. The reality is often different, which is why we confirmed once again in the previous report that the European Central Bank can and must collect statistical data. But on the other hand – one should not be so unworldly – one must of course also have the instruments in the quiver, if, for whatever reason, someone is not willing or willing to abide by the rules of the game. Let me say it again: the aim should be that the rules of the game are not violated in the first place. But it's like driving over the traffic lights in red: most people don't, some do it anyway. We must see that those who knowingly violate the rules of the game can also be sanctioned. That is why it is a step in the right direction. You can discuss whether it is sufficient, you can still refine it. But I really think that this is a wonderful report and I hope that it will be implemented quickly and, of course, evaluation, as always, if it is not enough.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President! I would also like to add that the right of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions owe out very important sanctions here, namely those that address the personal responsibility of the bankers themselves, the boards of the banks, who have taken the risks that they should not have taken. This is completely missing from the report. Otherwise, I think the report is good, but it is a building block for a banking union, for supervision of credit in the euro area, which is carried out by the European Central Bank. We reject this supervision for reasons of principle. It is not right to mix monetary policy and banking supervision. Indeed, the recent announcements by the European Central Bank show that economic policy is now also being dragged into the ECB's sphere of competence, because the ECB is trying to pursue economic policy and facilitate lending through ABS purchases. None of this is democratically controlled, and a Parliament should not allow things to slip out of its control.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The adoption of the Single Supervisory Mechanism requires amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2532/98. In particular, Article 18 of the Single Supervisory Mechanism gives the ECB new powers to impose economic administrative sanctions where banks infringe directly applicable EU law. From the outing point of view my group has criticised most elements of the banking union, including those relating to an increase in the ECB's power.  The ECB should not receive even more powers than it has. That's why I voted against it.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. - The Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) has become operational. This mechanism will give the European Central Bank new powers in connection with the supervision of banks in the euro area. The financial crisis has shown that stricter supervision of the financial market is essential. For market control to be effective, transparency is essential. Information must reach the market and be correctly interpreted by the actors. To this end, they must be used as a basis for decision-making. The ECB needs a clear and unequivocal power of attorney to impose sanctions. As concrete considerations, we in Parliament have made three recommendations. Firstly, administrative sanctions must be published in general and without delay. Secondly, there must be clarity on who is ultimately responsible for initiating a transgression procedure. Thirdly, the limitation periods should not begin from the date on which the infringement took place, but from the date on which it was decided to initiate an infringement procedure.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - This, like the previous report, focuses primarily upon issues which do not affect the UK directly. Nevertheless, the indirect effects could lead to British or British-owned banks facing sanctions. I therefore voted against giving greater powers to the European Central Bank.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which proposes amendments to the Council Regulation on the rights of the European Central Bank (ECB) to impose sanctions. The financial crisis has highlighted the need for better regulation and supervision of the EU financial sector. New rules have been adopted to ensure that all financial actors, products and markets are properly regulated and effectively supervised. Financial markets and all their users concerned need to be trusted that the supervisory authority will be able to take measures in the future if banks fail to comply with the rules. I agree that the ECB must have clear and unambiguous powers to impose sanctions if banks fail to comply with the rules.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. — Regulation 2532/98 of 23 November 1998 gave the ECB the power to impose sanctions on banks or similar institutions that evaded an obligation arising from a European text or an ECB decision (e.g. the establishment of legal reserves). These penalties were limited to 500K euros and 10K euros per day of obligation, which is not a deterrent given the banks' balance sheets. It was therefore clear that there was a need to move to stronger sanctions, depending on turnover and not capped in absolute terms. This is what the text does, which goes in the right direction, that of strengthening the obligations imposed on banks. However, once is not customary, this text is part of a supranational logic which puts the decisions of the Member States on the green light of the ECB and, therefore, risks seriously impeding our banking and monetary sovereignty. That's why I abstained.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. - I voted in favour because, as a result of the adoption of Council Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013 of 15 October 2013, the ECB has competence for prudential supervision of credit institutions. This requires the defining of periodic coercive budgets, general budgets and scope, sanctions where obligations are not met, the procedure for initiating infringement proceedings and the time limits for sanctions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to entrust the ECB with tasks relating to prudential supervision policies for credit institutions and, in particular, sanctions.  Thus, after the introduction of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), the large banks (approximately 130) of which 13 banks of this total still need to be stabilised should be monitored directly. The Financial Stability Board (FSB) has published its annual list of 30 private banks that would not withstand the next crisis. It thus requires capital from these banks equal to more than 20% of assets and stricter solvency standards than those in Basel III. In addition, national banks will also be subject to ECB supervision to initiate a sanction procedure, losing even more powers to Frankfurt.  I therefore abstained on this vote, considering the need for control of the major European banks.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against this measure because the text seeks to further reduce the scope of action of the Authorities of the Member States. Although national central banks have been guilty of serious supervisory omissions in the past, I am convinced that this ECB, whose top management defines the euro as an irreversible process, is not the entity that can reassure citizens and businesses.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - The crisis has forced the adoption of rules ensuring that financial agents, products and markets are adequately regulated and receive efficient supervision, with banking union as a colophon, for the long-term survival and prosperity of the euro.  Comprehensive supervision was necessary, hence the recent implementation of the Single Banking Supervision Mechanism in the euro area, however, with the ECB as final supervisor with the task of ensuring a coherent and consistent implementation of the single regulatory code and being able to decide to directly monitor any credit institution. Beyond transparency on the quality of banking assets, the ECB needed clear and unequivocal authority to impose sanctions. Now, with an explicit general delimitation of the responsibilities of the ECB and the national authorities, it must publish its administrative pecuniary sanction decisions and whether or not an appeal has been brought and the time limits for the enforcement of sanctions are reduced. Finally, I welcome the adoption of the Social Democratic Amendment which provides that the sanctions paid by financial institutions will go to the Single Resolution Fund in order to finance future crises in the sector.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which proposes amendments to the Council Regulation on the rights of the European Central Bank (ECB) to impose sanctions. The financial crisis has highlighted the need for better regulation and supervision of the EU financial sector. New rules have been adopted to ensure that all financial actors, products and markets are properly regulated and effectively supervised. These rules form a framework for all 28 EU Member States and form the basis for a well-functioning single market for financial services. There is broad agreement that the crisis has been accompanied by a lack of regulatory credibility, as implementation has proved to be seriously flawed. Traditionally, there is a great lack of confidence in market discipline in the financial field, but transparency is essential for the proper functioning of the market monitoring system. This means not only having the necessary information, but also ensuring that this information effectively reaches the market and, in addition, is properly interpreted by market participants and used in decision-making. The European Parliament notes that there is no qualitative impact assessment that is necessary and that some shortcomings could be effectively addressed through the impact assessment methodology. Parliament also proposes to improve some elements of the recommendation and to make the following major changes.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EC) 2532/98 on the European Central Bank's sanctions powers.  Indeed, the strengthening of prudential standards and sanctions against credit institutions that do not comply with them, is consistent with the implementation of this ECB mission. However, I condemn the supranational logic that governs the economics of the text. Thus, national authorities must obtain the approval of the ECB to initiate a sanction procedure.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: In writing. I voted against this text because I believe that the ECB cannot validly impose sanctions without increased political responsibility on the part of the Executive Board.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. - The ECB has been given the power to sanction credit institutions in the event of a breach of EU law or its own decisions. The EU resolution raises the amount of sanctions from a maximum of EUR 500,000 to twice the profit made or 10% annual business. In addition, national central banks lose the opportunity to initiate proceedings on their own initiative, which was possible when the offence had been committed in their jurisdiction. From now on, the national authorities will be given the green light by the ECB to initiate a sanction procedure, thereby demonstrating the supranational logic that drives the technocrats in Brussels and Frankfurt. Demonstrating my desire to strengthen the power of control over banks and to refuse the technocratic and supranational forward flight, I abstained on this vote.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. I voted against the measure. I do not trust the ECB, which is in the process of building the euro, which has brought profit to the banks and misery to the citizens. We need more responsible action.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The European Central Bank has recently begun its new role as supervisor of credit institutions. This function is crucial in order to regain the confidence of investors in the European market. His role as a supervisor is separate from his monetary policy prerogatives. As a result, the ECB needs a new mandate in order to be able to sanction the bodies under its supervision. When credit institutions do not meet the various criteria drawn up by the European legislator, the ECB must act. We have put in place mechanisms to prevent citizens from finding themselves in a crisis situation similar to that of 2008. In this supervisory role, the ECB is now in a position to ensure compliance with these mechanisms. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - The ECB's powers have been increased exponentially and this is in line with the need to unify supervision of European banks. These are key steps towards building Union banking. As a result, there is a need for better regulation of the financial sector in the EU and better supervision of it. I therefore voted in favour of the amendments to Regulation (EC) No 2532/98 on the power of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions because I believe, sharing the reasons proposed, that in order for the regulation to be fully effective, it must be accompanied by strict supervision and enforcement.  Supervision of the financial sector should be strengthened by improving coordination between national supervisory authorities and strengthening the powers of the ECB.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — This report shows that the financial crisis highlighted the need for better regulation and supervision of the financial sector in the European Union. Regulation that ensures compliance in all 28 Member States will help Europe avoid another financial crisis. I have voted in favour as I support clarification of processes and responsibilities of the European Central Bank.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — The entry into force of the Single Supervisory Mechanism gives new powers to the European Central Bank. In this institutional framework, it would be very dangerous not to give the ECB the power to impose sanctions as well. It was therefore automatic for me to vote in favour of this draft regulation, in the hope that this power will never be used for European financial institutions to start doing their lung work for the economy again soon and to behave always and only according to the laws in force.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — The regulation is necessary in order to give practical effect to Article 34(3) of the Statute of the European System of Central Banks (ESCB), which provides that, within the limits and under the conditions adopted by the Council, the ECB is entitled to impose fines or periodic penalty payments on undertakings for failure to comply with its regulations and decisions. The fines and periodic penalty payments imposed by the ECB are subject to the following limits: fines: the upper limit is EUR 500 000; periodic penalty payments: the upper limit is EUR 10 000 per day of infringement. Periodic penalty payments may be imposed in respect of a maximum period of six months following the notification of the decision to the undertaking. The decision on the appropriate sanction is based on the principle of proportionality. Under the regulation, the Executive Board of the ECB has the power to decide whether an infringement has occurred and whether sanctions should be imposed; however, the national central banks may initiate and also conduct part of the infringement procedure.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The entry into force of the Single Supervisory Mechanism obliges the ECB to amend Regulation No 2535/98 on the ECB's power to impose sanctions. I agree with rapporteur Swinburne, especially on two aspects: first, the increase in transparency so called for by the EP by defining the obligation to publish sanctions enforcement decisions, but authorising the ECB to postpone such publication when this is disproportionate to the company or could destabilise financial markets; secondly, the amendment of the procedure for counting limitation periods in order to combat impunity (from the date on which the decision was taken to initiate the proceedings and not from the date of the infringement, which is often only discovered late).

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The financial crisis has made it clear that there is a need for better regulation of the financial sector in the EU and better supervision of it. In addition, the subsequent crisis in the euro area highlighted a new dimension by highlighting the potentially vicious circle of contagion risk between banks and states. The amendment of Regulation (EC) No 2532/98 should be a further step towards the application of a more coherent and more integrated regulatory framework, which is why I am voting in favour of its application. Indeed, I believe that regulation is fully effective, it must be accompanied by rigorous supervision and enforcement, on the one hand by improving coordination between national supervisory authorities and, on the other hand, by strengthening supervision at EU level to manage risks and issues with cross-border implications, under the ultimate leadership of the ECB.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – The financial crisis highlighted the need for better regulation and supervision of the financial sector in the EU. Supervision by the ECB is essential to safeguard financial stability in Europe. Thus the ECB needs clear and unequivocal authority to impose sanctions on banks of the euro area. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. I am voting against this resolution because it concerns a particular procedure for monetary policy and the European System of Central Banks.  Following the extension of the ECB's specific powers in the prudential supervision of credit institutions, a number of amendments have been proposed to the regulation allowing the ECB to impose sanctions. The ECB therefore submitted a recommendation to the Council to propose a number of amendments, in particular on the definition of late payment and on the new general principles and scopes. Within the Single Supervisory Mechanism, which became fully operational in November 2014, the ECB is therefore responsible for imposing sanctions on credit institutions that do not comply with certain rules.  I cannot support a report that gives even more powers to the ECB without prioritising the role of the ECB.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The adoption of the Single Supervisory Mechanism requires amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2532/98. In particular, Article 18 of the Single Supervisory Mechanism gives the ECB new powers to impose economic administrative sanctions where banks infringe directly applicable EU law. From the outing point of view my group has criticised most elements of the banking union, including those relating to an increase in the ECB's power.  The ECB should not receive even more powers than it has. That's why I voted against it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I think it would be a step in the right direction if the ECB, as a general rule, published without undue delay its decisions on imposing sanctions and whether such decisions had been appealed or not. It further addresses deficient supervision related to competence between the ECB and national authorities on infringement initiatives.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The Regulation on the Sanctions Powers of the European Central Bank (ECB) was adopted in 1998 and needs to be amended. In the wake of the banking and financial crisis, the European Union has carried out a series of ambitious reforms. In this context, we have been asked to entrust the ECB with new tasks, notably in the context of prudential supervision. It is to reflect these changes that a rule change is proposed. Because it will build a more coherent and integrated regulatory environment, I support the adoption of this text.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — The ECB's sanction procedure defined in the report removes the power of national central banks to initiate sanction proceedings against a bank. While the strengthening of sanctions is necessary and is partly proposed by the report, the reduction of the sovereignty of national institutions is not acceptable. In view of these major imperfections, I abstained in this vote.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted against it, as the report is part of the new banking union which they want to establish by giving more power, if possible, to the ECB. For the ECB to oversee and, at the same time, to dictate the monetary policy of the countries of the European Union creates a conflict of interest that we must keep in mind when analysing what the establishment of a European banking union will entail. Because at a certain point monetary policy decisions (such as interest rate variation) may conflict with the objective of financial stability. Thus, if monitoring detects a stability problem, the solution may require a change in interest rates in the opposite direction.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - The proposed amendments promote a more specific mode of operation and a wider range of ECB competences over the respective national authorities of the Member States. We are voting against this plan because the extension of the ECB's role and competences in the EU Member States limits the national and economic sovereignty of the respective states. The ECB should assist the Member States and not circumvent them.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. — I have abstained on the vote regarding the overall modification of Regulation (EC) 2532/98, concerning the powers of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions. Although I consider positive many of the changes introduced, I disagree, alongside my political family, with the amendment that allows delaying publication of sanctions by the ECB until all legal recourses are exhausted. This notwithstanding, I am very satisfied that an amendment tabled by myself, proposing the transfer of sanctions proceeds related to the supervisory function of the ECB from this Institution to the Single Resolution Fund (SRF), has passed with broad support political support, including the S&D, ALDE, GUE and the Greens. I hope the Council will take on board this proposal, which will mobilise these proceeds for a concrete and productive purpose, increase the credibility and resources of the SRF, and create a truly European funding source for it. It is a step forward for the banking union, and a more complete economic union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This Regulation is another step towards the implementation of the Banking Union, in particular the Single Banking Supervision Mechanism (SSM). This SSM gives the ECB new supervisory powers over euro area banks, such as authorisation of all banks in the EU, implementation of the single set of rules in the euro area, direct supervision of large banks (130) and monitoring of supervision by national supervisory authorities of less significant banks. With this Regulation, the ECB may at any time decide to carry out the direct supervision of one or more of the credit institutions, and national competent authorities may impose sanctions on credit institutions directly supervised by the ECB only when it requests them to file a case to that effect. In addition to the usurpation of supervisory powers of national institutions, since with this Regulation the ECB assumes supervisory functions that until now have been performed by national institutions, such as Banco de Portugal, this Regulation gives the ECB a capacity to impose administrative sanctions that is significant and States will lose control, regulation and intervention over banking , thus seeing even more limited the possibility of this strategic sector being put at the service of economic development. We voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. - The financial and economic crisis, which has hit the European Union and its people hard, has highlighted the lack of regulation and supervision in the financial sector. These new powers of the European Central Bank are the result of an extension of its role under the Single Supervisory Mechanism. The main changes concern, in particular, the definition of penalties, general principles of scope, penalties in the event of non-compliance and procedural rules relating to the opening of infringement proceedings. A condition for maintaining the euro as the single currency for the countries of monetary union is a more precisely managed and integrated Economic and Monetary Union.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) Since the proposed amendments serve to bring the current Rules of Procedure into line with the new supervisory tasks conferred on the ECB in the meantime, and in view of current European economic policy, I shall vote against the report.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. - I am voting against the report on the draft Council Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be extended to 2532/98 on the powers of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions, since the extension of the ecb's role and competences in the EU Member States limits the national and economic sovereignty of the respective States. The ECB should assist the Member States and not circumvent them.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. — This regulation of the power of the ECB to impose sanctions is a step forward in the banking union process, a process that is one of our means to end the current economic crisis that is threatening the well-being of EU citizens and to prevent another crisis in the years to come.  I welcome the positive aspects that our Committee has introduced and especially the higher level of transparency in infringement procedures. I also strongly support the amendment presented by my colleague Jonás Fernández that would transfer ECB supervisory function sanction revenue from this Institution to the Single Resolution Fund (SRF). This amendment avoids conflicts of interest in the ECB and increases SRF credibility and resources that will permit faster recovery of the banking system. While I consider many of the changes introduced to be positive, I have abstained on the modification of (EC) Regulation 2532/98 for the following reason: I, along with my political associates, disagree with the EPP Party’s amendment that would delay publication of the decision ‘until all legal means have been exhausted’. This would eliminate the timeframe for collection of sanctions and consequently contradicts the principle of transparency that is one of the main pillars of the S&D political view.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. - Monetary policy has operated in a situation of ever-observed but somewhat moderating financial fragmentation and difficult challenges! We have had a number of discussions with Mr Draghi in the ECON commission, where we have been allowed to hear the good results. Despite these results, I believe that further efforts will need to be made to ensure that there is no harmful interaction at Member State level between states with problems, different economic prospects and the vulnerability of banks. Of course, further progress in establishing a Banking Union can make a major contribution to removing these obstacles and, if necessary, it can obviously be sanctioned in accordance with Mrs Swinburne's recommendations. I welcome the report and voted positively in favour of this report.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report on the powers of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions. After surviving the financial crisis, I see an urgent need for better supervision and regulation of financial sector. Giving the power to impose sanctions is one of the ways to ensure that the European rules are respected and followed. As Member States are closely related and spill-over effect is mostly unavoidable, we cannot act with an individual mind any more. We have to feel responsibility for each other.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. - If banks do not meet their obligations or report to supervisors, they must be dealt with harshly by the competent national authorities.  The Party for Animals is opposed to the transfer of powers to the European Central Bank or the Banking Union. These are not democratic institutions; this would further restrict public and democratic control of banks. The European Central Bank has a reputation for vagueness and lack of transparency, and the ECB's double mandate is a dangerous mix of monetary policy and banking supervision.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for the draft EP Resolution on the draft Council Regulation amending the Regulation on the powers of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions on the basis that it is clear that the credibility and strength of the Single Supervisory Mechanism must be based on the possibility of concrete sanctions imposed by the ECB. It was the global financial crisis that showed the need for better oversight for both better regulation of the European financial sector and a more integrated Economic and Monetary Union.  Therefore, I believe it is necessary to ensure that the implementation of the ECB's powers is in line with such an objective in order to strengthen the implementation and supervision of the financial sector in the EU.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. - Taking advantage of this debate today, I think it is important to introduce political and also democratic reflection on the nature of the ECB and its missions in euro area monetary policy. For example, who sets and how do inflation targets? I believe that it should be the European Parliament together with the Council and the Commission that determine the recommended inflation. Similarly, I believe that the ECB should consult the Council and the Commission on the instruments to be used to raise current inflation because we are at risk of deflation and economic atoning for several dangerous years. It is clear - and I would like to acknowledge this - that Mr Draghi is trying to stimulate domestic demand and facilitate credit, but enormous resistance remains in the ECB's internal rules and legitimate internal differences between national central banks in relation to these policies. Isn't it time to talk about a new Central Bank Statute?

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. —I voted in favour of my colleague Kay Swinburne's report on the draft regulation on the European Central Bank's sanctions powers. This text aims to update the powers of the European Central Bank, whose scope has been extended to strengthen supervision of credit institutions.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I supported the report on the draft regulation amending Regulation 2532/98 on the European Central Bank's sanctions powers, with the aim of establishing a coherent regime for all administrative sanctions imposed by the European Central Bank in connection with the fulfilment of its prudential supervision missions. The European Central Bank mainly recommends a redefinition of certain general principles applicable to administrative sanctions as well as a revision of the sanctions regime. I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. - It is of paramount importance for the ECB to impose sanctions on banks not complying with the regulations. However, the sanctions should distinguish between systemic and minor banks. Furthermore this distinction implies that, if the sanctions imposed on too-big-to-fail banks are not significant proportionally to their size, the proclaimed sanctions will not deter them from complying with the regulation. This window of opportunity for banks inclined to violate the regulations should close.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. - The Commission's draft provides that the ECB may impose sanctions in the event of breaches of EU law and non-compliance with ECB regulations. Excluded are cases where a sanction would destabilise financial markets. In this case, publication could be delayed by three years. The draft also provides for a better delimitation of competences between the ECB and the national institutions. Better regulation and supervision of the European financial sector, with clear rules for all actors, products and markets, should be sought. I therefore welcome the approach of a single, coherently applied set of rules for the financial sector, which provides for enhanced surveillance measures at European level and whose completion leads to better coordination of the national supervisory bodies. I reject the Commission's proposal before us.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Key Swinburne because I believe that strengthening the ECB's competences in financial supervision will help to ensure greater protection for citizens. With the crisis in the eurozone, the risk of contagion between banks and states has emerged, and therefore better governance and better integration of economic and monetary union will guarantee the survival of the single currency.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - I am satisfied with the outcome of this report and with the adoption of the amendment which states that 'the revenue from ECB sanctions in the exercise of its supervisory functions, including the collection of statistical information, will belong to the single resolution fund, which will be nourished by the contributions of the banks themselves'. It should be financial institutions that finance their potential crises, not European citizens.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The adoption of the Single Supervisory Mechanism requires amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2532/98. In particular, Article 18 of the Single Supervisory Mechanism gives the ECB new powers to impose economic administrative sanctions where banks infringe directly applicable EU law. From the outing point of view my group has criticised most elements of the banking union, including those relating to an increase in the ECB's power.  The ECB should not receive even more powers than it has. That's why I voted against it.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. - I voted against this statement because I do not believe that the ECB should be able to impose sanctions on commercial banks. The ECB's role is monetary policy, not banking supervision. Banking supervision has been entrusted to the ECB within the framework of the Banking Union, but this was a mistaken decision, because there appear to be conflicts of interest between the ECB's monetary policy and prudential mandates. The measures recommended in the report are perfectly useful in providing a supervisory authority with instruments to enforce its mandate, and the rules and deadlines presented in the report provide legal certainty. In this respect, the report must be affirmed on the premise that banking supervision is properly located at the ECB. In my opinion, however, this is not the case, and that is why I rejected the report in plenary.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the Swinburne report because the European Central Bank has become a state in the European Union and has enormous supervisory powers, while at the same time, as a member of the troika and a creditor of the EU Member States, it acts in a way that creates a conflict of interest within it in the performance of its duties.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. "On this vote we have chosen to abstain because this text does not propose any major developments or significant progress. The decision to initiate a sanction procedure after violation or non-compliance with European texts or decisions remains, logically, that of the ECB. But the text also suggests increasing sanctions on Member States, an uncertain decision that could have serious consequences for the economies of Member States in this time of crisis.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Swinburne report in line with the PPE position. The Regulation on the power of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions must be amended in order to comply with the new role of the ECB following the extension of powers relating to the SSM (The Single Supervisory Mechanism). The text provides for changes to the scope of the regulation, procedural rules, publication of sanctions and limits on sanctions. The compromise adopted with the adoption of the text also allows for a delay in the publication of sanctions by the ECB until all legal remedies have been exhausted. In practice, the sanction against a 'non-virtuous bank' is only published when it is procedurally definitive, obviously in order to avoid negatively influencing the markets.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - (IT) With the crisis in the euro area, there was a risk of contagion between banks and states, and with it the knowledge that, only better governance, and greater integration of economic and monetary union, would guarantee the survival of the single currency. Strengthening the ECB's powers in financial supervision will help to provide greater protection for citizens. It is clear that, in this task, it cannot ignore the authority to impose sanctions. That is why I voted in favour of the report signed by Mr Swinburne, which recognises the role of supervisors vis-à-vis banks that do not comply with the established rules.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. — This report follows the creation and implementation of a single banking supervision mechanism in the euro area, the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM). The Regulation gives the ECB new supervisory powers over euro area banks, such as the authorisation of all banks in the EU, the application of the single set of rules in the euro area, direct supervision of all major banks, including banks with assets of more than €30 billion or representing at least 20% of their home country's GDP (around 130 banks), and , finally, monitoring the supervision exercised by national supervisory authorities of less significant banks. This also means that this regulation gives the ECB the capacity to impose administrative sanctions and thus strengthen its position as the most powerful and seemingly endless non-democratic entity. Member States thus become more weakened in the context of the regulation and intervention they had on banking. For these reasons I voted against.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I abstained on this report because I do not believe it went far enough in relation to transparency. There is a wide consensus that a lack of credibility of regulation contributed to the crisis, since implementation appeared to be severely deficient. Traditionally in financial matters a lot of faith is placed in ʽmarket disciplineʼ, but to have the system of market monitoring functioning well, transparency is very important as well. This means that not only the necessary information must be available but also that this information is effectively reaching the market, and, moreover, is adequately interpreted by the market participants and also used in their decisions.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — The competences of the ever-growing European financial market need to be improved in order for full control to take place. The Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) has strengthened the powers of the European Central Bank. However, I find it very drastic that a national managing authority should not have the right to impose sanctions on a bank that is under the direct supervision of the ECB. In addition, the ECB may provide banks with invoices for its supervisory activities. In my opinion, this approach must be criticised in the strongest possible terms, as the ECB can enrich itself by imposing its supervision on banks. I do not agree with this approach, which is why I abstained.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. - This report is part of the Banking Union and the Single Security Mechanism which came into force on 4 November 2013. The report aims to clarify and strengthen the ECB's powers. The aim is to give it the means of administrative and financial sanctions against financial market players and banks. Thus, sanctions that could previously be delayed indefinitely will be effective after a maximum of 3 years. Prescription deadlines are changed.  Penalty revenue is available to the ECB. This strengthens the INDEPENDENCE of the ECB and its powers from national banks. They will no longer be able to sanction the banks which the ECB will supervise. The supervisory criteria in which these sanctions will be taken remain focused on the development of financial competition, far from any objective of de-enunciration of the economy. Against the independence of the ECB whose objectives are contrary to the interests of the European peoples, I vote against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — The financial crisis has revealed the need for better regulation and supervision of the EU financial sector. New standards have been adopted to ensure that all financial actors, products and markets are properly regulated and supervised effectively. These standards create an elementary framework for all 28 EU Member States and provide a basis for the smooth functioning of the single market for financial services. For regulation to be fully effective, it must be accompanied by strict supervision and enforcement. The aim is therefore to improve the supervision of the financial sector at EU level, on the one hand, by improving coordination between national supervisors and, on the other hand, strengthening EU-wide supervision, under the ecb's maximum guidance, in order to deal with risks and issues with cross-border repercussions. The two levels of supervision are complementary and fundamental to preserving financial stability in Europe. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – This report follows the recent financial crisis and notes, among other things, the need for clarity on who is responsible for infringement initiatives and for timeframes concerning administrative penalties. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this report, as I support this clarification of general processes and responsibilities of the European Central Bank.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I firmly believe that we need to strengthen our efforts to ensure that the market monitoring system works. This includes increasing the transparency of the financial sector. That is why we believe it is necessary for the ECB to immediately publish its sanctions decisions, unless it undermines the stability of the system. We also wish to establish closer cooperation through the establishment of a series of closed-door meetings with the Chairman and Vice-Presidents of the committee concerned. Finally, in order to avoid any overlap between the ECB and the national banks, we wanted to define their respective responsibilities further.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – I abstained at the final vote on the report on reviewing powers of the ECB to impose sanctions, because the final text includes a broader derogation to the principle of transparency.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. - Regulation 2532/98 of 23 November 1998 gave the ECB the power to impose sanctions against banks or similar institutions that evaded an obligation arising from a European text or an ECB decision (e.g. the establishment of legal reserves).  These penalties were limited to 500K euros and 10K euros per day of obligation, which is not a deterrent given the banks' balance sheets. It was therefore clear that there was a need to move to stronger sanctions, depending on turnover and not capped in absolute terms.  This is what the text does, which goes in the right direction, that of strengthening the obligations imposed on banks. It is noted, however, that the proceeds of the fines remain allocated to the ECB's budget, which makes it directly interested in its sanctions policy and is not in line with the principle of universality. Second, national authorities lose the opportunity to initiate sanction proceedings on their own initiative.  This is only a consequence of the evolution of economic and monetary union, but this is a new loss of sovereignty that must be denounced.  In the end, abstention is justified by this neutralization of the text's progress.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. The European Central Bank (ECB) has been granted enhanced sanctioning power against credit institutions in cases of breaches of EU law or its own decisions. The amount of these sanctions is therefore revised very sharply upwards, from a maximum of 500k euros to twice the profit made or 10% of annual turnover. Moreover, it is now impossible for national central banks to initiate proceedings on their own initiative, even if the infringement has been committed in their own jurisdiction. We will now have to wait obediently for the ECB's green light for any sanction procedure. The supranational desires of the technocrats in Brussels and Frankfurt are clearly stated here. However, the necessary strengthening of the supervisory power over the entire banking system cannot be disputed.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this report. The global financial crisis has shown the limits of financial regulation in Europe. Among the measures that have been decided to strengthen our legislation, prudential supervision of credit institutions was passed in 2013. Consistent with this extension of jurisdiction, it is essential to strengthen the ECB's sanctioning power in this area if the new legislation is to be effective.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — Of course, it is very important that the ever-growing European financial market is better controlled and monitored. As early as 2013, the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) extended the powers of the European Central Bank to this end. In this report, the ECB considers it necessary to increase the possibility of sanctions against banks in order to maintain its credibility. This is a clear allocation of powers to the ECB in the area of sanctions. This may seem reasonable, but there is a risk that the expansion of the ECB's powers will deter investors and move credit institutions out of the euro area. For these reasons, I abstained on this report.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This report gives the European Central Bank broader powers to impose sanctions on banks that do not comply with EU law, and to be able to publish sanctions. Although the report might have had some merit, the text severely limits transparency with respect to sanctions against banks as soon as there is a legal remedy, making this text of little use. So I abstained.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - I supported the draft draft amending the Regulation on the powers of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions. The financial crisis clearly signalled that the EU's financial sector needs tighter supervision. By increasing the new modernised rules, more integrated solutions and cooperation, the financial markets of the 28 Member States will be ensured for sustainable operation.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. The economic crisis has made clear the need for better economic and monetary governance, which safeguards the economic and financial stability of the Union through an integrated supervisory system. The lack of credibility of regulation has been one of the main triggers of the economic crisis. I believe that uniform rules and better coordination can strengthen supervision of the financial sector, and I would therefore vote in favour of them.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. - I voted for resolution on the powers of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions. The original regulation, adopted in November 1998, needs to be amended to take into account that the scope of the ECB’s powers has been extended concerning the prudential supervision of credit institutions (Single Supervisory Mechanism). The ECB recommendation includes amendments to the scope of the regulation, procedural rules, and publication of sanctions and limits of sanctions, among others.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. "The supranational logic that prevails in this report prevents me from supporting it. Sanctioning banks that circumvent or break the law is obviously a good thing, but it is not for the European Central Bank to do so. So I abstain.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — The economic or financial crisis underlined the evident need for better regulation and supervision of the financial sector in the European Union. The European Central Bank's sanctions recommendation is important because it is an integral part of the implementation of the Banking Union.  Regulations authorize the European Central Bank to impose control over credit institutions. These are administrative fines in the event that those institutions violate the conditions directly applicable by Union law, sanctions in case of breaches of regulations or decisions of the ECB. It is important to highlight the publication of administrative penalties where the proposal is that the ECB undertakes to publish in a timely timely way the fines taken for direct breaches of Union law and sanctions for breaches of regulations and decisions of the ECB.  I am of the opinion that transparency and uniform rules with better coordination can strengthen the supervision of the financial sector of the European Union. I therefore support Kay Swinburne's Report on the European Central Bank's sanctions-imposing powers.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - The euro area crisis has demonstrated the need to regulate the EU's financial markets much more consistently, which logically relates not only to strengthening the ECB's powers, but also to improving the coordination of its actions with euro area Member States. An integral part of the ECB's supervision of the entire financial system must also be its ability to enforce compliance with the rules and, if necessary, to impose sanctions. I fully agree that the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) instrument should play a crucial role in the process of restoring confidence in financial markets in the EU.  But trust in financial markets can only exist on the condition of maximum transparency on all sides. I consider the European Parliament's support for the rapporteur's amendment on the possible postponement of the publication of ECB sanctions and their discussions behind closed doors as an unfortunate decision which is in direct contradiction with the principle of transparency and, by extension, with the achievement of the primary objective of restoring confidence in the regulation of financial markets.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — Following the financial crisis of recent years, it is important that a decision has been taken to regulate the financial sector in the EU more fully and that there has been a need for a more in-depth and integrated approach.  That is why I think it is right that new rules have been adopted to ensure that markets and products are monitored more closely with the single functioning of the financial market and better supervision at UNION level, through coordination between national supervisory authorities and, at the same time, by increasing EU supervision under the last side of the ECB.  I agree with the provisions of the regulation which extend the scope of the European Central Bank and, consequently, the power given to the ECB to impose sanctions provided that there is an improvement in the transparency of its decision-making procedures. I also agree with the procedure on how decisions were taken to impose infringement sanctions. Of course, in order for financial markets and all users of the sector to have confidence in a supervisory body, the ECB must have the direct and unequivocal authority to impose sanctions against banks that do not comply with the rules.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — I cannot agree to this request because of the fundamental misconstruction of bringing the ECB on board with the banking supervision. How does the ECB intend to solve the dilemma of keeping bonds from banks in its own portfolio in the future, which it has to close? Will it be prepared to inflict losses on itself for the benefit of taxpayers? Since the ECB has already broken rules on several occasions and to a considerable extent, I also see my vote against as a protest against the permanent threat to the savings of German and other citizens.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — There is no need to say that the financial and sovereign debt crises have demonstrated the need for more thorough and centralised prudential supervision, the work of which is largely the responsibility of the European Central Bank.  To this end, it requires more leeway in the application of sanctions. In particular, it must act in such a way as not to cause panic in the financial markets. I am therefore in favour of such prerogatives.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 2532/98 on the power of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions, as it considers that, in view of the new prudential supervision tasks of banking institutions undertaken by the European Central Bank (ECB), these amendments are justified, which, in essence, aim to define the specific rules on the ceiling of penalties imposed by the ECB in the exercise of its supervisory tasks (new Article 4a), the specific procedural rules for the imposition of such sanctions, including the review procedure (new Article 4b) and the specific time limits applicable to administrative sanctions imposed by the ECB in the exercise of its supervisory tasks (new Article 4c). In fact, strengthening the credibility of the Single Supervisory Mechanism presupposes that the ECB has a clear and unambiguous authority to impose sanctions on banks that are in breach of the legislation.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — The crisis has forced the adoption of rules ensuring that financial agents, products and markets are adequately regulated and receive efficient supervision, with banking union as a colophon, for the long-term survival and prosperity of the euro.  Comprehensive supervision was necessary, hence the recent implementation of the Single Banking Supervision Mechanism in the euro area, however, with the ECB as final supervisor with the task of ensuring a coherent and consistent implementation of the single regulatory code and being able to decide to directly monitor any credit institution. Beyond transparency on the quality of banking assets, the ECB needed clear and unequivocal authority to impose sanctions. Now, with an explicit general outline of responsibilities between ECB and national authorities, it must publish its administrative pecuniary sanction decisions, whether or not an appeal has been brought and whether the time limits for the enforcement of sanctions are reduced. Finally, I welcome the adoption of the Social Democratic Amendment which provides that the sanctions paid by financial institutions will go to the Single Resolution Fund in order to finance future crises in the sector.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — Since 4 November this year, the single mechanism for banking supervision in the euro area (single supervisory mechanism- SSM) has been fully operational.  To this end, the amendment to Regulation (EC) No 2532/98 on the power of the European Central Bank (ECB) to impose sanctions prior to the establishment of the SSM is an important step in the effective implementation of a more coherent and effective regulatory framework.
