The SSM confers new supervisory powers on the ECB over euro area credit institutions, which include the authorisation of all banks in the EU and the consistent and consistent application of a single set of rules in the euro area, the direct supervision of significant credit institutions (around 130) and, finally, the monitoring of supervision by national supervisory authorities of less significant credit institutions. In addition to the obvious need for updating, the strengthening of the credibility of the SSM requires the ECB to enjoy a clear and unambiguous authority to impose sanctions, so this report proposes several amendments to that effect with which I agree, and i have voted in favour of it. I end by recalling that the SSM represents a fundamental step in achieving genuine economic and monetary union in Europe.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against it because the text tends to reduce the scope of action of the Member States' authorities and, although we are aware that in the past the national central banks have been guilty of serious omissions in terms of supervision, we are also unconsconsted that this ECB, whose summits define the euro as an irreversible process, is the entity that can reassure citizens and businesses.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. - I voted against it, as the report is part of the new banking union they want to establish, giving it more power if possible to the ECB. The ECB's monitoring and, at the same time, dictating the monetary policy of the countries of the European Union creates a conflict of interest that we must keep in mind when analysing what the establishment of a European banking union will entail. Because, at a certain point, monetary policy decisions (such as interest rate variation) may conflict with the objective of financial stability. Thus, if monitoring detects a stability problem, the solution may require a change in interest rates in the opposite direction.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. - I abstained on this vote because the publication of sanctions imposed by the ECB will be delayed ʽuntil all legal means of appeal have been exhaustedʼ.  Furthermore, reforms being introduced as part of the banking union need to pay more attention to the impact that the ongoing changes will have on banks’ operating costs and on banks’ propensity to lend. Necessary as they are from a certain perspective, current bank regulation proposals will inevitably raise operational costs. So will the measure by which the ECB will hold new powers to impose sanctions. The measures could make banks think twice before they lend to projects that they might consider problematic under the new circumstances. So costs to lenders could increase even as the latter will find it more difficult than before to raise project funds. This is hardly the time to raise lending costs or to promote more risk averseness in the banking system. A balance must be kept between the need for banking institutions to be run prudently and transparently, and that other need for banks to respond quickly and efficiently to project proposals. Is this balance being reached at European level? The question remains open.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The adoption of the Single Supervisory Mechanism requires amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2532/98. In particular, Article 18 of the Single Supervisory Mechanism gives the ECB new powers to impose economic administrative sanctions where banks infringe directly applicable EU law. From the outing point of view my group has criticised most elements of the banking union, including those relating to an increase in the ECB's power.  The ECB should not receive even more powers than it has. That's why I voted against it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of amending Regulation (EC) No 2532/98 concerning the powers of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions. The financial crisis highlighted the need for better regulation and supervision of the financial sector in the EU. New rules have been adopted to ensure that all financial actors, products and markets are appropriately regulated and efficiently supervised.  There is a wide consensus that a lack of credibility of regulation contributed to the euro area crisis since implementation appeared to be severely deficient. It has become clear that a better governed and more deeply integrated economic and monetary union is required.  For regulation to be fully efficient, it needs to be accompanied by thorough supervision and enforcement. I support the ECB Recommendation to upgrade the supervision of the financial sector at EU level: improving coordination between national supervisors on the one hand and enhancing EU-wide supervision to deal with risks and issues with cross-border effects on the other hand. Both supervision levels are complementary and essential to safeguard financial stability in Europe.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I supported the proposal for a report on the european central bank's sanctions powers.  The financial crisis underlined the need for better regulation and better supervision of the financial sector in the EU. The new rules will ensure that all participants, products and markets are adequately regulated and that their adoption is effectively monitored. These rules create the basis for all 28 EU Member States to function properly in the single market for financial services.  The eurozone crisis has fuelled a potentially vicious cycle of contagion and risk-taking. The European Central Bank aims to achieve better supervision of the financial system. For regulation to be fully effective, it must be accompanied by fundamental oversight and good implementation. This is why the aim is to improve financial sector oversight at EU level, to improve coordination of national supervisors to tackle the risks and problems of running the ECB.  Supervision is important for preserving financial stability in Europe. The changes that will follow will have a positive impact on all member states.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - The adoption of the new regulation 2532/98 allowed the ECB to impose sanctions and the financial crisis showed the need for better regulation and supervision of the financial sector in the EU. Therefore, I supported new rules that ensure better financial regulation. These rules allow all 28 Member States to support the functioning of the single market. This has raised new questions. It has become clear that deeper economic integration and monetary union are needed if a single currency is to be maintained. For regulation to be effective, it must be accompanied by supervision. This is why the aim is to set financial sector supervision at EU level. In November 2013, the SSM (Single Supervisory Mechanism) was introduced, which has been fully in use since November 2014. As a grudge, the rapporteur cites a lack of a quality impact assessment. He understands the urgency of supplementing regulation (EC) 2532/98 with regard to the installation of the SSM, but believes that some shortcomings could have been addressed by a high-quality impact assessment method.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. - I abstained in the vote because some parts of the proposal are beneficial, but I do not agree with others. In particular, provisions that streamline the work of the European Central Bank are beneficial. However, a number of other provisions increase the ECB's otters and even take it to the systemic level. In particular, there is a provision whereing the ECB may postpone the publication of a decision for up to three years even if 'the ECB considers that the immediate publication of the decision would jeopardise the stability of the financial markets'. Thanks to this provision, the ECB will be able to arbitrarily refuse to publish virtually any decision, sufficeing to declare that it "believes" that its publication will have a negative impact on the stability of financial markets.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Expanding the role and responsibilities of the ECB in the EU Member States limits the national and economic sovereignty of the respective States. The ECB should assist the Member States and not circumvent them.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. - It is widely accepted that the lack of credibility of the regulation has contributed to the current crisis, its implementation having apparently registered significant failures. It is customary for "market discipline" to be given great faith in financial matters. However, in order to ensure the proper functioning of the market surveillance system, transparency is just as important. This means that not only must the necessary information be made available, but it must also truly reach the markets and be well interpreted by the participants and used in their decision-making. Therefore, to establish the credibility of the MSU, transparency on the quality of banks' assets is not enough. The financial markets and all concerned participants must also be assured that in the future the supervisory authority will have the power to sanction banks that do not comply with the rules. This implies that the ECB has clear and unequivocal authority to impose sanctions.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I supported this legislative resolution on the powers of the European Central Bank (ECB) to impose sanctions, as I think it is particularly important to grant the ECB the power to impose sanctions, as well as to publish decisions imposing administrative fines. I also support efforts to strengthen international coordination between the ECB and supervisory authorities outside the Union with a view to agreeing on common principles and the implementation of sanctions.  In order to establish a practice valid for all Member States of the Union, it is important that national authorities remain competent to impose administrative penalties on credit institutions only where the ECB requires them to initiate such proceedings. I also consider a more appropriate proposed solution replacing the period of five years following the commission of the infringement with a period of three years after the initiation of the infringement procedure, since this prevents the statute of limitations in the event that the alleged infringement is known only later.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. "It will be in everyone's interest if banks in Europe are properly supervised and everyone knows and abide by the rules. Of course, it is always best when agreements are conducted in good faith, but sometimes they are abusive, so it is important that the European Central Bank has the power to penalise such institutions. I therefore hope that this instrument will be implemented quickly and properly. Another measure that could be targeted in the future is not sanctions against the authorities, but on the persons responsible for the decisions taken.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - The results of the recently published stress tests have shown that the overall assessment procedure for the balance sheets of the main European credit institutions has in fact favoured the systemic banks most exposed to derivative instruments. The controversial methodology used to identify shortfalls in banks' balance sheets has in fact undermined the ECB's credibility and adequacy in carrying out the supervisory function.  I therefore voted against this report, which gives the ECB the power to impose sanctions, which further strengthens the new supervisory powers assumed by the ECB on 1 November.  Granting the ECB new enforcement powers risks only threatening proper supervision of a banking sector over which democratic institutions and regulators have lost all control.  On the contrary, before consolidating a supervisory system that has proved inadequate, it is necessary to solve the problems at source by reviewing the entire architecture of the Banking Union. We cannot continue to give new powers to an institution that not only does not offer sufficient guarantees of transparency and independence, but which has clearly shown that it has no interest in protecting financial stability and the real economy, not by hitting the most speculative and damaging banking activities.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The adoption of the Single Supervisory Mechanism requires amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2532/98. In particular, Article 18 of the Single Supervisory Mechanism gives the ECB new powers to impose economic administrative sanctions where banks infringe directly applicable EU law. From the outing point of view my group has criticised most elements of the banking union, including those relating to an increase in the ECB's power.  The ECB should not receive even more powers than it has. That's why I voted against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This Regulation is another step towards the implementation of a regulatory framework for achieving the objective of the banking union, in particular for the Single Banking Supervision Mechanism. With this Regulation, the ECB completely exceeds its powers under its statutes and may at any time decide to carry out the direct supervision of one or more of the credit institutions, and national competent authorities may impose sanctions on credit institutions directly supervised by the ECB (130) only when the ECB requests them to initiate a case to that effect.  In addition to the usurpation of supervisory powers of national institutions, since with this Regulation the ECB assumes supervisory functions that until now were performed by national institutions, such as Banco de Portugal, this Regulation gives the ECB the capacity to impose administrative sanctions. States will lose the power of control, regulation and intervention over the banking they still held, thus further limited to the possibility of this strategic sector being put at the service of economic development.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — The possibility of the ECB being given the power to impose sanctions on banks may certainly be a further step under the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) to improve or expand the European financial market. Nevertheless, I see this extension of the ECB's powers as a threat in terms of national competences and a deterrent to investors. That is why I abstained.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. - I voted on the report on the competence of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions, because, on the way to the establishment of a real banking union at the level of the euro area, but also with the participation of some of the Member States that have not yet adopted the euro, the role of the ECB is very important. We need stricter supervision of the European financial system, and this role rests with the ECB. However, in order for regulations to prove their effectiveness, they must be accompanied by a supervisory and enforcement mechanism. We need more transparency, without which the effects of the financial crisis cannot be completely removed. Market confidence must be accompanied by the confidence of citizens and all those involved, and this is achieved through greater transparency of all new regulations and mechanisms that will ultimately constitute a true functioning banking union in Europe.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The Regulation amending Regulation No 2532/98 is another step towards implementation and a regulatory framework for achieving the objective of the banking union, in particular for the Single Banking Supervision Mechanism. This SSM gives the ECB new supervisory powers over euro area banks. With this Regulation, the ECB may at any time decide to carry out the direct supervision of one or more of the credit institutions, and the national competent authorities may impose sanctions on credit institutions directly supervised by the ECB at any time (130) when requested by the ecb to initiate proceedings to that end. In addition to the usurpation of supervisory powers of national institutions, since with this Regulation the ECB assumes supervisory functions which until now were performed by national institutions, such as Banco de Portugal, this Regulation gives the ECB a significant capacity to impose administrative sanctions and states will lose the - little or almost no - control, regulation and intervention power on the banking they still held, thus seeing even more limited the possibility of this strategic sector being placed at the service of economic development. We voted against it.

name: Neena GILL
text: Mr President, global warming is costing the world more than USD 1.2 trillion a year, not to mention the human cost of climate change, which is simply unbelievable. Climate change has increased extreme weather events everywhere, including numerous examples in my region in the West Midlands. These have resulted in floods which have caused significant damage to no less than 70% of businesses over the last few years. West Midlands is also facing an increased risk of water shortages and lower agricultural productivity. The list can go on of events caused by climate change. So while the precise consequences may differ from region to region and country to country, we are all affected. That is why I voted in favour of the motion for the resolution on the 2014 Climate Change Conference. It is crucial that the EU takes a leading role during the COP 20 in Lima. This will be crucial for paving the way towards an ambitious and legally-binding international agreement for climate action, to be agreed in Paris next year.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Mr. President, I am pleased to vote for this resolution on climate change, since it is the basis for a conversation in Lima in early December 2014. We actually laid the ground up a long time ago, it was in Kyoto, however we didn't hold up well and obviously we need universal global action.  I hope Lima will help, that there will be a turning point for the big summit that will happen next year in Paris. In any case, it is good that both the United States and China have become involved. Europe doesn't need to have a complex. We only produce 10%-11% of greenhouse gases, unlike these large ones that produce 50%.  However, we must be at the forefront of this fight and I therefore support this project. I especially support the project of reducing the temperature by 2 degrees, which we have to stand up to, but also large binding targets by 2050, reducing emissions by 50%.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the international conference on climate change to be held in Lima next week seems to be born under the best auspices. The recent signs of openness to an agreement and the willingness of the US and Chinese governments to play a more significant role in global efforts to tackle climate change give us hope. Indeed, the scale and seriousness of the threats posed by climate change can no longer postpone the need to take concrete measures at global level to limit warming and begin the transition to a low-carbon economy.  I therefore hope that the Lima Conference will really create the conditions for a legally binding international agreement in Paris in 2015. At the Conference, Parliament presented itself in a clear and ambitious position with which I agree, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Climate change is threatening the entire planet. Its consequences slow down economic growth, make it difficult to eradicate poverty and undermine food security. I supported the resolution because the urgency of the need to act in favour of tackling the global climate crisis is very acute. Every day, the media reports on the various natural disasters affecting humanity on all continents. Every year, at various international conferences, but also here at the EP, we adopt resolutions and calls, but over time we once again state that progress in this area is no or only minor. I therefore expect the new Commission to take a more proactive approach to tackling the global climate crisis and to make it clear that the issue of climate change is one of the most important strategic priorities. The European Union should be a leader in international conventions and a unifier of the positions of the various international institutions on taking concrete global action to combat climate change.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Madam President, we are often told that politicians should leave the field of climatology to the experts. Of course, that is true, but it works both ways around. I am not the right person to ask about meteorology or ocean currents or the Medieval Warm Period or sunspots – absolutely, leave that to the experts. But I am an elected legislator, and it seems to me that the question of how we respond proportionately and how we maximise our resources in dealing with the issue is the proper business of those of us who are answerable to constituents rather than of specialists in the field of climatology. Let us accept what seems to be the consensus, which is that the world is warming partly as a result of human activity. How we then deal with that is a political, rather than a scientific, question. The particular issue is how much we spend on seeking very slightly to mitigate the rise in temperatures with huge sums of money, versus adapting with a fractional sum of money. I look around the world and I see that in Helsinki the mean temperature is about 5 degrees, in Athens it is about 21 degrees, in Rio about 35 degrees. All support large human populations. I think we might just be able to adapt.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the progress on climate at the G20 summit in Brisbane and the new Sino-American commitments to reduce polluting emissions make it possible to approach the climate conference scheduled for December in Lima with optimism. Negotiations at the next Conference must put the planet on track to reach an ambitious global agreement in Paris in 2015 and keep global warming within 2 degrees. Moving to a low-carbon economy will create jobs and develop the technologies and products that are needed.  With regard to the role of the European Union, I believe that the targets on renewables and energy efficiency for 2030 should be a starting point. The real target must be a real blue economy. We need more ambitious targets, we can accelerate the process of decarbonisation of the economy by implementing a series of measures at global level, including the establishment of a programme for the progressive replacement of fuels and high-carbon technology, the introduction of a global carbon tax, the overcoming of tariff barriers to the spread of low-emission technologies, the protection of intellectual property for producers of low-emission technologies , the introduction of financial measures and technological cooperation to support emerging economies in order to build the infrastructure necessary to modify the energy system. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm a rá gur thug mé tacaíocht do mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir anseo, agus dar ndóigh tá an-jab déanta ag Karl-Heinz Florenz mar a dhéanann sé i gcónaí. Freisin, tá moladh ag dul duit féin as ucht an tslí a rinne tú do jab inniu – go héifeachtach agus go neamhspleách.  Maidir leis an ábhar seo, bhí mé ag an díospóireacht anseo níos luaithe agus tá níos mó dóchais faoin ábhar seo anois ná mar a bhí le cúig bliana anuas, nó níos mó b’fhéidir. Is dócha go n-éireoidh níos fearr linn i Líoma agus i bPáras amach anseo ná mar a d’éirigh linn i Kyoto blianta ó shin.  Ag an gcruinniú mullaigh cúpla mí ó sin, bhí áthas orm gur tugadh aird faoi leith ar chúrsaí talmhaíochta agus an áit speisialta atá ag an tionscal sin san ábhar seo, ach freisin chun bia a sholáthar don domhan. Is maith go bhfuil an tuiscint seo ann anois.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam President, I supported this resolution because climate change is a reality and we need urgent agreement, and the Lima conference is an opportunity to bring positions closer together, to mitigate differences and to agree on a good framework, to devise a way and paths to achieve a common goal.  In recent years in Europe we have witnessed a change of climate, from extreme droughts to extreme floods, which has not bypassed my homeland Croatia, but also our neighbourhood. If this continues, food production will die, and people will lose their homes. Man has questioned his survival through his actions.  Therefore, the use of renewable energy sources and energy efficiency are elements of the overall European policy and an opportunity to develop green technologies that will create new jobs, protect the social security of employees and protect the environment. As a European, I am proud to live in a society that takes the danger of climate change seriously by civilization and fulfils its obligations.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. - Parliament is finally voting on a resolution with a different nuance: the hope that Lima will really be the antechamber of a binding agreement that will allow us to stop the climate emergencies in Paris. That is why we cannot accept Amendment No 9, tabled by the EPP, which aims to undermine two of the central pillars of the resolution by eliminating the demand for binding targets also for energy efficiency and for the promotion of renewable energy. On the other hand, we also reject the amendments tabled by the EGUE which seek to call into question the effectiveness of the emissions trading scheme as an instrument to combat climate change at global and European level. The Spanish Socialists believe that the STD needs to correct its shortcomings, but it remains an excellent tool for achieving common greenhouse gas reduction targets.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Lima climate summit. When we talk about climate negotiations, we move with hope, but we always end up with discouragement. We must understand that this climate crisis we are living in is a global crisis and must be our priority. And it is the capitalist logic that relocates production where there is less regulation that has led us to this spiral of crisis. We should therefore not only worry about CO2 emissions, but about ending the logic of market capitalism. To combat climate change, we should refuse to participate in this destructive race. This Lima Conference should take a major step forward and adopt a binding global agreement.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. - The United Nations Climate Change Conference in Lima at the beginning of December 2014 will prepare key targets for the 2015 World Climate Conference in Paris. A global and binding agreement on climate action should be concluded in Paris next year. The primary objective in this context is to limit global warming to less than two degrees. Clear targets for reducing greenhouse gases by 2050 should, among other things, help the economy – especially energy-heavy companies – to adjust to the limit values in the long term. In this resolution, Parliament also reminds Member States of their commitment to provide USD 100 billion a year for the Global Climate Change Fund by 2020. This resolution is to be welcomed, as we need clear, comprehensible and reliable global targets in order to act effectively in the interests of climate protection. The EU has a role to play in the world.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. - I cannot support the wording of this resolution, despite believing that we should protect the environment of the world in which we live.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution on climate change, which notes that, in order to achieve a global rise in temperatures below 20 C, it is essential to use the conference in Lima to draw up the main elements of the international agreement that can be reached in December 2015. in Paris. It is important that the EU and its Member States do not forget the commitment to increase contributions to the UN Green Climate Fund in order to allocate EUR 100 billion annually by 2020. US dollars of support. The agreement must provide for clear measures to mitigate, adapt and implement climate change mitigation, which will allow carbon dioxide emissions to halve by 2050 compared to 1990 levels. The agreement on financing, technology transfer and capacity building will be an essential element of support for developing countries. It is also important that the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) take action to achieve sufficient results in the fight against the effects of climate change.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. — I voted against this text, which once again reveals the inconsistency of European policy: it imposes very strict environmental standards on our companies and at the same time refuses to protect them from competitors who are not subject to the same regulations.  More fundamentally, instead of encouraging an increased flow of goods and people, which generates ever more greenhouse gas emissions, the European Union should consider the need to relocate the economy.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the preparation of the Lima (UN) climate change conference, which raises the natural issue of sustainable development and the necessary protection of the natural environment, does not provide credible solutions to the environmental problem.  The text and amendments presented in this proposal, based on the work of the IPCC (whose independence can be questioned), reveal flaws in the substance. Environmental objectives, especially in terms of timing, are very vague, the financing of climate policies is poorly defined (Green Fund), and some parties are not part of environmental policy but rather external demands as in point 45 on "approaches respecting people's equality".  It is quite clear that the mere requirement of numerical results will not solve the future ecological requirements because it becomes necessary to challenge the entire global economic system based on productivity and the search for profitability at all costs, even if it neglects the causes for the planet.  In light of these elements, I have spoken out against this report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. " Parliament finally votes on a resolution with a different nuance: the hope that Lima will really be the antechamber of a binding agreement that will allow us to put a stop in Paris to climate emergencies. That is why we cannot accept Amendment No 9, tabled by the EPP, which aims to undermine two of the central pillars of the resolution by eliminating the demand for binding targets also for energy efficiency and for the promotion of renewable energy. On the other hand, we also reject the amendments tabled by the EGUE which seek to call into question the effectiveness of the emissions trading scheme as an instrument to combat climate change at global and European level. The Spanish Socialists believe that the STD needs to correct its shortcomings, but it remains an excellent tool for achieving common greenhouse gas reduction targets.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because climate change is inevitable and can be an irreversible threat to human health and survival, biodiversity and the planet, and it is therefore a matter for all countries – at national, European and international level. If we are to achieve the European Union's objectives in the areas of environmental, development, humanitarian aid and disaster risk reduction, economic, foreign, security and human rights policies, concrete and tangible results are needed to address climate change. The European Parliament expects the EU and the Member States to play a constructive role at the lima meeting in 2015. A global binding climate agreement could be successfully agreed in Paris. We should bear in mind that the governments of the world have a shared responsibility, including with regard to future generations, in order to take appropriate action in the area of climate policy. The European Union should therefore substantially strengthen the EU's climate policy and urgently reach an agreement on binding ambitious targets for emission reductions, energy efficiency and the use of renewable energy sources by 2030, with the exception of biofuels that are harmful from a social and environmental point of view.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — (IT) I wholeheartedly support the motion for a resolution on COP 20 in Lima. Climate change and its dramatic consequences need ambitious strategies: at the Lima Conference, all the parties involved must agree on a draft negotiating text for the new agreement to be reached in Paris in 2015. The progress made by China and the United States in recent weeks is an important signal: after the failure to ratify the Kyoto Protocol, we now finally have the conditions for reaching a global agreement. Europe must continue to play its leading role and, in this respect, Parliament's resolution reiterates the need to set ambitious targets for 2030. Investing is the key word: infrastructure and innovation are key to reducing CO2 emissions and at the same time can increase the competitiveness of our economy. I consider it important to commit to increasing economic resources for climate mitigation and adaptation. I also hope that the funds from the Juncker plan will be directed towards sustainable economic growth.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because it is clear that the EU must have a very advanced and modern policy in terms of environmental protection. We must position ourselves so that European standards are the world standards (because they are the most advanced) and, in the same way, we must ensure that our own standards evolve towards even more environmental protection and energy efficiency.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. I voted against: this is the usual annual resolution on the unfccc's annual Conference of the Parties (COP), the usual unilateral climate policy that is suicidal for businesses and ineffective against pollution.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. - The text of the Resolution sets out the urgency of already resolving international climate commitments in order to keep temperature rise below 2oC from pre-industrial levels and increase the reduction commitment of up to 50% of emissions by 2050 compared to 1990 levels. The Resolution insists on making Lima the decisive pre-summit for binding global commitments in Paris 2015, including the final mobilization of climate finance to achieve the joint target of $100 billion per year by 2020.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The United Nations Framework Convention on Global Warming - COP 20 - takes place in Lima, Peru from December 1 to December 12, 2014. The European Union needs to speak with one voice at this convention. It is for this reason that the European Parliament has proposed a resolution to allow for a coherent discourse in front of the rest of the world. I voted in favour of this resolution.  However, I would like to remind you that it is important to remain pragmatic in our approach to climate change. Of course, we have to make a lot of environmental efforts, but it must not be at the expense of our economy. We are currently in a serious economic crisis. We cannot set environmental targets that are too restrictive for our companies and thus make them less competitive with the rest of the world. European environmental standards are already very high, we must now ensure that they are working properly. We need to strike the right balance between competitiveness and environmental standards in order to get out of the current economic crisis.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — I support this resolution as it supports green initiatives and aims at fighting global warming. This resolution emphasises that the countries that have already committed to an emission reduction should continue to make deeper emission cuts, and that others should also set emissions caps and reduce greenhouse gases’ intensity.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. — Climate change represents an urgent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, biodiversity and the planet, and therefore, must be addressed at international level. The negative impact of climate-change is already visible in natural and human systems on all continents and across the oceans. The EU negotiators attending the upcoming UN climate summit in Lima must do their utmost to ensure that significant progress is made towards achieving a new global climate agreement next year and avoid a 2°C  rise in global temperature. The EU must remain to the fore and broker the best possible deal. The Lima summit, and the summit in Paris next year will test EU diplomacy. A sort of ‘Paris alliance’ for a legally binding climate deal should be established in order to guarantee success. Sufficient funding must be granted for climate protection. USD 10 billion have been allocated so far but we must find a way to reach 100 billion.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) The climate is one of the great challenges facing humanity as a whole. When I approach these problems, I see how important it is that there should be greater coordination between states, and how useful the European Union is in these cases. Going to Lima to negotiate with greater bargaining power is crucial to delivering a cleaner planet to subsequent generations, while taking into account the costs of adaptation and the need for a step-by-step approach. I voted in favour of this resolution with these considerations in mind.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — We need to adapt to climate change. Adaptation strategies are needed at all levels of administration: at the local, regional, national, EU and also the international level. The ability to cope and adapt also differs across populations, economic sectors and regions within Europe. The Commission adopted an EU adaptation strategy in April 2013 which has been welcomed Ireland and other Member States. Complementing Irish initiatives that are already in force, the strategy supports action by promoting greater coordination and information-sharing between Member States, and by ensuring that adaptation considerations are addressed in all relevant EU policies.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - In recent decades, climate change has had an impact on the natural and human systems of all continents and pose an unprecedented threat to human societies, biodiversity and the planet. The whole world must therefore urgently prepare a response to the challenge posed by climate change. To this end, I consider it essential to conclude an agreement at the Paris climate conference in December 2015, which is inplace by an ambitious legally binding international agreement for post-2020 climate action. On the other hand, it is necessary to strengthen and extend urgently the measures in force to limit greenhouse gas emissions by 2020 and beyond. At the same time, the funding provided by developed countries for the reduction, adaptation, transfer and development of technology and capacity building in developing countries should be increased, in line with the establishment of a Green Climate Fund.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the United Nations Conference on Climate Change to be held in Lima from 1 to 12 December 2014. Environmental protection and respect for the Kyoto Protocol, and the agreements signed, must be the cornerstones of European development in the future, with the aim of matching industrial interests and respect for the environment. Unitary climate policy needs to be reinvigorated and agreement quickly reached on ambitious and binding emission reduction targets, energy efficiency and the use of renewable energy sources by 2030, as these targets would help boost international climate discussions, as well as being in line with the EU's commitment to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. The EU should commit to reducing global warming and helping to cut global carbon emissions from 40% to 70% by 2050 This requires efforts to be made in all regions of the world and the EU certainly cannot stand by and watch passively.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Climate change affects not only health but also every aspect of our lifestyle. The resolution identifies a number of actions that would help ensure a better approach towards addressing climate change. I voted in favour of this resolution which is a step towards keeping the EU in a leading position on climate change.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. According to the scientific evidence presented in the 2014 reports of the working groups for the IPCC's fifth evaluation report, the warming of the climate system is unequivocal. The widespread and massive impact of climate change is already clearly observable in natural and human systems on all continents and oceans. Continued greenhouse gas emissions will cause further warming and changes in soil, atmosphere and oceans in all regions of the globe. All countries, regardless of their wealth, will be affected by the impact of climate change. Global greenhouse gas emissions in the decade 2000 to 2010 were the highest in human history. Without decisive global mitigation action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the increase in the world's average temperature is likely to reach 5°C by the end of the century and, according to the IPCC conclusions, some risks due to climate change are significant. For the above reasons and in order to take concrete measures quickly to phase out, between now and 2020, all subsidies harmful to the environment, I could only vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Lima climate summit. When we talk about climate negotiations, we move with hope, but we always end up with discouragement. We must understand that this climate crisis we are living in is a global crisis and must be our priority. And it is the capitalist logic that relocates production where there is less regulation that has led us to this spiral of crisis. We should therefore not only worry about CO2 emissions, but about ending the logic of market capitalism. To combat climate change, we should refuse to participate in this destructive race. This Lima Conference should take a major step forward and adopt a binding global agreement.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we need to ensure that the COP 20 in Lima makes significant progress on setting out the main elements of the 2015 global climate agreement and increasing our global ambition until 2020 to make sure that we remain within the ʽbelow 2°Cʼ objective. We need immediate action to solve a problem which has a vast impact.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. As a major player in the fight against global warming, the European Union must transform its exemplarity into leadership. Under the Kyoto Protocol, the EU reduced its emissions by 19% between 1990 and 2012 while experiencing an increase in its gross domestic product of more than 45%, demonstrating that environmental improvement and economic development are not contradictory. It is with this conviction that I believe it is essential to support all that can create a positive dynamic on the way to the Paris conference.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. - The European Union must continue to play a very active role in the fight against the global climate crisis, and the new Commission must ensure that environmental protection and climate change action programmes can receive adequate funding.  In all its endeavours, the EU must take into account that climate change policies must be linked to measures taken following the Rio Conference and in the light of the Millennium Development Goals and the post-2015 agenda.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament reminds us of our ambitious climate change objectives with this resolution. The European Union must speak with one voice in Lima at the UN climate change conference to contribute to an international agreement at the Paris conference in 2015. It is necessary for stakeholders at the conference to agree on binding targets and financial means to keep temperature rise below 2oC.   In particular, I welcome the fact that the resolution recognises the certain exposure and vulnerability of the agricultural and forestry sectors to climate change. In particular, it calls on stakeholders at the conference to include in their national contributions a section on agricultural land, made up of appropriate common data to track, trace and measurablely verify the achievement of several objectives in terms of productivity, mitigation and resilience to climate change. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. The UN Climate Change Conference to be opened in Lima on 1 December will be a litmus test of the political's concrete will to reach an ambitious and fair global agreement on climate change. The commitments made by China, the United States and the European Union to reduce emissions bode well. One of the highlights discussed at the Conference will certainly be the issue of deforestation, which, according to 2013 data, reached 3.3 billion tonnes. Deforestation has a really important role to play in climate change, and that is why it must be combated on a global scale, through the involvement of institutions and civil society. For these reasons, I have decided to support this motion for a resolution.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. — The Union must be ambitious and persuasive at the COP20 conference in Lima. Concrete and rapid action is needed because, as it stands, our commitments are not likely to minimize the damage of climate change. The Union must play a leading role in the negotiations by speaking with one voice to influence the other countries of the world. The recent agreement between the United States and China is a step in the right direction, but remains insufficient.  The Lima conference is expected to set the necessary conditions for the conclusion of a binding global agreement in Paris in 2015 to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. We also need a commitment from industrialized countries to developing countries, which contribute the least to emissions but suffer the most from their effects, to help them fight and adapt to climate change.  Finally, at European level, we must commit a genuine 'Grenelle of the environment' to reconcile stimulating growth with reducing greenhouse gases. The EU budget must support green growth by promoting energy-efficient and efficient activities in the use of energy and raw materials.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it was important for Parliament to make its voice heard on climate change because the Lima conference is a springboard conference before the Paris conference in 2015. Nevertheless, we must not shoot ourselves in the foot by setting ourselves far too restrictive targets without our partners leaving the same, we must pay attention to the competitiveness of European companies.  The European Union must be at the heart of the negotiations, must have a strong message and must push as hard as possible for a reduction in CO2 emissions, but our representatives must not forget that this is a global problem that requires a global response and not just a European one: it is good to lead by example but we must ensure that we are followed.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — In line with my position in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I will not vote in favour of the motion for a resolution which turns out to be built on vague ideas and imprecise objectives, some policies being projected on deadlines too far away to be realistic.  In addition, the text paves the way for legally binding provisions for states and proposes releases of large financial masses without specifying the objectives and means of controlling this expenditure. It is therefore not acceptable to support such undertakings, which are otherwise based on ideologically marked work. Finally, this draft resolution presents aberrations that fall within communist planning where it is assumed that objectives achieved are synonymous with unambitious objectives. These policies are leaks forward that no longer have any contact with reality.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. - We believe that this motion for a resolution, although containing several positive elements, is moving in the wrong direction. In our view, this resolution promotes the interests of industries and businesses that will be strengthened to become 'green' with European taxpayers' money.  A policy is also being promoted, with regard to developing countries, which wants the EU to support economic states outside its territory to reduce their pollutants, emissions of harmful gases, etc., while the EU might not even have trade relations with countries that on the altar of "development" sacrifice the environment. In addition, we consider the EU's interest in reducing pollutants in third countries to be hypocritical at a time when in EU Member States, such as Greece, the environment is being destroyed by exhaust gas, smog, illegal and legal - inappropriate landfills and fires.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – I am voting in favour of parliament's motion for a resolution. We urgently need to act, because climate change is already causing serious problems for all countries. In Hungary, for example, excessive rainfall and flooding, as well as the dense alternation of precipitation shortages and droughts, have become common. With regard to the targets indicated in the motion, I would like to draw attention to the following: On the one hand, strict EU commitments are of no use if other economies that are much more polluting and have higher co2 emissions than the EU economy do not make commitments of this magnitude. The EU's negotiating delegation must therefore demand that it adopt stricter commitments and greenhouse gas emission reductions only if other economies responsible for Earth's greenhouse gas emissions, such as the United States or China, do the same. On the other hand, the role of renewable energy production and residential and industrial energy efficiency should be much more pronounced. The EU must refrain from taking any action to prevent the use of renewable energies. For example, we should not limit the planting of useful wood varieties that provide biomass feed material, the production of first-generation bioethanol produced from surplus yields, or support for combustion-efficient biomass boilers. Thirdly, we must refrain from introducing a system of accounting for agriculture. This would impose unnecessary burdens on farmers and Member States. Furthermore, CO2 emissions are difficult to measure here. Emission reductions in this area are already assured.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — Climate change poses an urgent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, biodiversity and the planet, thus requiring treatment by all parties at international level. They are also an unprecedented threat to both the biosphere and the production and supply of food and water, especially with regard to the poorest populations on most continents, as well as to health, well-being and economic development worldwide. Climate change has had an impact on natural and human systems on all continents and oceans and is affecting the planet's flora and fauna. However, the EU has been reducing its emissions and, as a result, has almost halved the average emissions intensity between 1990 and 2012 and reduced per capita emissions by 25%. According to the World Bank, the fight against climate change would add up to €1.9 billion annually and it is important that governments take concrete action against climate change without further delay and for a global agreement in Paris in 2015 to achieve this goal.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - We agree on more ambitious greenhouse gas emission reduction targets (in line with IPCC recommendations). We agree on the principle of co-responsibility and aid to developing countries to cope with the consequences of climate change. Industrialized countries are the main polluters, causing changes in the composition of the Earth's atmosphere. The least developed countries suffer the most consequences. But we again strongly disagree with the means set to achieve the goals that are again pointed out. Instead of a regulatory approach, we continue to insist on a market approach to climate change, the carbon market, the purchase and sale of the right to pollute. The carbon market has not only not contributed to a reduction in emissions, but is now objectively a disincentive to the adoption of low-carbon technologies. For one simple reason: it is cheaper to buy permits to pollute. We have long advocated the need for sectoral policy coherence – trade, agriculture, energy and others – with emission reduction objectives. The incoherence today is manifest. That is why we have tabled amendments to the resolution to purge it of its negative aspects and to point out others that are missing. Unfortunately they were sinking, so we could not vote in favour.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. - (4) The EU has an important role to play as a driving force in the UN climate negotiations. Europe accounts for only 10% of global emissions, in order to tackle the climate issue, we must get the rest of the world to take its share of responsibility. We have demanded that the EU have an ambitious, realistic and cost-effective climate policy. It is necessary to convince other countries to follow our example.  The Social Democrats and the Green Party have pursued a climate policy overbidding policy without being rooted in European economic reality, which no country supported. If the demands had been pursued in the European Council, it would have risked broken negotiations with no European objectives at all. However, the new Swedish Government abandoned not only its own proposals, but also our ambitious and realistic approach to complement the European Commission's proposed tripling of the rate of emission reductions with commitments in other countries equivalent to another 10%.  This undermined the new Swedish Government's ability to push for a more ambitious European climate policy. The Social Democrats and the Green Party then pushed together with the Sweden Democrats for Sweden to support climate goals that were less ambitious than we had demanded. We regret this because it weakens the EU's voice in international negotiations and reduces the possibility of agreeing on an ambitious global climate agreement.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – From 1 to 12 December, the Conference of the Parties to COP20, the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, will be held in Lima, Peru. It is very important for the representatives of the European Parliament to see a fundamental progress at the conference in question on setting the main points for the forthcoming climate agreement, which should be concluded in 2015. The main objective is to increase global climate ambitions over the next five years, in particular by increasing funding to reach the target of USD 100 billion per year by 2020. The planned Conference in Lima will be crucial for establishing an ambitious and legally binding international agreement to be signed in Paris next year, setting out climate action after 2020.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted against because there is no strategy worthy of the name for the planet and which is totally counterproductive for the EU.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Resolution on the 2014 United Nations Conference on Climate Change, bearing in mind that climate change poses a serious and irreversible threat to our society and to the biodiversity of our planet. Failure to act forcefully and promptly triggers unprecedented effects that pose a serious threat to society's livelihoods. Regardless of the level of development or its geographical position, all States in the globe will be affected in one way or another if we do not act.  The Union has always been characterised by being fully aware of this serious problem and by being at the forefront of taking measures to address it, so we must continue to move towards sustained progress in the environment, the economy and industry: three aspects of the same European objective in order to continue to be an example that the rest of the world can follow in the future.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. - Parliament is finally voting on a resolution with a different nuance: the hope that Lima will really be the antechamber of a binding agreement that will allow us to stop the climate emergencies in Paris. That is why we cannot accept Amendment No 9, tabled by the PPE Group, which aims to undermine two of the central pillars of the resolution by eliminating the demand for binding targets also for energy efficiency and for the promotion of renewable energy. On the other hand, we also reject the amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL Group which seek to call into question the effectiveness of the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) as an instrument to combat climate change at global and European level. The Spanish Socialists believe that the ETS needs to correct its shortcomings, but that it remains an excellent tool for achieving common greenhouse gas reduction targets.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. - I abstained from voting in favour of the next already inferno resolution, which is a motion for political interpretation for the UN Conference (COP 20) on climate change in Lima (Peru) in December this year. As long as the anthropogenic causes of global warming are merely hypothetical and science does not clearly provide evidence of this, serious discussions on CO2 emission reductions cannot be organised for so long. Unfortunately, this evidence is still lacking and politicians are left only scaring societies with disasters, which, unfortunately, is already evidence for some EU politicians.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Writing. - We all recognize that it exists and we are all witnesses to climate change. We all recognise that carbon dioxide and sulphur dioxide emissions are the cause. We agree with the declarations. But what do we recommend? Unfortunately, nothing substantial, as long as the European Union continues to rely on conventional energy sources. So whatever we say, it's just empty words, nice words and wishes. A yes vote is not enough. We have to ask ourselves how we can get out of the way to destruction. Otherwise, we consent to our conviction. What's to be done? We must not forget that man is a creation of nature. He can't make natural laws, he can only make the most of what's there. We are neither above nature, nor under nature, nor out of nature. Let the European Union set an example by abolishing conventional energy sources and by exploiting mild and renewable sources. Otherwise we make fun of ourselves.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. "I would like to recall the contradictions of the European Union's climate policy. On the one hand, the draft resolution considers that climate change poses an imminent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, biodiversity and the planet. On the other hand, Europe is a cult of deregulation and liberalisation of international trade, which have the mechanical effect of increasing energy consumption and the flow of goods. In short, globalized trade is the leading driver of greenhouse gas emissions.  The Lima conference is therefore doomed in advance, since environmental policies, whatever their binding nature, are cancelled by free trade policies. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the European Parliament's position for the next COP 20 meeting, voting in favour of what the Group of the European People's Party has refused to support: political will for a more ambitious emission reduction and for binding energy efficiency and renewables targets to be set. These are key elements for the future of the planet and, with the advancement of the positions of the United States and China in favor of a strong agreement, Europe cannot go with a limited position in ambition and lacking in content. We need a post-Kyoto agreement, mainly to ensure the development of the countries that suffer most without being the main causes, developing countries. The Socialists will continue to strive to eradicate poverty, improve social welfare, reduce inequality gaps, but we are committed to doing so without destroying the environment globally.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. — Like most of my colleagues, I voted in favour of the resolution on the 20th United Nations Climate Conference (COP 20) to be held in Lima, Peru, from 1 to 12 December 2014.  Given the seriousness of the threats posed by climate change, urgent action is needed. The text proposes binding targets for 2030, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 40% compared to 1990, increasing the share of renewable energy to 30% of the energy mix, and achieving 40% energy savings.  The European Parliament is calling for increased funding for the fight against climate change, including by inviting Member States to contribute to the Green Fund in order to raise $100 billion annually by 2020.  MEPs want the EU and its member states to play a constructive role at COP 20 in Lima, in order to create the conditions for a binding global agreement in Paris in 2015. Governments around the world must take collective responsibility, especially to future generations, and take appropriate action to effectively combat climate change.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution on the climate change conference in Lima, Peru. I absolutely agree that governments of the world share a collective responsibility for future generations, therefore they have to take adequate actions. Decisions made in Lima are extremely important in order to be able to reach climate change goals in Paris 2015.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. " Parliament finally votes on a resolution with a different nuance: the hope that Lima will really be the antechamber of a binding agreement that will allow us to put a stop in Paris to climate emergencies. That is why we cannot accept Amendment No 9, tabled by the EPP, which aims to undermine two of the central pillars of the resolution by eliminating the demand for binding targets also for energy efficiency and for the promotion of renewable energy. On the other hand, we also reject the amendments tabled by the EGUE which seek to call into question the effectiveness of the emissions trading scheme as an instrument to combat climate change at global and European level. The Spanish Socialists believe that the STD needs to correct its shortcomings, but it remains an excellent tool for achieving common greenhouse gas reduction targets.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. - According to European Commission data, the European Union is responsible for 11% of global greenhouse gas emissions and is on track to meet its own reduction commitments. The fight against climate change can only be effective in the future if other developed countries and the major emitters currently developing make ambitious commitments comparable to the EU before the 2015 Paris Conference. The EU cannot solve the global emission reduction deficit on its own.  In the wake of the historic announcements made by the United States and China on this subject, it is hoped that they will soon catch up with their emission reduction commitments to the level of Europe.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. "Do we have to have such high ambitions that we will achieve nothing, or do we have to set achievable goals that can be followed by all?"  The Lima conference should not be a repeat of Copenhagen's failure because the future of the planet and the interest of all are at stake. Lima will be an essential step as it prepares for this major event that is the Paris conference in 2015.  That is why I argue that we must set ambitious but not excessive targets.  Thus, I fear that by setting binding targets, by 2030, reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% from 1990 levels, 40% in energy efficiency, in line with research on the potential for cost-effective energy savings, as well as producing at least 30% of total final energy consumption from renewable sources , we were embarking on a trajectory that will be difficult to hold and that this will discredit us in the eyes of our partners. Moreover, does such a posture not run the risk of our companies and industries relocating their activities to countries where regulations are less stringent?

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. – The effects of climate change cut across societies, economies and every single ecosystem. It is essential that we strengthen international efforts to mitigate against these effects and next week's Climate Change Conference in Lima is an important part of those efforts. The EU has taken significant steps to reduce carbon emissions but more needs to be done. My own country, Scotland, has set a target to use renewables to generate the equivalent of 100 per cent of our gross annual electricity consumption by 2020. Scotland is a relatively small country but efforts such as this are essential if we are to tackle climate change.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for the RESOLUTION on the UN Climate Change Conference in 2014, as I believe urgent action is needed globally, as climate change poses a serious threat to the whole world.  The fact is that scientific research has established that CO2 emissions will increase further and that this will worsen the global warming situation. It is imperative that the European Commission strongly advocates tackling the global climate crisis by mobilising additional resources and efforts, out of accountability to future generations.  It is also necessary for other international organisations to engage in the fight against climate change, in particular countries with more developed economies that can contribute strongly to the same advanced infrastructures, and it is in this fight that the role of research and innovation is important.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the United Nations climate change conference in Lima from 1 to 12 December 2014. The text underlines the need for action in the fight against climate change by answering the question of financing climate change and indicating how different economic sectors can contribute to the improvement of the situation. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — This vote on the 2014 UN Climate Change Conference (COP 20 in Lima) comes against a favourable political backdrop following the presentation of the fifth report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, at the UN Secretary-General's Summit of Heads of State in September, the European Climate and Energy Agreement on 24 October to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels and the bilateral climate agreement between the United States and China dated November 12.  In order to reach a comprehensive agreement at the Paris conference in December 2015 to limit the rise in global average temperatures to 2oC, it is now up to all parties to the Climate Convention to demonstrate their credibility by making known their official contributions for the beginning of 2015 and by setting the precise terms of their commitment. The European Union must secure strong commitments from its partners to ensure a balanced international agreement that does not penalised the competitiveness of European industry.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. - I strongly supported the resolution, as climate change represents an urgent and potentially irreversible threat that must be addressed at international level. The EU must do its utmost at the upcoming UN climate summit to ensure that significant progress is made towards achieving a new global climate agreement. It must remain on the front line and broker the best possible deal for human societies, biodiversity and the planet.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) I am voting in favour of this document because climate change undoubtedly represents a serious threat to society as a whole, to biodiversity, to agriculture and to the whole planet. I believe it is right for the European Union to take action to counter the negative effects, and the document highlights the need for the EU to play a leading role in the fight against the global climate crisis. The European Parliament delegation to Lima, which I have the honour to lead, is ready to ensure maximum commitment in this direction.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. — Climate change is a global problem that threatens the biosphere, the stability of communities and societies. Research shows that climate change is not a myth – global warming is actually happening, and human activity contributes the most. If concrete measures are not taken to reduce climate change, the average temperature at the end of the 21th century is likely to be 5°C higher. It is therefore essential to find consensus at international level and to strengthen measures to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions and to keep global warming below 2°C.  Studies show that economic growth and the fight against climate change are compatible, and this can be achieved by countries with any economic capacity. It is important that, in december 2015, the European Parliament and the Council adopted a resolution on the The climate change conference in Paris would internationally agree on coordinated action on climate change beyond 2020, which would be aligned with the 2°C target and the right to sustainable development.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. - The Lima Summit must be decisive in preparing next year's Paris Conference, which I hope will make binding and tangible commitments, also in reference to the final mobilization of climate finance to achieve the joint target of $100 billion per year by 2020. The latest report submitted a few weeks ago by the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is very worrying and, in this regard, I have already asked a parliamentary question to find out what actions the new Commissioner for the Environment is going to take.  Each new information confirms the possible irreversible impact on the climate if no concrete measures are taken to contribute to a more sustainable environment. The report confirms the growing global warming and warns that global temperatures over the next decade may rise above 2oC.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. " Parliament finally votes on a resolution with a different nuance: the hope that Lima will really be the antechamber of a binding agreement that will allow us to put a stop in Paris to climate emergencies. That is why we cannot accept Amendment No 9, tabled by the EPP, which aims to undermine two of the central pillars of the resolution by eliminating the demand for binding targets also for energy efficiency and for the promotion of renewable energy. On the other hand, we also reject the amendments tabled by the EGUE which seek to call into question the effectiveness of the emissions trading scheme as an instrument to combat climate change at global and European level. The Spanish Socialists believe that the STD needs to correct its shortcomings, but it remains an excellent tool for achieving common greenhouse gas reduction targets.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Lima climate summit. When we talk about climate negotiations, we move with hope, but we always end up with discouragement. We must understand that this climate crisis we are living in is a global crisis and must be our priority. And it is the capitalist logic that relocates production where there is less regulation that has led us to this spiral of crisis. We should therefore not only worry about CO2 emissions, but about ending the logic of market capitalism. To combat climate change, we should refuse to participate in this destructive race. This Lima Conference should take a major step forward and adopt a binding global agreement.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - Climate change in recent years has been demonstrating its strength and leaving cuts in society, the environment and on the planet. These consequences that are felt today in every segment of life are the fault of human activities in the past and inactivity today.  Climate change policy objectives must be global, this is a problem that everyone must participate in in order for environmentally sustainable development to be a reality. It should also be ensured that large developed countries help underdeveloped countries, as the adaptation process is long and difficult, but still cost-effective for all in the long term.  I support this resolution, as it aims to ensure constructive debate at the Climate Change Conference, to consider the serious consequences of climate change and to warn of a lack of joint action by states. The European Union is expected to be one of the main drivers of positive change. The task of each Member State is to take measures to adapt to climate change, all to protect its citizens, society, economy and the environment. Economic growth needs to be achieved without further environmental burdens.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour because it is extremely important to support the UN Climate Change Conference, to give political support to the EU conference to be held in the capital of Peru in early December.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution because measures must be taken on climate change, which poses a direct threat to human societies, mainly affects our poorest fellow human beings, creates new migratory flows, reduces water resources and destroys the flora of the planet.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. - I voted for this Resolution which ʽEmphasises that global climate change policies are based on the 1992 UN Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) and that they are an integral part of the global efforts to promote sustainable development all over the world; stresses that the climate change policies must be seen in this wider context and linked with the follow-up on the Rio Conference, the Millennium Development Goals and the post-2015 agendaʼ.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — The scale and seriousness of the threats posed by climate change can no longer postpone the need to take concrete action to eliminate the serious consequences of climate change.  All governments worldwide have a responsibility, above all, to future generations, to implement appropriate climate measures. The Lima stage is a key step in the definition of financial commitments and cooperation in view of the Paris Conference, which will have to define the main post-2020 climate targets, so I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - Climate change is a serious threat to global society, biodiversity, and the planet as a whole. It is therefore necessary for all countries, including the European Union, to mobilise in the name of the common objective of reducing their negative effects.  The report highlights the need for the European Commission to play a leading role in the fight against the global climate crisis.  That is why I have decided to support it with my vote in favour.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — The objectives pursued are laudable, but implementation is unrealistic. Implementing the proposed measures would cause massive damage to Industry in Europe, while other countries continue to fail to pursue their own less ambitious CO2 targets, making them more internationally competitive. I abstained.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. By this resolution the European Parliament could have strengthened Europe's role in promoting a binding climate agreement. But paved with good intentions and incantations on the desire to keep global warming within 2% by 2050, it does not propose any innovative measures.  Worse, it is the carbon emissions market, which has proven time and time again its inefficiency, that is the cornerstone of its policy. The fight against global warming is not a matter of business or competitiveness. As long as the European Parliament and world leaders remain locked in this vision, no fight against global warming will be possible or effective. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — Climate change poses an urgent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, biodiversity and the planet, thus requiring treatment by all parties at international level. So governments must take concrete action against climate change without further delay and for a comprehensive agreement in Paris in 2015 to achieve the objectives that have been being negotiated for several years now. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – I support this resolution and voted in favour of it because it highlights the need for Europe to push for greater market penetration of environmentally friendly technologies in several fields. Europe has the capability to combat climate change in a high-tech manner and this should be supported by a legal framework. The resolution also acknowledges the complex relationship between developing countries and climate change. It also rightly points out that these developing countries have the least capacity to adapt to the challenges of climate change and will likely be amongst the worst affected. We are already seeing the effects of climate change further harming the livelihoods of the citizens of developing countries and the EU can help alleviate these pressures through technology transfers and capacity building.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Climate change poses an unprecedented danger to the future of our entire planet. In developing countries, climate change has already caused several thousand "refugees" and has caused recurrent food crises, internal tensions and even conflicts. Small island states and coastal cities are more exposed than ever to the dual threat of sea level rise and storms. Acting globally is a moral duty to our children and grandchildren. The annual Climate Conference (COP20) to be held in Lima next month is a decisive step. It will be an opportunity for the European Union to put international partners and Member States in front of their responsibilities and to pave the way for COP21, where a binding global climate framework is expected to be adopted. Europe must position itself as a leader in the fight against climate change and in defending the interests of developing countries. It has a role to play in getting COP20 and COP21 to achieve adequate results.

name: Sophie MONTEL
