text: In writing. The United Nations Climate Change Conference, to be held in Lima in December, will clearly not solve the serious problems of greenhouse gas emissions. The United Nations Intergovernmental Panel of Experts estimates that global emissions rose from 38 billion tonnes in 1990 to 49 billion tonnes in 2010. The IPCC has also noted that these emissions are expected to fall by more than 50% in a short period of time! The Kyoto Protocol's target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 5% for the 2008-2012 period has not already been met due to the non-participation of the United States. The failure of this conference is therefore predictable, as China and the United States reached an agreement on November 12, which clearly buried the objectives of the Duban platform (the Kyoto protocol). The consequences of this announced failure will be dramatic: water scarcity, pollution, increased risk of conflict, not to mention the increase in migratory flows. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. "I abstained on the final vote of this resolution. I am in favour of an ambitious climate agreement at the international level. However, this agreement must be balanced between Europe and other parts of the world. The European Union cannot continue to set more stringent environmental standards than elsewhere, because by doing so it is sacrificing its companies and employees by imposing an additional distortion of competition on them.  Increasing our carbon reduction targets, without our partners doing the same, would only encourage relocations to regions of the world where legislation is less restrictive. It would also create additional emissions when the finished products are repatriated to Europe. It is possible to reconcile industry and environment.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - (IT) With this resolution we wish once again to express our great concern about the serious consequences of climate change. We call on the Commission to take the lead in dealing with the global climate crisis, putting it at the heart of its next strategic priorities. All governments worldwide have a collective responsibility, including towards future generations, to take appropriate action in the climate field. We would therefore like to stress how important it is for the European Union, as one of the main protagonists, to speak 'with one voice' at the Lima Conference, seeking progress towards an international agreement and remaining united in this regard.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. — I supported this text, which is a useful reminder of the European Union's efforts to combat climate change and the importance of reaching a binding global agreement in Paris in 2015. With regard to the mention of maritime and air transport, if I fully support their contribution to reducing greenhouse gases, it must be through the development of new, cleaner technologies and not through the reduction of the flow of these modes of transport essential for global growth.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — We Europeans must, of course, also make our contribution to combating global climate change. But our approach must also be globally coordinated. Above all, as far as the distribution of the costs of this trade is concerned, there must be a fair distribution of the burden satisinly throughout the world. According to a study by Johannes Kepler University in Linz, the reduction of CO2 emissions by a further 40% by 2030 threatens around 61,000 jobs in Austria alone. Industry has already made its contribution to the fight against climate change in many European Member States on emissions trading. The report contains good approaches to binding climate protection regulations, but overall the EU's objectives are unrealistic and lead to massive damage (not only to the energy-intensive industry) in Europe, while other countries have far less ambitious CO2 targets. The US has more or less distanced itself from the Kyoto agreement, and Turkey has increased its emissions by 115% in the last 20 years. That is why I abstained.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This text is a good basis for an ambitious European Union position in the fight against climate change and for greater protection of the environment. I voted in favour of this report in order to push the European Commission to adopt the most ambitious position possible at the international climate forum to be held in Lima.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - I supported the resolution on the UN Conference on Climate Change in Peru. Climate change is an irreversible threat to society, which is why I believe that this must be dealt with extremely seriously in international cooperation. The international response has so far not been sufficient and measures should be implemented proactively and immediately. In order to support sustainable development, more prosperous countries need to help developing countries and to act more environmentally in developing their economies.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. The 20th Conference of the Parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change will be held in Lima. This is the last and decisive step towards the Paris meeting in 2015. In this context, the main elements of this agreement must be agreed in Lima and the draft agreement has been lost. We must urgently respond to the dangers involved and ensure that the climate does not thaw by more than 2 degrees. Not only the EU, but also the rest of the countries, must make commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. It is therefore essential that appropriate support is also provided to developing countries so that they can join this global struggle. Only joint efforts will combat climate change to combat much more effectively by preventing the potential threats to the population of the world as a whole.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Climate change is a potentially irreversible threat to man and the environment. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions is one of the priority objectives to ensure that global warming is maintained at 2 degrees Celsius. The Lima stage is a key step in the definition of financial commitments and cooperation in the run-up to the Paris Conference, which will have to define the post-2020 climate targets, and I would therefore like to vote in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. — The International Conference to be held in Peruvian Lima in December should prepare global partners for the development of an ambitious agreement in Paris next year so that the world can achieve the set climate warming target of less than 2°C.  In our resolution, MEPs reminded the leaders of the EU and the Member States of the commitments to increase the funds for the United Nations Green Climate Fund in order to provide $100 billion a year for it by 2020. As stated in the resolution of the Committee on the Environment, the agreement should contain clear measures to mitigate, adapt and implement a strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 50 per cent by 2050.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. —While environmental protection is undoubtedly a major issue, today's motion for a resolution is not reassuring. Its objectives are set for several decades, while the European Union has proved unable to anticipate a few years in most areas. Is it to delegate even more powers to the EU to add an ecological disaster to the economic catastrophe it has generated? I therefore vote against this proposal.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on the United Nations Conference in Lima because the European Union, particularly through the commitment and guarantee of a delegation from Parliament, must contribute to the maintenance of international efforts to deal with global warming, which threatens the planet, the health and economic development of society as a whole, especially in the poorest sections of society. This is due to greenhouse gas emissions, for which the entire international community is responsible and to reduce which it is necessary to implement policies that are more 'bold' than those already put in place. The 20% reduction target by 2020 is not ambitious enough. This and other objectives must be delayed in the light of the new opportunities that science offers. Climate protection must be financed and an eco-sustainable economy must be developed, focusing on innovation and competitiveness in order to increase energy independence and security and lower the cost of energy. These factors, combined, lead to an increase in GDP, stimulating growth and creating jobs. Within this framework, Europe must adopt a unified environmental policy before the international bodies. It is not just a question of safeguarding the planet by improving our quality of life, but of taking collective responsibility for future generations.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I supported a resolution defining the objectives of the European Parliament delegation at the Lima conference. Priorities should enable global partners to reach ambitious climate agreements in Paris in 2015 with the main aim of curbing global warming. The main objective is to keep the global increase below 2°C warming of the average temperature, reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2050, increase international 2020 targets and implement previous COP agreements, mainly in places of climate finance and adaptation.  It is essential to strike a balance between the environment and industry, i.e. climate change and policies to ensure an innovative and competitive industry at the same time. Environmental objectives must be ambitious and realistic in order to avoid further delocalisation of European industry, which would weaken the EU's leadership in the fight against climate change globally.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's position on COP 20 on climate change in a firm and decisive manner, because I believe that it is a top priority for Parliament and the other institutions to make a unique, strong and clear voice heard by all our partner countries at a time when very serious weather phenomena constituted by climate change are threatening us in an increasingly persistent manner. I believe that the international response is still too weak, as evidenced, for example, by the low results achieved in terms of global warming on the planet and the still excessively high CO2 emissions. That is why I believe that we need to reach a global agreement to eliminate the risk of co2 emissions being relocated. I understand that we are in a period of budgetary restrictions, but I believe that, in this area, we must try to increase climate finance, and we must also call on third countries to contribute in proportion to their resources. Finally, I welcome the result achieved at the last European Council, where all Member States will be required to reduce their emissions in accordance with their capacities and possibilities. It is an excellent result and it can serve as an example to others.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. — If EU representatives go to climate conferences, unfortunately, failure is all too often predetermined. It is true that targets are set full-bodied there, but the EU is failing to persuade the countries with the highest levels of carbon dioxide to implement them. The consequence of this is that the competitiveness of Germany and Europe is being severely restricted. The ineffective emissions trading and ever-new CO2 limits, for example, are systematically weakening the steel industry in Europe. On the one hand, this will result in the loss of jobs and, on the other hand, in the case of Germany, the costs of the EEG will largely be passed on to middle and low incomes.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — I am voting in favour of a resolution to allow the European Union to weigh in at the Lima climate change conference. In doing so, it was necessary to opt for a common position between the European Union and all the Member States. It is also a matter of insisting on the main objective, namely to obtain agreements with all international partners at the major paris conference in 2015.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — Climate change poses a potentially irreversible threat to human societies, biodiversity and the planet, and therefore calls for an urgent and determined international response. Measures to be taken include: the conclusion of an agreement at the Paris climate conference in December 2015 (COP 21), which calls for an ambitious legally binding international agreement on post-2020 climate action; the urgent strengthening and extension of existing measures to limit greenhouse gas emissions by 2020; and increased funding provided by developed countries for the reduction, adaptation, transfer and development of technology and capacity building in developing countries, as well as the simultaneous increase in public development aid, with a view to meeting the long-promised target of 0.7 % of gross national income. To this end, it should be noted the importance of the next United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP 20), which will take place in Lima, Peru, from 1 to 12 December 2014) and to urge the EU and its Member States to play a constructive and prominent role in it.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2014 UN Climate Change Conference in Lima from 1 to 12 December. With this text, our House is in favour of an ambitious global agreement for 2015 and encourages Member States to move forward in their negotiations ahead of COP 21 in Paris in 2015. We underline the importance of the European Union's contribution to the fight against climate change, and we call on other states around the world to do the same, notably by contributing to the Green Fund set up at the Copenhagen conference in 2009.  The particular situation of developing countries (DEVELOPING countries), which emit the least CO2 but suffer the most, is also taken into account by a call for a smarter development assistance policy. These provisions are in line with my vision of the role that the European Union must play on the international stage in the face of the challenges of climate change.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. - Parliament is finally voting on a resolution with a different nuance: the hope that Lima will really be the antechamber of a binding agreement that will allow us to stop the climate emergencies in Paris. That is why we cannot accept Amendment No 9, tabled by the EPP, which aims to undermine two of the central pillars of the resolution by eliminating the demand for binding targets also for energy efficiency and for the promotion of renewable energy. On the other hand, we also reject the amendments tabled by the EGUE which seek to call into question the effectiveness of the emissions trading scheme as an instrument to combat climate change at global and European level. The Spanish Socialists believe that the STD needs to correct its shortcomings, but it remains an excellent tool for achieving common greenhouse gas reduction targets.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. - The next United Nations Climate Change Conference will take place in Lima, Peru from 1 to 12 December 2014. On this occasion, I voted on a resolution calling for the relaunch of the European Union's climate policy and for a rapid agreement on ambitious and binding targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, energy efficiency and the use of renewable energy sources. I also reiterated my desire for an ambitious and legally binding international agreement on post-2020 climate actions, up to the challenge of limiting global warming to below 2 degrees. I also voted to urgently strengthen and expand current measures to limit greenhouse gas emissions by 2020 and beyond, and to increase the resources available to developed countries to finance mitigation and adaptation measures, technological development and transfer, and capacity building in developing countries. , in line with the creation of the Green Climate Fund.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. - I voted in favour because it is clear to me that managing climate change is one of the biggest challenges in the world. It must be understood that change requires the abandonment of old, unreliable technologies, in particular coal, and effective consumption reduction programmes. The European Union must take all measures to promote the development of renewable energy, thereby creating green jobs and added value for people living in the regions. The European Union can no longer delay decisions on ending fossil fuel subsidies. Nor can we close our eyes when new nuclear power plants are being built, both within the European Union and in its neighbourhood, under the guise of climate change mitigation. We no longer have the right to wait for other countries to achieve ambitious targets. We need to start with ourselves to change. Action must be taken by every person, every Member State. The European Union must make it clear that decisions need to be taken now, without delay before the next UN Climate Change Conference in Paris.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — The Lima negotiations will take place next month and could lead to an ambitious long-term climate agreement in Paris in 2015. The European Union will thus have to negotiate with its global partners, so that they invest more in climate policy to participate in environmental protection, develop sustainable technologies and enable job creation.  Following the recent agreement between the United States and China, it seems that we are on the right track to reach an agreement, but the European Union will have to remain firm on its objectives during the negotiations.  I therefore voted in favour of this resolution which supports the next lima conference and prepares for the future conclusion of a global agreement in Paris in 2015.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against it because it is the usual annual resolution on the UNFCCC Conference of the Parties (COP) which discusses a unilateral suicidal climate policy. If it were for the 'ambition' of the European Parliament, the ongoing process of relocation would be even faster.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Lima climate summit. When we talk about climate negotiations, we move with hope, but we always end up with discouragement. We must understand that this climate crisis we are living in is a global crisis and must be our priority. And it is the capitalist logic that relocates production where there is less regulation that has led us to this spiral of crisis. We should therefore not only worry about CO2 emissions, but about ending the logic of market capitalism. To combat climate change, we should refuse to participate in this destructive race. The European Union should start taking steps. It would contribute greatly to the reduction of greenhouse gases by implementing agricultural and food policies that respect the right of peoples to food sovereignty; encouraging production models based on agroecology, with peasants and farmers producing food and boosting local and local markets. This Lima Conference should take a major step forward and adopt a binding global agreement.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution on the climate change conference in Lima as the EU delegation plays a vital role in climate change negotiations. Climate change represents an urgent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, biodiversity and the planet, and must thus be addressed at international level by all Parties. It poses an unprecedented threat to the biosphere, to the availability and supply of food and water, in particular to poor people on most continents, and to health, livelihoods and economic development around the globe. I expect the new Commission to assume a proactive role in addressing the global climate crisis, including in terms of additional climate financing. The Commission must make it clear that the climate challenge is one of its top strategic priorities and to organise itself in a way which reflects this, at all levels and across all sectors in domestic and external policies and actions.  I am concerned by the extraordinary scale and seriousness of the threats induced by climate change and I fully support participation of the European Union in climate change negotiations in Lima.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — Human activity is the main cause of climate change and can only effectively combat its negative consequences. For this reason, I supported this resolution.  Unless we take decisive steps, the average air temperature will increase by five degrees by the end of the century, posing a danger to the total flooding of coastal parts of Europe, including Croatia. Therefore, we need to responsibly defend the interests of all people, nature and future generations, and one of the key moves is to set more ambitious climate protection targets, reduce fossil fuel incentives and enable the Green Climate Fund to function. Climate change can no longer be fought only declaratively, but a clear political position is needed. In order to achieve concrete progress in one's own country and then globally, it is essential to inform the public and make your country's authorities aware of the harmful consequences, but also of the instruments at their disposal.  Numerous technological developments allow us to more closely combat climate change. However, the instruments themselves are not sufficient, but a significant change in our habits and lifestyle is needed, turning to energy efficiency in everyday life and encouraging the use of renewable energy sources.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. — The Climate Conference to be held in Lima between the first and twelfths of December 2014 represents a milestone in the negotiations for a new international climate agreement. By that resolution, the European Parliament called for a reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by 2050. The fact is that we are witnessing climate change that has been happening in recent decades and have a major negative impact on nature and people all over the world. Many areas are at risk due to melting ice and the resulting increase in water levels. Ecosystems are destroyed and the amount of drinking water is decreasing. All this has a negative impact on people's lives, their health, access to food and drinking water. If we continue to release greenhouse gases into the air, the atmosphere will warm up, causing changes in the earth, oceans and atmosphere in all regions of the world. If we don't change anything and stand idly by, the average atmospheric temperature will rise by five degrees Celsius by the end of the century. For this reason, it is necessary to work on renewable energy sources, on energy efficiency and on reducing emissions. The atmosphere has a major impact on people's quality of life, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution calling for an improvement in the current situation.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I supported the UN Climate Change Conference Resolution as we witness daily weather events due to climate change. Delaying action will increase costs and reduce opportunities for progress.  The Lima conference is an opportunity to set key objectives before discussing the agreement in Paris in 2015. This agreement will clearly include mitigation measures, adaptation and implementation strategy aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions.  The European Union has reduced greenhouse gas emissions by 19% from 1990 levels. Climate finance agreements, technology transfer and capacity building will be key to helping developing countries. The commitments made by the EU and its members are to increase funding for climate action by capitalising on the UN Green Climate Fund and jointly mobilising $100 billion a year by 2020.  I would point out that Croatia has also suffered great damage this year due to extreme weather conditions and that a large number of Croatian cities have been affected by the floods.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe we need to take climate change seriously and that the EU should remain on the front line to broker the best deal.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. - I did not support the proposal because I am convinced that it will lead to exactly the opposite consequences as intended. Already current climate objectives and other EU environmental policies are expelling a number of firms outside Europe to countries such as China or India, where environmental standards are at a much lower level. As a result, the European Union's economy and employment are suffering, but the total amount of emissions may be rising. In such a situation, efforts to further reinforce climate objectives are irresponsible, as they will further reinforce this trend.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — There is talk of giving money to third countries for development, of giving 'incentives' to energy-intensive large industries to reduce their pollutants and, overall, of giving $100 billion to the Green Climate Fund by 2020.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - Of course i totally follow my colleague mister Leinen on this topic. This year’s Climate Change Conference in Lima needs to set out the main elements of the 2015 global climate agreement which shall include commitments to fight climate change by all countries in order to stay within the “below 2°C” objective. The S&D's call on industrialised countries to lead by example and present ambitious emission cuts by March 2015 and to provide financial support to help the developing countries achieve their own emission reductions. It is, therefore, crucial to provide clarity on how to scale up the mobilisation of climate finance in order to achieve the joint goal of USD 100 billion per year by 2020 - a goal which has already been agreed on in Copenhagen.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. - I hold this conference extremely important since it provides an opportunity to develop technical elements for the negotiations and the construction of a political platform for a conference to be held in Paris in December, where a new global framework for climate change (the so-called Agreement 2015) will be adopted.  I believe that the Union is in a great position to influence this process at the moment, as the Council decided last month to reduce gas emissions in the European Union by at least 40% (compared to 1990 and 2030 levels).  I supported this resolution because I am convinced that the conference is a great opportunity for the Union to come forward to the global public with one positive and ambitious environmental plan, both for the territory of the European Union and for all other conference participants.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. – Climate change represents an urgent and potentially irreversible threat to human societies, biodiversity and the planet, and must thus be addressed at international level. The goals of climate change policies can only be reached by turning the general course of development towards ecological sustainability in both the developed and the developing countries. It has to be a global commitment; if not, the effort of a few will be useless and unfair. I supported this motion for a resolution with the hope that the Lima Conference will be a success. There is an urgent need to act and for an international response to the challenge.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. — The fight against global warming is one of the priorities of the European Union's agenda. Global warming brings huge losses – some regions feel more, others are less, but this is particularly evident in the face of extreme natural phenomena. This resolution is the basis on which to work in Lima in December. The Lima conference needs to make important decisions to be taken at next year's climate change conference in Paris.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. - Parliament is finally voting on a resolution with a different nuance: the hope that Lima will really be the antechamber of a binding agreement that will allow us to stop the climate emergencies in Paris. That is why we cannot accept Amendment No 9, tabled by the EPP, which aims to undermine two of the central pillars of the resolution by eliminating the demand for binding targets also for energy efficiency and for the promotion of renewable energy. On the other hand, we also reject the amendments tabled by the EGUE which seek to call into question the effectiveness of the emissions trading scheme as an instrument to combat climate change at global and European level. The Spanish Socialists believe that the STD needs to correct its shortcomings, but it remains an excellent tool for achieving common greenhouse gas reduction targets.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Lima climate summit. When we talk about climate negotiations, we move with hope, but we always end up with discouragement. We must understand that this climate crisis we are living in is a global crisis and must be our priority. And it is the capitalist logic that relocates production where there is less regulation that has led us to this spiral of crisis. We should therefore not only worry about CO2 emissions, but about ending the logic of market capitalism. To combat climate change, we should refuse to participate in this destructive race. This Lima Conference should take a major step forward and adopt a binding global agreement.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - We agree on greenhouse gas emission reduction targets, with greater concern in meeting the targets set and on the need for other, more ambitious targets (in line with ipcc recommendations). We also agree on the principle of co-responsibility and aid to developing countries to cope with the consequences of climate change. The truth is that the most serious consequences for populations are felt in the poorest countries with fewer response capacities. As far as the carbon market is concerned, it is hidden that 1999 was precisely the year of the introduction of this flexible mechanism at the time of the Kyoto Protocol, and that in 2005 the EU's Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading Scheme was initiated. Instead of a regulatory approach, we continue to insist on a market approach to climate change and, even recognising the failure of this policy option, the EU is only concerned with low profit and disinterest in buying allowances, proposing to remove it from the excess of allowances.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Climate change is, of course, also a problem for Europe, for which solutions, or at least approaches, must be created to counter this threat. On the other hand, we must not forget, on the one hand, the essential economic aspect that arises, among other things, in emissions trading, which must certainly also be seen as detrimental in the sense of a growing European economy, especially since Europe has certainly made its contribution in this regard. What bothers me much more, however, is that the objectives of the conference are almost utopian and completely damaging to the European economy. Knowing that neither the United States, China nor Turkey adhere to these objectives, or even respect them, and for the reasons I have mentioned above, I abstained.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — Like previous resolutions, we agree on targets to reduce greenhouse gas emissions; with a greater concern to meet the targets set and the need for other, more ambitious targets (in line with the IPCC recommendations). We agree on the principle of co-responsibility and aid to developing countries to cope with the consequences of climate change. Since the main polluters, which cause such changes, are the richest and most industrialised countries, the truth is that the most serious consequences for populations are felt in countries with less responsiveness, where socio-economic circumstances are more unfavorable to their populations. The purposes set out in the Kyoto Protocol, with these mechanisms, which would be to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, with CO2 index, have been replaced by the desire to see another market functioning, free, generating millions of euros, becoming a business opportunity, as we always say. This Parliament merely proposes green-fronted solutions, such as that part of the revenue stemming from this market is aswerled to finance the fight against climate change.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the recognition of Palestinian statehood (2014/2964(RSP)).

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, first of all, let me say how much I appreciate the fact of being here in this capacity for the first time in my mandate, in this first three weeks or so, and maybe to reassure you and all this Parliament of the fact that maybe we can go back to the way the Treaties call me: High Representative/Vice-President. I assure you that I will be Vice-President of the Commission, so there is no need to switch the order. I give you a political reassurance on that, but I think it is good if we all stick to the Treaties in content and in form. First of all, I would like to thank you for this timely debate. I think it is a crucial debate coming at a crucial time. I have just visited, in my first week in office, Israel and Palestine, including Gaza, Jerusalem and the West Bank, and I can report back to you, as I did to the Foreign Affairs Council, that there is a sense of urgency in the region, on both sides – very different on one side compared to the other side, but on both sides there is a very tense situation where the lack of a political perspective is, at one and the same time, the consequence and the result and the cause of violence that risks returning. We see that in these weeks, with terrorist attacks on one side and decisions on the other side that risk endangering the perspective of a two-state solution. This sense of urgency is becoming greater and greater in the absence of a political perspective. In the past months we experienced first the suspension of the talks last spring, then the conflict in Gaza. Luckily, and thanks to a good political initiative by some actors in the region and internationally – starting with Egypt – a ceasefire was reached at the end of August followed by a donors’ conference not many weeks ago, once again in Cairo. But none of this is reopening the path to a political perspective, to direct talks or to steps that can bring back hope in the fact that what we call the ‘two-state solution’ can become a reality in the near future. We have some open points. On one side we have the dramatic open point of Gaza, where I saw a desperate situation, where I saw that the Palestinian Authority has more than difficulties in doing what we all hope it could do: start to rule Gaza, starting with the security side and control of the crossings. And on the other side we have decisions like the one on the settlements, which is actually moving in an opposite direction, rather than the one indicated by the agreed negotiations. In this framework, I think this debate today about the role that the European Union can play in this process is crucial. That is why I decided to go in my first week in office, because we are the first trade partner for Israel and we are the first donor for the Palestinian Authority. We can be the first political player in the region to facilitate a dialogue, which has to be a direct dialogue between the Israelis and the Palestinians, but which maybe, for the first time really, has the chance of becoming regional. I saw during my visit – and I have shared this with the Member States of the European Union too – the fact that maybe we have for the first time such a dramatic threat and challenge in the region, in the Middle East– namely Daesh – that poses the actors in the region with a different set of priorities. I saw an awareness both in Israel and in Palestine that the order of priorities is changing, not only in the region but also in Europe, and also on the other side of the Atlantic, also for the international community, and that we have a clear possibility there of uniting different actors which now share the same concern for the security and stability of the region. We have threats in the regional framework today, but maybe we also have an opportunity coming out of these threats. On the other side, the vacuum that is there and which risks being even more relevant, especially in Gaza, given the regional framework, could lead to even more dangerous outcomes. The situation in Gaza will either get better on the ground or there is a risk that it will open the way for a more worrying situation, in terms of who controls what in that territory and who networks with whom in the region. That is why I think it would be wise from my side today not only to listen to you in the debate, but also to try to give you some input on what kind of political elements we can have, as the European Union, to restart a peace process, to restart a political process – a political perspective. I will start with the regional framework. I believe that in 2002, the Arab Peace Initiative was probably a missed opportunity. Today that could constitute one of the elements of a renewed effort, regionally and internationally, to put actors around the table. We know that we have a Palestinian-Israeli conflict, but we also know that we have an Arab-Israeli conflict that we have to work on. Maybe this set of threats and opportunities in the region could give us an opportunity to work on the Middle East peace process on a broader scale and include, in particular, not only the Arab League  – which will have the ministerial meeting this weekend and which is certainly listening carefully to the messages coming out of here today – but also some key Arab countries: certainly Egypt, not only for the role that it has played historically and in the past months, but also because it has a certain leverage on Gaza through Rafah, and also Jordan, as it has a special role regarding the status of the holy sites in Jerusalem. I would also mention Saudi Arabia as the initiator of the Arab Peace Initiative in 2002. I can share here with you the thoughts that I shared with the Member States during the last Foreign Affairs Council on the need to have a European Union initiative, together with the Arab League and Arab States, in particular, and with the US – I am in constant contact with John Kerry, who is renewing his commitment to reopen the way for negotiations – and with the UN, also because we know that the UN Security Council could be a way to redefine the framework of an initiative. I would mention the UN Security Council with a view to having a resolution that would not split, but rather unite, the international actors to find a solution. The European Union effort is at the same time trying to put that framework together. I will not just take into account but I will take note of your debate today, because I believe that the parliamentary debates – and then if you are going to take a vote on this next month – can fit into the process of a European common approach. You know very well that the recognition of a state is not within the competences of the European Union. Technically and politically this is the responsibility of individual Member States, but I would never say to you – in the same way that I have not said this to the Ministers of the Member States when we had the Foreign Affairs Council last week – I would never say that this is not my business. This is obviously technically not my business, but politically it is, because I believe that we need – and I appreciate the drafts that I have seen of the resolutions that encourage me to do so – to share a vision and to share a common understanding of the situation and also, if we can also manage it – and I think Parliament can help us in that – to shape a common European approach of national initiatives that could go in the same direction. In this I think that this Parliament can play a very important role. That message is coming across today. I will take the opportunity to reply at the end of the debate, but it is also important for me today to listen to the orientation that is coming from the European Parliament, knowing that only if we manage to take into account all the different views and try to make a common view from these different views – coming from both different political groups and different Member States – will we have the chance to fully play our role in the region. Only if we send united messages as the European Union in the region can our potential really be used. Here also comes a good leverage that you have in terms of parliamentary diplomacy. Do not under estimate it. I will do all that I can, and I know that you know that you can count on that. But you also have some instruments, some important instruments, in your daily or weekly or monthly contacts with the counterparts there. If we manage to send a united and strong message, we probably have a chance of influencing the course of the events in the Middle East. I would like to state what our common position is already: sometimes we just refer to the two-state solution as a slogan, and I think it is useful to say what this means. Because I was surprised by the fact that, when I said when I was in Israel and Palestine that we need a Palestinian State, surprise! Well, the two-state solution means that we have to have an Israeli State that is able to live in security – and this is an issue we have to deal with – and also a Palestinian State that we do not have at the moment. So I said publicly that we can discuss the recognition of a Palestinian State. Some Member States are doing that in national parliaments; you are going to have a debate in this Parliament and I will be listening to your orientation very carefully. National governments are going to take decisions, or not, at this time or later, but the important thing is that we all work together towards the same goal with the most effective instruments, coordinating these instruments if we manage to. And that is my responsibility, to achieve these results, and these results are the creation of a Palestinian State within the 1967 borders, with swops if agreed, with Jerusalem as capital of the two states, and this has already been agreed; this is a central common historical position. But I think it is right that we go into the details of what our historical position is, to remind ourselves what a two-state solution means, with the right of Israel not only to exist but to exist in security and safety and peace in the region, and with all the Palestinians – all the Palestinians, whether in the West Bank, in Jerusalem or in Gaza – having one state finally. I am looking forward to listening to your contributions to that and I will take note of them in this framework, that of someone who knows very well that opinions which are expressed in Parliament, even if they are not, as in this case, targeted at an imminent decision that can become operational – because it is not in the power of the European Parliament, as it is not in the power of the High Representative/Vice-President, to recognise a state – it is our common responsibility to work together to achieve the goal that I just stated: the creation of a Palestinian State within this framework and working with Israel to guarantee peace and security in the region. I believe – I said that to the Israelis and I said it also to the Palestinians, and I am saying also to the Arab countries in the region – that there is no way of having security if we do not have a Palestinian State, and there is no way of having a Palestinian State if we do not guarantee stability, security and peace to the Israelis too. That is the very same concept, the core of the efforts that the European Union has always worked on. Today it is probably more difficult than ever, but sometimes, when it is more difficult, people around the table realise that a plus of political will and internal leadership is needed and they might make an effort in that direction.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European Parliament. The majority of Palestinians and the majority of Israelis want peace, want peace on the basis of a two-state solution. But there are forces on the Palestinian side, especially Hamas, which does not want a two-state solution and is using violence in Gaza. And there are circles in The Society of Israel who do not want this either, and who also partly sit in the government and do not want a two-state solution. We currently have a situation that is once again becoming dangerous: on the one hand, Gaza must be opened up so that it can develop, and on the other hand, Israel has a right not to be fired rockets from Gaza. Both belong together. The fact that we have the matter of the Temple Mount, as well as the attack on the synagogues, shows how dangerous it is when politics and religion are mixed together and where additional radicalization is brought about. The question of settlements also speaks for itself. Our goal is a two-state solution with a secure Jewish state of Israel and a viable state of Palestine. This can only be done on the basis of mutual recognition, as the High Representative made clear at the very end of her speech. One thing requires the other, therefore one cannot recognize the one beforehand, if not everything else is given, but this connection must be seen clearly.  The idea of bringing the United States and the United Nations more involved and acting on the principle of "we wouldn't like to be just the biggest donors we want to be a player there" means that the European Union now has more political initiative to take here. I also believe that the responsibility of the Arab states for this peace process – some of which are proxy wars that are taking place – is of great importance and that the appropriate capacity must be achieved here to resolve this conflict, which is becoming increasingly important in these days far beyond the region. For this reason, I hope that we will be able to work out a common position on the basis of our resolution. Because if we act separately, it will be a very difficult situation for us to make our contribution to peaceful development.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, today’s debate is quite simply saying that, if we support a two-state solution, then we must support Palestine as a state. It is an attempt to break the deadlock in which the viability of the two-state solution is increasingly questioned to avoid a new apartheid, which some say is already here. We used to talk about a roadmap, but that has been forgotten. This is an attempt to restart the journey. To our Israeli friends, your representative called this move giving Palestinians a state on ‘a silver platter’. Some platter! But, as my own party has said in Britain, Palestinian statehood is not a gift to be given, it is a right to be recognised. Our move today is supported by former Israeli Ambassadors to France, Turkey and South Africa, the former Israeli Attorney General and the former Speaker of the Knesset. They are not anti-Israel and, I promise you, neither are we. My group absolutely joins the condemnation of the horrendous Har Nof synagogue bombing, but the conclusion we draw from this and other terrorist acts is that status quo is not guaranteeing peace and security for the Israeli people. To those who have argued for delay this week, why should parliaments in Spain, France, Sweden, Ireland, the United Kingdom and now Denmark take the initiative, but not this European Parliament? To my friends in the European People’s Party, your current offer is to say that recognition can only be the outcome of successful talks, but that is only restating what is already the case. We share your concern that this must be a contribution towards talks, and I restate our willingness to find with you a good compromise on this point. To our Palestinian friends, we recognise that you have held back on asking us to do this until now, and we recognise that international recognition is vital to maintaining hope amongst your people to sustain political support for peace. Why should the European Parliament act? Because there is impatience at the continued settlement-building and despair at the continuing death toll. Because, as we have already heard from Mrs Mogherini, EU foreign ministers are discussing this, and there are merits to a common EU approach. Because, on the day of the award of the Sakharov Prize, our Parliament should remember the Israeli woman to whom we gave the Sakharov Prize in 2001, who lost her own child to a Palestine suicide bomber, and who asked us to support this proposal. Given what she lost and what she asked us, who are we to disagree? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Does Mr Howitt accept that one of the largest stumbling blocks to a lasting peace is the Hamas call for the destruction of the State of Israel? Does he agree with me that, were Hamas to revoke this core principle, then it could lead to a fresh, everlasting approach?

name: Richard HOWITT
text: blue-card answer. – I am absolutely for Hamas and everyone else recognising the right of Israel to exist, and for peace and security for the Israeli people. My group will always speak out against terrorism. However, these terrorist acts are killing Israelis just as Palestinians were killed in Gaza, and the status quo is failing. My group believes that this initiative can, in recognising the Palestinian State, provide the extra impetus which finally brings talks to a successful conclusion and peace to the Middle East. This is a vote for peace.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we in this House all dream of the day when we may welcome the end of the hostilities and when peace between Israel and the Palestinians will finally be achieved in the Middle East. For as long as I have been an MEP, the debate as to how we can in fact realise this objective has been a matter of fierce exchange in this House and elsewhere. My group, the ECR, accepts that lasting peace can only be achieved when all sides return to the negotiating table in order to bring about a two-state solution. We support this two-state solution as being the only feasible outcome for long-term peace and stability, and we are fully committed to working towards the eventual recognition of a sovereign, independent, democratic and viable Palestinian state, which may peacefully co-exist alongside Israel, based on the 1967 borders with land for peace swaps. However, I personally have deep concerns regarding whether this particular motion today, for unilateral recognition of Palestine, is premature. The dual needs of mutual recognition and concrete security arrangements on the ground, which are of paramount importance in achieving peace, would not be addressed by EU Member States granting immediate symbolic recognition to a fledgling Palestinian state. Furthermore, there are fears that this resolution might endanger peace by facilitating a hardening of the Palestinian position towards more intransigence and preventing lasting mutual recognition. This will all require much compromise in order to achieve the final agreement. As such, unilateral recognition of a Palestinian state at this stage would, in my view, arguably not assist in bringing Prime Minister Netanyahu and President Abbas to the negotiating table, but might actually result in pushing the two sides further apart. We must recognise the Palestinian state at a time most helpful to the peace process. But firstly we must resolve the question of Gaza under Hamas, which is an EU-designated terrorist organisation. Whilst I have serious reservations as to whether this resolution is a good idea at this time, solving this issue will nevertheless remain a foreign policy priority for the ECR, and I agree with you, Madam Vice-President/High Representative: the 2002 Arab peace initiative is a very good place to start the negotiations, even today, a decade later.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the distrust of European citizens over the institutions of the Union, considered distant, excessively bureaucratic and slow, aged, without the capacity for reaction, has been growing over the past few years. Well, with the postponement in relation to the Resolution on the Recognition of the State of Palestine, we send back to the citizens the message which we are so critical of. We Europeans, who have distinguished ourselves by the defence and promotion of human dignity against the multiple violences and discriminations of just causes, who have distinguished ourselves by raising our voices when necessary, are once again out of the task. I would even say that we put interests back before the fundamental values of European thought. However, I do not resign myself. In a complex and rapidly moving world such as today, we must aspire to be a leading, non-follow-up Parliament of the Member States. We must set the interests and set the priorities of states on the basis of the common values that form the foundations of the European Union. We can't afford to stay in line with decisions. We must be at the forefront. Ladies and gentlemen, the Swedish Parliament's courageous announcement to recognise the State of Palestine must be the beginning of a new wave of international recognition that we must support. Our influence cannot continue to be shaped by sending large amounts of public resources to rebuild a region every time Israelis and Palestinians come into conflict. We must lead international pressure in the search for a solution based on the creation of two states, Israeli and Palestinian, coexisting in peace, security and prosperity. A solution that the European Parliament has been advocing for years, decades. And it is therefore our political responsibility to help that solution materialize as soon as possible. We can't put it off anymore. Recognizing Palestine will be a step that future generations will remember as Europe's decision to put themselves on the right side of history. Recognizing the Palestinian state is investing in peace.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, 135 countries already – representing approximately 80% of the world’s population – recognise Palestinian statehood. This includes eight EU Member States, most recently Sweden. There have been resolutions passed in Ireland and Britain calling for recognition of Palestinian statehood. Similar debates will take place in France, Belgium and Demark. The Israeli onslaught in Gaza this summer has shown that the status quo is not acceptable to the millions we represent who protested, and it should not be acceptable to anyone who genuinely supports a peaceful and just resolution. Those who claim that recognition of the Palestinian State would negatively impact on future negotiations, ignore the reality that 20 years of negotiations have advanced little and have reinforced Israel’s occupation, which consistently undermines a two-state solution through settlement expansion and land confiscation. The international community needs to influence change by action, because the worrying situation emerging in East Jerusalem and the preposterous Jewish State Bill demonstrate clearly that Israel is not prepared to be a partner for peace. Recognising the State of Palestine on the 1967 borders will send a clear message that the international community and the EU are opposed to occupation and committed to a two-state solution involving two fully-fledged, recognised states, as outlined by the High Representative: Israel and Palestine.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all let me thank the High Representative for sharing with us her thoughts about the thorny question of the Israeli-Palestine conflict and about the recognition of the state of Palestine as part of the two-state solution. Thank you, Madam High Representative, for expressing your openness to note the results of this debate and to take it into consideration in your further steps. I especially welcome your call for a united and strong message coming from this very Chamber, but let me just tell you that the united and strong message that you, Madam, expect from us could have come forward more easily had we had the opportunity to debate a resolution with this debate. The fact that we cannot debate a resolution seems to be a result of a slight majority at the time on Monday but I very much hope that the result of the debate will change the minds of many of those who voted to remove the resolution from the table. I understand what my colleagues on the Right are saying: that we have to do a lot for a comprehensive peace settlement, we have to help both the Palestinians and the Israeli side in regard to going back to the negotiating table and achieving a lasting result, and I understand that we are far from it. There is a lot to do. Nobody denies that and we Greens very much hope that the EU will be among the most important partners to help bring that about. But for the life of me I cannot understand how that can be hampered, how that can be objected to, by actually recommending to the Member States recognition of the Palestine State on the basis of the 1967 borders now. It is just not me that does not understand that. Let me offer you a quote: ʽRecognition of Palestine would help to preserve the two-state solution’, which is the policy of all responsible political parties in Europe. ‘It would reward and encourage moderation’ on both sides. This does not come from what my Conservative friends sometimes call the loony left; it does not come from a raving anti-Semitic extreme right. It actually it comes from Sir Vincent Fean who served as British Consul-General in Jerusalem for four years. I cannot get a higher authority on that except possibly Alon Liel, a former Director-General of the Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs, who shares these thoughts. If we are worried, rightly, that the European Union is becoming lame, then actually we should be worried because we are making it lame, unless we vote immediately for the recognition of Palestine. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – The EU’s interference in Ukraine was close to causing war, and I do not see why it would do any good for this body to interfere in the arrangements that are already being made by major states. This business in Palestine/Israel has been going on for the best part of 2 000 years, and if the Roman Empire and Pontius Pilate could not solve it with their rather rougher methods, I do not see how this body can do much better. Why not leave it to the Americans, the British, the French and the Russians – the major powers – to settle this as best they can? It does no good for people in this Chamber to interfere in this.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: blue-card answer. – I am not sure what kind of answer you are expecting from me on that one, as Britain and France are actually Member States of the European Union, represented here in this very Chamber. That is one thing. The other thing is that, at the end of the day, if 135 states have already recognised the State of Palestine and this did not increase the violence, why would recognition by a few more Member States of the European Union do that? I cannot understand why it should.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Palestine – why should this state be born? Because it is an act due to the Palestinian people, but it is also in the Israeli interest; above all, it is an ethical, historical and political necessity, a master wall in the house of peace. But when we debate recognition in this House and someone subordinates it to peace, we must remind ourselves that these are two quite different situations. The recognition of a state is the responsibility of the international community; the peace process between Israel and Palestine, on the other hand, concerns their peoples. We must not get confused. That is why the preventive conclusion of peace would be useful, but it cannot be an essential condition.  The negotiations must be on an equal legal as well as a political basis. But recognising a State means giving it not only rights but also specific duties, because a true state must have a legitimate and democratic government, which guarantees the security of its territory and is capable of disarming sectarian and extremist organisations. The Palestinian people cannot do this alone. He needs our presence and experience, not just our money. We're their neighbors. If we do not assume these real responsibilities, we will deceive the Palestinians, we will deceive the Israelis and ultimately we will lie to ourselves. After 66 years we cannot downgrade this opportunity to a miserable attempt to wash our consciences. Before it, the future Palestinian State has two paths, the two extreme opposites of today's Islamic world: on the one hand, the lucidly fanatical absolutism of the so-called – and unfortunately also seductive, for many – Islamic State; on the other hand, the wonderful example of the Republic of Tunisia, which has begun brilliantly on the laborious path to full democracy. As a member of our delegation during its legislative and presidential elections, I can testify to this with my own eyes. That is why I hope that this Parliament will be able to pay tribute to the great effort, the great enthusiasm of the Tunisian people.  These are the two ways ahead. Staying in the status quo today is impossible. Which of these models will prevail in Palestinian society will also depend on our courage today, on our consistency in the years to come.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, at the moment some parliaments of European countries are taking decisions to recognise the Palestinian state. The Communist Party of Greece supports the palestinian people's fair request for recognition of the Palestinian state as a UN member state and for the recognition of the Palestinian state by the government and parliament of our country. The Communist Party's position is that the fight to end the Israeli occupation and to create an independent, viable and sovereign Palestinian state on the 1967 border, with East Jerusalem as its capital, must be strengthened. We must also tear down the unacceptable wall, free the political prisoners, end the settlements and leave the settlers with the return of all Palestinian refugees to their homes. In any case, we note that it is at least contradictory to have countries that recognise the Palestinian state while at the same time supporting the logic of the perpetrator and victim equation and upgrading their political, economic, military relations with Israel, either within the European Union or at bilateral level. This is an attitude that arms Israel, which continues its attacks on the Palestinians, which is expanding settlements and is destroying the Palestinian people. We express the internationalist solidarity and support of the Communist Party of Greece in the fair struggle of the Palestinian people.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to condemn the terrorist attack on the synagogue in Jerusalem last week and express my full sympathy for the victims. Secondly, I would like to remind you that the theme of recognition of the Palestinian state has recently been brought back to the agenda in some Member States, either as a result of the vote of resolutions on this in national parliaments (in the United Kingdom, Ireland, Spain, soon France and perhaps Denmark) or as a government action (sweden case).  As I said in Monday's procedural discussion, the European Parliament is divided on this issue. I think we have a fundamental divergence of views. Among the proponents of the immediate recognition of a Palestinian state, the prevailing view is that this unilateral act is in fact a tool to restart the flu-like engine of peace negotiations on the conflict in the Near East. Defenders of this vision argue that Palestine would thus have a better position in the negotiations. However, this view is, in my view, flawed, because it clears the negotiation process of content.  What good is it to negotiate, if one of the points we had to agree on, namely the existence of a Palestinian state, is already decided? I do not think that we serve at all, through such immediate recognition, the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, we are only dividing and antagonizing the two sides further and showing that the negotiations are unnecessary. For the EPP Group, the only solution to this conflict is indeed the coexistence of two states, Israel and Palestine. Recognition of Palestine, however, is only possible as a result of a negotiation process between the two parties in a comprehensive peace process.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President/High Representative, I would like to thank you from the outset for your balanced, pragmatic and, yes, so long awaited speech by the European Parliament. So far, our Union has been absent from this meeting with history. Members of the European Parliament are concerned about the increase in violence, acts of terrorism and condemn the recent loss of life in Jerusalem and the acts of terrorism that have underpinned them. The Group of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament takes note of the initiatives of some national parliaments to adopt motions in favour of the recognition of the Palestinian state and welcomes this. I appreciate that, in the current context, so tense and complicated, peace negotiations and recognition must go hand in hand. Recognition is a challenge and an opportunity, a leading Israeli leader told me recently, but also an additional step towards a solution. Our objective must be the existence of two equal, sovereign states that live in peace and in respect with international rules. Simple recognition is not enough.  Strengthening the viability and statehood of The Palestinian requires a common strategy of international actors – the European Union, the United States and the states in the region that you mentioned – but also financial and logistical aid to make this happen within a predictable horizon. The European Union must quickly become a major player who, together with the United States and the states of the region, will contribute to the relaunch of the peace process and its completion within a reasonable time horizon. Only then, through a lasting agreement and mutual recognition, including by the Arab states, of the Israeli state, can we guarantee the legitimate framework for the existence of the two states and peoples. And once again, I encourage you, Madam Vice-President: a European strategy for the Near East.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Mrs Mogherini, I would like to present you with a fundamental problem, if you will allow me. You were talking about the two-state solution. That does not, logically, presuppose a Palestinian state next to a Jewish state. The most recent Palestinian resolution of 30 September 2014, Section 3a, calls for the Palestinians' right to self-determination. Nothing wrong with that. But now it comes: to this day, the Palestinian Authority refuses to grant the same right of self-determination to the Jewish people in terms of the State of Israel! That will not help peace and a two-state solution. See the debate in Israel at the moment. My question is: how do you stand in it? Five years ago, I asked your predecessor, Baroness Ashton, that. It was silent in all languages. I hope that you will be more honest and that you will ask that question to the Palestinian side: 'How is that? You ask for something and you give nothing back! No reciprocity. Finally, and this really needs me, this is the third debate on the Middle East. We have had a summer in the context of the Gaza conflict full of anti-Semitism ... [The President deprives speaker of the floor.]

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr President, I appreciate that the Vice-President came early. We were not used to that from her predecessor, and I hope she will keep it up. Vice-President, you have been informed that we were unable to have a debate today with the draft resolution. In fact, although you were asking for input into your considerations, I am afraid you are seeing the reality, which is that this House is split. I do appreciate what you said, which is that, while you do not have sufficient competences in this respect, you do see this as your business. I also appreciate that you said there should be an attempt at a common approach in this respect. I think that, as with any other area in the European Union, whenever there is a deadlock – deadlock in the Council, deadlock in the Parliament – the Commission, and in this case the Vice-President and the High Representative, has a unique opportunity to provide leadership. That is what we would be looking for. You spoke of a draft – or input to a – common approach. We would very much welcome it if you came in the very near future with somewhat more detailed elements of this possible common approach. We would definitely be happy to debate it, and I am sure that this common approach can be based on what you have said. There will be no peace without a Palestinian State; there will be no Palestinian State without security for Israel. I had more points to make today, but you have taken them out of my mouth, which is positive. Please take this as a warm invitation to come forward with a draft, which I am sure might also facilitate the debate in the European Parliament. I hope that in December we will manage to come with a draft resolution and that colleagues from other groups will consider the draft on the table.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Mr President, the decision of more and more states to recognise the Palestinian state sends a positive signal of support for peace and support for the Palestinians' fight against occupation. Unfortunately, the EPP and Conservative political groups did not allow the same message to be sent by the European Parliament, as they voted against the right of MEPs to adopt a resolution calling for the recognition of the Palestinian state. The European Parliament has a duty to support the fight for the creation of an independent, viable and sovereign Palestinian state, on the 1967 border, with East Jerusalem as its capital, a state whose people will decide, a state that exists in peace and security next to Israel. The situation in the region is becoming increasingly dangerous. The logic on which the Oslo Agreement was built in 1993 has unfortunately been blown up by Israel's aggression and by the expansion of settler settlements. Then many try to convince us that this is a religious conflict between Palestinians and Israelis. But reality proves otherwise. The occupation of the territories that Israel has seized by war continues, the problem of the return of refugees remains unresolved, settlers are increasing, the wall of human rights is being maintained, Israel's attacks on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip are continuing, which is still blocked. The GUE Group will continue to support efforts to recognise the Palestinian state. But we also expect the European Parliament to enlist in solidarity in support of the palestinian people's struggle to end the occupation and for liberation and to support efforts for lasting peace in the region.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Mr President! The situation in Israel and Palestine is deteriorating day by day and there is no indication that the Israeli Government wants peace. Contrary! It is now proposing an outright apartheid law and there are constantly more settlements being built, now at full speed in East Jerusalem, too.  So far, neither the United States nor the European Union has tried to stop this dangerous madness, and now Jerusalem is becoming a war zone. And so it is not just because of the horrific violations of the Islamic Shrine of Al-Aqsa on the Temple Mount.  The EUROPEAN Union must and can act quickly and properly.  Let us listen here to the representatives of the 730 prominent Israelis who are in Strasbourg today to call us out. They call on us to recognise Palestine. Such recognition will give hope to the Palestinians and can avert desperate violence. Recognition is an essential condition for the negotiations between Israel and Palestine to take place on fair terms and, therefore, to get off to a good start at last.  Recognition must be now! To make it conditional on peace negotiations is to give Israel a veto, which is both stupid and very immoral: to impose conditions on the occupied rather than the occupiers! Where else in the world is the EU so unfair? Nowhere, hopefully. So stop here too! Respect for human rights and the international legal order must apply everywhere, especially in a democracy which I still consider Israel to be.  So-called friends of Israel in the conservative group managed to postpone the vote in this House until next month. But they are Israel's worst friends. The true friends are those who help Israel to a dignified survival. It requires a just two-state solution and ensures peace in Israel with its neighbours, which the Arab initiative has offered time and time again, and it gives Palestine hope and future. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question, see Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. - I'd just have a simple question. What does your belief that recognition of Palestine will lead to lasting peace?

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: blue-card answer. – If we do not create equal conditions so that two equal partners are negotiating, there is no chance of getting real negotiations. I cannot guarantee anything, but I can guarantee to you that, if you do not recognise Palestine and give it a chance to act as a real partner, there will be no true negotiations, as we have seen from Israel not delivering up to now.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: Once again, last week's terrible attack on innocent, praying civilians at the Jerusalem synagogue proves the ruthless, violent nature of the Palestinian Authority's terrorist regime.  A Palestinian State is nothing like IS, the Islamic caliphate. There is no struggle for freedom from Palestinians. There is only violence by Fatah and Hamas in the name of a barbaric ideology. Those who wish to recognise a Palestinian State legitimise terrorism, legitimise anti-Semitism and legitimise crimes against humanity. Anyone who thinks that recognition of a Palestinian state brings peace in the Middle East closer is blind. This recognition will be celebrated by Hamas and Fatah as an acknowledgement of their claim to the whole of the Holy Land, as an acknowledgement of their anti-Semitic purpose of killing all Jews in Israel. Let all those so-called Palestinians from Gaza, Judea, Samaria return to their homeland of Jordan. Anyone who wants to recognise a Palestinian State will expose himself as an anti-Semite. I call on the European Commission to immediately stop all EU financial support to the Palestinian Authority, to strongly condemn recognition of a Palestinian State and to fully recognise the right of the Jewish people to pray on the Temple Mount.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen: Eyal Yifrah, Gilad Shaar, Naftali Fraenkel, Muhammad Hussein: four boys torn from their lives by religious extremism that has led the two sides to no longer talk to each other. There really does not seem to be room for a transformation of thought that leads the two sides to recognize each other, to approach, the only prerequisite for a real path that leads to peace, to the acceptance of the other as a neighbour – perhaps not as sympathetic as possible – without achieving the profound desire to annihilate it. In this context, we have recently received a proposal – suddenly, without debate – and we have suddenly had to discuss a motion on the recognition of the State of Palestine. A motion that does not actually help the peace process because we are not developing a real, high debate, we are not telling Palestine and Israel what their reciprocal rights and duties are. But suddenly Parliament found itself with this subject and the Conference of Group Leaders did well to postpone the debate. It would probably be appropriate for us to postpone it any longer, for us to come to the final vote on this motion when we are fully aware of the concrete results, of what the recognition of a State means, which is not only the recognition of rights but also, and above all, the recognition of duties.  So let the European Parliament take all the time it needs; every Member of Parliament is informed, he builds his or her own convictions. Long live the experience as Commissioner Mogherini told us. Make a conviction of yours and then we will come back here to give our indication. We have no need to run, probably slowing down the peace process.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul As a Swede, I am proud that my government has recognised the State of Palestine. But Sweden is certainly not the first, just a link in a long chain, and that chain must become longer and stronger. With the recognition by the EU of the State of Palestine, we are also opening the window of opportunity that is now there suddenly before our eyes. Recognition would help Israel and Palestine to live side by side in peaceful coexistence. A peace agreement and a two-state solution would be facilitated if the parties to these negotiations were less unequal. The criteria for the recognition of the State of Palestine under international law are met. The international community has judged Palestine to be stately. Not recognising Palestine on the grounds of israeli occupation would be contrary to the principle of international law if no right out of an injustice. Eu Member States reaffirmed their readiness to recognise the State of Palestine as appropriate in 2009. The question then is: when is it appropriate? Yesterday or today or very soon? In view of the very difficult situation in the region and the high level of conflict and in the light of the analysis of international law, there is no reason for undue delay. We should take decisions on recognition. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: question ("blue card").
