Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to ask Mrs Ulvskog in the light of the fact that we in this House and in government institutions often talk about the importance of a common strong European foreign policy. Given that we say that it is only by acting together that we can influence foreign policy globally, I would like to ask Marita Ulvskog – given that the Swedish Social Democrats have on several occasions stated that they support this objective – the question is therefore: how is the action now in line? Unilateral action with the aim of Europe speaking with one voice.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Colleague, I am very sorry, but the blue-card system is there to ask a question, not to make a speech and then ask a question. Please stick to that.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: answer ("blue card"). Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I am grateful to the President for instructing Mr Adaktusson on how to do this. My answer to Mr Adaktusson is that, of course, it is every country, each Member State, that decides on recognition. However, such a strong mark as we would make from Parliament on this issue – to show that we are united – would be of great importance to Palestine, to Israel and to the High Representative, who has made an excellent impression here about where she stands and how she will deal with this issue in the future. I firmly trust the High Representative.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Madam Vice-President, you have said it: there is a lack of political perspective. The result of this frustration is that there is indeed increasing pressure in several Member States to move to unilateral recognition of Palestine. This debate is also raging in my own Member State, Belgium. It is clear to us that the right to self-determination of the peoples also applies to Palestine. That principle is an important principle for my party and also for myself as a Fleming. But the only way there is that of politics and diplomacy. And recognition without a negotiated peace agreement will undermine further talks for a balanced two-state solution that guarantees the security of Israeli and Palestinian citizens. You said that the EU could be the first political player to start the dialogue. Well, we would like to encourage you to stop being content with the role of lender, but to be a real actor in the political, humanitarian and security areas.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Mr President, thank you also to the Vice-President for the clarity and also the shared empathy of your opening remarks. That changes us a little bit. Since we have been debating this issue, the opposition and our differences are obviously known here. However, as we can hear in this debate, there are many observations and feelings that we actually share, starting with evidence that has been repeated: the status quo is not an option. De facto, however, the negotiations are at a standstill, a situation that obviously continues to cause frustration and leads to a hardening of postures, such as this law on the Jewish character of the State of Israel, counterproductive even in the eyes of the President, as the policy of implantation that continues but also like this violence, again and again, that of Fatah which does not control its armed factions , that of Hamas militias and the attacks, including the one in Jerusalem.  Something has to move, we agree on this point, but not on this, at least not according to this schedule. Let us be clear, it is the timetable that I do not accept, nor this unilateral and unconditional recognition which will inevitably freeze any ability of the Palestinians to compromise afterwards, nor this recognition, today, of a State that is not one of them. Two governments, two entities, one of which is a terrorist movement and recognized as such; how are we going to get around that reality and how can we also accept that we are granting this status today to those who refuse to recognize the State of Israel?  I am convinced, Mrs Mogherini, that there is no alternative. Our role is to bring the partners of peace back to the negotiating table, but not to raise banners that would jeopardize the future.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, I thank you for your words and I salute your courage. The vote on a clear resolution of our Parliament recognizing the Palestinian state would be a strong act, an act for peace and justice. Israel has its state and its security must of course be guaranteed. But what is missing today is a state for the Palestinian people. The debate we have today stems from the impasses of the Oslo process and, therefore, from the need that we now do it differently and to build on international law, namely UN Security Council Resolution 242 of 29 November 1967, which recognises the territory of the Palestinian State with its capital , East Jerusalem, and Resolution 1860 of January 8, 2009, which confirms this. Only Israeli leaders do not recognize this right, whereas contrary to what has just been said, the PLO and the Palestinian Authority recognize and have recognized the State of Israel. As soon as Palestine becomes a member of the General Assembly of the United Nations, it would be treated on an equal footing, from a legal point of view, in the negotiations that the European Union, the United States and the Arab League should accompany.  Beyond our differences in this Parliament, let us produce this act, let us vote on such a resolution, let us stand on the side of the 137 states that have already recognised the Palestinian state! This is also in the interest of the Israeli people, whose citizens' movements, women's movements, are calling for this state.  Let us return to our role as actors for peace and security in the Middle East (The speaker agrees to answer a question "blue card" (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I would like to ask, when Mr Le Hyaric spoke about the contribution to peace by recognising a Palestinian state, whether he believes that such an act of recognition would lead to a halt to the firing of rockets from civilian objects from Palestinian territory to Israel, that it would lead to a halt to the construction of terrorist tunnels towards Israel, etc.?

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear colleague, these are always the same questions in black or white.  I am against the rockets you are talking about, but the ones that are occupied today are the Palestinians. The people who are taken from the land, the water and the territories are the Palestinians. The ones who are sent the most sophisticated weapons in the world on their heads are the Palestinians. Therefore, let us constantly stop looking for pretexts not to move forward on the road to peace. What I am proposing is that here we should take, together across our differences, a symbolic political initiative, certainly, but which would strengthen the position of the High Representative, so that we can finally recognise this State. Why are some states recognized and not this one? That's the question I'm asking.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul I am also proud that Sweden has recognised Palestine and that it has given ripple effects. That was our idea. I am convinced that we can only move forward in the peace process if there is a possibility of reaching a two-state solution before it is too late. With strong pressure on the Israeli Government. Broad recognition of many EU states is such a lever. But Israel is not just its government. There is an Israeli opposition that is also asking us to recognise Palestine. It is the peace movement, of course, but it is also former Israeli ambassadors, legal chiefs, scientists, directors-general, etc. We should listen to them too.  And those who have not yet decided whether or not they want us to vote in favour of recognition, I would urge you to actually travel to Palestine and Israel. To visit Hebron together with the organization Breaking the silence, which are Israeli soldiers who tell what the reality is. It's an experience you won't forget.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for her work on I was pleased with the refreshing words you said here in this Parliament after your trip to Gaza, and also to the fact that you are finally starting to break up old structures of a unilateral pro-Israel policy, which has not produced peace in recent decades. So, after 193 of 195 countries opened the door to recognition in the United Nations General Assembly in 2012, now that the position of Europe's countries such as Spain, Great Britain, Sweden and Ireland has clearly taken a stand that we want to overcome this status quo, that Belgium, France and Denmark will soon follow suit, it is time for the european community of states to send a signal here. to make new negotiations possible. The Palestinian people have had to pay for it with occupation, division, destruction of property and infrastructure, expulsion and a heavy toll of blood. Ladies and gentlemen, in December, you will have to decide, by voting on the resolution, whether the violations of international and human rights committed by the State of Israel will continue to be sanctioned or whether this injustice will restore Palestine to its right with your vote in favour of recognising Palestine.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, this debate, like others taking place in several Parliaments in several Member States these days, seems to me to be a sign of the level of impatience and unease that is causing the jam, the blockade of the peace process. There are many years of uncovering and conflict; there are many initiatives, many mediation and negotiation efforts, the last and very intense of Secretary of State Kerry; there are many acts of violence and clashes, for example, what happened in Gaza this summer; and there are many hateful terrorist attacks, such as last week's in the Jerusalem synagogue. After all these long and violent years we are faced with a situation of fed up and concern, without a horizon of a close solution. It is urgent to promote a genuine peace process, with which the parties are truly committed. Unilateral acts must be avoided to hinder this process, for example settlements— which the entire international community rejects. The objective of the negotiations must be the solution of the two States living in peace, security and prosperity. Today, here, as in other Parliaments , among others, recently the Spanish Parliament - we are debating the recognition of Palestine. On this subject, what I want in this forum is to insist that there be rigorous European coordination that demonstrates that there is a genuine European foreign policy. We should not repeat what happened, for example, at Unesco. Ladies and gentlemen, it is not for this Parliament to recognise States, obviously, but to declare that serious peace negotiations are urgently launched and that the European Union is involved in them. In this regard, I welcome Mrs Mogherini's commitment and I also hope for good coordination with the indispensable power on this point, which is the United States. We are living through very difficult times in the region, as the ISIS challenge is posing enormous problems in Syria and Iraq. Frank, robust, genuine israeli-Palestinian negotiations will create a space for dialogue and hope for peace throughout the Middle East, which is currently plunged into a sea of violence, intolerance and frustration.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, first of all, I would like to echo your opening speech and tell you what are the important points that our resolution will have to include. First of all, as you said, it is a question of highlighting the important role of the European Union, that is, being a major player of choice in the region. Therefore, we will have to make clear our desire to recognize the State of Palestine in order to contribute to the coexistence of two states: the State of Palestine and the State of Israel. There will necessarily also be clarifications to be made on territorial boundaries, colonization, the status of the Gaza Strip, Jerusalem, the capital of both states. We will also have to indicate that we are not alone in this will and this search for peace, we have with us Egypt, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, the United States, the Arab League , as you have also said , and, of course, we must make sure that we ask the United Nations Security Council to take this will and this research into its own hands.  Why recognize the State of Palestine? There are places where symbols matter more than others, and I believe that the European Parliament is one of those places. Our political duty is to bring about peace in the Middle East and, therefore, the coexistence of these two states. In conclusion, I would just like to recall this beautiful phrase from Mahmoud Abbas: "There is not one state too many in the Middle East, but one is missing".

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Firstly, I must say that we are debating this issue at all in the European Parliament. Unfortunately, I say with regret, the European Parliament is once again breaking into things that, frankly, are none of its business. On a subject as delicate as this, each State should have the right to set its own line, to act on its own national interests, and the European Parliament should not determine or recommend any solution in this regard. He's going through his own powers, and that's the only way he's going to complicate the situation.  Secondly, on the subject itself, it must be said here that part of the Palestinian representation is progressing through violence and terrorism, that it makes no secret of the fact that it wants to destroy the State of Israel, and that is simply unacceptable.  I want to hear here that the European Union will not support these people, that it will not provide them with any funding, and that it will not take any steps to create false hopes in them. I think that is more important and that this is the content of our debate.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Dear President, Honourable High Representative, First of all, I would like to thank you for being honest, open, and I would also like to say a very lucid performance, even with sufficient confidence. I would have liked you to remain like this throughout your term. I would also like to support you when you mentioned the Initiative of the Arab States, the Peace Initiative. I think we will have to go back to this document as one of the basics and a framework for a peaceful solution to the problem. We, here in the European Parliament yesterday, postponed the position on the recognition of a Palestinian state. I would say that it is more than obvious that politicians are lagging behind their own public and for voters who want faster peace in the Middle East, faster solutions, lasting security solutions, both for Israel and for its Arab neighbours, and for us. The status quo is unacceptable, leading to an escalation of violence, the courageous ness of the Israeli government and the humiliation of the Palestinians. The recognition of a Palestinian state at the moment may not be the only, perhaps not optimal move, but it will help to create the dynamics of the process that stands now. If Israel and the Palestinians want to do so, this dynamic will lead to a solution. Finally, I would like to inform you that on Friday the Slovenian Parliament will also be debating the recognition of Palestine, and I can personally say that I am optimistic about this that I expect Slovenia to go down this path.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Mrs Mogherini, I would first of all like to thank you for your presence here and for the proposal you make. A proposal to be perceived has to be clear and simple, and its was very clear and was very simple: a two-state system, 1967 borders and with Jerusalem as the capital. It's not an innovation, it's the United Nations proposal, and we've been discussing it for a long time, but I want to thank you for your proposal. In any case, the recognition of a State implies having to have other elements, right away ending the occupation. The European Union does not recognise the occupied territories, it must not truly recognise them, and not continue to act as if they did not exist. It also implies self-determination, it implies fighting so that no arms are sold to the oppressive state. You have to work in all dimensions.  I applaud your initiative, Mrs Mogherini, but I tell you, without paternalism: Keep fighting for it. Because if not it is as the poet would say: the truth has two faces and the snow is black after all.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: Mr President, I would like to add my own congratulations to the High Representative’s very lucid opening remarks. This century-old tragedy has its roots in empire. My own country, Scotland – and indeed the UK – has a bounden moral duty of obligation to the peoples of this region. Statehood has long been promised, and this is not a new discussion. Going right the way back to 1917, Balfour, a Scotsman, contemplated two states in the Balfour Declaration. The UK’s own White Paper of 1939 read ‘the objective of His Majesty’s Government is the establishment within 10 years of an independent Palestine State’. In Scotland today we support recognition, government and parliament, alongside many other countries. To those that say that negotiations with Israel should not be circumvented and that now is not the right time, I say: no, enough. That line has been used to give Israel a veto over the whole process for too long. We need to change tack, colleagues. There is no peace process worth the name. Israel’s policies account for the lion’s share of that failure, alongside our own hypocrisy and inaction. We must recognise Palestine urgently.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, in international law, a state is a population, a territory, a government and legal recognition that sanctifies and sees it.  Against the recognition of such a state for the Palestinian people, a number of my eminent colleagues have said that perhaps we could consider returning Palestine to Jordan. But the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan has long since abandoned its rights to the West Bank. In these conditions, what can be done? Can we be satisfied with the status quo? I have heard from a number of our colleagues who say that recognition of the Palestinian state will not be enough to restore peace. It is obvious, but will maintaining the status quo be enough to restore peace? I am quite surprised, moreover, because I have heard from Czech, Polish colleagues from countries which, for a very long time, have been occupied by others, and in an extraordinarily painful way often, and have had great difficulty in having their independence and sovereignty recognized but who are very hostile to the recognition of the same independence when it comes to the Palestinian people.  I will, of course, be objected to terrorism, which is quite reprehensible, but it is clear that terrorism feeds on despair. I will be objected to the lack of recognition of Israel by the Palestinians but, as I know, this recognition took place in 1993 and even Hamas recently placed itself under the banner of the government of Mr. Mahmoud Abbas.  I fear, especially for Israel, that it is too late. If Israel does not negotiate now, if we did not want to negotiate with the Palestinian government, we have Hamas. If we don't negotiate with Hamas, we'll have the jihadists.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, I believe that we must bear in mind two facts. First, for decades, the conflict between Israel and Palestine has served as a pretext for terrorism and a breeding ground for fundamentalism. Second, on both sides, the victims are mostly civilians.  The basis for a solution is well known - you pointed out them: two states within the 1967 borders, Jerusalem as the capital of both states and the security of Israel guaranteed. Today, we must act. The windows of opportunity for a comprehensive and lasting solution are dwindling with each outbreak of violence, including the latest - this attack in a synagogue - and lead to radicalization on both sides.  My personal experience and the contacts I have had with the leaders of the two peoples make me say that a solution is possible on the merits and that the major problem is a problem of mutual trust or rather a lack of mutual trust between the interested parties, especially for the implementation of a possible solution. I believe that in this area, the international community and Europe, in particular, both have a role to play. The European Parliament has no jurisdiction to recognize a state, but we must act and you must act, we are counting on you for that.  Mrs Mogherini, what concrete initiatives do you envisage and how soon do you intend to take them with both the Israeli and Palestinian authorities and with the leaders of the Arab States you mentioned, which I think can be one of the keys to the solution, ensuring that the commitments that will be made are respected?

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Mr President, thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for your work and for your commitment. I am very proud that Spain has decided by an almost unanimity of the House to recognize the Palestinian state. Because you have listened many times, and you will have said it too: Europe is going slowly, Europe is not present as a political player in the region. I think we're late. We're late to find a solution that's decent and fair. And we have to remember in this debate that there's an occupant, right? There's an occupant and there's a busy town. And the occupant has responsibilities over the safety and life of those whose territory he occupies. I agree with the consensus. I think it's very important to this issue. But consensus can't be an excuse to keep doing anything, to stay standing here. We need to move. We need to keep ourselves in mind. And, moreover, Palestine is already a state. It is a state with a territory, with a government, with a Parliament. It is a state that it is time for all of us to recognize now.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I am speaking as a member of a country that was once also the home land of many millions of Jews. Warsaw – from where I was chosen – was the largest concentration of Jews in Europe before the war. Unfortunately, this centuries-old symbiosis of Poles and Jews was interrupted by the crime of the Holocaust committed by the Germans – carried out mainly on Polish soil. Today Poland is also a great cemetery of Jews. And that is why the security of the Jewish people is so important to us. I believe that the premature unilateral recognition of a Palestinian state does not serve this security well. On the other hand, it is clear that further Israeli-Palestinian dialogue must be promoted. Thank you.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, the European Union's timid and undermining policy has been sealed by the latest tragic events in Gaza. Today, the Union seems to be taking an essential step, although it is some 60 years late. Recognition of the Palestinian State creates a new regime and mandatory commitments for the European Union.   ・ ; ・ ・ .®  ・Æ・¿ ・ .  ・ , ・ .®  ・ ・® ・ The Commission's report is based on the results of the report, which is based on the results of the 2014-2013 financial year.  ・ . ・ . ・ .

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on Monday evening you decided to postpone the vote on a resolution recognising the Palestinian state. Is that serious? Is there still time to hesitate when each passing day further reduces the possibility of a Palestinian state. What are you afraid of? A week ago, I was at the United Nations to say how much we are aware that, on the road to peace, the recognition of Palestine is the first urgency to be realized. The international community looks at us and tells us how much we parliamentarians have a role to play in pushing heads of state to reopen dialogue. One hundred and thirty-five states, the English, Irish, Spanish, Swedish and, perhaps tomorrow, French parliaments are taking the plunge. What about us? Palestinians and Israelis continue to need our support.  Let's show that we are capable of breaking walls! The two-state solution was too late. In this Chamber, let us recognize that there is not one too many states in the Middle East, but that one is missing! Let us have the courage to recognize the State of Palestine! Let us show that, through our political will, a just and lasting peace is possible!

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, the UN General Assembly in 2012 approved the upgrading of the Palestinian Authority to a state as an Observer. This upgrading of the international status of Palestine from entity to non-UN member state, a regime similar to that of the Vatican, gave Palestine a birth certificate. In the last two years, however, all we have noticed is an increase in Israel's aggression, thousands of raids and massacres of civilians, a continuation of occupation of the Palestinian territories and a continuation of their settlement. There is no doubt that the law is on the side of the Palestinians, who are fighting, although not always in the most cadet ways, to gain the right to a homeland of their own, even if it has now shrunk to 22% of its original area. Many experts have tried all this time to find solutions to stop the carnage at some point; I don't know. War operations, rather than diminishing, are thickening. But the Palestinians deserve a state of their own, and that is not my observation, but a demand of 135 countries that have recognised that state. Many years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, it is, if anything, foolish to discuss today whether we will continue to allow Israel's policy in the Gaza Strip. In other words, a people who remind us at all times of the genocide they have suffered does not hesitate to do the same to a people who only ask to have a state. History is rather repeated not as a faithful copy, but as a reminder of the respect that peoples must have with each other.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: Mr President, Vice-President Mogherini, I would like to thank you for your general approach to the issue as well as for the mood , if I may say — with which you have come to Parliament, as you reiterated by saying that you came to listen. It is true — and you said this and some Members have reiterated this — that this Parliament has no competence in the recognition of States, but as the mayor of Barcelona says , and I like to quote it , it is important for a political manager to know what is within his competence and what is his responsibility. And the Middle East is the responsibility of the European Parliament. More than not, to those who have complained here today that we should let states do their job and that the European Union should not meddle, perhaps it is good to reflect that, after so many centuries of state failures in managing the conflict in the Middle East, it would perhaps be appropriate for the European Union to be given the opportunity to seek peace where states have already demonstrated their failure. The recognition of Palestine as a state, subject to international law, can never be perceived as a decision agreed against Israel, a state to which I hold high esteem and to which I will always defend against those who deny it its right to exist. I am convinced that, after so many years of conflict in the Middle East, the only possible solution is the peaceful and negotiated coexistence of two states, Israel and Palestine. I am convinced that such coexistence is possible, but this end will only be achieved if negotiation and dialogue are given an opportunity, if it is accepted that the past must stop dictating the present and let us prepare for the future.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Mogherini, in the meantime, I wanted to thank you for your visit to the Middle East at the beginning of your term of office. Starting from there to try to resolve a conflict that is at the basis of the countless problems we have in the region is decisive. However, as you know, the way is not easy and, as we can imagine, the problem is not simply that of recognising the Palestinian State – even if the subject exists, as it does exist – but above all that of what we can do so that the peace negotiations, which are still still negotiations today, can really proceed.  There's not much time. I hope, as you say, that there will be a new awareness between the parties, but I fear that extremism in Israel, as well as in Palestine, may prevail and permanently close the spaces for dialogue. So if the key issue is the resumption of negotiations, then what can we do to achieve all this, beyond diplomatic action? A lot, I think. We can and must act on all the instruments at our disposal, including economic, financial and commercial instruments. We are the main donor to the Palestinian Authority. The European market is by far the first market for Israel and its exports. We should use these two levers to exert the necessary pressure and to force negotiation and its successful conclusion.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: Mr President, [no sound] … quite correctly observed when Europe does not anchor itself firmly to its values, it sets itself adrift. We have much of which to be proud in our history, but the burned scars on children in Gaza have left a permanent imprint on the minds of our citizens and are now permanently etched on our humanity. Far too many of our governments have been caught off guard and out of step with public opinion: rushing to provide denials as Europeans watched the horrors inflicted on innocents unfolding second by second, their suffering and hopelessness capturing the European conscience, pleading for calls of ‘never again!’ Today our parliaments are reflecting that public mood, one after another lining up to state clearly that the time has come to give the Palestinians a state and a homeland in order to protect them. There should be no parliament from where that call should be louder or clearer than the European Parliament. Madam Vice-President of the Commission, you quite clearly have recognised the urgency we feel that this matter should be dealt with, yet illegal settlements continue as we sit here debating. A failure to do all in our power to end such horrors so that this should never happen again is to unanchor Europe and set ourselves adrift from our values and our humanity. Madam, be innovative, and this Parliament will be with you. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8)).

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Karim, we are always talking about Israel and gaza and the West Bank. Is it always the Israelis who are responsible, who are basically threatened with permanent annihilation by the Palestinians, especially Hamas? What about the relationship between the Palestinians and the Arabs? As far as I know, all the Arab states have renounced support for the Palestinians since Arafat spoke out pro-Saddam Hussein in the early 1990s. Why not appeal to the friends of the Palestinians before appealing to a state threatened with permanent annihilation?

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: blue-card answer. – In my remarks I very clearly referred to the ‘innocents’. There are innocents on all sides. The fact that we are seeing young children being subjected to the sorts of horrors which are completely unimaginable ought to awaken the humanity in all of us. That is where Europe must once again pin its values and pin the hopes of the citizens of Europe, who today want us to come forward with a positive, momentous action programme. That is something to which I believe our High Representative was referring today, and for that you will have our support.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: Mr President, look, I cannot stand the wrongdoing in the debate on Palestine. I can't stand her. Desmond Tutu said it a lot better than I did a moment ago. He said, "If you are neutral in situations of injustice, you have chosen the oppressor's side." A while ago it was said that why the European Union should intervene in matters that are not its own. Does the European Union not intervene when it maintains a preferential trade agreement with Israel by ignoring the article on the fulfilment of human rights contained in that same agreement? Doesn't the European Union intervene when its members sell arms to Israel? As part of the international community, should the European Union not enforce all United Nations resolutions on the territory, including 194 on the return of refugees, including 242 on the withdrawal of occupied territories? And we were still talking about the recognition of the State of Israel. It's impressive. Today the situation shouldn't, it couldn't be worse. And this is because of the invaluable complicity of the European Union, of whom we are here. Symbol of this complicity is Durcao Barroso collecting an award at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem in occupied territories.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when I was a child, the issue of Palestine had been going on for some time, and I had hoped that it would be a short-lived issue. I now find myself as an MEP and we are still discussing the issues concerning Palestine and Israel. But then we who talk a lot, who give lessons to the whole world, have not been able to solve this kind of problem and it really makes me think that then it is a little difficult to teach others when we are not able to bring home a result.  For example, the agreement with Palestine and Israel cannot be unilateral, it must be bilateral, it must be directed between Palestinians and Israelis, because otherwise it would only come out that Palestine is given a great role and at the same time Hamas is rewarded, and for what I have seen Hamas is only a terrorist action, which very often resembles the actions of the Nazis. And then I wonder about the Palestinians and Arafat's money: how did Arafat make all this money? Who took this money from, where did he put it and why didn't he help his people?

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Now that voices are being raised to follow the Swedish Government's decision to recognise a Palestinian state, there is reason to react.  The unconditional recognition is a signal that the outcome of negotiations can be achieved in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict without talks between the parties. This is contrary to the EU's fundamental view so far that bilateral negotiations are the only way to lasting peace and an independent Palestinian state. Against recognition, serious obstacles to international law also speak. Today, in fact, there is no Palestinian state. As a result, the criteria for recognition of the International Montevideo Convention are not met. The prerequisites for recognition are that a new State controls its own territory and has resolved any border disputes. That is not the situation today. Recognition of a state is not a gesture or a political endorsement in general. It is a statement of facts under international law. In this House, therefore, we must refrain from populism and from the irresponsibility of the spirit of the Swedish Government. In the name of decency, we as a Parliament cannot ignore the fact that the Palestinian territories are largely controlled by Hamas. Hamas' goal is to wipe out the state of Israel. By the EU, Hamas is branded a terrorist organisation.  The serious situation right now, when we speak, in the Middle East requires political responsibility and a Europe that acts together. What is at stake is a peaceful development based on negotiated negotiated negotiated negotiations between the parties and on fundamental values of international law and democracy. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Blue card question. – I would then like to ask my Swedish colleague whether he is inattentive to the fact that, for example, the UN said at the end of the 1940s that something should be Palestine; that we have talked about Palestine plenty of times; and whether he considers that it is in accordance with international law and justice that conditions be imposed on the occupied rather than the occupying power?

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: answer ("blue card"). Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr International law is clear in terms of the requirements for recognition and the fact that – wherever we stand on this issue – is that the criteria for recognition are not met. I think that is one of the most important objections to Palestinian recognition at the moment. That does not mean that we should not recognise Palestine when the time comes. But that time comes after there is a negotiated agreement between the two parties.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the High Representative for the priority she has given to this Israeli-Palestinian conflict from the beginning of her mandate. I would also like to thank the Member States which have already begun this recognition process.  Recognition of the Palestinian state is not a reward, it is simply a right. Recognition of the Palestinian state is not negotiated with an occupier. The recognition of the Palestinian state is for us the guarantee of a resumption of dialogue which, until today, has failed. It is also a breather for the two-state solution which has been defended so far by the Union. Recognition allows for more even negotiations between the two parties. But recognition is also more responsibility for the authorities and the Palestinian Authority.  The Union must play its part today. Parliament must support you, Madam High Representative, and that is what we want in this Parliament today. I also salute the hundreds of Israeli patriots who have signed this petition for the recognition of the Palestinian state. These Israeli patriots have the love of their country and know that this recognition is the best solution to guarantee the State of Israel.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! Which Palestinian state should we recognise? That of Hamas in Gaza or Fatah in the West Bank? I can understand the desire for a Palestinian state. But this step wants to be well thought out and, above all, prepared. The most important question to be answered in this context is: will this step lead to peace and stability in the Middle East, or would it not create a new breeding ground for even more unrest? Would Hamas abandon its stated objective of destroying Israel, or would it not be legalised in the form of the state and in the future and pursue its objective with the support of the European Union? It is important to make it clear that human rights must be respected, that the protection of minorities must be granted and, above all, that it must be clarified that the Palestinian state would be a democratic constitutional state. As long as these questions are not answered convincingly, as long as we have no guarantee that the new state is a democratic constitutional state, I can only warn against recognising a Palestinian state. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: blue-card question. – It is really horrifying to hear all these people talking about Israel as a rule-of-law state. Could you please tell me what Israel has to do with the rule of law when every now and then they keep killing innocent civilians, including children? What do they have to do with the rule of law when they rob other people’s land, in violation of all the United Nations and other international law regulations? They keep building settlements; they have summary killing and summary demolition of people’s homes. What does it have to do with the rule of law? Sir, would you please tell me what you mean by the rule of law, and why you support Israel, the state of child killers and land robbers?

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Madam President, there are two possibilities. Either you did not listen to me properly, or the translation is truly catastrophic. I did not even mention that Israel is a state governed by the rule of law. Israel is a state governed by the rule of law! That is a very different point. But I did not mention that in my speech. Madam President, this Parliament should take care of very different things. This Parliament should be concerned about what it really does, for example, not to support terrorism in Israel and Palestine. That is what this Parliament should be concerned about. To respond once again to your question with regard to the rule of law, I wanted the Palestinian state, if it is recognised, to be a state governed by the rule of law. And that has to be ensured beforehand, we can't try to do that on good luck.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: The recognition of the Palestinian state represents an elementary act of justice in the face of what has been the martyrdom of long decades suffered by the Palestinian people. Recognizing the Palestinian state, in accordance with UN resolutions, based on the borders of 66 and with capital in East Jerusalem, is the best way to relaunch peace negotiations. The two-state solution must be supported and implemented. Many personalities of Israeli society share this view. The European Union is one of the main donors to that region, it must use all its political and economic weight to end Israeli aggression and to help all Member States that have not yet done so recognise the Palestinian state in the name of the most basic human rights of the people.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul A two-state solution is necessary to achieve peace and stability in the Middle East. However, a two-state solution must be based on two states that recognise each other's right to existence, which can recognise each other's right to sacred borders and which can contribute to the rule of law and respect for human rights and freedoms.  If these demands are not made, then we run the risk of unilateral recognition without the ability to control their territory against terror, without the need to comply with human rights and freedoms, then that means an opening for terrorism. A two-state solution must never mean recognising terrorism, contempt for human rights and freedoms and contempt for the role of women in the society in which they live. Let us be clear that in the Middle East we are talking about today, we are seeing today a development of terrorism and violence and hatred on a scale that we have not seen before and which goes far beyond conflicts between Israelis and Palestinians. To accept, in this situation, the practice of terrorism by a part of a state, to drop the demands for a state to function as a state in this situation, undermines the chances of achieving a two-state solution that contributes to peace and democracy. We all know that Israel is living under constant threat of terror, war and violence, anti-Semitism of the worst kind. Not only from their closest neighbors, but from a wide range of movements. A two-state solution must mean creating security and respect for all people, for Israelis and for Palestinians. Therefore, demands must be made. We must never recognise terrorism. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I would like to ask my colleague when he believes that occupation can be a factor of peace in a region and when he believes that resistance can be called terrorism, the resistance of one people against the occupation that another people imposes on it.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card answer. – I can certainly tell my colleague that an occupation must end by having achieved peace and the recognition of peaceful cohabitation. But if you accept movements like Hamas, Hezbollah and the even worse extremes, I can assure you that they are not fighting for independent, democratic sovereign states. They are fighting for a society where people’s rights are humiliated. I do not want to have a Palestinian state that is in control of those who are today leading Gaza. I want a Palestinian state that can fulfil democratic obligations, that respects each and everyone. That is what it is our duty to secure and that requires a long-term process.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: Mr President, let begin by thanking High Representative Mogherini for the hard work that she is putting in to find a solution to this terrible problem in the Middle East. One hundred and thirty-five countries, including many European ones, have already recognised Palestine. Recently Sweden and the parliaments in the UK, Ireland and Spain followed suit. While this is progress, it is saddening that it took over 2 000 Gazans to die in the latest Israeli attack for Europe to start acting. Every nation deserves to be recognised, and the Palestinians have suffered immensely. It is a huge disappointment that the EU vote has been delayed. Every second wasted costs innocent lives. The greatest threat is the illegal settlements in Palestine, which continue to grow without account. The two-state solution is the only real chance for peace, putting both on an equal footing. Israeli citizens believe this too, and an Israeli petition in favour of this has been publicly handed over outside Parliament this evening. The EU must have a coordinated approach to ensure peace and security and stability for all. It is time to give the Palestinians some hope. I urge all of us to take the bold step forward and vote to recognise Palestine.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Mr President, since 1948 Israel has violated all United Nations resolutions as well as human rights and international law, and no European country has questioned its recognition. Recognition of the Palestinian state is a responsibility and moral obligation of the same countries that led to its partition in 1947. Otherwise, it would also mean Europe's weakness to become a peace-promoting agent. Recognizing Palestine will be a step that future generations will remember as Europe's decision to put themselves on the right side of history, something like what happened to apartheid in South Africa: the countries that held it are remembered with embarrassment today. Today the Sakharov Prize reminded us in this House of all that human dignity must be at the heart of all policies. Recognition of Palestine is a basic proof of the existence or not of the political will to seek peace and to be against injustice and illegality. (She agreed to answer two questions posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned South Africa. Do you not agree with the words of Nelson Mandela, who once said that he could not conceive of Israel withdrawing or giving up land if Arab states did not recognise Israel within secure borders? Do you not recognise that passing the motions that you want to have in this House will lead to a Government of Hamas, a terrorist organisation which does not accept the right of Israel to exist, and therefore there will be no peace?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I would like to ask my colleague whether she recognises the existence of an Israeli state? Who gives it the right to call aggression when Israel resists terrorist attacks?

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: "blue card" response. – It is often said that there is no blinder than the one you do not want to see. Whoever has one of the largest armies in the world, who is crushing the population, who are occupying territories, tearing down and destroying the homes of Palestinians and throwing them off their lands, not respecting and imprisoning women and children, as well as killing, is the aggressor. And, as the Founding Charter of the United Nations says, every occupied people has the right to defend themselves.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: I have listened carefully to you, Madam Vice-President, and I strongly support your courageous efforts towards a mutually agreed solution, for peace and coexistence in the Middle East. It is high time we were talking about the recognition of a Palestinian state here in the European Parliament.  I am aware of the sensitivity, as well as the urgency of wise moves. In my country, Slovenia, this week, we are deciding on further steps towards recognition of a Palestinian state. The Social Democrats have already taken this decision. The fact is, we want to establish two countries. Two safe countries that will guarantee peace in the region. It has been difficult and painful for decades to monitor violence, armed conflict, illegal construction, the constant violation of international law and human rights. Every innocent life, not one side or the other, hinders and exacerbates the search for a solution. I agree with you that we need a strong, common European message here, in the European Parliament. I have the hope that mrs Mogherini, with you, with your team, will achieve a two-state solution and their mutual recognition. It will be the only guarantee of peace in the Middle East.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, why do we have to recognise the Palestinian State? Not to weaken and hurt Israel, but to restore to it a force condemned to perish if it is only military. No state can survive as a democracy if it occupies land that is not its own. I believe that Israel finally needs to provide itself with borders that are not only legal but legitimate, that we cannot ask the Palestinians for endless subjugation, for the renunciation of statehood. That was also the case in Europe. Borders can be surmountable if not more contested.  Israel owes its birth to the black history of Europe, and we are jointly responsible for it. That is why it is important for this Parliament to make the gesture: to grant the Palestinians the redemption of a statehood. If the gesture is not made, the Israeli governments will feel a short relief, new wars such as the sleepwalking nationalisms that destroyed Europe in the name of an ethnicity or a land that is guiltily sanctised will fall back into ever-increasing wars.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with the point made by my fellow Members about the need to achieve a balanced position that achieves the broadest possible consensus within this Parliament, but I believe that this position must focus on the political issue of the recognition of the Palestinian State in a clear way. Some Israeli politicians, I am thinking of Hilik Bar of the Labour Party, think that it is Israel that should even take this action first, and I think they are right, for their own future.  At the same time, however, I believe it is essential that our document should be seen, once approved, as an act of greater legitimacy towards the Palestinian State in order to reopen negotiations with Israel. A position of Parliament cannot be interpreted as a recognition that denies the usefulness of the negotiations and the reopening of them by the Palestinians with Israel and vice versa. The negotiations are the only way to reach a definitive solution to the conflict with the necessary and fundamental intervention also of the European Union, which has fortunately fully successfully successfully obtained its strength and influence also thanks to Federica Mogherini in these first weeks.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, High Representative Mogherini, this debate expresses the exasperation of much of the European actors with regard to the degradation of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the entire region. Immobility is not an option and this resolution aims to help move all the Member States of the European Union towards recognition of the Palestinian state. But this recognition has to be mutual, because it is imperative that it is not one-way, but also behaves the wisdom and courage of Palestine to recognize the State of Israel, because it is the only way to contribute to a safe peace in which two democratic states, committed to international legality, can coexist. This certainly requires no commitment on the part of the European Union to encourage the creation of governance structures in a community that already exists as a people and is already based on its territory, but which also requires a determination to live at non-conflict and secure borders with a neighbouring State, an adjoining state and a democratic state , as is the State of Israel.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Mr President, the High Representative can clearly see that this is the most sensitive and most difficult foreign policy issue that the European Parliament has to tackle. To tell the truth, I am ambivalent. I do not know what the right decision is, because one thing for sure is that peace can only be achieved if and when Israel and the Palestinians are ready. For decades now, there has been frustratingly little progress in peace processes. Not because no one tried; we have seen many attempts by outside powers to initiate, to prompt, to cajole the two sides into settling their differences, but to no avail. And, by the way, it was mainly the United States and not Europe that, up until now, undertook those numerous efforts. The great number of victims on both sides over the past 40 years is a sad testament to the failure of many diplomatic attempts. To recognise the State of Palestine might bring the parties back to the negotiating table but, as I said, we cannot force them to make peace; only they can do this.

name: Vincent PEILLON
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, first of all, thank you for your commitment, we have been waiting for it for a long time. Finally, the Union is beginning to tackle an important problem! You are looking for peace and a political role for the Union, so you need credibility and unity. Let us be careful that this debate does not put us in the situation, which you knew a little when you went to Gaza, where we would lose our credibility, where we would be disunited. In Gaza, you saw it, you were able to enter it, the Palestinian government could not, in its own territory.  We are acting in this discussion as if the states or parliaments that encouraged the European states to take a position had the same position. It's not true! The French Parliament, the Swedish Parliament and the Spanish Parliament have different positions. The Union disagrees. In Spain, we are not talking about recognition and negotiation, but about negotiation and then recognition. You have to be careful to give strength to your action. Finally, 135 States have already made this recognition, and we have seen that this has not encouraged peace. We need to get out of the status quo, we will fully support you, but we need an initiative that, beyond recognition, is an initiative and a path to peace that takes both into consideration. There is a form of laziness in this initiative. Let us be careful that it does not divide the European Parliament, the European Union, and that it does not make us lose all credibility.

name: Boris ZALA
text: Mr President, Palestinian people deserve a sovereign state just as Israel has the right to live in peace. As a friend of Israel I support the recognition of Palestinian statehood. The move is not meant to undermine Israel’s position; on the contrary, its purpose is to rescue the two-state solution, which is the only alternative for Israel’s security. Today, after the failure of Kerry’s initiative, after violence in Jerusalem, it is time for the EU to assume more responsibility. Recognition of Palestine is a powerful diplomatic tool; we should use it wisely to help restart peace negotiations. Recognition of the Palestinians in the pre-1967 borders will strengthen all those Israelis and Palestinians who believe in the two-state solution. Mr Netanyahu may not like to hear it, but I am convinced that recognising Palestine could be one of the EU’s greatest contributions to Israeli security.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Mr. President, Madam High Representative, recognition of a Palestinian state should be the starting point of a new process, but it is also an act self-exprehensible. I do not see an independent Palestine as a new factor in the continuation of the long-standing conflict, but as an opportunity for a more effective search for a new peace settlement.  I say this as a participant and witness to the disintegration and establishment of states on European soil itself. Until the international community recognised the Republics of the former Yugoslavia as a new state, peace did not exist as an indication, although negotiations were very much, futile of course. Certainly the recognition of a Palestinian state must in no way be used to legalise a terrorist standoff with Israel, and guarantees should be sought in this regard. On the other hand, Israel's right to defend itself has often been abused and passed into the practice of state terrorism.    And something about us, the European Union and the European Parliament: as a so-called 'soft power' we need to face really hard choices from time to time. We have to do this for the sake of our prospects as a role model in the 21st century.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Personally, I do not share the views that are sharpening Israel and highlighting Palestine, we have to look at the problem in a comprehensive way. I would like to consistently warn against taking any unilateral action without consulting Israel. I would not want that move to disrupt, I would say, the very fragile current ceasefire between Israelis and Palestinians. I don't want people to die. I want peace to reign in the holy lands. There really must be two sides to this peace. I therefore agree with the view that the European Union is not the one to say that one state or another should be recognised, because then there will be a situation where there is a referendum in Spain and there are states from outside that recognise a state that we do not want to recognise.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 29 November, the UN celebrates World Day of Solidarity with the Palestinian people. After more than 60 years of waiting, the issue of the recognition of Palestine has finally become very topical for all european chancelleries. After Sweden, Spain, the United Kingdom and Ireland, France, Denmark and Belgium are also officially recognising Palestine as an autonomous state and subject to international law. Finally, therefore, the principle of 'two states, two peoples' and the principle of mutual recognition are being affirmed as conditions for the Palestinian people and the Israeli people to live in peace, security and democracy.  Europe must help to find a solution that meets the economic and humanitarian security needs of Israelis and Palestinians, working towards the resumption of the negotiation phase. The recognition of the Palestinian State can make a decisive contribution to peace in the Middle East. This issue is measured by the European Union's desire to become indeed an important and decisive player in the international political arena. In the meantime, good work and congratulations to Mr Mogherini on what he is doing.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, I support the recognition of the Palestinian State with the 1967 borders. Palestine has been an observer at the United Nations Assembly since 2012 and this recognition is an act of peace. It is based on negotiations, agreements and words to replace weapons and war. We prefer it to Israel's unilateral and violent acts of occupation. And in Europe, wars and brutal human rights violations made us understand the importance of peace. Mahmud Abbas used exactly this idea in 2012 before the United Nations Assembly. He convinced 138 countries, which Hamas's rockets did not get. Israel did not respond—as it usually is—and did not per cent multiply Palestine's desires for peace, and that is what it does with the violent aggressions it suffers and which we condemn without nuance. Let us help the chosen people understand that the Palestinians are their fellows, who are people, who are not enemies. Thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for all your efforts.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Mr President, it is time for politics, as ploY exponent Saeb Erekat has said. And recognition of the State of Palestine is a way—the fairest—to move towards a precisely just and lasting peace. It is also necessary to modify the game board, to alter the correlation of forces and to make the dialogue possible. We need political audacity, facts on the ground and overcoming inertia. Recognition must also serve to give the Palestinian people the dignity they deserve at the international level. It's time to recognize the Palestinian state. It's time, because Palestine can't wait. Peace in the Middle East cannot wait.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, thank you very much for being here and for your attitude, above all. For the European Union to recognize the Palestinian state is just the beginning. It involves taking on a new active role in relation to the conflict that Member States have been unable to stop or re-produce for so many years. An active role not only humanitarian or condemning rhetoric. To summarize this role, we could use six verbs in telegram: one, reopen the borders; two, avoid or close new and previous settlements; three, systematically rebuild cities and facilities as many times as necessary; four, to sanction economically and politically the non-compliance and violations of United Nations resolutions; prohibit or limit, or in any event control, arms trafficking; and six, be present, be there, already send a delegation from this European Parliament to Gaza and, to some extent, adopt an attitude towards Palestine as if it were our protectorate. That I believe is the responsibility that the European Union assumes when it recognises the Palestinian state.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Mr President, this is a very serious situation, as we all know, and of course, we all want a fair resolution for both sides, and this can only be done through serious international diplomacy. I would suggest national diplomacy, but I do hope that everyone’s diplomacy works.  This is far too serious. It is too serious as well for gesture politics, and yet everywhere I go, at home and here, I see those on the Left making gesture politics: queuing up to expose their bleeding heart about this, and then not having the courage to take questions on the issue when someone wants to discuss it with them. Back in Dudley, where I come from, the Labour group is trying to make a motion to ban the purchase of goods from Israel – another absurd gesture. You cannot do these things; this is far too serious. Have some grown-up political thought for once, and allow the diplomats to do what is required. These are people’s lives and not just your gestures.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Dear Commissioner and my fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. Since the first intiface, in 2000, 125 Israeli children have been killed by this bloody conflict and 1,450 Palestinian children have been murdered by the Jewish state. You call Hamas a terrorist. I ask if it makes sense to conclude that if Hamas is a terrorist organisation, according to you, then the Jewish state can then be called a terrorist state without further anaming.  The question of how long the European Union wishes to have an associate partnership with a terrorist state makes sense. I ask you, Commissioner, do you not see the time to finally suspend, at least, the associated partnership with Israel, which is undoubtedly a terrorist state that kills children and constantly robs land. Thank you very much!

name: Ana GOMES
text: I've been here since the beginning of the debate. I asked for the word in catch the eye, I asked it in front of members who spoke in the meantime and therefore I wash here my protest as to the selection criteria of people in catch the eye.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Madam President, I have chosen one person from each political group, in the order in which they have come forward. The criteria are very clear and transparent. I ask Commissioner Mogherini to speak.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: Mr President, under our Rules of Procedure, the catch-the-eye procedure is supposed to be for individual Members, not for spokesmen of political groups. I know this because I was the rapporteur that introduced this into our Rules of Procedure many years ago. It is supposed to be for individual backbenchers, not spokesmen of political groups, and if you say you have taken one backbencher per political group, then that is discriminatory against the backbenchers from the large groups. It favours the backbenchers from the small groups and the non-attached Members. So that is not a correct application of the procedure.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: We have adopted these principles, we have done so in every debate, and it was not the intention of any of the Presidents of the European Parliament to discriminate against anyone. I gave the floor according to the reports, that is, the one who applied more quickly was given the opportunity to speak. Please, Commissioner Mogherini.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, honourable Members, let me thank you for this debate. I was surprised when I heard that many of you were thanking me – that is part of my responsibility and my role to be here. It is also useful for me being here and listening to this debate, but I will get to our institutional and political relationship at the end, when I will maybe touch upon the way forward, as some of you have rightly mentioned the need for joint work in the future. Let me start by saying very sincerely and from my heart that this debate this afternoon shows not only that this is, as some of you mentioned, one of the most difficult issues on foreign policy in Europe – I am afraid we might have many of those – but it is definitely not the easiest one to start with. However, on the other side, let me very frankly say that this debate this afternoon mirrors the debate that is there in the region, and this is worrying to me because I think that this debate this afternoon shows that our frustration, and even our sense of desperation, is deep, and that we risk being trapped in the false illusion of us needing to take one side. We could not make a worse mistake than this. You will never convince me – and I am sure that the majority of you in this House do not want to convince me – that you can be pro-Israeli without also being pro-Palestinian and that you can be pro-Palestinian without being pro-Israeli. The best way of helping the Israeli people is to build a Palestinian state, and the best way of helping the Palestinian people is to secure Israel’s security. We have the responsibility to facilitate the dialogue between two camps, and in the two camps to strengthen those that want dialogue and want and understand that they have to live together, share a land and share an interest. If we lose lucidity, if we lose our capacity not to be trapped within the conflict ourselves, we lose our possibility to play this role – and there are not many international actors that are able to play this role, so we are bearing with us a responsibility. In this conflict there are two things that are dangerous. The first, as someone said, is that it has gone on for too many decades. When I was born this conflict had already started. We are getting used to it, and this is dangerous. The second element that is worrying and is making things very complicated is that there is too much history and too little future in the debate. Barbara Spinelli was saying that we in Europe are somehow responsible. We bear a historical responsibility as Europeans for part of the roots of this debate, and so here it comes: a debate among us that mirrors the historical debate, sometimes going back hundreds of years, concerning how to get out of this trap. I will always remember one of the best conversations I had in the region, and that was not with politician but with a novelist, who told me that we are trapped in a bubble. We need someone from the outside to burst the bubble and let us out. And this is our role. This can be our role if we keep the awareness of the responsibility that we bear. It is not only a historical responsibility but, to me, it is a responsibility for the future. So I am – and I will always be – a friend of Israel and a friend of Palestine and will always work to show that this is the only way to be friends of both and of each of them. I would really like us to manage to develop this awareness together, because this is what the Israelis and the Palestinians need in order for us to convince them and to help them, as they are not friends. It is difficult, but at least it makes it possible for them to share their land and their future. What is our role? It is not interference. I heard someone say that we should not interfere and that it is not for the European Union to do anything about this. This is either for the Member States or we should leave them alone. Our role is also to take care of our neighbourhood, our region. These are our neighbours – for many of our Member States, many other countries and for us. It is our sea – the Mediterranean; the Middle East is close, and our relations with both the Palestinians, the Israelis and many of the countries that are concerned by the conflict are so strong that this is our business. Definitely so. So it is not a matter of interference but one of playing our role in a responsible and effective way. I heard many of you referring to the fact that we have to discuss the recognition of the state and discuss the negotiations. Still I feel that many of you might share my vision, which is that neither the recognition of the state nor even the negotiations are goals in themselves. The goal is having a Palestinian state in place and having Israel living next to it. Some of you have said that I do not have an answer, and maybe we all, as an international community, still do not have a complete answer about what are the right steps to take and in what order. I think the debate this afternoon reflects this very well – this questioning ourselves. What is the right order in which to take our steps? What is clear in my mind is that we cannot just sit and wait, because sitting and waiting is not keeping the status quo. Sitting and waiting is bringing us to the point where we close the doors to further negotiations and to the peace process. It is not going anywhere if we just do not do anything. It is getting worse and worse. What are the steps? In my opinion, and from what I have heard today, I see as an element of my future work to strengthen inside the two camps the political leaders and the communities – not only the political leaderships but also the communities, because society has a role to play here – that are committed and that are capable of delivering peace and working on peace. Elmar Brok mentioned the fact that not everyone – in Israel or in Palestine – wanted two states. We have to be aware of that, because more and more people, both on the Palestinian side and on the Israeli side, are talking about a one-state solution. We have to be aware of that. It has not come out here but it is coming out there. It might not be the case that our vision for the future will stay the same for decades. It is deteriorating for us as well. So first, find better ways to support those internally in the two camps that are committed and help them show their own public opinion that this path is delivering for their own public opinion. This is the big question mark that we have to find an answer to. What is the best way to strengthen and make credible the people who on both sides still believe that peace is possible there? Second, I believe, as some of you have recalled, that we have to work with the region. This sounds familiar today; it was not as normal only a few years ago, and that is why the peace initiative in 2002 did not go far. Now this is something we all agree on; we need to work with the countries and the region. Some of you, including Ms Alliot-Marie, have invited me and others to come back here with a detailed plan or even set it out today. I think it would probably not be serious enough from my side after three weeks in office to come to this Chamber and give you my detailed plan for peace in the Middle East. You would not believe me, and you would be right. What I can share with you today is the main political elements of the efforts that the European Union is making, which are the ones that I described in the beginning and some of those that I am underlining now, and a road map – although a road map with the Middle East is not really working – but a plan, a way, steps that we can work on, and the commitment to come back here in this Chamber and update you on the steps taken, given the fact that I believe the European Union has a role to play – but not alone. Because we have to be aware of the fact that, yes, we do have a role to play without necessarily sitting and waiting for others to call us to a table. We can initiate processes but we need to work with those international actors, starting with the United States and the Arab countries and the UN and the UN Security Council, to work together to restart a process. And I would mention here a country that no one in this room mentioned, but it is there in the UN Security Council and in the Quartet: Russia. Not for the sake of negotiations; this is another trap we have to escape. Negotiations are something good, because while we have a process going on, violence is less likely to happen. But I believe that we also run the risk of calling for negotiations again for the sake of the process, and this is eroding the credibility of the process itself. We need the process to bring a result, especially on the Palestinian side – but also on the Israeli side. The criticism about the process and the talks is: yes, but what does it bring to our people? We need to make sure that the process and the talks deliver something very concrete for both parts, not in the far future but immediately. In this framework we can discuss further, and we will do it. For sure you will do it here in this Chamber. We will do it also with the Member States and we will do it also with our partners internationally, because I believe that all our diplomatic efforts need to be made together with the others. I will mention another point that was raised by someone. We have two other challenges that are really European ones. One is anti-Semitism. I know you are working on that already, but I would be ready to work with you on that because I think we have a major challenge there that puts at risk our own sense of communities in Europe. And we have a parallel risk, which is that of Islamophobia, when we tend to associate in our societies Islam and terrorism or Arab societies and terrorism. We have to decouple the religious element and the political element, not only in the Middle East but also in Europe, and I think here we have a cultural and not only a political challenge that we could face. I know very well that, as the European Parliament is for me a central body of the European institutions, it also has its autonomy and I would respect it, so my attitude today and for tomorrow and for the next five years, as we share the period of mandates, is and will always be to share, to listen, to decide together, if not officially politically, but to respect your autonomy. The decision whether to take a vote on the resolution or not is your decision; it is not my decision and can never be my decision. I will always respect your decisions; I will always respect the outcome of your decisions and try to work together hand in hand. As someone was saying, I will also try to be as innovative as possible and hope that you can help me in this. I would invite you to use your power – which is not a little one, it is a big one – to support and shape this role of the European Union in the Middle East. I believe it is up to you to work on a united, strong and useful resolution or decision. (Murmurs of disagreement) I am sorry; I know that it is boring. But I think that you can leave if you are too bored. I think this would not just be a reflection of your debate; this could be a useful political tool for the European Union. So be aware of the fact that this is going to be, as many of you have mentioned, a real contribution to the role and the work that the European Union can do in the Middle East. Do not waste it. Use it carefully, wisely, but use it in a way that can work on the results that we need. We need symbols; sometimes symbols are part of the steps, but we need to concentrate on what can make the click in the process and restart it again. The lack of hope and the sense of desperation that are not only there in Gaza, though mainly in Gaza, but also in Tel Aviv and Jerusalem are waiting for a push from our side: someone to burst the bubble and let the desperation out and some hope and future in. (Applause)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.  The vote will take place during the next part-session of our Parliament.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ana GOMES
text: Written. – The recognition of the State of Palestine is a long-due step and urgently needs to break the deadlock in the Peace Process. The EP should support Sweden and national parliaments that have made progress in this direction. By the Palestinians, but also by the Israelis. In Israel today, the contradiction between the Jewish State and the democratic state is increasingly being dug. Formal recognition must be accompanied by a European effort to support the functioning of a state in Palestine, capable of providing security to the region, including Israel. The EU must make Israel feel that it no longer tolerates the policy of oppression and occupation to which the Palestinian people have been subject since 1967 – a policy that plays the game for extremist forces such as Hamas. The EU-Israel Partnership Agreement should be suspended for as long as illegal occupation is maintained. With no end to the occupation, Palestine will not be safe ground – for Palestinians and Israelis. The European Union must counter the reactionary rhetoric of Benjamin Netanyahu's government. The Israeli people must understand that the price of their security and peace passes through the authority of a viable, democratic and independent state in Palestine.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – Those of us who are equally the friends of Jews and Palestinians must again today condemn the recent attacks on Israeli churchgoers and balance this with disapproval of Israeli policies towards the Palestinians.
