Our declarations have little to no impact. Outsiders – Americans, Russians, jihadists, Europeans – cannot make peace happen in Israel and Palestine. Only, the Israelis and Palestinians can do it. Yet, developments in the area are having a powerful impact on the world we live in. On the one hand: despair and deep rage; on the other: a determination to maintain at all costs full control over Palestine. If peace is to be ever achieved, the only way out is for the dominant side to make concessions on major make-or-break issues, within well-defined limits. It needs to show good faith in doing so. The dominant side in Palestine is the Israeli Government. The make-or-break issue now is the spread of Jewish settlements with the full connivance of the government. Unfortunately, since the murder of Yitzhak Rabin, successive Israeli governments have demonstrated neither political will nor good faith in dealing with make-or-break issues. So unless this changes, both sides are condemned to keep living their epiphany of hate and despair.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – I support High Representative Mogherini's ambition for the EU to finally play a meaningful and international role in a lasting peace settlement in the Middle East. For us to be effective and credible in this, the unity and impartiality of the EU is essential.  At present, the main challenge is to end violence, to end acts of terrorism and to create political conditions for peace negotiations, in which recognition of Palestinian statehood is an important instrument, but not an end goal. Recognition can serve the cause of lasting peace if the logic of Hamas terror is broken. If not, we can continue to count on new acts of terrorism fuelling the vicious circle of violence and, on the other hand, hamas tactics that undermine the Palestinian government as a negotiating partner with meaningful influence and as an effective state administration.  Europe, working with the international community and leading its efforts, must use the time gained by postponing our resolution on recognition, precisely to eliminate these conditions and reduce the terrorist threat. In the absence of political conditions, recognition on the part of the EU may prove counterproductive not only from the point of view of the peace process: as a Hungarian MEP, I must point out that in some Member States, typically in Central and Eastern Europe, it can also provide ammunition to extremist, neo-Nazi political forces who support it purely on anti-Semitic motives and thus harm the perception of the Palestinian cause. I would be pleased if better preparation for the recognition of a Palestinian state and more effective action against terrorism would also help to address this particular threat.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (2014/2019(RSP)).

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, I would like to start by remembering that today in this hemicycle the Sakharov Prize was given to a man who is fighting for freedom of thought, democracy and peace in his country just the day after the International Day against Violence towards Women. Last year’s prize went to Malala Yousafzai, who this year won the Nobel Peace Prize together with Kailash Satyarthi, who worked on the right to education and children’s rights. I believe that this means Parliament is keeping a very open and effective eye on the protection and promotion of human rights. Last week we celebrated the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, and I welcome the unprecedented global support for the Convention. You know that the European Union has a treaty objective to promote the protection of the rights of the child. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child guides the EU at the moment throughout its actions in realising the rights of the child, as included in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. You know too that it is the most ratified human rights convention worldwide. All the European Union Member States have ratified it, which means that, indirectly, the rights are binding not just for the Member States but for the action of the European Union as such. Let me refer here to a letter that I have received from some Members of this Parliament asking for a ratification of the Convention by the European Union. That would turn respect for the rights of the child from an objective to a legal obligation. Let me say at the outset that I am ready to work with Commissioner Jourová to look at and examine the possibilities of proceeding in this direction and explore them. Let me also say that I very much welcome Parliament’s initiative to adopt a resolution on this issue, and I appreciate the efforts of the Italian Presidency to have the Council adopt conclusions on the promotion and protection of children’s rights in early December. Within the European Union we have done a lot. I am sure that you are all aware of the progress that has been made on internal policies in this area. But I know very well that under my responsibility lie, in particular, the steps that we still need to take on implementation and the work that we can do outside the European Union, especially when we see how many children in the world are victims of violence, war and rights violations, how many children are mostly affected by poverty, and how many children flee from their countries for different reasons. I really believe that we have a responsibility to take in our external action. I was looking at the figures, and I was satisfied to see that today, children’s rights are a priority in 86 of the EU delegations in the world and 116 have prioritised gender-related issues. We also know very well that the two elements are sometimes are interlinked, especially in the work that we do around the world. We have been working very closely with UNICEF, especially in developing a child rights toolkit which, to mark the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention, all the EU delegations, together with UNICEF country offices, presented around the world last week. In the spirit of the same cooperation we have actively supported the UN campaign ‘Children, Not Soldiers’, jointly initiated by the UN Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict, and UNICEF. More than 108 000 children affected by armed conflict have already benefited from the EU decision in late 2012 to use the Nobel Peace Prize to assist children in conflict situations. This EU Children of Peace initiative has been turned into a multiannual assisted programme on education in emergencies with more than EUR 12 million committed since 2012. On child labour, it is encouraging to me – even if only partially – that, according to the International Labour Organisation (ILO), the global number of children in labour has declined in the last 14 years. However, 85 million child labourers aged from 5 to 17 years old are involved in hazardous work, which is one of the worst forms of child labour. We are using our human rights dialogues to encourage countries to sign, ratify and implement – mainly implement – the ILO Convention 182 on the Worst Forms of Child Labour. Let me also refer to the need that we have to make targeted efforts to protect children from female genital mutilation and early and forced marriage. Again here, I refer to what happens inside the European Union and globally, because we tend too often to think that these are problems that happen only far away from us, while we are also responsible for what happens within our European Union. In July there was an important girls’ summit in London, where the EU announced its commitment to allocate more than EUR 100 million for the next seven years to gender equality and children’s well-being. I am personally committed to sticking to that engagement by the European Union and mainly to working on the follow-up to this commitment. We will continue to work in close relation with the UN: with the UN system, with the UN special representatives and envoys, and with other organisations like the Council of Europe. But let me stress mostly the work we can do with civil society organisations, with NGOs, which I value very much as a great possibility for partnership for fruitful cooperation, in particular as we work towards one of the main challenges that we will have for 2015, which is the work on the post-2015 Development Agenda. It is important that children’s rights are completely and fully included in that Agenda and that we find active and effective ways of working on that. I will close here, because I know that the President is worried about the fact that we are running very late. I thank you very much for this initiative. I believe it is extremely important as a resolution. I will conclude by mentioning a paragraph in the resolution, if you will allow me. It is paragraph 28 that calls on the Vice-President/High Representative – again I would invite you, if possible, to refer to my title as it is referred to in the Treaties, i.e. High Representative/Vice-President; nothing personal, nothing political (I will be always be sitting on this side of the hemicycle; I am, and I will be, Vice-President of the Commission, but we have to refer to the Treaties in the right way) – anyway, it calls on me to prioritise children’s rights in all EU external action so as to ensure the effective mainstreaming of children’s rights, including in the context of human rights dialogues, trade agreements, the accession process and the European Neighbourhood Policy and in relations with the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, in particular countries in conflict. I am fully committed to doing that and extremely happy that you asked me to commit to that, because for me, cooperation with you in this field, together with the partners I mentioned, is going to be extremely helpful. I look forward to effective and useful work on this topic in the near future.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report I think you will all agree with the proposition that children are our future. We should be careful about the future. Unfortunately, the reality is different, not only in Europe, where many children and young people grow up without perspective. Children are still dying of hunger, especially in underdeveloped countries, and in many regions children are being abused as soldiers. We should have all this in mind when we celebrate today the anniversary of the signing of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. The Convention contains global standards for the protection of children and establishes the fundamental rights to non-violent education and parental care. The Lisbon Treaty and the EU Charter also require the protection of children's rights. Nevertheless, violence is still allowed in ten Member States in child-rearing. A slap can never be healthy. Violence against children is unacceptable. It is a crime against defenceless people and shakes their primal confidence. It is a crime against our future. Yes, we need legislation that is in line with the UN Convention and, above all, we also need accompanying public campaigns. Children need the feeling that they are welcome and that we consider them to be equal. This includes a willingness to invest in the education system. Especially in times of austerity, this is put to the test. The negative consequences are difficult to catch up with. Every euro not spent on children is a mortgage on the future.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, there are certain fundamental values and principles which we should all agree about. This is one of those issues where our political affiliations, ideologies, genders and nationalities should be put aside to focus on how we can really protect and provide for the generations which will follow us. How we treat our children, and those of the most vulnerable, is how we should be judged as a society and as democracies. How well we protect those that do not always have the ability to protect themselves is also how we should be judged as legislators. This Parliament has done a lot of work in the area of children’s rights, but we need to do more. More needs to be done to protect children in the online world, and to protect them from exploitation and bring to justice those who commit the most despicable of crimes. More also needs to be done in our relationship with third countries to see how we can better harness the influence and resources of the EU to protect children in conflict zones. We must end the devastating effects of children being used as soldiers, being trafficked and being torn away from their homes, their families and their childhoods. We must also do more to battle the most basic but serious of challenges such as hunger and poverty, and to make sure children no longer needlessly die around the world from a lack of access to health care. Every child should have the right not to be trapped by their own circumstances, but for their life to be full of potential and opportunities, regardless of their gender, their background, their financial situation, disabilities, ethnicities and religions. I trust that, at least on this issue, we can all be in agreement. (Applause)

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Madam Vice-President, Mr Vice-President, twenty-five years ago, the world made a promise to children to do everything we can to protect them, to promote their fundamental rights, their right to live, their right to survive, their right to grow and flourish, and their right to speak and have their voices heard. This year, as we approach the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, there is much to be welcomed and to see progress, but there is also reason to be alarmed and concerned. Thousands of children are still lagging behind, thousands of children are being violated every day. I am not talking about what is happening elsewhere, in the world facing war and violence, I am talking about what is happening in Europe, in the 28 Member States of the Union. However, in agreeing to honour the obligations of the Convention, the Governments have committed themselves to defending and guaranteeing these rights and the Vice-President, who has just left us, has made a very interesting step forward in agreeing to help us to ensure that the Union itself, as a Union, signs the Convention.  There are still two problems. First, the detention of children. Article 37 of the Convention stipulates that no child should be unlawfully or arbitrarily deprived of liberty. However, many children, minors, are detained, remanded in custody or in detention, and I am thinking in particular of migrant children. It is unacceptable that these minors should not be considered primarily as vulnerable beings. The second problem is poverty. As the Unicef report points out, 6.5 million children in Europe have fallen into poverty in the space of four years. In conclusion, children are of course our future, we all agree on this, but we must put them at the heart of our priorities and at the heart of our European project. We are counting on the Commission because the colleagues are all unanimous in moving in this direction.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I welcome the opportunity to put children and young people’s rights to the front of the EU agenda. A lot has changed since the original UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, both for better and worse, and I am happy that the resolution takes note of the new challenges facing children and young people today. We must put young people at the heart of policy and encourage their involvement in the decision-making process. We must encourage young adults to vote and make their voice heard, and use their expertise to help to educate, to inform and to make, for example, the internet a safer place. A Spotlight programme recently exposed Facebook photos of schoolchildren in the North of Ireland being exploited. We need to empower young children and young people to preserve their internet integrity, and we need to ensure their privacy is protected. We must continue to push children’s rights globally and ensure all children have the right to a childhood free from war and all the atrocities that accompany it, and I am mindful of the children in Palestine whom we spoke about here earlier today. Within the EU we must put a renewed focus on children and young people, as many of them have paid the awful price for the reckless bankers who created the economic crisis and the subsequent relentless austerity policies that followed, and the lack of investment in our young people, our tomorrow’s world, is absolutely appalling.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, that is another Francophone gender identity crisis! I too want very much to welcome the cross-party initiative in this House and the substantial resolution that has been tabled. The Convention has been an extremely important initiative and, as we look to children’s futures, we can see that many of them face a very uncertain future across this globe – whether that be the impact of climate change, experience of conflict or the gross inequalities that exist both within and between countries. That is why a revised Children’s Rights Strategy is important for us in this Parliament. We have yet to deliver, for example, on real gender equality throughout the world, which is having such a major impact on so many girls’ lives, as we have clearly seen from the Sakharov Prize winners of last year and this. They clearly demonstrate also the need for every child to be able to live in peace, free from violence. We trust that the Millennium Development Goals and the post-2015 framework will also help move things forward. Yesterday’s EU 2020 Strategy resolution and today’s resolution both make reference to the Commission’s recommendation on investing in children, breaking the cycle and enabling all children to fulfil their potential. I trust that we can bring that perspective into the investment package that was introduced to us today. We need to address the inequality of opportunity faced by many, even in the European Union and even in the richest areas, such as London, which has the highest rate of child poverty in the UK. So there is a lot in which we can invest to help give our children better lives – whether that be housing, better health care or the opportunity to play in a healthy environment. We need to be mainstreaming that way of thinking across all our policy areas.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a newborn girl bled to death a few hours after being born and abandoned by her mother in a dumpster. It happened in Palermo, Europe, just over 48 hours ago. This is yet another case of inhumane violence against a child, and it comes just days before the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. It is impossible in the world to count cases of child labour exploitation, physical violence and unfortunate practices of sexual abuse, as Dr Mukwege said this morning in his beautiful speech. And this violence leaves children who suffer huge scars, which in addition to aesthetically scarring the body irreversibly mark the soul. Well, I wonder, Mr President, and I wanted to ask Mr Mogherini that she has left, what we can actually do beyond conferences, resolutions and treaties. Perhaps, since the 'market god' is the indispensable dogma of this Europe, one could try to build an economic system regulated on ethics before profit, starting to sanction, hinder and boycott those multinationals that become accomplices in child abuse, and there are many, not to say almost all, that operate on our market.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Thank you very much! With regard to children's rights, I would like to ask the Commission representative and my fellow Members for ideas and assistance on an issue that we all encounter every day, both as private citizens and as lawyers, and yet we do not somehow define it as a child legal problem. This is the situation of children whose parents often kill each other in divorce proceedings, divorce proceedings, custody proceedings that have dragged on for years in desperation and loss of hope, in order to express themselves so casually, and the child often lives in this situation completely alone, depressed and at the mercy of him.  I must also say that many of my legal colleagues, as lawyers, are not only trying to promote the settlement, but also inslaming tensions. What experiences, what ideas do you have? Do you see this as a question of children's rights? Could some Kind of European action be launched using the best experience to protect and help these forgotten children? In fact, parents would often need help in these situations. Thank you very much!

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Mr President, the 25th anniversary of the conclusion of the Convention on the Rights of the Child is a milestone in an ongoing, multi-year struggle to demonstrate significant achievements in the field of the protection of children's rights. But it is also a point of intense concern because we cannot remain silent in the face of the fact that even today, 25 years later, there are always children, in every corner of the world but unfortunately also in Europe, who are deprived of their fundamental rights and are the subject of sexual harassment, trafficking, illegal employment and victims of all kinds of racist discrimination.  The economic crisis is added to this landscape. In countries such as mine, Greece, the crisis has plunged hundreds of thousands of children into poverty with dramatic consequences: deprivation of food, clothing and access to health care and education, taking into account the most recent UNICEF report published a month ago. We're talking about children who mature before their age in an unnatural way. No one doubts, I think, that Europe is an area of democracy, equality, justice, solidarity, principles, values, but I wonder how we can take pride, when we have not yet been able, using our legislative weapons, to provide full and comprehensive legal protection to the most vulnerable and vulnerable social group, to the continuators of our work, to the children, to those who allow them to fall victim to criminal offences. , criminal acts and social exclusion. Colleagues, let us think, as we have an obligation and duty, and let us act with this in mind: if we could ask them, would they ever choose these children to be born if they knew they would live under such tragic circumstances?

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Convention on the Rights of the Child is the Treaty on Human Rights that has achieved the most ratifications in history, but despite the complete framework of instruments, rules and commitments on children's rights and the first developments in achieving the agreed objectives, for millions of children throughout the world the daily reality is still in stark contrast to these commitments and objectives. Children still face serious threats to survival, the lack of opportunities for quality education and adequate health and social care. They are victims of the worst forms of child labour, they suffer sexual exploitation and abuse, diseases, armed conflicts and various forms of violence. They are forced into early marriages and have to endure harmful traditional practices. Children belonging to vulnerable groups and children in particularly difficult situations face particular risks and are exposed to discrimination, marginalisation and exclusion, and girls face specific risks and therefore need special attention. As far as the European Union is concerned, therefore, human rights guidelines are needed to build a solid regional framework for work in the European Union for the promotion and protection of human rights in Europe's global external policy, in the field of human rights and in particular on children's rights. In order to achieve this, we need, first and foremost, guidelines on the promotion and protection of children's rights, European Union guidelines on children and armed conflicts, we need to integrate the protection and promotion of children's rights into all policies in the European Union's external relations and in its programmes and activities. Finally, it is essential that in the European Union's development policies and the European Consensus on Development, the rights of the child between the Member States of the European Union are constantly implemented through the reference to the main international frameworks on human rights and the Millennium Development Goals.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr. President! Today we are celebrating 25 years of UN children's rights. But the general human rights of 1948 apply to everyone, regardless of age, and therefore also to children. What, then, are explicit children's rights supposed to do? Not human rights, but children's rights! The new is not the rights, but the new is the addressee of rights. After all, who is taking the rights of children? These are the parents, father and mother. And father and mother, parents, do not even exist in the UN Charter of the Rights of the Child. Children are granted rights against parents, and the state then enforces them. It's definitely the beginning of it. We should beware of this. The state's sovereignty over cots is exactly what we have to reject. The Pope said yesterday: without an indissoluble family, we build our society on sand. Let us keep the state away from our children and strengthen parental rights!

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the occasion of the celebration of the 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, I would like to draw the attention of this House to a concern which I believe is essential but very neglected. I want to talk about the protection of children on the internet. As you know, the Convention on the Rights of the Child stipulates that the child needs special protection, special care and, in particular, appropriate legal protection.  In the real world, it is relatively easy to know when it is a child, first visually; on the other hand, in cyberspace, virtuality and anonymity do not make it as easy to identify a child or a minor. That is why it seems to me that more specialized protection mechanisms are needed.  Hence a first proposal: as cybercrime against children is on the rise, I think it is urgent to think about better codifying the status of minors on the internet. In my opinion, we should consider a more active and energetic collaboration with internet providers, so that the user accounts of minors can be identified as such all over the internet. This is not very difficult to do and would allow many adults who abuse children to be prosecuted on condition of anonymity.  Second proposition: cyberpredation covers the use of the internet for the purpose of communicating online with underage children and manipulating them for criminal purposes, not only to commit sexual abuse - there are other forms of abuse.  That is why, as Canada, the United States and Belgium have already done, it would be appropriate for the European Union to adopt a directive that applies to all Member States and allows the necessary measures to be taken to ensure that any form of cyberpredation is punishable.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: November 20 is just 25 years since the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which set the standard for the protection of children's rights, was adopted. It is more than important that we do everything possible to ensure that the Member States also urgently fill the gaps in the application and preference of children's rights in legislation and, above all, in practice, because it still mercilessly shows us that there is something to work on and something to fix. As a clear example, I can cite the case of the over-the-course child protection system in Norway, where two boys who are Czech citizens and live with their mother in Norway, were removed on the basis of an anonymous statement from their mother, and even though these allegations proved to be false, these boys were still not returned to their mother and were stuck in the Norwegian system. But there are many such cases. As MEMBERS of the European Parliament, we should also appeal to establish the position of Ombudsman for Children's Rights in all Member States in order to ensure children's rights even more effectively. Children do not have the choice as adults, but they are only dependent on the legal protection we provide them. The resolution is strong and courageous, it is up to us whether we can deliver it.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear children in Europe and around the world, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work he has had. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child marks a milestone in the history of the rights and protection of children. However, 25 years after the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, we are still living in a world where children's rights are trampled underfoot every day. Every year, 2.9 million children still die of hunger, and 72 million children still do not have access to education. And in the EU, too, 20% of all children still grow up in poverty. This situation has worsened dramatically, particularly during the crisis. It is therefore up to all of us to make an effort to change this unsustainable situation. On the 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, we are not only called upon to improve the socio-economic situation of children. This anniversary, 20 November, is also an opportunity for me to ask questions about the democratic rights of children. How can children actually influence democratic decisions here in this Parliament and other political institutions? We, the Members, have not been elected by children. Children in all our societies are deprived of a central instrument of participation, the right to vote. I believe that the Day of Children's Rights should again be a date every year when we talk about this situation and put it to the test and, above all, discuss with children how they can be involved in the democratic decisions of parliaments.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are celebrating the 25th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. However, much remains to be done. I want to talk first of all about the right of the child to a traditional, indissoluble family, made up of a man and a woman, because it is this right that depends, according to all psychological studies, on the full development of the child.  On the other hand, I would like to tell you about an experience. I recently went to the Donbass and saw the special view that the Kiev government has of protecting children. Are the right to life of the child (Article 6), the right to identity (Article 8), the right to education (Article 28) compatible with systematically targeting schools with heavy weapons? Are they bad children?  So, ladies and gentlemen, let us celebrate the rights of the child but, through our actions, we are implementing support for those who truly seek the rights of children. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: blue card question. – What do you mean by traditional and indissoluble family? Don't you think that boys and girls need the love of their parents, and that this is much more important than defending each here their concept of family, yours and me mine? Don't you think what boys and girls need is the love and care of their parents?

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Answer "blue card." Mr President, dear Mrs Valenciano Martinez-Orozco, I do not believe that the traditional family can be contrasted with the love of children. On the contrary, it is the place where this faithful and loyal love and respect, in continuity, of the child, which has landmarks, namely a father and a mother, are fully expressed.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: Mr President, thank you, Mr Dombrovskis, for being here with us today. The Congolese doctor who was awarded the Sakharov Prize this morning told us that in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, unfortunately, people have already become accustomed to seeing the images of violence and all the crimes that are happening there as usual in the media. Unfortunately, we must admit here today that the same thing happens to us in Europe. Babies and children are abandoned weekly in hospitals, in the streets, as in ancient Rome in the imperial forum. They give up and leave them to their fate. Many children are also dying across the Strait, crossing the Mediterranean. And all of this is related to policies which, of course, the European Union must already deal with in a decisive way. I welcome the statements made earlier by the Vice-President of the Commission on the matter, because we also want greater coordination in not only national laws, but also in European legislation so that, whenever we are opening some legislative episode, both this European Parliament and the Commission and all European institutions take into account the rights of vulnerable children , who are defenseless and, indeed, as one colleague acknowledged, without the necessary political support. I believe that here today, in this Parliament, we are finally discussing an issue which is a priority for all, but above all for those children who are abandoned and who have no one's defence. We have solutions. We need to better integrate judicial policies and actions, help Europol to ensure greater coordinated action among all, and also to require that European Union aid, which, for example, goes to third countries, covers above all children in these countries, who do not have such aid, and that it does not reach them because it is lost along the way. As many of my colleagues have also said, it is necessary to defend the rights of children in the world of the internet, this new world, in which they are often not counted. And, above all, I wanted to specifically mention the phone helplines where children can call. Twenty-one countries have them, but European countries are still missing from adopting them.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child and adolescents, which is today the 25th anniversary, has represented a great cultural and legal advance on a global scale. But there are still many problems relating to the protection of minors both in Europe and outside. We therefore need a strong relaunch of the European Union's commitment in this area, and the resolution proposed to this Parliament goes precisely in this direction, touching on issues that the Community and national institutions will have to face by exercising their competences to the full.  There are many points I would like to be able to focus on, but for reasons of time I shall confine myself to a few which I consider to be particularly important. These include the problem of unaccompanied immigrant minors. In this regard, the resolution clearly states that the duty to protect the child take precedence over any migration policy, thus making explicit a legal obligation already derived from the primary law of the Union. But it is essential that this is clearly reaffirmed because that obligation is often violated or ignored. The Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe has also recently stressed the need for alternatives to the accommodation of the many immigrant children in detention facilities.  Appropriate measures must also be found to avoid or limit the psychological trauma suffered by the children of prisoners or by children forced to live in prison with their imprisoned mother.  Finally, the judicial systems in the Union must be adapted to the special and delicate functions of juvenile justice, which affects more than one million children in Europe every year. In this regard, as rapporteur for the draft directive on procedural guarantees for children under investigation or subject to criminal proceedings, I hope that the European Parliament will soon be called upon to vote on a measure that could serve to build a shared model of juvenile due process. One final point is the hope that Europe as such, the European Union, will be able to sign the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: We are 25 years since the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of Children, which us have begun a new era of looking at a child as a human rights bearer. Much has been done over the years to implement children's rights. However, there is a large group of children who are discriminated against because of age and whose rights are overlooked. They're conceived babies before birth. In Slovakia, four NGOs proclaimed the Declaration of the Rights of the Conceived Child 15 years ago in order to draw society's attention to the need to also exercise the rights of unborn children. Under the current legislation of several European countries, conceived children have the right to inherit, to be endowed, to have the right to a dignified burial. Yet they are legally denied the right to be born. It must therefore be stressed that every conceived child has an unencumovable and inseparable right to be born, as the Pope emphasised here yesterday. He has the right to life to be protected by law from conception to natural death. I believe that it is in the best interests of the child to be conceived and conceived in the marriage of one man and one woman, and he has the right to be conceived and carried in his mother's lap.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Much has been done in the 25 years that we have the Convention, but still a large number of children, as has already been said, live in very poor conditions in the world.  Dr Mukwege described only a fraction of cases of very cruel violence against children this morning.  In addition, there are tens of thousands of children in South Sudan who suffer from malnutrition and many of them die. This country, beleaguered by armed conflict, has not joined the Convention on the Rights of the Child. I am not in support of the European Union as a whole acceding to international conventions, but in the case of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, I would be very much in support of the Union's acceding. I therefore welcome the fact that the High Representative/Vice-President of the Commission has promised to work on this.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: Mr. President! Unfortunately, no country has yet created the conditions for the requirements of the Convention on the Rights of the Child to be fully met. The United States has not even signed it, but there are also many shortcomings in Europe's implementation. More than 20% of children in the EU are affected by poverty. Austerity policies limit access to basic care. Thousands of refugees are drowning in the sea, including an unbearable number of children. One of the most blatant abuses of child rights is the situation of child refugees. Despite Article 22 of the Convention, children do not receive adequate protection and humanitarian aid. This concerns, among other things, the right to the highest possible level of health at taint. This is particularly dramatic when severely traumatised child soldiers are not entitled to psychological treatment, as in Germany. Unfortunately, the Convention on the Rights of the Child does not preclude people under the age of 18 from being drafted into the military. Here, military interests are placed above the interests and protection of minors. And in response to the reactionary notions of family, I would just like to say that no love from father and mother or from father and father can replace a functioning health system.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, while it contains many laudable objectives, the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, signed in New York twenty-five years ago, leaves many outstanding issues that deserve to be addressed.  First, by taking the step on the right of the child, the right to the child materialized by the possible adoption by same-sex couples endangers the rights of the child in terms of his education, development and stability.  In this Chamber, we do not intend to denounce many countries which use child labour, including the youngest, on a large scale, and which benefit from association agreements with the European Union. But it is true that unbridled globalism, which prevails over the majority of these benches, seems more concerned with making Europe a platform with little regard for the production conditions of many associated countries.  Finally, the rights of the child cannot be mentioned without forgetting the defence of the right to life. For twenty-five years, nothing has been done to prevent the acceleration of abortion and to advance the policy of the defence of life.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the European The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, adopted 25 years ago, has shed new light on the protection of children's rights. I hope you will hear what I have to say with the help of the interpreters, even though I lost my voice this afternoon.  Along the anniversary, EU Member States must renew their commitment to respect and protect children's rights in practice. That is why several of us and my fellow Member Corazza Bildt have initiated this draft decision on this subject. After all, missing children, malnutrition, violence against children and child pornography are all problems that we need to address at the highest level.  There is something else that I would like to draw your attention to: I am thinking of online bullying, which is on a frightening scale among young people, because the world of the Internet also penetrates the most protected children's rooms. Statistics show that half of teenagers have been victims of such harassment.  Hungary sets an example in many areas in the field of child protection, I am thinking here of child-friendly justice, the elements of the new Hungarian penal code protecting children, or civic initiatives such as 'All children should eat well', which will make hot meals available to thousands of children every day. We must share good examples and practices that can be used to remedy them, both within and outside the Union. Thank you.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Mr President, twenty-five years ago we told the children that we would protect them, that we would take care of them. We told the children; I do not know if we were also talking about girls, because the reality of girls on this twenty-fifth anniversary of the Convention remains very harsh and there are some figures that we need to know. More than 700 million women worldwide were married as minors. More than a third of them had not turned fifteen. Nearly a quarter of teenage girls between the ages of fifteen and nineteen – which are seventy million in the world – have been victims of some form of physical violence. One hundred and twenty million girls under the age of twenty—one in ten—have had forced sex. And a third of these victims had no idea that what was wrong with them was an act of violence. Half of the world's teenage girls think it's justified for a man to beat his wife under certain conditions. That is the reality of girls, and perhaps girls should talk more, because they need even more support from the international community. They largely represent the possibilities of many countries to succeed. It will be the women and mothers of the future who will give their lives and those who will be able to educate their sons and daughters. But as long as we do not connect discrimination against girls with the defence of children's rights, we will not resolve the huge gap between them and them. It's one of the girls we need to talk about on this twenty-fifth anniversary of the Convention, because I think they're the big forgotten ones. Dr. Mukwege has also given an example today of how important it is to work with women and girls.

name: Marek JUREK
text: A quarter of a century after the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child was established, the first of these rights – the right to life – is systematically violated by most western countries. And let us remember that evil has a terrible dynamic: consent to so-called abortion increasingly results in neonatal infanticide, the killing of children who have survived an abortion attempt. It's time to stop this horror.  Today in Parliament we announced the creation of a European Federation to continue the work of the European 'One of Us' initiative. In the name of the work and dedication of the hundreds of thousands of participants in this petition, I call on the European Union to stand on the side of the right to life owed to every child from the moment of conception. Thank you very much.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, respected colleagues, I invite you to do everything in the year in which we celebrate the 25th anniversary of the adoption of the Convention on Children's Rights so that children can feel our care and protection and that in the world in which we make decisions we feel safe.  As a person who advocates the protection of human rights, I want to warn that the rights of many children are being violated, and in particular violation of the basic human right – the right to life – comes to the fore.  Many children are hungry, do not have a home of their own and do not have access to education, which constitutes discrimination. Children of Christians in Syria and Iraq have been kidnapped by ISIS, isis sells them in markets, rapes girls and recruits them, and in some parts of the world children are used as living shields in armed conflicts - which is inadmissible.  In what kind of people we will be, our fathers and mothers play a crucial role in raising us and learning what is good and what is not. I therefore call on the proponents of this resolution to highlight in it the important role of families in the upbringing and formation of children, as explicitly stated by the Convention on the Rights of the Child. I must also express a serious reservation towards one segment of the resolution introducing the term 'sexual identity' of a child for which there is no international definition which can cause numerous problems in implementation and lead to unnecessary legal processes at the European Court of Human Rights or the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child. If a child reports a discrimination case because they are not allowed to change the sex they seek based on their sexual identity, many European countries will be accused of discrimination because they do not allow their laws, quite justified, for minors to change gender. Therefore, I call once again for changes in the resolution that would exclude the part related to discrimination on the basis of the "sexual identity" of the child, but I also call for changes that will put emphasis on the right of the child to grow up in the auspices of the family with the mother and father.

name: Anna HEDH
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul The Convention on the Rights of the Child is one of the most important human rights documents in existence. Today we have talked a lot about the external dimension – i.e. what the EU can do for children's rights outside the EU – but europe can never credily put pressure on countries outside the Union if we do not treat all children on our territory ourselves in accordance with the Convention on the Rights of the Child. There are daily violations of the Convention in the EU Member States. These range from refugee children who are locked up and denied the right to school and care, to various forms of physical violence such as barnaga, which, incidentally, is still allowed in a number of EU Member States. In 2011, the Commission adopted a communication on an EU agenda for children's rights. Now is the time for us to take the next step: to adopt a full-fledged child rights strategy and an accompanying action plan. It should cover all EU activities both within the Union and beyond. Children and young people's well-being should be taken into account in all measures affecting them. In addition, coordination and resources will also be required. Since the child perspective is often forgotten when the issues of the future are to be set out, we Social Democrats proposed, for the new term of office, a Commissioner with special responsibility for child rights issues. But to no avail. Here the Commission has an opportunity to reconsider. In addition, during the last parliamentary term, I put a question to the Commission as to whether they are planning to ratify the EU Convention on the Rights of the Child. That the EU would unilaterally commit itself to the Convention. Unfortunately, the response I received was substandard during all the criticism. I hope that the Commission will resolve this.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Mr. President, children are our future, so it makes me happy that there is a high level of awareness of the need to protect their rights and freedoms.  The fact is that children are particularly vulnerable and there will always be those who will try to abuse their kindness and naivety. That is why there must be concrete policies, but also repressive measures that will put an end to such behavior. The resolution calls for decisive steps in the right direction and recommends a wide range of measures to protect children's rights and freedoms, and I support it from that side.  Personally, I wish that the important role of the family as the main protector of children that prepares them for life and follows them through all the good and bad that he carries is more prominent. Although I consider the spirit of the resolution positive, I regret that on several occasions terms related to gender ideology are used because such formulations provoke unnecessary controversy in things around which we should be unique.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Frankly, reading the resolution discussed today is quite an unpleasant experience for me. We stress that the Convention on the Rights of the Child is the most widely ratified Convention of the United Nations. And what if every day we get new information about violence against children, their beating, abuse, forced labour, sexual abuse, etc., etc., etc.? So what if the list of threats is still just as long and the progress of civilization brings new threats? Do we really need an information impulse every time to think that children need our protection and care, that this is our greatest good? Our youngest generation is our greatest wealth.  That is why I would like us in the European Parliament not only to call for action, but to work diligently, in our parliamentary committees and plenary, to prepare legal solutions that children will actually protect. In our work, after all, we are preparing solutions that help fight violence against children, their sexual exploitation or forced labour. Let us remember that adults are responsible for all this, and therefore it is our primary duty to prosecute those who commit these heinous crimes.  Therefore, all the countries of the European Union, all law enforcement authorities, public prosecutors' offices in the Member States should cooperate closely with each other. In the field of civil law, too, we have the capacity to create legislation that, in difficult situations, such as the divorce of parents or the abduction of children from their country to another country, will at least minimise the harmful effects of this situation on the child. It is worth pointing out here that the institutions of the state are not only guided by the letter of the law, but also by the spirit of the law. They are to be not only such a mechanical execution, but a person who thinks. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr President, i would like to thank you for your comments. Eleven years ago, your party wrote in its programme the beautiful words that the right to life of the unborn should be protected as Polish legislation does. It is a pity that you did not repeat this here in the European Parliament today. In fact, why?

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Mr President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab It is good that the Lord has said what my party has done well – so I do not have to remind you, because it works. Thank you very much.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: Mr President, I think it is an important debate we are having today, and I want to firstly put on record my thanks to organisations like UNICEF which work very hard to promote children’s rights in very difficult situations all over the world. We have had 25 years of some progress, but, as colleagues here have said, also some difficult situations. Elena Valenciano talked in particular about the problems facing girls, and this is something I hope the new Commission will address, particularly in our external policies as well as our internal and development policies, because we know that girls are getting left behind with all the problems that were outlined. Dr Mukwege told us this lunchtime about appalling abuse: sexual abuse of children and babies that he has seen and had to deal with, and I think this shows us that there is still a long way to go. In my own country, though, we are unearthing many scandals of children having been exploited in the past and being exploited now today, and abused; many in the state’s care. So in our own countries we have work to do. The question is: what are we going to do about it? Next year we have an opportunity, because world leaders will gather at the United Nations in September and they will agree a successor programme to the Millennium Development Goals. We know those MDGs delivered for children in some areas, and now we need to make sure the new Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) really deliver for children, and I hope the new Commission will put its focus on making sure that happens and that they will deliver a programme for us on children for that negotiation.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Last week, we commemorated the 25th anniversary of the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. On this occasion, 17-year-old Dominik Drdúl from Slovakia, who was born with a health disadvantage, spoke at the European Commission. In his speech, he pointed out, among other things, that the number of children in institutional care is increasing and that I quote 'This is a terrible place for children and I am very angry that this is still happening in the European Union, as this is happening in breach of the Convention on the Rights of the Child'. It is shocking and unacceptable to me that there are still places where children with disabilities live in inhumane and undignified conditions, such as a children's home in the Greek city of Lechaina. According to media reports, in this institution children with mental disadvantage are subdued with medication and literally locked in cages, their personal movement is limited to a minimum. We cannot accept such treatment. I therefore call not only on Greece, but also on the other Member States where similar practices occur, to ensure decent conditions for these children to live in community facilities, in accordance with the Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: I am very glad that we are discussing the Convention on the Rights of the Child after pope Francis' speech yesterday. He reminded us that Europe is getting older, it is no longer fertile, because man and human dignity have ceased to be at the centre of our attention.  The Convention emphasises the right of the child to a decent life, to its development and to the care of both parents. Trends show that although most people still think that a complete family with both parents is the best model for raising children, more and more children are born out of wed marriage. In some developed countries, this is even 40%.  The Convention clearly puts the interests of the child at the forefront. It is not intended to interfere with the rights of parents. On the contrary, it emphasises that the family creates the best environment for the development of children and that every child has the right to the care of both parents. According to this principle, decisions on foster family care should also be guided, but not managed.  In this context, I call on the Norwegian authorities to stop restricting the rights of the two Michalak siblings who have been taken from their families despite having a mother and a wider family capable of taking care of them. Unfortunately, this is a sad experience and I want to thank the citizens of the Czech Republic, members and this Parliament for supporting the pressure on the authorities in Norway to stop restricting children's rights to care for their families. I therefore also support the motion for a resolution tabled here, although it is not perfect and I will certainly support the amendments that have been mentioned here. This resolution points out that children's rights are still not being respected in the developed countries of the European Union. I believe that our activities will be here for the benefit of children and their rights.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: On the anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child , I would like to draw attention to the written statement I made two years ago. It concerned the creation of a European Day to combat child sexual abuse. Sexual violence is unacceptable and is also subject to convention. My written statement, despite an intense campaign and a great desire to show our attitude to the truly difficult problems faced by children, received 130 votes of support from 750 Members. At the same time, support for a colleague who filed a written statement for a European Day of Homemade Ice Cream received almost 400 votes. A colleague organised a free ice cream tasting in the parliamentary hallways.  I like ice cream, too. I would also prefer to have the opportunity to try children who are happy, free and respected every day, not just on the anniversary of the convention. Let's think about the deeds, because the kids have enough empty words, too.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Today we are reminded of a quarter of a century of children's rights, in which we, as politicians, could have done much more to give children around the world a real good, happy life. I would like to warn us, especially all the missing Members: let us not revel in complacency and self-affirmation here! There are still far too many children in Europe who have to live in poverty, with suffering or in destroyed family circumstances. I do not read anything in this resolution about the right of children to have a family. The term appears in the many pages just twice, and only indirectly. I know that there are groups that would prefer to remove the term entirely from the political vocabulary. I say to all of you: words do not change reality, children need parents, our society needs children, and Europe needs families! We all applauded Pope Francis yesterday, many even in standing ovations. In view of this, it is simply shameful that we forget the families in this resolution. I would like to join a colleague once again in saying that parental voting rights throughout Europe, that is what we need. Children and parents must play a role in all our decisions in Parliament.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: 25 years of the United Nations Convention on the Right of the Child. It is clearly a good time to put children back on the agenda and to defend their interests and rights. Despite the importance of all the issues discussed in this Parliament, I believe that everyone will agree that this will be one of the priorities that most consensus can generate. The Union's action in this area is not new. But we have to be even more ambitious. We cannot be satisfied that all the Member States of the European Union have already ratified the UN Convention and the other additional protocols. We must ensure that, in practice, what we legally subscribe to is carried out. Among the various scourges we have to combat, I want to highlight cyberbullying, child violence, child pornography and genital mutilation. No tradition, culture or religion should serve as a justification for violence against children. We must help and promote better conditions for the most disadvantaged children, in less resourced families or in poorer communities. But we also need to ensure that our justice systems are prepared to deal with children and that our education systems are inclusive and combat early school leaving. We do not forget that almost seven million children under the age of five died in 2012 from causes that could have been prevented and avoided; whereas around 170 million children are subject to child labour; that a quarter of a million are child soldiers. We cannot fail to strongly condemn the indoctrination and use of children for terrorist or military activities. That is why I support this resolution, which takes a global view, addressing all the issues necessary to better protect our children.   A Europe that does not care about our children would be a Europe with its future-facing back.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: The 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child is an ephemeris worthy of our evocation and must lead us to a profound reflection on the current situation of children in the world. And we must start with our political space: the European political space.  Unfortunately, we are led to realise that child poverty in Europe is far from the part of the past. In recent years, there have even been significant setbacks in countries where very violent austerity policies have been applied. A recent UNICEF report rightly points out that the number of children suffering severe material deprivation has increased in some European countries, as has the proportion of people who say they do not have enough money to buy food for themselves and their families. And this European situation is even paradoxical if we see what is happening happily in other parts of the world. Good examples come to us, for example, from Latin America, from countries such as Chile, Argentina or Brazil, where very significant steps have been taken to promote children's rights.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, we are celebrating the 25th anniversary of this convention, but a few months ago we had to mobilize for the girls abducted by Boko Haram and, a year ago, we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Malala Yousafzai. This shows that nothing is yet won. I would like to emphasize five points. Two hundred and fifty thousand child soldiers are two hundred and fifty thousand children who may never find a place in society and who will reproduce the cycles of violence in which they grew up. The European Union must do all it can for children in conflict situations with initiatives such as the Children of Peace. This brings me to my second point, access to education. Access to education must be guaranteed in conflict situations to prevent children from enlisting in armed groups, but also so that, in reconstruction, the young people who have received an education are those who carry the hopes of a country. Thirdly, I would like to point out that children's rights go hand in hand with women's rights, particularly in the area of health, because there is a strong link between women's health, newborn health and child development. Fourthly, I believe that we need to take more measure of the role of the internet. The internet makes millions of children vulnerable to abuse. Children's rights defenders, including EU Member States, must seize this tool of the internet and improve their cooperation. Finally, it is through the prism of child protection, before that of migration policy, that we must consider the situation of migrant and refugee children while protecting ourselves against criminal networks that would like to take advantage of this priority that we give to the rights of children. Colleagues, there are indeed many challenges, but I believe that, if we join the ratified document, the results will not be long.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: Mr President, Article 27(3) of the Convention reads as follows: 'States Parties shall, where necessary, provide material assistance and support programmes, particularly with respect for nutrition, clothing and housing'. If there is one image that represents like no other the extent to which the economic crisis is baiting with the weakest, it is that of increasing child poverty. According to Caritas, 28% of children in Europe – their families – do not have sufficient income to meet their most basic needs. And avoiding this is not only a commitment made in the Convention, it is the moral duty we have with the current generation of Europeans. We can, we must and demand that, through the European Social Fund, we introduce a minimum income of insertion, at least for families without income with children in their care. I find no policy more laudable or more honourable objective than to prevent children in Europe, to this day, from searching the rubbish, in the bins, to be able to eat something. Ensuring through a minimum income to meet their most basic needs, children and their families, giving them dignity, is the best tribute we can pay on this twenty-fifth anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: Sur President, id-drittijiet tat-tfal qed jiġu mżebilħa f'ħafna pajjiżi fid-dinja. Issa, waqt li qed nitkellmu, hemm tfal li qed jiġu abbużati u m大aħħda minn drittijiet fundamentali, suġġetti għal qtil, traffikar, abbuż sesswali, diskimarimzzjoni, u sfruttament ta' hawk tip. Issa, waqt li qed nitkellmu, 57 miljun tifel u tifla huma m大aħħda mid-dritt bażiku għall-edukazzjoni. Għalhekk nemmen li rridu naħdmu aktar biex il-viżjoni tal-Konvenzjoni għad-Drittijiet tat-Tfal, issir realtà. Irridu niġieldu hawk tip ta' vjolenza kontra t-tfal, inkluż vjolenza fuq l-internet, is-cyber bullying, u hawk vjolenza fiżika u psikoloġika, biex b'hekk niżguraw li dawn it-tfalment igawdu tful-tfulija taghomħ. Issa hu l-ħin li l-potenzi politi大i jqumu u jaħdmu għal futur xieraq għat-tfal tagħna. Qed nitlob flower-Gumssjoni u r-Rappreżentant Għoli biex tiffirma l-Konvenzjoni tan-Nazzjonijiet Uniti, għan-nom tal-Unjoni Ewropea, biex b'hekk ikun hemm document u leħen sod, li jkun gwida għal kull bniedem, għal kull nazzjon. It-tfal huma l-futur. Però ma ninsewx li huma wkoll il-preżent li għandna ngħożżu u fuckraw. U għaldaqstant irridu naġixxu issa.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Mr President, this month we are celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, ratified throughout the European Union, by 194 States. It is undoubtedly the most complete declaration of the rights of the child that has ever been made. It demonstrates a global commitment to the protection of the rights of the child. Since its adoption in 1989, conditions have certainly improved, but indeed there is still a long way to go, because there are so many forgotten and invisible children. It is those children—millions of children around the world—who are vulnerable, those children involved in armed conflict, orphaned children, child soldiers. More than half of the world's victims of human trafficking are children and many deaths of children dying from drinking water difficulties in developing countries could now be prevented. Two hundred million children under the age of five cannot achieve their development because of poverty, and nearly half of people in extreme poverty are children. This data gives us the view that we have a lot of work to do , also in the European Union — because 27% of children are at risk of poverty. Moreover, sexual abuse remains unfortunately a real problem. The lives of thousands of children are at stake and, therefore, the implementation of the Convention and the support of the Union, the Commission, all the institutions and society as a whole would cause thousands of children's lives to stop suffering. That is why the request is to the European Union: to promote the rights of children decisively and to promote them on the international stage.  The European Union has signed the Millennium Declaration, which includes the Millennium Development Goals, which include reducing child mortality. It is to comply with the Convention on the Rights of the Child. In the end, a memory for the most vulnerable children, especially girls, disabled girls, immigrant girls. All the effort must be devoted to these groups as a matter of priority.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: 25 years ago, we promised children that we would protect them, fight for their rights to grow up in a healthy and safe way, and provide opportunities for learning and development so that they grow up full members of our society. However, the latest UNICEF report provides shocking figures on how many children are in poverty in Europe, how many children are in poverty worldwide. I will talk about the European Union– the most impact on the change of poverty has been on those indiscriminate austerity, and above all at the expense of children. I therefore believe that we need new measures. For example, the Children's Guarantee Initiative, which could provide specific, financially sound measures to help poor children in our European Union. In addition, the EU Recommendation on investment in children and the fight against child poverty must be implemented as quickly and effectively as possible. And here we must first talk about helping families raising children.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: Sur President, it-tfal huma l-futur u l-preżent tagťna. Individwi bid-drittijiet u b'dinjità inherent. Li ninvestu fit-tfal ifisser li ninvestu f'infrastruttura li tassigura żvilupp intellettwali, psikolożiku u emozzjonali b'mod olistiku. Din tirrikjedi politika komprensiva u strateżika. Investiment f'infrastructure soťjali gťandu jassigura li fl-Ewropa jkollna system li mill-ewwel tidentifika t-tfal f'riskju u tipprovdilhom is-servizzi meťtieťa. L-aťjar interess tat-tfal jibqa' żrafa sakemm ningażżaw l-istakeholders kollha relevant, social welfare officers, pulizija, leżiżlaturi, żudikanti u edukaturi. Viżjoni f'liema t-tfal huma individwi bid-drittijiet anke fil-parteżipazzjoni tagťhom fil-familja. F'xi Member States din titlob bidliet leżiżlattivi u sożjali u l-Unjoni gťandha tkun il-katalista liżżib din il-bidla. It-tfal gťandhom vuèi u l-aťjar interess tagťhom jitlob li kull deżiżjoni żudizzjarja li taffettwahom gťandha tikkunsidra l-opinjoni tagťhom, speèjalment fil-proʻeduri tal-familja b'element cross-border. Mhux l-Istati Members kollha jirrikonoxxu dan b'mod ugwali, u ťafna drabi l-vuèi tat-tfal hija lanqas mismugťa. Dan mhuwiex aèettabbli. Tfal b'diffikultajiet ta' saťťa mentali huma esposti gťal levelll ogťla ta' abbuż. L-Unjoni gťandha tassigura li jirťievu l-ogťla levelll ta' kura żo faèilitajiet li jirrispettaw id-dinjità tagťhom u li l-iżvilupp edukattiv u soèjali tagťhom jiżi fażilitat. Gťat-tfal f'kura l-ewwel prijorità tal-Unjoni gťandha tkun li tiffaťilita u tgťin strutturi li jsaťťu family-based care billivesti tin f'servizzi ta' social welfare li jingťataw lill-familji f'diffikultà. Fejn family-based care ma tkunx possibbli gťandna nassiguraw li l-miżura ta' kura alternattiva tipprovdi l-ogťla levelll ta' kura li tassigura żvilupp sťiť tat-tfal. Insejjať lill-Gvern Malti sabiex juri impenn veritier u reali fir-rigward tat-tfal billi jgťaddi liżi li tirrikonoxxi u tipproteżi d-drittijiet tat-tfal, jipprovdi fondi suffièjenti lil social institutions li joffru kenn lil dawn it-tfal f'periklu.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Under Article 3 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, States are to respect the rights and responsibilities of parents when ensuring the protection of the child. According to Article 14, States are to respect the rights and obligations of parents in guiding a child in relation to the exercise of his or her right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion. Under Article 18, parents have a prior right to raise their child. According to Article 29, they are also intended to ensure that the child's education also develops respect for his or her parents, their cultural identity and values. According to Article 35, they are intended to prevent child trafficking by all means. Today, these provisions are regularly ignored in Europe. Many Member States do not respect the rights and obligations of parents in relation to their own children. This is particularly evident in situations where parents do not agree with aggressive sex education, at which time states do not hesitate to use violence either, only to violate one of the rights of the child guaranteed by this convention. And legalizing surrogacy is just eye-opening to child trafficking. However, we will not find any of this in this resolution. The family is mentioned only twice. Once in relation to family allowances and then in point 23, which talks about bringing families together. Instead of condemning gross violations of children's rights in the European Union, the proposal attempts to make their gender and sexual identities more difficult. In doing so, the Convention defines a child as a person aged between 0 and 18 years of age and sexual identity is not defined at all in international law. The resolution seeks to protect children in different situations and at different ages, but not a single sentence protects a child's right to be born. For these reasons, I also believe that the resolution as presented is not a worthy reminder of the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Emil RADEV
text: Ladies and gentlemen, the 25th anniversary of the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is like any such anniversary – enough time has elapsed to assess the progress made, but also insufficient to fully comply with all the rules set out in the Convention. The document contains universal principles for the rights of all children, regardless of their background and culture, valid at all times and without exception, existing for the simple reason that children were born. Although a number of countries comply with their legislation with the Convention, unfortunately the idea that children have their own rights is not widely accepted. Too many children are still considered property, subjected to exploitation and violence or involved against their will in direct involvement in conflicts. As a union of democratic states, the European Union has a moral obligation to be an example in the implementation of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. It must develop policies representing today's children and future active European citizens in the first place. All actions taken, whether in terms of economic recovery or ensuring long-term security, must be for the sake of a better future for our children.  I hope we will discuss soon not how to overcome, but how we have overcome the challenges of guaranteeing the rights of the child.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: The 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child is the result of our responsibility and commitment to work for member states to adopt all legal frameworks for the promotion and protection of the rights of the child. In addition to everything that has been said today, I would like to stress that we must also encourage children to know what their rights are and to know that violence is illegal, even in cases where it is carried out by people who trust them. We are committed to continue to care for the rights of the child and to work towards member states to take all legal frameworks and other measures to end violence against children.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Thank you very much for the floor, Mr. President. Although a lot of worrying words have been said here in this Chamber today, I believe that children do not have the ability to act for their own rights, so we have a special responsibility here. And this does not only cover what has been listed so far, but I would also like to join in the previous speech by a colleague here: many children in Europe are simply starving. Almost a quarter of European children are almost on the brink of starvation. In the mere, some Member States collect horribilis taxes on food. In my country, Hungary only, the government charges food taxes by 27%. These things must also be taken into account when we say that we take care of the fate of children. Thank you very much!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, since 1989 the UN has adopted the Convention on the Rights of the Child, but the situation remains dramatic in many countries. In Greece in particular and because of the memoranda imposed by the Troika, according to a Unicef report, the average family income of households with children has dipped to 1998 levels. Child poverty has worsened, from 23% in 2008 to 40% in 2012 and the country now ranks in the penultimate position of OECD countries, based on the proportion of young people who do not study and work. At the same time, according to a survey by the Hellenic Statistical Authority, the percentages of households in the country that are unable to offer basic goods to their children increased dramatically during the five years 2009 to 2013. Particularly acute are the problems faced by three- and long-term families. The Greek people have therefore been impoverished by the memoranda and there are now widespread phenomena in Greece of violation of the rights of the child.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van The Convention on the Rights of the Child is currently the convention with the highest number of Member States in the world. However, it is consistently being violated. This means that, unfortunately, a recognised right has not yet been implemented and that the implementation of the principles of the Convention must now be dealt with as seriously as it was ten or twenty years ago.  150 million children in today's world cannot read or write, one in ten children suffer sexual harassment, a large number of children are still dying of diseases that the world has long been able to treat and limit.
