Last year, 6.5 million children died worldwide. The problem, among other things, is that we value success mainly through statistical averages, but it creates a shifting sense of success.  The rights of millions of children are still being violated every day, most of all the rights of the poorest 20%. Millions of children are suffering in conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Ukraine and elsewhere. It is important that you work together to solve this problem both ... (The speech was interrupted.)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are celebrating the 25th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. It's unfortunately a sad birthday.  Dr Mukwege, in one of the crudest, truest and most touching speeches ever made in this House, has shaken our consciences, reminding us that even today in many countries the rape of boys and girls is a weapon of humiliation and submission. In Uzbekistan and many other developing countries, millions of minors are being exploited to ensure that European multinationals make more profit. The list is very long and we in Europe too have failed in our duty. Go and see what happened to education and social care in Greece. Go and see the unworthy price paid for austerity.  The High Representative's proposal is right, but without trade relations consistent with our principles. As long as we allow economic policies that are contrary to children's rights, the dreams of many children in Europe and throughout the world will be endless nightmares.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, I would like to say to the honourable Members of the European Parliament that upholding the rights of children and preventing and responding to any kind of violence against children will remain a top priority for the EU. This is also witnessed by the fact that, together with our Latin American and Caribbean friends, we table every year at the UN in New York a resolution addressing specific challenges for children. This year it was discrimination and inequality. Many challenges remain when it comes to complete fulfilment of the rights of children worldwide and ensuring that the post-2015 world will be a better place for children. Nevertheless, we are encouraged by this 25th anniversary, and the almost universal ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child proves that there is an abundance of political will to make a lasting difference. We are also encouraged by the staunch support shown by this House with its resolution on the rights of the child. The Commission and the European External Action Service look forward to close cooperation with Parliament in ensuring that the rights of the child are effectively mainstreamed in legislation and policy, as requested by this House.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: We have received a motion for a resolution, tabled in accordance with Article 123(2). The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 27 November 2014. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – The UNITED NATIONS Convention on the Rights of the Child entered into force 25 years ago. In this context, compliance with the Convention shall be examined every six years in each Member State. The civilian report sent in February 2014 underlines that between 2006 and 2012 the situation of children in Hungary deteriorated considerably and has now become unacceptable. It is worse than the country's economic situation would justify, or the government would like to see it. We're in a crisis. In Hungary, according to newly published Eurostat research, a third of people (33.5%) poverty or social exclusion, an increase of 5 percentage points compared to a year earlier (!). According to the latest figures from the Child Benefit Association, 43 per cent of minors are affected by poverty. Education and the social care system are primarily responsible for helping to break out of the poverty trap. This system has been continuously downsized over the last 5 years: by lowering the school age from 18 to 16, by nationalisation of the school system, by segregation in schools now openly and directly supported by the State, and by significantly limiting unemployment benefit and converting it into public work, by making housing benefit and free meals available to the most needy children impossible. Hungary, many small regions are in a state that we have only seen in the third world. We also have a duty to combat child poverty within the Union.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: written – The twenty-fifth anniversary of the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, let it also be an opportunity to warn that even today many children are discriminated against, are suffering from hunger and poverty, and are not receiving education or healthcare, many are homeless. Children are the most vulnerable in every state, in every establishment, so protecting them is very important. We can name the problems of children in underdeveloped countries and in countries where there is violence and wars, but also an advanced Europe has not yet tackled the problems of discrimination against children by sex, sexual exploitation, child labour, poverty and children's lack of access to education. The achievements of the present day, such as internetisation, aggressive advertising or cyberbullying, also contribute to endangering not only the upbringing of children, but also their own. That is also why it is important to talk about children's problems, not only on the anniversary of the UN Convention, but in adopting different policies in the context of education, healthcare, poverty, support for families, surrogate families, but also homeless children. I will support the resolution and believe that, on the next anniversary, we will be able to talk about improving the application of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. – Children's rights were explicitly incorporated into the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in 2000. This is important and very progressive compared to Germany, for example. In Germany, children's rights are still not part of the Constitution, which I very much regret. But for me, this inclusion results in numerous commitments for the EU. On the one hand, there is the unacceptably high number of children living in poverty who do not have sufficient access to education and participation in society. Children are not small adults, but have special needs that must be laid down in European law: we must ensure that special attention is paid to the interests of children when it comes to building requirements, social and spatial planning. This includes the participation of children in all planning processes that affect them. We must work this in order to make children's rights more than fine words.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writting. –We are currently celebrating the 25th anniversary of the adoption of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. In the context of economic, social and cultural rights, States Parties to the Convention should undertake necessary measures to the maximum extent of their available resources and, where needed, within the framework of international cooperation. Poverty and social exclusion is a challenge to all Member States. The UN Convention recommends international cooperation to better protect the economic, social and cultural rights of children. European treaties also provide a framework for such cooperation. We cannot ignore gloomy statistics that in new Member States every third child lives at risk of poverty and social exclusion: for example, 9.5 % of Estonian children lived in absolute poverty in 2012. I call on my colleagues in Parliament to intensify political pressure on the Commission and on their Member States to start real and substantial cooperation to fight child poverty in the European Union. The first and the most important result of this cooperation might be the introduction, in the interests of children, of minimum social standards to be met by all Member States, if necessary with the assistance of the EU and other Member States.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission Declaration on the outcome of the G20 meeting. We ask Mr Gozi to speak and make the introductory declaration (2014/2968(RSP)).

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, thank you for the opportunity you give the rotating Presidency, as Italy, as a member of the G20, to speak on this issue, since you know that at the G20 the European Union is represented by the PRESIDENCY of the EU Council and the Presidency of the Commission. However, we were pleased to accept your invitation to comment on the results of the G20. This is a result that we regard as very positive, because it is certainly very consistent with our approach to economic matters, which we have given, we have tried to give and we have proposed during the six months that we are chairing the Council of the European Union. The issue of growth in Brisbane has been taken up by everyone, and I have to say that as Italy we have certainly not suffered from a lack of company. The desire to overcome the unnecessary dualism of austerity/growth was clear and it was above all clear that there was a desire to do more, much more and much better in favour of growth and investment. We need to change the game and we need to focus much more on growth and jobs. This was a summary of the message that came out of the G20.  The central message, which is also found in the summit conclusions, is that the world economy, and in particular the European economy and the Japanese economy, are still a long way from the growth rates they are expected to achieve. The global economy remains vulnerable to possible shocks, and the third point – on which the progress we have made, even recently – has also been underlined– is the need to strengthen the resilience, resilience and resilience of the banking system. From this point of view, the banking union and the stress tests that we have carried out and are carrying out within the European Union have certainly been identified as a very positive step forward. What are the global and possible responses that emerged from the summit? It is certainly necessary to propose a set of growth strategies based on public and private investment, based on stronger promotion of competition and a commitment to increase trade and employment.  Very important is the commitment that all G20 members have made to increase demand, especially through a new internal investment policy, and in general the commitment to create a new regulatory climate that is much more favourable, including new instruments, such as securitisations in favour of small and medium-sized enterprises. The recognition of the serious and serious gap between global investment and real investment is a very clear gap, and it is also this morning's debate that we had when Mr Juncker presented the investment plan. A gap that is very evident in Europe. It has been highlighted by everyone in Brisbane, and that is why the Global Infrastructure Initiative has also been launched in particular for the infrastructure sector.  That's why it's very important, as a further contribution alongside the Banking Union, alongside stress tests, as a further contribution by the European Union – a contribution that was already mentioned, because it was announced by the President of the Commission and all the European members of the G20 – the full and rapid implementation of the investment plan presented this morning by President Juncker and mentioned precisely in the G20 conclusions, which for us is a first response to a broader and new investment policy that we must pursue at European and national level. Another very important issue that is linked to the work we are doing during the six months has been the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance, in particular the need and importance of taxing the real profits where they are generated. An important reference has been made and much work has been done in Brisbane on the 2015 erosion and profit shifting plan and so-called erosion and profit shifting base.  There has also been a commitment to increase the automatic exchange of information between countries and to complete the necessary legislative processes within the systems of the various countries in order to achieve an exchange of information. The fight against tax fraud, against evasion, even against overly aggressive tax plans, has also emerged. Moreover, this is a priority issue for the European Union, an issue to which the Italian Presidency has made a great deal of effort, and I would just remind you of the progress made on the automatic exchange of information between tax administrations. The last issue of interest to us as Europeans, and this is unfortunately not a good thing, but it does not depend on Europe or on Europeans, is the lack of progress in implementing the reforms already identified in 2010 with regard to the Monetary Fund. international level in this area. This remains one of the top priorities for the G20 and certainly the United States of America has again been required to speed up and commit itself to ratifying those reforms already identified in 2010. Of course, we are now committed to fully following up and implementing those guidelines in which we are fully involved, above all – and I will end here, Mr President – because of the emphasis on growth and the need to change the economic policy approach clearly at a time when Europe and Japan certainly need to do more and better than other partners, who have suffered equally from the crisis but are emerging from it at this time more quickly, and we also think it is more convincing.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, I am glad of the opportunity to debrief this Parliament on the outcome of the G20 Summit in Brisbane, where President Juncker, President Van Rompuy and I myself represented the European Union. It was the ninth G20 Summit after the launch of the LEADERS process in 2008. Let me state at the onset that I am very pleased with the results of this meeting. Not only are they encouraging and ambitious results from a global governance standpoint, but they also reflect the main – if not all the – desiderata of the EU and, I believe, of this Parliament. Let me emphasis four main points. First, on the global economy. As per G20 mission and tradition, the state of the global economy was the main item on the agenda. The G20 sent a message of confidence while remaining realistic about the current economic outlook. G20 leaders called for a policy mix that strikes an appropriate balance between the need to promote demand, implement structural reforms and act with fiscal credibility. These are the three pillars of our economic policy, so we could not agree more with this recipe. In order to strengthen the recovery, the Australian Presidency focused on identifying measures that should be adopted in order to foster growth, create jobs and support investment. This delivers strong policy coherence on investment between the global G20 level, the EU level and national level, which is most helpful for the current global economy. In this connection, G20 leaders welcomed the Commission’s EUR 300 billion investment package, and the Brisbane action plan notes that the European Union announced in October a major initiative mobilising additional public and private investment over the years 2015 to 2017. This is meant as a strong signal of encouragement for our investment initiative. Leaders also recognised the value of securitisation to help finance small and medium-sized enterprises. Second, tax transparency. Work related to the international tax system was an important deliverable of the summit. Leaders emphasised the importance of taxing profits where they are generated. President Obama said that the work of tax transparency is the G20 at its best, and we agreed with this. The G20 endorsed progress made on the base erosion and profit-shifting initiative of the OECD, which tackles issues such as the importance of transparency to counter harmful tax practices and the taxation of profits generated online by internet companies. Leaders committed to completing this work by the end of 2015. We called for an automatic exchange of taxpayer-specific rulings. Thanks to the support from many other leaders, we succeeded in securing a stronger emphasis on the final communiqué on this important issue. We will keep the matter on the G20 agenda and move ahead in the EU. Third, on trade. The announcement just two days before the summit of an agreement between India and the US on the implementation of the Bali Trade Facilitation Agreement changed the tone of the discussion. As a result of this agreement, leaders could focus on the implementation of the Bali decisions and the perspective of the completion of the Doha Development Agenda. We underlined the importance of robust and effective WTOs as a response to the current and future challenges. We all agreed to discuss ways to make the system work better at the next G20 Summit in Turkey. Finally, on climate change. After a difficult discussion, and with the support of key international partners, we overcame strong efforts to limit the reference to climate change to a bare minimum, which would not be acceptable for us. This was yet another example of the EU and its G20 Member States working together and in unison to uphold and to promote an EU position. We eventually obtained a reference to the need to communicate the intended nationally-determined contributions well in advance of COP 21, and to mobilise finance for adoption and mitigation, mentioning the Green Climate Fund. These are practical steps which should facilitate reaching an agreement at the Paris Conference. You may recall that the starting point of the Australian Presidency was not to mention climate change at all in the G20 context. I look forward to a fruitful discussion.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The European Commission today presented what I believe to be a necessary and very ambitious investment plan for Europe, a strong impetus to restore confidence in the European economy. I very much welcome the fact that the European Union has already actively promoted this plan in Brisbane. The world often expects positive news from both the European Union and the G20. The two initiatives, the G20 Investment Initiative and the Investment Plan for Europe, are two promising examples. Moreover, we should not forget that credibility is the cornerstone of sustainable growth and jobs. We need to continue the structural reforms that have already been undertaken and to keep them on the right track. The fairness of corporate tax policy is also an important item on the EU and G20 agendas. The Member States have already done a great deal to ensure that Europe plays a leading role in the automatic exchange of tax information. However, we also recognise that the driving force is still a G20 initiative with close OECD cooperation. The globally defined standard for reporting on the automatic exchange of tax data must continue to be promoted on a reciprocal basis, even beyond the G20. The European Parliament wants to go further in terms of transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policy. As the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we insist that there should be an understandable, forward-looking and rapid input on so-called extended tax incomes. Such a special report must be drafted by Parliament, and this report must include proposals such as transparency coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies. In the meantime, we call on the G20 to continue its work in this context.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would particularly like to thank the Presidency for its comments on tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. After all, the tax practices in individual Member States that have come to light in recent weeks and have been discussed throughout Europe are only the tip of the iceberg. According to a 2012 study, EU Member States lose €1,000 a year in tax fraud and tax fraud. That is almost eight times the EU budget for the current year or, in other words, about three times what the President of the Commission presented to us this morning as an amount for the major investment programme for Europe. It is overdue to act here. The EU must lead the way in this. This is an important first step. However, it is equally important that we actually continue to act and move forward on a global scale. The issue of taxation was therefore rightly on the agenda at the G20 summit. The commitment to a fairer organisation of international tax agreements is a start. However, further steps must now be taken in a timely manner. Let me mention three of them. Firstly, the OECD initiative against profit shifting and tax cuts in the EU and at global level must be taken forward. Profits are taxed where they are generated. Multinational corporations must no longer shift profits from high-tax countries to tax havens in the form of often ridiculously low royalties. To achieve this, we need an automatic exchange of information. Secondly, we need a targeted approach to tax havens. The OECD definition does not go far enough here. A clear definition and a clear set of criteria for tax havens are needed in order to identify them and take action against them. We in the S&D are therefore calling for a blacklist to be drawn up for tax havens across Europe. Thirdly, the fight against money laundering. This, too, must be strengthened. The owners behind often nested letterbox companies must be brought to light. To do this, we need public registers that are accessible to everyone. The overriding objective of all measures must be: even what has often been legal but has been recognised as illegitimate must also be completely and permanently prevented at both European and global level. In other words, tax practices that are illegitimate must also be illegal in the future.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, I would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! All the initiatives mentioned by Commissioner Dombrovskis described in the G20 documents, both the conclusions and the action plan, which is intended to lead to an increase that also increases employment – valuable employment, not on the basis of 'junk contracts' – are very important. Infrastructure programmes, large programmes, the adaptation of the banking system and the establishment of an infrastructure 'hub' are important.  However, there is one aspect that needed to be indicated at the G20 summit: that is security. Security also has an economic dimension, and its absence kills any hope of growth and development. However, this issue is completely not reflected in the G20 documents. After my region's entry into NATO and the European Union, we have experienced an incredible period of economic growth. The entrepreneurial spirit has been liberated. Foreign direct investment, major infrastructure projects. All these opportunities have been killed by open aggression in our region, the threat of balkanisation of the region. You, Commissioner, and the President of the Commission, the President of the Council, represented only part of the European Union at the G20. You have not identified any economic, developmental or social risks to our region. Behind the media veil of Vladimir Putin's isolation, there has been an agreement above our heads.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. Mr. President, 200 million unemployed, of which 75 million are young people. It's a statement from Brisbane, Australia, the first statement that the analysis, which is unfortunately accurate, is probably the numbers and higher. But what pleases me are a few things that are as a result of this summit, and the first is something that is intangible. There was finally talk about the need to employ young people in a very concrete way, it was mentioned on several occasions. And also extremely important, which is the right to equality of women in the labour market and employment of women, in the desire that women should be on an equal footing in the part concerning quality employment and getting a quality job. World growth is conditio sine qua non of course getting out of the crisis.  How much will Europe participate in this? After today's announcement, of course we expect this to be significant and that is why we are extremely pleased when we are even more pleased about the need to invest in large projects, but we are even more pleased by the fact that medium and small enterprises are recognized as growth generators. It is also important for us to talk about climate change, about their problems, to talk about the green economy, that is, the Green Climate Fund and what the green industry means today and tomorrow in the world.  Of course, it is important to have a private and public partnership that is also recognized as a growth generator at this summit and of course what colleagues have already mentioned, which is extremely important tax transparency, because there is huge money going around here in the world economy, unfortunately many times that money is not taxed where it should and does not serve in the function of growing the economy.

name: João FERREIRA
text: gue/NGL Group. – The results of the G20 meeting denote, first of all, the degree of depth of a crisis that is far from being overcome. The inability of the main capitalist powers to overcome the systemic crisis in which they are plunged is visible. For this very part, because it is a systemic crisis, which will find no solution, but in the context of the suppression of the unjust and oppressive system that has generated it. In the face of new data that highlight the prospect of stagnation or even recession in some of the major economies, for example in Europe, the hundreds of measures pointed to the economic recovery result in little more than a handful of nothing and another of nothing. In the absence of room for manoeuvre for the application of Keynesian revenue, such is the scale of the crisis reaffirming the prospect of channeling public resources to multinationals under so-called infrastructure investment programmes.  Once again, there is talk of combating tax evasion, but not a word is said about the necessary end to tax havens, on the deregulation of the financial system, which continues to allow evasion, in addition to other criminal practices such as money laundering.

name: Petr MACH
text: on the efdd group. Mr. Ferreira didn't finish it. Do you find it hypocritical to talk about the fact that profits are to be taxed where they are made, and that at the same time the European Commission is led by Mr Juncker, who was prime minister in a country that is and was a tax haven and which offered favourable tax rates to those who come to tax in his country?  You are talking about trade, I agree that free trade can promote growth, but do you find it hypocritical that, on the one hand, you are negotiating a trade agreement with the United States that contains an arbitration clause, and at the same time your Members will propose a division of Google tomorrow? I think that if they propose it tomorrow, and if the TTIP treaty were in place, that would be the first opportunity for arbitration so that the European taxpayer would have to pay money to an American company.  You are talking about investment, how important investment is to the economy. I agree, but what you're offering is hypocrisy again. President Juncker has unveiled the idea, a plan for the European Commission to take EUR 8 billion from the European Union budget, that the European Investment Bank will add another EUR 5 billion to it, and that by some miracle it will generate 315 billion investments. Don't you find that hypocritical? You talk all the time about growth, about jobs, but we are in an area of the European Union where there is no growth, where there are no jobs. You devised the Lisbon Strategy until 2010, to be the most competitive economy in the world, and we have become an economy that is not growing at all. Please keep this hypocrisy.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, beyond the media spectacle, there was little to expect from this new edition of the G20, except confirmation of the european Union's orientations, which are increasingly subject to the globalist ideology and the interests of the United States. While some persist in the dream of a world government under American protectorate, others, like Russia, which is far from being as isolated as you like, are preparing the multipolar world of tomorrow that patriots of all countries are calling for.  At the G20, the Australian Prime Minister's anti-Russian rantings had nothing to envy to the collective hysteria of the European institutions. On the other hand, I call on our Parliament to draw inspiration from Australia's strong, clear and firm migration policy.  Operation Sovereign Borders, launched in September 2013, has deterred illegal immigrants and dried up the networks of smugglers who thrive on the world's misery. If we really want to, we too can protect our borders and prevent so many unfortunate people from perishing trying to reach them.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, the G20's commitment to work to boost growth and economic resilience is now highly topical. And it is timely not only because growth, both globally and in Europe, is very weak and weaker than expected, but also because President Juncker, a few hours ago, presented here the EUR 315 billion investment plan. In the case of Europe, the amount of the aid was EUR 1 million. This is an ambitious project which, if properly implemented, has the potential to achieve the desired objective, namely to create more than one million new jobs within the next three years without burdening Europe with debt. It is, of course, a plan that needs clarification and even detail, because the details matter and because the devil sometimes hides in the details: the European Commission must tell us how the EUR 315 billion is generated. The multiplier is highly ambitious, reaching 15 by leveraging the funds. An even more important question is what will happen to the countries in crisis. President Juncker said today that countries in crisis have priority. The first country to suffer the most serious consequences from the crisis is Greece. What procedure will be followed to ensure that these countries benefit first from the programmes coming from the new Fund? We need to keep and make use of the Commission's initiative because it is very important and because it is a direct response to the G20 commitment. We must also be immediately given clarifications on how the Commission and the European Investment Bank will move in relation to new and innovative financial instruments. What's that going to be? It is a very important part of the new investment project and we need to know, not because we see the Commission's initiative negatively but because we need to exert pressure, we need to work to have more confidence and to reduce risk. It is obvious that the new project has a very basic and ambitious objective: to change the image of Europe. We no longer have time in Europe, this was reflected in the G20 declaration and, even more so, the countries that have suffered the effects of the crisis do not have time.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: Madam President, it is true that I am not passionate about the G20. From the first summit in Washington, after the fall of Lehman Brothers, to this day they accumulate a series of unfulfilled initiatives, of unfulfilled promises: suppression of tax havens, greater regulation of financial systems, better governance mechanisms and taxation of financial transactions. But we cannot ignore, Commissioner, that the European Union has once again focused the big concerns of this summit: near-zero growth rates, unbearable poverty and unemployment rates for global economic growth, risk of deflation, a drastic wage devaluation that has made us more vulnerable to outside economic situations and, above all, , more unfair inside. Everyone is asking the European Union to change. Everyone is asking the European Union to do more, but above all, to do different things to get out of the crisis and stimulate growth. They're asking us for common sense. And in the meantime, all we are capable of is a Europe divided between those who want change and stimulus, and those who resign themselves to austerity and failure. Commissioner, only with monetary policy, however expansive, we will not get out of the crisis. We need more ambitious fiscal stimulus than Juncker put forward this morning in Parliament. We need to bury the austerity demanded by Germany and flexibly interpret the Stability and Growth Pact. We need structural reforms to be fair, not to depress domestic demand, to maintain the purchasing power of citizens. We need higher incomes, worrying about income, ending fraud, tax evasion. We need to be able to enter to stimulate more. And in short, we need solidarity, height of sight and turns to avoid a decade lost in economic growth and, above all, a society defeated precisely because we are not able to change.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Commissioner, at the G20 summit, you once again concluded that Europe lacks growth. There is nothing surprising about this at all, because Europe is basically doing everything it can to ensure that there is no growth. It raises taxes, it worsens the business environment, the European Union is inventing new regulations all the time and it is setting unrealistic climate targets. And then everyone is just wondering that there is no growth, that companies are leaving Europe. The only solution for which the European Union can recover is even more government spending, even more of what has caused the debt crisis, even more spending, even more debt. If the European Union really wants to tackle growth and actually reduce unemployment, it must let banks and states that cannot manage go bankrupt, reduce the level of regulation, stop overreacting to the environment, climate objectives and systematically improve the business environment.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: It is to be welcomed that the leaders of the world's major powers have gathered for the 20th meeting in Brisbane to discuss today's fundamental issues. It is good that heads of state have discussed and provided guidance for the future on issues such as global and sustainable economic growth, climate change and the fight against Ebola. It should be noted that the relatively unified position of the participants in assessing the situation in Ukraine and russia's role in it. The fact that Russian President Vladimir Putin attended the meeting, as well as the fact that the leaders of many countries have expressed open opinions and assessments of the events in Ukraine directly to the Russian President, is a good thing, and hopefully this will help him to get used, help stabilise the situation in Ukraine and find a peaceful and wise solution. Although, seeing what is happening today on the Lithuanian-Russian border, seeing other Russian actions, there is more space for doubt than would have been.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Let us remember that the Community of the 20 largest states is a very important and very powerful institution, that it represents two-thirds of the world's population, that it represents two-thirds of global trade, that it represents more than 80% of global gross income. When such a powerful community comes together, I also expect great solutions, and I do not expect Mr Juncker's sleight of hand with an investment package without fresh money and just a pushback of money, but I expect structural solutions in the financial sector. The first would be that, since it became clear during the 2008 crisis, we have finally made a separation of commercial and investment banks, so that no longer ludicrous bank managers can go to the financial casino with the money of savers and investors, but have the obligation to invest this money only more, and investment banks are separated from it separately. This would bring stability to finance. Secondly, the area of over-the-counter trading must finally be put on a leash, so that we no longer deal with two-thirds of all stock exchange transactions in the area of dark pools, in the area of over-the-counter trading, leaving managers and banks free to trade and there to be ever larger, uncontrollable, non-transparent structures. The summit has achieved that the gap between the G7 countries, on the one hand, and the BRICS countries on the other, has widened. We do not need that. We need a prosperous future for the international community, of the great blocs, in the interests of the people, so that the primacy of politics is regained and the financial markets are no longer left on a long leash.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the European Central Bank, the OECD, the IMF and now even the G20 say that all the economic assumptions we had over the last 20 years, which were neoliberal assumptions, are no longer working and that today we need to increase the demand for goods and services at the international level.  To this end, we know that the issues of tax evasion, tax evasion, investment and ecological transition are top priorities. As my colleague Gutiérrez Prieto said earlier, the Commission and the European Union must now make these new assumptions, which are good assumptions, and act. This means acting decisively and quickly on the issue of tax evasion and it means that we need to go much further in terms of investment compared to this morning's proposal, which is a first step but insufficient. In particular, we must target investment where it is useful for a new development model and therefore make every effort to ensure that the ecological transition takes place in the European Union so that we are the pioneers in this area and that we are ahead of the curve. That is it, we need to make a change in economic policy today, even the G20 says so. It is time for us to follow that path.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, the Group of Socialists and Democrats takes note of the progress, it is right, modest, which has been communicated to us and nevertheless enjoys the commitment of the G20 states to increase gross domestic product by at least 2% by 2018. But the big conclusion is this: if other countries have managed to overcome the effects of the crisis in the same period, and Europe has not, it means that our recipe has been bad and the others have had a better exit from the crisis. We also take note of the desire to relaunch investment and create jobs, just as the investment plan discussed in Parliament was. On the other hand, we have taken note of the agreement to prevent cross-border tax evasion through the mutual exchange of information, as well as the taxation of profits at the place where it occurs, but nothing significant is said about the fight against tax havens and, let's face it, this is the real problem, it is the colossus, it is the giant, equivalent to the GDP of the United States, which remains untouched , is the hideout where the world's untaxed money hides. Negotiations on climate change have been discussed, but we Europeans must complain that we have not been to the hill between the United States and China (it had been signed, it is right, before, in Beijing). And the last remark: very little about Ebola. Does the G20 not recognise that the Member States and existing international entities have failed to prevent the crisis, have failed to coordinate so that its scale and effects do not reach the magnitude it has today and do not entail the economic, social and human costs that we will all experience? All of us Europeans, but also the states of Africa. This is where I expected it to be the leading role of the European Union and our respected voice.

name: David MARTIN
text: Madam President, there are four European Union Member States in the G20 as well as the European Union itself. And, sadly for all of us, our growth is stagnating while by and large the growth of the other G20 countries is rapidly expanding. So, while I welcome the Commission’s investment pledge that we heard today – to kick-start the European economy – I think we have to be realistic and say that we cannot have sustained economic recovery by endogenous means alone. We need to look to exogenous growth in order to get our economy really moving and to sustain our growth. That means expanding our international trade agenda. As the world’s biggest market, we are not yet realising our full potential. The G20 reaffirmed its commitment to the multilateral trading system, something I and my group welcome. We welcome the fact that the Bali package has been given a kick-start as a result of the G20 negotiations. But for the immediate future, multilateralism is not going to be the answer, sadly but realistically, so we have to look at our bilateral trade agenda. We have to make sure that the Singapore and the Canadian free trade agreements are ratified. We have to make sure that we succeed in our negotiations with the US and Japan; we have to ensure that we get a good investment agreement with China. But we have to ensure that we do all of these things not at any price, but at the values – funnily enough – set out by the G20. We have to ensure that these agreements include an emphasis on fair growth, an emphasis on sustainable development and fair labour standards and tax transparency and strong financial regulation. If we can achieve that in our bilateral trade agreements, we can contribute to the G20 objectives and to expanding the European economy.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the G20 summit in Brisbane marks a turning point in the response to the economic crisis that is stifling our continent. Growth, development and employment have become not the goal of a single country, but a strategy common to all large countries. A strategy that has been put into practice in Europe today with the investment plan presented by President Juncker, a plan which, with all its limitations, nevertheless represents a turning point in the Economic Policies of the European Union by abandoning the old path of austerity.  We need a Europe that plays the attack on the international stage, a Europe that takes back the leading role in the production of goods and that is not afraid to be a protagonist again in economic and trade relations. We must have the courage to transform that Europe that is a little tired, aged and compressed, which tends to feel less like a protagonist, as the Pope well described it yesterday in this House, into a Europe that is running again and that still represents an opportunity for future generations.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at the Brisbane Summit we discussed global growth, supply and demand, GDP, monetary authority and the stability of the financial system, structural reforms. However, reading the final communiqué, I was particularly struck by the lack of references to those economic and productive sectors that, with the everyday nature of their activity, define the economy. I am referring to micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, which, especially in Europe, form the backbone of the economic system and which every day are committed and engaged to cope with the most serious period of economic activity since the post-war period. Nothing is also said about the fight against tax havens. I believe that the G20 should also have dealt with these issues and should have made concrete and global proposals on these issues.  On the other hand, the approval of the G20 anti-corruption action plan for 2015 and 2016 is a good one, which I hope will lead to improvements in transparency and efficiency in both the private and public sectors, as well as the reference to the actions to be taken to mitigate the effects of climate change and to promote youth employment, which has reached unacceptable levels.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Madam President, Mr Gozi said the result of the G20 was favourable to his view of economics. Well, if his view of economics is reflected in what Mr Juncker said this morning, with his giant watering can of EU funding that he was going to randomly splash around the place to an economy that is already in debt – up to 90% of GDP, by his figures, and 50% of that GDP made up of the state sector – only weeds of financial mismanagement, debt and despair will grow in Mr Juncker’s garden. Frankly, if that is what we are trying to achieve, God help us.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, I would like to say to the honourable Members of the European Parliament: thank you, first of all, for this debate and for your comments. We will surely take good note and make good use of those comments and recommendations as we embark on another G20 year under the leadership of Turkey later this year. Despite some critical assessments that I have heard, I am convinced that the G20 is here to stay. It is the only global forum which brings together both advanced and emerging countries, and it is indispensable for moving the global economy from crisis to recovery. The pace of the reform may be slower than we hoped for, but we also know this from our own experience in the EU. Progress has to be made at the global level for it to be effective at all levels. Brisbane was a G20 Summit with a significant number of deliverables. We have strong coherence on global economic policies, which should help to foster recovery in Europe too. Several speakers also raised the question of security in a context of the situation in Ukraine, and while this has not been a part of the official G20 agenda, it was discussed very much indeed on the side-lines of the G20 Summit, and President Juncker also had a serious conversation with the President of the Russian Federation, Mr Putin, as regards Russia’s aggression against Ukraine. For the G20, 2015 needs to be the year of delivering on implementation and completion of the agenda. The global growth strategy, financial regulation and tax should remain at the centre of its work, and we count on the support of this Parliament to move this ambitious agenda forward.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President- in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there have been many issues raised. Mr Mach and Mr Simon referred in particular to the need to combat tax evasion and avoidance. Of course we must do this, we must do it at G20 level, we must do so in the new European legislature, where it will be essential to eliminate tax havens and combat tax evasion and avoidance, to do so globally and to take the necessary measures within the European Union as well. That was the meaning of our commitment during the Presidency. I would remind you once again of the important agreement on the exchange of information between tax administrations and cooperation between administrations, which was reached in October and which will be formally adopted in December. Mr Martin referred to the need to promote the trade agenda both multilaterally and bilaterally. On the fringes of the G20, the United States, together with European leaders, reaffirmed the importance of making all possible and necessary efforts for an ambitious conclusion of TTIP, and we have also confirmed this to the Council. During our presidency, we have worked to make very significant progress, practically reaching the goal of the trade agreement with Canada, and we have also made progress with regard to Singapore and Japan. These are the issues which you, Mr Simon, have mentioned and which I fully agree with. Mr President, I would like to make a very important Jakovčić referred to the figure that was right to remember, because that is the reference point from which any proposal not of economic theory but of concrete economic and social policy must start, that is, 200 million unemployed globally. We need answers, we need significant commitments to promote participation in the labour market. It is very important that a lot of space has also been devoted at G20 level to this issue. Entrepreneurship must certainly be promoted, initiatives must be taken in favour of the most disadvantaged unemployed, starting with the disabled. And this emphasis on the most vulnerable by G20 leaders seems to me to be something that we need to work and on which the European Parliament will also be able to do a lot in this European legislature, just as we must promote structural reforms from the labour market to promote employment. Finally, Mr Gutiérrez Prieto, Mr Balas and Mr Danti referred to the need, which we share as presidency, for a change in global economic policy. And it seems to us that at the G20 there have been a number of messages from various quarters about the European Union and the need to speed up the change in economic policy approach that has taken place at Eu ropean Union level. This seems to us to be an important step.  It is true, I agree with what you have said, we need new fiscal stimulus, we need to use all the flexibility possible in the Stability and Growth Pact. This is what our leaders wrote in the strategic agenda for the Union in times of change in June. This is where we must start and that we were pleased to find in the plan presented by President Juncker this morning and in the words of President Juncker and Vice-President Katainen, who have clearly said that national contributions to the investment plan will be neutral from the point of view of the Stability and Growth Pact.  Here's a smart application of the rules we have. It is clear that public expenditure in favour of investments pursuing common European objectives cannot be regarded as current expenditure. We see it, we saw it this morning, there is a nice application of this in Juncker's plan. We hope – and we also did so at the General Affairs Council on cohesion policy – that this intelligent application of the rules that we have will also extend to other investment instruments that we have from national and regional eco-financing within cohesion policy, which are another national contribution to the growth objectives and should also be assessed as neutral for the purposes of the Stability and Growth Pact. Finally, you mentioned the term solidarity: we too believe that we need much more solidarity in the European Union. The term solidarity is found 21 times in the European Treaties. There are 21 articles about solidarity. We have not seen in recent years consistent and convinced implementation of this issue of solidarity in various areas by the outgoing European Commission, and we hope that this will be a commitment that the three institutions together will carry out in the new parliamentary term. Mr President, I would like to make a very important Etheridge invoked God with regard to economic policy and I understand that we can be inspired by the Supreme Pontiff who has addressed this House, but I do not believe that there is a need to invoke God. It is enough to be a man and a politician of good will to make the most of the enormous potential that the European Union has to respond to the need for more growth and more jobs that our citizens rightly ask of us.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: Written. – Once again the world's twenty largest economies have come together. This has been the ninth summit since the beginning of the global crisis. The European Union is going through a moment of uncertainty with weak growth, although it is important to note that in those countries that have gone through difficult times and implemented structural reforms, these reforms have led them to lead growth in the euro area. I am pleased to know that the more than a thousand measures presented by all G20 members to accelerate growth and promote job creation from early next year could boost global gross domestic product (GDP) by 2.1% through 2018. This figure is supported by calculations from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the Organization for Cooperation and Development (OECD). The G20 has promoted the Global Infrastructure Initiative, a plan that aims to drive public-private collaboration for the development of new infrastructures. In this regard, I consider the investment plan presented this morning by the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, as a great example.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Next item on the agenda is the Commission statement on the Digital Single Market (2014/2973(RSP))

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, honourable Members, it is a pleasure to be back in the European Parliament and in Strasbourg. I agree with you that the Digital Single Market requires our immediate attention. For this we need the Telecoms Single Market as a solid basis for the future. I know this Parliament agrees with the ambitious plan to achieve a truly connected Digital Single Market, as can be seen in your resolution and your support for the Telecoms Single Market package. But I am worried about the direction that the Telecoms Single Market negotiations have taken in the Council, where Member States are divided. The Telecoms Single Market is an essential building block of the Digital Single Market. Without it, we cannot achieve the rest. The European Council asked for it in October 2013, and tomorrow in the Telecoms Council, Member States need to be ambitious and take a decisive step towards achieving it. What kind of Digital Single Market would we build without decent solutions on roaming, net neutrality and, more importantly, on spectrum? The net neutrality concept has to be solid and should be clearly defined. Concerning spectrum, more cooperation in spectrum allocation is not a technical issue. It is about getting high quality – and decently priced –connectivity and new services. Our citizens want the best the internet can offer. They want an internet that is safe and accessible to everybody. This is not a reality in Europe today. There is even more work to do to achieve a truly connected digital single market, a market where every consumer is able to enjoy digital content and services – wherever they are in the EU – including government services. It means every company should be able to share and sell its wares to a market of 500 million, using seamless online channels. Today, a small business trying to spread across the EU faces 28 rules for consumer protection, data protection, contract law, tax rates. Consumers trying to buy online face endless barriers. And it just costs too much, both for consumers and businesses. I want to see more efficient parcel delivery across Member States and to tackle e-commerce. I want to make sure we can do online what is possible offline. This is why I have proposed a set of initiatives to my fellow Commissioners and committed to focus on six main areas of work that I will steer and coordinate in my role as Vice-President. A first area of our work will be about building trust and confidence in the online world. As I said during my European Parliament hearing last month, both these issues matter a great deal to me. They are vital if a Digital Single Market is to exist in Europe and function properly. This means moving further on consumer rights, ensuring that the Consumer Rights Directive is fully implemented but also simplifying and modernising the rules for online purchases and digital products. It also means concluding negotiations on data protection rules and cyber-security. Another work area relates to removing restrictions and preventing new ones from appearing. One particular area to address will involve putting a stop to the blocking of online consumers based on their location or residence. This will be about reforming and modernising copyright rules and getting rid of unjustified curbs on transfer and access to digital assets. Again, as I said during my hearing, I am committed to getting rid of geo-blocking. This goes against the core principles of Europe’s single market. Our other areas of work will aim to guarantee online access, connectivity and investment, build the digital economy and make the Digital Single Market matter to businesses and their opportunities. In your resolution, you address non-discrimination when using search engines. I agree that we need to address this issue: search engines are a key part of the development of the Digital Single Market. We should discuss a broad range of measures starting with transparency, self-preference and vertical services in this area. There are also competition tools to address this issue. The Commission will remain vigilant when it comes to competition law infringements that hamper the Digital Single Market. Commissioner Vestager will decide how to proceed with the ongoing investigation into Google’s business practices, once she has heard those who most directly affected by such practices are. I also want to promote e-society, ensure that our citizens have the skills needed to get ahead in the digital age and stimulate digital innovation and research to keep Europe a world ICT leader. I know you also have more ideas. Thank you for setting them out. We will examine them very closely. Our timetable is ambitious. In 2015 the Commission will present its strategy and prepare corresponding measures based on a clear assessment of the most urgent obstacles to be removed. We will not overcome these obstacles by words or by weak rules. Better regulation means efficient rules, minimum burdens for business and consumers, effective competition and high-quality services across pan-European markets. There are different ways to achieve that – harmonisation, mutual recognition, ‘country of origin’. These are the principles that the single market was built on. The same must apply online. I made this principle clear in my hearing and I will fight for it. That is what we need to achieve. We have the political steer from the European Council, from President Juncker and from this Parliament. Now we need action, and the determination to deliver a fully functional Digital Single Market. The benefits of a Digital Single Market are EUR 260 billion a year, potentially more. Imagine ending those barriers, making this a benefit to Europe, not the cost of non-Europe.  This is the jolt that our economy needs and the opportunity our citizens want. It is not something we should turn our backs on. It is what we can build with a Digital Single Market. We have a great opportunity, and we should make the best of it.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, Mr Ansip, thank you very much for your clear words with regard to the draft resolutions before us today. We are talking today about how we can achieve a genuine Digital European Single Market in the coming years. The new Commission under Jean-Claude Juncker was right to set itself this objective, as this has significant growth potential for consumers and businesses alike. Of course, the European digital single market must be open and fit into a global Internet. However, we want to ensure that the European legal framework provides fair and clear conditions for all suppliers and for all consumers. That is why we must turn our eyes to various points in the coming months. Firstly, we need more coherence in Europe on individual legislative proposals, all of which are committed to this objective. Secondly, we want all citizens to be able to participate in this Digital Single Market in the same way. And thirdly, we want all users involved – consumers, consumers and suppliers – to feel safe in this market in the long term and to be able to benefit from the many innovative offerings. The attempt to achieve this coherence has meant that many committees were involved in drafting this resolution. I would therefore like to begin by thanking everyone for bringing this resolution to a close. I hope that tomorrow we will be able to find the most coherent and broad support for this text in order to be able to launch this path towards the Digital Single Market together. We hope, Vice-President Ansip, that you will be very committed to this!

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Let me first ask you to correct a mistake. You have just said that the European internal market is based on the principle of the country of origin. That is simply wrong! It is built on the greatest possible harmonisation, and we should continue to do so. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In our world, we have the experience that competition on the Internet is simply very much distorted and that many young start-ups, service providers and others have no chance of gaining real access to citizens and consumers, because there is market dominance through individual search engines. We should be really clear about that. I am astonished that Mr Schwab, who is one of the initiators of this resolution, has completely forgotten to mention it now. I think that we need to ensure that our young companies, the young people who come from university, the start-ups that have new ideas, really have a chance to present their services freely on the Internet and also to have market access. We want citizens to have the freedom to decide for themselves where they receive their information and in what context they receive it. I think we really need to get on with it. And the European Commission has been investigating, investigating and investigating for years! I think it is time for the European Commission to really come up with results in this area, so that we can ensure that the people, the young entrepreneurs, the young entrepreneurs, that our economy also get a good chance in the global market. For us Social Democrats, there are, of course, other issues that are also very important in this context: consumer protection, but also net neutrality and data protection. However, my colleagues in my group will go into this in more detail.

name: Vicky FORD
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, we need a 21st century approach to the digital world. If we do not make it easy for organisations, businesses and customers to operate electronically, it will harm competitiveness, jobs and growth and e-commerce, particularly in terms of the savings for consumers and opportunities for business. But it is essential that we also work with partners around the world. We cannot afford a ‘fortress Europe’ approach. We must have an open internet where traffic is treated equally. But advances in Internet Protocol Television (IPTV) in particular put pressure on capacity, meaning service providers need to address technical management issues. We need infrastructure investment, and we need to promote an environment that encourages that investment. However, fundamentally-anti-competitive behaviour is not acceptable. As in all sectors, dominant players should not be allowed to abuse market positions to the detriment of others. Internet searches should not discriminate, and search results for users should be unbiased. But this is a competition law issue, and the EU Competition Commissioner plays an important legal role. It would be entirely inappropriate for the European Parliament to prejudge the legal process of any investigation. In the past, when competition laws had been breached, the Competition Commissioner has prescribed various remedies, including fines, ring fencing or perhaps even requiring companies to spin off parts of their operation. This resolution should not be read as an instruction to the Competition Commissioner on what specific actions she should take in her current investigation. The resolution, however, is not just about searches; it is about the whole digital market place. We must join the race, embrace the digital world, or our economy will be left behind. My group’s amendments focus on the benefits of e-commerce for businesses and consumers, and on real actions we can take to tear down the barriers that our digital entrepreneurs face. I hope this House will support those amendments. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8)).

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for your enthusiasm to answer the question. That is lovely. I was wondering if you would share with me the concern that if too much regulation comes from the EU – or any state or organisation – into the internet, it could stifle the growing political discourse that goes on in the internet, shown brilliantly by Barack Obama and being shown in our own country as well. We have to be very mindful of that. Would you agree?

name: Vicky FORD
text: blue-card answer. – That, sir, is precisely why I say we must break down barriers – including legislative barriers – to enable our entrepreneurs to trade across the market of 600 million customers across Europe. That is why I am prepared to enter into the negotiations to help consumers and businesses to trade in this marketplace. I have yet to see your group turn up to the negotiations.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the ALDE Group fully supports the better regulation of the digital single market but, unlike others, we understand the importance of the independence of the Commissioner for Competition as well. While other groups might want to use this plenary debate as a platform for solely attacking one company, the ALDE Group would like to actually address the topic of this debate: the Digital Single Market. Next year, as announced by its President Mr Juncker, the Commission should propose a digital single market package. Parliament should be part of shaping this package. The real priority is how we can act to urgently break down national restrictions and existing barriers to growth and jobs. My group has a global vision on how to reform the digital business world and make sure it serves all Europeans, no matter where they live in Europe. We have a global vision where every citizen, even those living in the remotest areas, has access to high-speed broadband. We have a vision where net neutrality is European law. We have a vision that includes finally doing away with roaming once and for all. We have set this out – and more – in our resolution. Mr Commissioner, I look forward to seeing our vision and the package in the next year. Madam President, the Digital Single Market and the internet are far greater than one company. All large technology companies, including Google, must create a level playing field in internet commerce, services and search. They should not use their dominant position against competition and consumers. If they will not do so voluntarily, of course the Commission should be able to use all the powers in its mandate to compel action. But let me stress once again that Parliament and our Member States should respect the independence of the European Commissioner for Competition. Commissioner Vestager must be free to take whatever action she thinks best to protect European citizens and consumers in the Digital Single Market. She should not take actions based on political pressure from Brussels or beyond, even from me or anybody else in this House.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What we are talking about is the clear and binding establishment of net neutrality. That is what we decided in April of this year, and we want to do so today in the context of this directive. What is the best consumer protection in data protection? This is a strong data protection package – regulation, basic regulation and directive – so that we can also secure clear and strong consumer rights and provide legal certainty for businesses. But that also means that we really do not have consumer protection as long as intelligence services can snoop on citizens with impunity. That is why, in the Moraes report, we have called, among other things, for the European IT industry to be promoted in order to become more independent and to actually implement fundamental rights standards. And something else about start-ups: If you want to promote start-ups, you have to limit market power and be in favour of net neutrality. This is the only way to achieve more equal access to the Internet. I therefore call on you to take part in the 'Save the Internet' campaign and to contact the Council so that this knowledge is actually leaked in the Council. This is extremely important to us, and I would ask you to take part in it.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the digital world, our thoughts and our own identity are bits that travel on the network. Therefore, if all men are equal, the bits must also be the same. This is the principle that is called net neutrality. And I am glad, Commissioner Ansip, that you have heard that you will support this principle. But parliament, thanks to a number of amendments last April, fortunately included in the legislative package on telecommunications a correct definition of net neutrality and the obligation for providers to observe it. They will be able to offer specialized services and disseminate some content of better quality and speed, only if they do not worsen the quality and speed of diffusion of others.  But a few days ago, thanks to a leak on the edri.org website, we learned that instead the Council of the EU, under the Italian Presidency, wants to remove from the telecommunications package the obligation and the definition of net neutrality, naming it only as a vague objective to aim for. If this is confirmed, if this principle is ever watered down in Europe, sacrificing it on the altar of the free market in competition, the Internet will lose its role as a free and creative space that has contributed so much to human progress over the last twenty years.  Without the neutrality of the Internet, it could become a service to the individual as a mere consumer, just as it has happened with television, which as an instrument of mass cultural evolution has become an instrument of information control and therefore of public opinion control. Without net neutrality we might not even have been able to read this leak I mentioned, as it would be possible to make access difficult for you to facilitate it to trivially commercial content.  Consequently, net neutrality is also a matter of democracy and freedom, and I call on this Commission and this Parliament to maintain the principle of net neutrality in the telecommunications legislative package that will be negotiated with the Council and to make this clear in the approach to the digital single market package.

name: Julia REDA
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for The resolution on the Digital Single Market does not bring much new in content. Parliament underlines its decision that we need a net neutrality law. And we are calling for long overdue copyright reform for the digital age. On both points, however, the resolution does not say anything that Parliament and the Commission have not already decided or announced. The original reason for this resolution has long since been taken off the table. That was the threat of the old Commission's settlement of the competition procedure against Google. So why are we now dealing with this resolution? The purpose of the resolution seems to be to prepare a Europe-wide right to protect the rights of press publishers. With such a regulation, a license fee is payable for displaying small text excerpts from press articles available online. Germany has already tried in vain to finance large publishers through Google in this way. The piece of the puzzle that was missing in Germany, which led to the failure of this plan, is now to be created here. Under the pretext of neutrality of search results, a compulsion is established to display content in Google searches for which publishers receive money. This would effectively result in a Google tax from the alleged protection of the performance of publishers. The side effects are fatal. Google can afford to pay for text snippets. But small competitors and private individuals cannot. In Germany and Spain – and this happens to be the countries of origin of the initiators of this resolution – the right to protect benefits restricts the right to quote. This hinders the basis of the free exchange of knowledge on the Internet. We must not export this bad idea to Europe under any circumstances. If our aim is for the Commission to prevail against Internet giants, then we are concentrating on measures that work! We must finally put an end to tax dumping in Europe. So, instead of the rhetoric against Google, the grand coalition could finally set up the Committee of Inquiry into Luxleaks. Because what we do not need are newly invented levies for individual companies, which, incidentally, restrict free communication on the network. What we need is a functioning taxation of all companies in Europe.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: Madam President, at your hearing, Commissioner, we heard you sing candour at the praises of the single digital market, a panacea announced against the evils afflicting the Union. Additional revenue, growth, the economy, in your opinion, the digital single market would solve all the problems facing the countries of Europe. I am telling you that no, the single market must not be an indisputable religious dogma and that it is not the solution to the problems of European nations.  We do not question the importance of digital development for the future and that it is an undeniable source of wealth and development for businesses. We are also aware of the differences between countries and citizens in terms of access and use of the internet. But building the centralized digital single market adored like a god is by no means the solution.  Your objective in this House, the Council and the Commission is , as we know - to bring down the last protective national impulses, and all today's motions for a resolution still prove this. This single digital market will be the last proponent, the one that will deal the blow to artificial barriers, as the Commissioner so ad by the imposed Commissioner so a good thing. Unless it is the last straw that spills over the patience of the peoples and, in particular, of the French people already well-filled with your stinging interventions in national affairs that do not concern you. You want, like the single market, to impose on European nations the way forward in spite of the interests of the member countries. You do not listen to the people who have clearly expressed their refusal to see you intervene in their daily lives again.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Madam President, colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sánchez-3, for What do we need in Europe? Again and again the same thing. We need economic growth, we need new jobs. How can we achieve this goal?  One way could be to invest more and more money in the economy. The difficulty with this approach is that our Member States are already in such debt that we cannot afford to borrow more money to try to stimulate our economy. It will simply lead us to even deeper misery. What other options do we have? The second option for us is precisely the legislative option to improve conditions so that this economic growth can arise. That is to say, we have a single market in Europe, which we all know that it does not work to the end – in fact, in any area entirely. But one area where, we know, the single market is not working to the end, is precisely the digital market. It is split up across 28 different Member States: we have different regulations, different taxes, and it is difficult for businesses to work across national borders. If we adopt the right measures with the Commission's initiative to break down these barriers to the single digital market, we will actually boost economic growth without forcing or requiring our Member States to increase deficits by borrowing money and investing.  So we can achieve economic growth in Europe by promoting the creation of a digital single market, without increasing member states' debts and keeping a solid foundation for our future. Thanks for the attention!

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Madam President! Allow me to make a preliminary comment on Mr Schwab and others. Yes, digitalisation creates new jobs, but the bottom line is not necessarily additional jobs. Nevertheless, digitalisation is progressing and, at the same time, there are increasing debates about the protection of privacy and personal rights. If we, as Europeans, want to play an important, perhaps even leading, role in this digital agenda, we must effectively combine digitisation and the protection of fundamental rights. Businesses want to protect their data, their developments, and consumers need clarity about what happens to whom with their data. The European data protection package, when it comes to time, regulates data economy, tight earmarking, the shortest possible retention periods – in other words, clear rules for all those who offer products and services in Europe, wherever they are based. We also regulate that there are uniform rules in Europe, because this makes it easier for companies to work on a standard rather than 28 standards, and we create legal certainty and clarity for both sides, including consumers. Protection of fundamental rights and growth, even in the digital world, are not mutually inclusive, they are conditional.
