I am deeply convinced that the strategy of a successful European Digital Single Market will be all the more successful the clearer the citizens, but also businesses, can be confident that their fundamental rights are also digitally protected and that fair competition is also guaranteed online.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The EU-wide digital single market offers a wide scope for innovation, investment, jobs and economic growth. Uniform, comparable rules in the areas of data protection, privacy, consumer protection, copyright and, in particular, the protection of children and young people must be ensured at a high level. E-commerce will change our society, our social coexistence, cultural life, in short: our daily life. A common large European market offers space for European champions in this field. To achieve this, we need a free Internet, net neutrality, no monopoly position of providers, search engine operators, no market concentration or supply filtering. And we must be careful that big data does not lead to the glass consumer. It is very important that we need the protection of children and young people. We need to make it easier for families to protect their children from the dangers of the World Wide Web, even when they access the Web. In order to successfully meet these challenges, we need overarching strategies, a set of rules in the area of data protection, privacy protection and, overall, citizens' rights.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Madam President, in order to release all the jobs that we want to get from the new digital sector, in order to release all the inventions that might be possible from the new digital sector, we need to tear down barriers between 28 countries and consolidate one common legislation at European level. This is actually the big problem on the internet – not what one company is doing today or what it did yesterday. My big problem with this resolution is that a few parties think that they can fix the internet better than the internet is actually working by itself. Because it is freedom that has provided us with the internet we have today; and it is freedom that is the nourishment of the internet. If we try to think that we can regulate – if there is an American-founded Google, we should create one ourselves; if there is an American-founded Facebook, we should found one ourselves; if there are Cloud services in America, we should have them for ourselves – then we do not understand what the internet is. It does not care about any national boundaries whatsoever, nor does it care that there are national boundaries keeping development down, keeping the innovations down, keeping economy down and keeping jobs away. We have a great possibility here in this House, working with Commissioner Ansip, and also working with Commissioner Vestager when it comes to competition measures. Because we are not the ones who can decide; we are not the body that is actually making the judgement. We are the body that puts the legislation forward and we do not make the judgements on different companies. Just a few years ago we thought Yahoo would prevail forever; we thought that was the system we would use for many years. Today the market is totally different – a big shift in just a few years. I believe, colleagues, that if one of you invented a browser that was better than the ones we are using today, just in a few months the customers would change: the users would change and go to the best one, because we are also acting on a market and we do not pay for using the browsers. We do not pay for it, which makes the consumers and users very easy to transform. We can take example after example: a few years ago everyone had a hotmail e-mail address and then this was changed for a gmail one, and so on. This will keep changing the market. What the drafters of the resolution are saying is that they actually know better than the internet how it should be run and that they want the internet we have today to prevail. What we have to do is to create the internet of tomorrow, not copying the solutions that are already there but actually creating new solutions for the future.

name: Michel REIMON
text: Madam President! Now we have heard many interesting opinions and speeches. But I find it even more interesting what we have not heard so far. The words 'democracy' and 'freedom of expression' did not happen, but were always about the market and the economy. The Internet is probably the largest democratization machine of mankind, at least as important as the printing of books a few hundred years ago. We should not look at this exclusively in economic terms. I would warn against that. When the Commission appoints a Commissioner for the Digital Single Market, we in Parliament, as representatives of the people, should not enter into a purely and exclusively economic debate, but should work to ensure that the democratic aspect of the Internet is as prominent as possible. Search neutrality, net neutrality should first of all be promoted for democratic reasons, for reasons of freedom of expression. That should be the most important thing for us as parliamentarians. I do not have that aspect. I think it is a pity that the Greens' amendment on this has not been included in the amendment.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Madam President! Personally, I think it is very good that the new Commission is being upgraded by a Commissioner for the Digital Agenda. We all know that the digital world knows no national borders, and this recognition must finally prevail in action and in legislation in Europe, especially in the Member States. It is about nothing less than the added value and competitiveness of our European economy. Those who demand more growth must place much greater emphasis on the digital market. We are working to ensure that there is more investment in Europe and, above all, a better investment climate. At the same time, of course, we need high-quality, solid investment projects. Therefore, we should not focus solely on the traditional industries, digital infrastructure must, of course, be one of the top priorities. We do not need new roads to nowhere, instead we need data highways that strengthen our innovative strength in Europe. It is about nothing more and nothing less than investing in the future. In doing so, we must make use of the fact that the digital agenda has a cross-cutting function. Those who invest well here do something for the big ones, for small and medium-sized enterprises, they do something for the founders of companies, and they also do something for the citizens, for whom digital networking is, of course, increasingly part of everyday life. We are counting on the new Competition Commissioner to address competition issues consistently and to propose solutions in a timely manner. We know that the issues of data protection and copyright must be resolved with particular care. In doing so, we must also promote international standard-setting. Access to the digital market must be equally possible for competitors. We must therefore resolutely combat discrimination. Europe needs a new, strong common position here, because technological progress leaves us no time to wait. Let us start with a policy for the future! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: blue-card question. – I actually agree with what you say on technical innovation – but do you? The EPP group actually surprises me a bit on this resolution, because I think there is far too much market regulation and intervention. I usually understand when the S&D goes in that direction, but not when the EPP goes that way. So, do you actually think that your regulation proposed on the table here is more important than working for net neutrality, where my colleague Ms Schaake today sent a letter with 131 signatures to the Commission defending net neutrality?

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – Now, of course, 133 signatures are a lot. However, we must also say that we have found a good, balanced proposal here. Andreas Schwab did his job really well. We are on the right track here, and we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats also have a clear position on this. Surely this can be assessed differently. That is what we are doing here, unlike the Liberals. We believe that we have really put forward a balanced proposal here and do not want to interfere too much with the market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I have pointed out before in this Chamber that the competitiveness of the European economy must not be based on the Chineseisation of wages. It must be based on the knowledge economy, investment, education, new technologies and innovation. The digital single market that we are discussing here today requires investment in the development of information and communication technologies. So far, the funds invested in this area in the European Union fall short of the investments made in the United States and Japan. The investment programme announced today by Mr

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul A digital time needs a digital single market, but it is unfortunate that today we are dealing with this resolution instead of working on the actual issues that belong in the ITRE and in the JURI Committee, that is, in the Legal Committee. Some ideas put forward here by the major parties are quite populist, such as politically breaking away some major internet search engines into their components. It's pretty headless actually.  Everyone understands that it is Google that is referred to here. It is deeply inappropriate to engage with political claw-proofness in the Commission's work on an ongoing competition law case that takes place in real time. I am grateful that we have a Commissioner like Mr Ansip, who knows what the Digital Single Market really means and who knows what liberal ideas stand for in these contexts.  In the area of the Committee on Legal Affairs, the resolution has not created as much mess, i am pleased about that. We will continue to modernise European copyright, but we will also create common copyright legislation and ensure that licensing takes place properly. It is important that we build on the work that was done last parliamentary term, for example with the report on collective rights management and on-line music licences for music. I think we should work more on putting time and energy into this kind of concrete work rather than this kind of rather pointless debate in plenary.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Mr. President! The Digital Single Market is essential for economic development in the European Union. It has great potential not only in economic terms, but also in the preservation and dissemination of cultural and creative content, cultural diversity in Europe. In order for these potentials to be exploited in a positive sense, we need fair and transparent market conditions for all participants. The cultural sector in particular is characterised by its diverse structures, by large and small players on the market. The Digital Single Market offers opportunities for all. However, we must ensure that market dominance does not lead to a gatekeeper function that makes access to the digital market more difficult and prevents fair competition. That is why access to the network, but also the discoverability of content, must be non-discriminatory, open, transparent and respect for the fundamental rights of each individual. Net neutrality, fair non-discriminatory search and discoverability, but also fair conditions in copyright and respect for copyright are key points for new creative content and services to have a chance in this digital single market in the future. We therefore call on the Commission to really apply and exploit the possibilities of competition law in order to counteract excessive market concentrations and the abuse of dominant market positions, especially when vertical or horizontal convergence leads to distortions in the market. We also call for copyright to be adapted to the changed conditions in the digital market, which balances the different interests of consumers, content providers, rights holders and authors, especially the creative artistic sector.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We cannot talk about strengthening consumer rights in the Digital Single Market without simultaneously discussing net neutrality and the authorisation of special services. I find it remarkable how audacging telecommunications companies and cable network operators are to supposedly support net neutrality and an open Internet, while at the same time demanding the generous authorisation of special services. The argument is always the same: they stress that they would like to push ahead with the required network expansion, but demand compensation via special services in which they then exclusively bundle offers of the open Internet, forward them prioritized and let themselves be paid dearly by providers and customers. Otherwise, the expansion of the networks would not be financed. If we allow this, we will buy fast Internet at the price of net neutrality and fundamental freedoms. As Members of Parliament, we have a duty to protect freedom of information and communication. This means that we are above all committed to an open Internet. A narrow definition of special services and their strict limitation, as decided by Parliament in April, is essential if we do not want to undermine the openness of the Internet. Neither the state nor we as parliamentarians, and least of all a private company, have to decide which legal content arrives at the end customer and which does not. Maintaining the open and free Internet is a prerequisite for ensuring social participation, diversity of opinion, innovation and fair competition. These values must be at the heart of any digital agenda. Nor must these objectives be undermined by special contractual agreements. It cannot be our job to pave the way for contractual relationships such as Comcast-Netflix or Spotify-Telekom. The least we have learned from the Google case should be that we should correct mistakes before they arise. It would be downright negligent to allow new business models to be made possible, only to later be astonished to discover that they create market distortions. But then it will be too late. The debate on net neutrality is not only about fundamental freedoms, but also about ensuring fair competition opportunities in the long term in order to take advantage of the opportunities offered by digital development. The legal safeguarding of net neutrality is not a left-wing spinning mill, but a necessity in socio-political as well as economic terms.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: Mr President, I am disappointed that the discussion over this resolution has turned into an anti-Google debate. The EU is lagging behind the US and its main competitors because of the fragmented digital market and very slow broadband roll-out, but mainly because many decision-makers still see digital solutions as a threat rather than as an opportunity. In order for innovation to flourish, we need to allow some creative destruction. Yes, the use of digital services might lead to some sectors being phased out, but it is so that new sectors can emerge. I come from Estonia, a country which made a choice to embrace digital innovation and became successful at it. We have been the test subjects for many different digital services, and we like them because they make life easier. Demand creates new opportunities for companies to create services which eventually lead to jobs and growth. But it is important not to overregulate the market. A week ago the inventor of the World Wide Web visited Parliament. He said that they built the web as an open platform so that people could use, invent and be creative. This invention would not have happened with over-regulation, so this is not what we need today. What we need is the promotion of digital entrepreneurship. We hope that Vice-President Ansip will lead the way.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Mr President, the Digital Single Market can, if we do the right things, transform the European economy from being the world’s biggest economy to being the world’s biggest and most dynamic market, but that requires that we understand the freedom of the internal market and the reforms we need to make, but also the freedom of the internet, and that we are able to take decisive decisions that we more or less all know what it is about. First of all, we must refresh our targets for capacities and speeds. We cannot have outdated charges for speeds and capacities that belong to the past. We need to talk about gigabytes much more than megabytes in the future. We need to open up the 700 MHz band in order to ensure that we in Europe can have the best preconditions for the new services. We need to ensure that we can develop pan-European network services with a high level of competition that can provide us with a single telecoms market without any roaming – not only without the cost but without the roaming as such. We need to ensure that we can have a VAT system that is supportive of digital services. We need to ensure that we have freedom for users but also freedom for new service providers. We should not lack any of those, and the debate about net neutrality must in this sense support the emergence of new services. We need to ensure that we have competition at all levels and understand that if we do the right things, we will not need to regulate all the Googles but can be the home base for the new Googles, Yahoos, BlackBerries and all the other Apples that we can have, and also the Ericssons, the Nokias and the Siemens. That must be our target.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: Mr President, I really welcomed Commissioner Ansip’s initial comments when he talked about the Telecoms Council meeting tomorrow and the disappointment that we fear will be had with the result there, and I think that Parliament took a very strong position and we hope that tomorrow, the Council and the Member States will see sense. We live in exciting but technologically disruptive times. Just 25 years ago the World Wide Web was founded; just three years ago smartphones became commercially available and affordable, and technology is changing and transforming our day-to-day lives. Sadly, the Digital Single Market still remains fragmented, and not every EU citizen has access or possesses the relevant skills in order to benefit fully from what digital technologies and the internet have to offer. In my constituency of Scotland, there are still too many areas where access to fast and reliable broadband is non-existent, thus denying EU citizens access to the potential that is there within the Digital Single Market. We need an internet which is accessible and affordable to all, as well as safe to all. Wi-Fi access for everyone in every cafe and public space is not a reality in Europe today. All our connector devices use radio waves, and that is why spectrum policy and Member State coordination of spectrum policy becomes vital. We need to prepare our citizens for the opportunities of this new marketplace by providing them with digital skills as well as stimulating digital entrepreneurship. I would like to say thank you to Commissioner Ansip and that I think we all look forward to working with him in the weeks, the months and the years ahead to make this a reality.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, welcome to this House at these first sessions you attend. I believe that from your previous experience, because of your sensitivity to digital issues and, therefore, the digital single market, we will have a person who will really be delivered and will carry out a very interesting management. But sometimes these things don't depend on personal will, they depend on many other factors. Let me tell you and this House the following. We're running out of time. We are running out of time for someone to continue to believe that in the European Union it is possible to have a single market, a single digital market. We repeat to the fullest what today, with all the goodwill, has been repeated here: the five hundred million potential consumers, what it means in terms of GDP or what the single digital market would entail in terms of European GDP, which would mean in terms of job creation, and many other data that we use time and time again to explain the extraordinary potential it has. But one thing is potential and one thing is reality. Signals are needed, evidence is needed. Because we need to build a trust that is going to slings everywhere in the European Union. There's no confidence and that's what needs to be recovered. And it is therefore necessary, indication, signals are needed, we need evidence that we are actually taking —as is up to those of us in politics, with leadership and political will —decisions that show the way, the evidence that we are actually going to create a digital single market. And I would like to refer in that context to what is pending and which has not yet come forward, to the single market in telecommunications. Who's going to explain to those five hundred million we talked about that it's not possible to have roaming fees that don't carry the burden they're putting on for citizens, businesses, professionals, etc.? Who's going to explain it to you? That is why, Vice-President, that is why, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is essential that the single market for telecommunications comes to an end and that we can enter into the trilogue and at least try to reach an agreement. Because the time, if not, Your Honor, will run out.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr. President! This resolution contains many important aspects and demands to revitalise the common digital single market. For example, the demand for data protection for building trust, for the creation of an EU framework for cloud computing, for the neutrality of search engines or for the provision of broadband and new copyright to all citizens, so that the potential that the Internet offers can also be exploited, and, of course, the demand for securing net neutrality. However, the resolution does not present any new perspectives, but builds on projects of the previous parliamentary term. At that time, we developed good and well-founded positions. We must continue along this path, defend and develop achievements. I am particularly concerned about net neutrality, and I am simply opposed to it being phased out through the back door. This principle must be enshrined in law, as we have decided in this House. Commissioner Oettinger was not so clear and so clear at the hearing what he meant by that. It is a question of the decision of this House. Only a neutral network that forwards all content equally and quickly is a good network. An open and free Internet is characterized by the fact that it does not prioritize services, but forwards services according to the end-to-end principle. Only a neutral network allows for innovation and prevents monopolies. This is the only way to ensure that we can exploit the enormous potential of the Internet for social and economic development. If we want to continue to drive the innovation engine for the creative industries, we must give all services and content the same fair chance of being able to reach all Internet users in principle.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that our debate this evening will serve as an electroshock so that Europe emerges from its dazedness, which makes it a colony of the new digital world. Google controls 90% of online search; however, we do not have rules to limit this hegemony. The first of the reforms we need to adopt is one that aims to prevent discrimination and abuse of a dominant position upstream.  The second problem is digital taxation. Let's take the example of France: in 2013, Google paid only eight million taxes in this country for more than one billion turnover. We need to find solutions so that companies that capture value added online also participate in the tax. With respect to copyright reform, I want to be clear. If we want to continue to produce cultural content and promote European cultural diversity, we must protect copyright. We also need to encourage content financing and we need to better distribute digital dividends. Finally, while it is important to combat anti-competitive practices, it is still necessary to have competitors in front of them.  So let's invest in networks, research and innovation, fund digital start-ups and bring out the great champions to allow Europe to return to the race! I am sure that the Juncker plan will be essential on this point.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: I very much welcome the fact that the new Commission has included the creation of the Digital Single Market among the top ten political priorities for the next five years. We need to adapt the internal market rules to the new, digital age. The benefits of faster growth of the European economy and the creation of new jobs are certainly well known. Today, the Internet is one of the drivers of economic development. It is therefore also very worrying that Europe is lagging behind its main competitors, such as Japan, the United States or South Korea, e.g. in the high-speed networks or media services market. Successful internet companies are not created in Europe, but are created in the United States. Whether it's Facebook, Google or China's Alibaba server. I believe that the present resolution will contribute to the faster implementation of the necessary changes. However, we must not forget that the Digital Single Market is not just about opportunities. I would like to draw particular attention to two intertwined threats. One of them is the lack of consumer protection as well as the protection of personal data. It is appalling how the mere use of technologies such as smartphones exposes us to the threat of misuse of user data, for example for the marketing interests of large multinational supranational companies. We must pay very high attention to these issues if the Digital Single Market is really to serve not only businesses but also consumers.

name: Michał BONI
text: Mr President, if we want to avoid drift in Europe, we need to use all digital drivers for development, start a serious debate with all stakeholders, think in holistic terms and accelerate the implementation of the Digital Single Market, as is properly suggested by the resolution. But there are some problems as well. Firstly, the problem in point 10 is more complicated. It does not only concern the functioning of search engines but also social media, on-line shopping sites and mobile applications. Very often, users do not know how all those solutions are interdependent. You should ensure that these kinds of services clearly identify and keep separated advertising, product promotions and other paid-for content. This should be integrated in the business models. Secondly, monopolistic advantages do not create a healthy balance in the market, but we should not look for a scapegoat to explain our weaknesses. We can put the problem of search engines, but we also need to understand the use of search engines as a vehicle for usual economic activity, also by new start-ups. We need systemic and clear competitive rules for all, but we should also accept the ways the market works. So if we want to use the word ‘rebundling’, we should require a fair and transparent process of analysis of the situation. Thirdly, why do we have problems with implementation of the Digital Single Market? Is it investment shortage, lack of a consolidated telecoms market, limited access to fast internet, lack of privacy protection as a background for trust, uncertainty of net neutrality or lack of new copyright with respect for authors? Yes, but not only. Fragmentation is a key issue. Member States are not sufficiently brave, are often opposed to a common view and avoid taking the decisions which would make it possible to have a European market without the administrative burden of 28 legal regimes. So Mr President – let’s do it! (Sustained applause)

name: Renato SORU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in one and a half minutes I will be able to say that the Internet was born on three fundamental principles: technological standardisation, openness and net neutrality. On these three principles – standard, openness, neutrality – what has happened in these 25 years has happened. An instrument of prodigious growth, an instrument for creating new technologies, new businesses, new jobs that has changed the way we work, the way we study, the way we inform ourselves, the way we do politics. It has completely changed everything we do, on the basis of these three principles, all of which are under threat: that of the standard, that of openness, that of neutrality. That of openness: because it does not seem strange to us, but that web that we have known as open risks becoming and is increasingly becoming a space of enclosed places, of large closed compounds, where you enter and it is difficult to get out. There are services that are now becoming totalizing. There is a saying on the Internet: whoever wins takes everything. But "whoever wins takes everything" is not the way we want for our market. But it happens like this, so there is only one social network; one microblogging site, only one; there's only one search engine. There's only one of them. Is that what Europe will want for this market in the future? I do not think so, nor should our friends in ALDE want it.  Openness, the concept of openness that has been so important in bringing the Internet to where it is under threat today, Commissioner, is under threat from the concept of neutrality. Do not touch any of these principles. They were the basis of the success of the Internet, of everything that happened. Do not have a responsibility to erase it for the future.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: Mr President, I am very passionate about digitalisation but so, I think, is this Commission, as the Digital Single Market is one of the main priorities. I look forward to working together with the Commission on delivering the ambitious promises that we have been making since the beginning of this mandate. The internet is a global and common resource. It is not for commerce alone, nor for one company or country alone. Digital policy brings about real, measurable effects that impact our citizens. Internet neutrality is one example. I want to reaffirm my commitment to net neutrality. Through enacting legislation, we have paved the way for the internet to act as a key driver of competitiveness, growth, social development and innovation. Roaming is another clear example of the way digital policies impact Europeans. I would not exaggerate at all by saying that lifting roaming charges would be an absolutely revolutionary step. We should dare to do it. I am confident that Member States’ governments will stand together with consumers to ensure an end to roaming premiums as soon as possible. The topic we are discussing today is especially important to our businesses. We need a tough market referee to ensure a fair playing field for all – search engines or otherwise – but we do not need to target companies. The EU’s job is to protect the playing field, not protect or target the players. Europe needs the ‘can do’ spirit. New ideas should be welcomed. Those who succeed should be celebrated and not punished through extra rules and taxes. New ideas and approaches are very much needed in the public sector. Europe cannot be digital if the public sector is not digital. A digital public sector can build and shape new markets, save taxpayers money and ensure public services reflect the way we actually live our lives today. Digitalisation means disruptive, rather than incremental, development and this is the future ahead of us. I say we start really investing in it today.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We are talking about our citizens expecting a well-functioning Digital Single Market and Europe must be a leader in this area. And this market will only function well if it not only promotes innovation, creativity, entrepreneurship – as you are talking about here – but also meets the needs of consumers when it is able to meet the expectations of these consumers. And – true – the consumer wants to feel safe in the digital market. And our task is to remove the barriers that have been mentioned here in order to help consumers take full advantage of the digital single market. That is why we need to start negotiations with the Council as soon as possible on the abolition of still too expensive roaming. There is so much work to be done to ensure net neutrality that time is not enough here to exchange everything: but these are issues of electronic payments, by resolving online disputes to the functioning of copyright and the postal market. Thank you very much, Commissioner, for highlighting this.  The functioning of the market, search engines very strongly affects how citizens use, how they can use the internet. For many citizens, this is the gateway to the internet and that is why it is so important for users to know why they are getting such and not different results and to make these results as objective as possible. We are getting a lot of signals from consumers, from traders, that the market is not functioning as it should, that it lacks transparency. It is not working properly and the European Commission needs to take a closer look at this. Perhaps she should consider whether legal action should even be taken on this matter. So let me ask you, colleagues, to support a resolution tomorrow that is not just about search engines, but about the whole digital reality.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the completion of the European digital market is a priority and its positive impact on economic growth and the quality of life of our citizens does not allow us to waste any more time. With the network, companies find new outlets for their productions, reaching their customers directly wherever they are in the world. But they can also use the clouds to store their data, and the list of opportunities is very long.  The investments in digital that President Juncker reiterated this morning require a firm commitment on the part of all. Of course, in order for the European digital market to express itself in the best possible way, it is not enough to remove barriers, it is necessary for operators to be able to compete on an equal footing with each other. And the network, in order to be truly free and open, must not have masters, that is, subjects who abuse their dominant position acquired precisely by exploiting the free and open nature of the same network.  What some people are doing on the network and with the network requires us to take action to protect citizens and businesses. The European Commission must do this by resolutely applying the rules of competition. But in order to maintain effective competition, we must all consider that now different actors such as search engines, content aggregators, e-commerce platforms, broadcasters and telcos now provide similar services and therefore it makes no sense for them to be subject to different rules. A real level playing field demands equal rules for everyone. The market is unique and it is the market for content.  We therefore need common rules drawn up together in a coordinated and integrated way if technological convergence is to be made any sense. An example: the editorial responsibility that currently applies under the Media Services Directive only to classical publishers should be extended to other actors. Mr President, in its judgment in the Google Spain case, the Court of Justice gave us precise indications that do not only concern the right to be forgotten. Of course, data is important, but that's not all. The judgment reminds us of the importance of applying European and national law to all companies, including those established in third countries but providing services within the territory of the Union, having an effective link with our economy. These non-European companies, and I will end here, if they take resources such as advertising in our countries and make a lot of money selling our data, they have to pay taxes and they have to be subject to the same rules as European companies. They cannot benefit from the absence of rules from the third countries in which they are based.  I therefore hope that the Commission will take account of the opinion of the European Parliament, in the interests of our industry, our businesses, but above all our fellow European citizens.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the digital single market is one of the areas of evolution and a valuable tool for Europe's recovery. However, this important efficiency tool must be well calibrated in order to achieve an overall protection result for the parties involved, who remain at the centre of a spontaneous and free use of digital tools and must be able to seize all the opportunities without limits.  I have no difficulty in believing, to quote a critical ity, that the same Internet search algorithm of the most used engine (Google) may not be indifferent to the need to return, even by means of subsequent and unaware acceptances by the user, geolocation and other references, customized answers that respond to market logics and perhaps not in competition more than free competition.  We therefore need to pay greater attention to the issues of the protection, control and security of users on personal data, the resolution of events such as the right to be forgotten on the web, with respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights, because only within a framework of defined rules do investments flourish and generate the positive impact that we hope for on our social and cultural life. Only with certain rules can the digital single market be created by guaranteeing a level playing field for all businesses and security for citizens.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, in an increasingly digital and ever-changing world, our responsibility is above all to protect European consumers, to protect them from the leakage of their data on the internet, to protect them from all infringements of net neutrality, to avoid a caste internet, and to combat the digital divide for them. , to eliminate roaming charges as soon as possible and, above all, to combat any abuse of a dominant position. As such, I call on the Commission to continue its investigations into Google's practices. It is unacceptable that Google prefers its own services when it is used as a search engine. It is unacceptable that this practice has not yet been sanctioned and it is completely unacceptable that in the 21st century, in the European Union, consumer rights are not being respected.  Commissioner, the whole European Parliament is begd to do so, act, protect consumers, it is your duty. We in Parliament will help you.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Mr. President, I am a signatory to this resolution, because it primarily protects consumers and calls for clear rules of the game in the digital marketplace. The resolution asks, inter alia, to eliminate discrimination in the digital market, given the consumer's domicile.  I believe that this is a very important element, especially considering that as many as 25% of citizens of the European Union are discriminated against when shopping online. If the causes of discrimination for only 10% of these consumers were eliminated, the UNION's GDP would rise by 1.7%. Also, the digital market as it is now leaves a lot of room for manipulation at the expense of consumers.  For example, each of us has at least once justifiably judged that he has subscribed to shipping costs. The fact is that as many as 62% of consumers do not feel safe or are familiar with their rights. That is why it is necessary to create clear regulations, and what is also very important, to communicate with consumers.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: A common digital market? The idea itself concerns the opportunities offered by a European single market. Protecting the European digital economic market, supporting private initiatives in the field, common rights for users and producers, tariff reductions, free internet access – the benefits are many, but how we take advantage of them will determine the effects of the common digital market. Europe has the capacity to be a leader in the digital field. In this respect, we need to engage in coherent and open dialogue with all partners across Europe.  I come from a country, Romania, a leader in IT&C, but whose opinion is rarely heard. It's certainly not the only case. Europe's diversity and regional specificities can strengthen the common market, if we take them into account. Europe does not need to copy Silicon Valley, because europe's small entrepreneurs and digital creators can do more. We just need to create the facilities by which they can assert themselves and develop, whether they are in London or Bucharest, Paris or Riga. And last but not least, we have to fight for what we have gained, the reduction of roaming charges.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Mr President, it is truly wonderful that a comprehensive resolution has been prepared on the digital single market. We have a lot of opportunities in Europe when it comes to digital services. They bring us significant new business and economic growth and also improve productivity. We know that the population is ageing throughout Europe and it is therefore useful for us to be able to automate many services. Then they are often the most comfortable for the user to use as well. Similarly, thanks to the digital economy, we are able to take the environment well into account. However, I wonder and criticise the paragraph in this resolution which calls for a differentiated business in search engines. We all know that this is primarily about Google, which is a very popular search engine in Europe. We know that we have a free market and that citizens have the choice of Yahoo, Bing, Yandex or Baidu. There are a great many different search services and machines, and I do not think it is a good thing that the European Parliament is sending out such a message. It has already been suggested to Google that it is important to distinguish commercial content from other content.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Mr President, this resolution brings essential elements for consumers in the digital single market. As such, it reaffirms the House's desire to have roaming charges abolished as soon as possible. Indeed, we cannot wait. We must also make it clear that net neutrality is a fundamental non-negotiable principle for equality and fairness in the treatment of consumers.  We are, of course, faced with dominant digital players. As such, the separation of search engine activities from commercial activities is an indeed interesting avenue to restore equity in the digital single market and ensure sincere treatment for consumers. I regret, however, that perhaps we are not going any further. I think it is essential to remember that when it comes to fairness, we must also establish equity between creators and internet giants. That is why, tomorrow in the vote, I will support this resolution and I call on all my colleagues who are concerned about helping creation in the Digital Single Market to vote for Amendment 84.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Thank you for the opportunity, Mr. President. Listening to this debate today, I see, first and foremost, that there is a very strong will in the European Parliament to look at creating the most advanced digital single market in Europe. I do not wish to get involved in terminology debates, but if I may suggest this, let us talk about a digital union from now on. That would be the real thing for our aspirations, not just a single internal market.  However, at this point, I must note that, although everyone is calling for the widest possible spread of the Internet, in my country, Hungary, the Hungarian Government is currently planning to impose a heavy special tax on internet users. Commissioner, I think you will pay attention to this, because the European community cannot allow this. Thank you very much!

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: Mr President, in this digital world the borders between territories, between parties, between nations are disappearing. There are different rules and we have to be open to all kinds of new ideas and to all kinds of cooperation. We have to think more about the future than about the fears we have from the past. In this work, we shall also have very good cooperation between Parliament and the Commission, because we are representing European interests. However, we see that from the Council we have a lot of problems which are caused by individual interests. I especially want to stress the issue of personal data rights, because the data protection issue is very crucial. In order to go on with any kind of digital services, we have to have very strong common, simple and understandable data protection regulations. I very much hope that, in cooperation with the Commission and Parliament, we can make it clear to the Council that the package of data protection is crucial for the development of the Digital Single Market. It is not a market, I agree. It is really a digital society in Europe, and it should live according to the basic principles of the protection of interest and basic rights. I want to remind you that Commissioner Ansip, when he was a candidate, said that he sees access to digital services and to the digital world as a human right. I agree very much. We have to achieve that. Our partners in the Council of Europe are now proposing the new set of rules of digital rights. On 10 December 2014, they will show that in Brussels. I hope that we have good cooperation with the Council of Europe on digital rights.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, we live in the digital age and our community and society are digital. So, Mr. Commissioner, I'm sorry you're not listening to me, but I understand you have other responsibilities. I would like to encourage you that when you plan and when you come out with your concept in 2015 to do so by thinking about one of the freedoms of the European Union. The European Union is based on four freedoms, but today we are talking, I am convinced deeply, about a new freedom because the digital age is not just a matter of consumer protection, data protection, trade or something like that. It's like electricity, it's like water, it's like something that's really essential for every human being. In this context, I invite you, when you actually talk and agree on a strategy, to take into account that this may be the fifth freedom of the European Union.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: Mr President, I have been closely studying the Google antitrust case for the past two years with Andreas Schwab, in a constructive way. Last week we proposed a rotation mechanism as a possible solution. We have listened to the arguments of the 22 official complainants, including the European Consumer Organisation, so it is not a problem from the enterprise of only one country. Google gives preferential treatment to its own services. This is the central issue – diverting traffic from rival links. Now Google has 90% of the market share in many EU Member States. European enterprises are losing revenues and people are being fired. European consumers are not getting the most pertinent choice, because of Google’s preferential treatment of its own services. We are not against Google or any other US company. We are against monopolies, and we want a level playing field in the European digital market. We want fair and neutral search in the interest of consumers.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Mr President, as someone rather legendary online – Star Trek’s Commander Spock – would say: ʽThis is most illogicalʼ. The growth potential of the Digital Single Market is being overstated here. Who would buy software in a language they do not speak or when technical support is unavailable in their mother tongue? The real barrier is not the 28 countries but the 24 languages. As a consumer, digital single market or no, I am more likely to buy American or Spanish software than German, because I do not speak German. If a UK company sells UK software to a UK consumer, there is no need for a layer of EU red tape to strangle it. Let us keep our internet free from political interference. Let us keep our internet free from censorship. Let us stop tilting at windmills, taking on the might of Google. Sadly, many of the benefits of these proposals, like Spock, are totally fictional.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for this stimulating and lively debate. The resolution covers the key and critical points needed for the development of a fully functioning digital single market. I can only support your call to the Council to open negotiations on the telecoms single market. It is a crucial building block towards a European market that fits the needs of our citizens. Barriers will not fall easily. But ensuring the implementation of existing instruments such as the Consumer Rights Directive, and the full enforcement of our rules – including competition rules – will guarantee fair competition, bring more transparency in the market and reduce the administrative burden. Our single market needs to further modernise consumer rules and copyright, but it also needs to adopt for the technologies ready to come on the market in the near future, such as big data, cloud computing and the Internet of Things. We have an ambitious agenda, and I look forward to working closely with Parliament on the development of the Digital Single Market. Thank you for all your many ideas for how to achieve this goal.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I have received three motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 27 November 2014. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – A functioning digital single market has huge potential for the EU and we have to make it our priority. In order to be able to compete with the US, we have to be more flexible, more innovative and invest more in our cutting-edge technologies. I congratulate Mr Juncker on his choice to make the digital single market one of the fundamental elements of the new Commission. I am especially glad that Mr Ansip became the Vice-President of the Commission for the digital single market. Estonia has showed the world that a small country can become a worldwide leading example for digital government services. Other EU Member States have a lot to learn from this example. I am confident that with Mr Ansip leading we can achieve a lot in the next five years and I see a lot of optimism in the EP.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: written – Completing the digital market is key to stimulating growth and employment in Europe. However, this cannot be done without creating a framework for data protection in the EU and a directive on cyber protection. The current situation in the digital field is broadly fragmented, with 28 national markets and different legislation in force on each. Too many barriers are blocking the free movement of goods and online services across national borders. Current research suggests that a deeper and more complete digital market can lift the GDP of the 28 EU Member States by at least €340 billion a year and create around 2.5 million jobs in total. A competitive digital single market cannot exist without fast, high-capacity broadband and telecommunications networks in all regions of the EU, but without the protection of personal data, privacy and security of electronic communications and networks. Only if we ensure the confidence of citizens and consumers in this market will we be able to build it.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the steel industry in the EU: protecting workers and industry (2014/2976(RSP)).

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, this is the first time (although it is late) for me to stand in front of you and present the current state of the steel industry in Europe. I would like to say a few words and present the overview of the current state. As you remember, the Commission adopted a year ago, in June 2013, a Commission Communication Action Plan for a Competitive and Sustainable Steel Industry in Europe, the so-called Steel Action Plan. This plan recognised the strategic importance of steel to the EU and emphasised that steel-making has a future in Europe, as the European steel industry has many assets in the form of modern plants, advanced products, demanding clients forcing, I hope, constant product innovation and an important domestic market, and of course a skilled workforce. It has also made significant efforts to reduce its environmental impact. The sector, however, faced and still faces major challenges: low demand, increasing energy costs, reliance on imported raw materials, strong and not always undistorted competition and challenging environmental requirements. In its Steel Action Plan, the Commission underlined the importance of addressing these challenges at both EU and national level. Shortly after the Communication on the Steel Action Plan was adopted, the Commission formally created in 2013 our High Level Expert Group on Steel, with the aim of providing a European platform for dialogue, exchange of information and best practice. In June 2014, a Commission staff working document was published which takes stock of the progress made since the adoption of the Steel Action Plan. While highlighting its implementation gaps, it provides an interim overview of the implementation of the actions by the Commission, individual Member States and industry as well, of course, as by social partners. The majority of the key challenges addressed are unlikely to be overcome in a single year, so the overview is a first snapshot, and implementation continues. In one year since the adoption of the Steel Action Plan, about half of the actions foreseen in it have been implemented. Moreover, the fact that the economic situation is slightly improving has led to higher consumption of steel in the main steel-using sectors and has therefore resulted in a better outlook for the steel sector overall. A strong commitment to follow-up underlines the importance of the Steel Action Plan for the sector. The constructive discussions in the meeting of the High Level Group have highlighted the usefulness and the need to continue the dialogue among major stakeholders in this important industrial area.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I very much appreciated your speech because it confirmed the commitment of the Commission, and in particular the Commissioner for Growth, Industry and the Internal Market, to the steel industry. It will have the support of the entire Group of the European People's Party in this action, because we are convinced that the steel sector is and will be decisive in achieving the target of 20% of gross domestic product before the end of 2020 from manufacturing.  This is a key area which must, however, be supported, it must be able to face the challenges that you have highlighted, with all the problems involved. It is therefore right to implement the Commission's action plan, but I believe that in a year's time a new report will have to be presented, as has been done this year, and next year we will have to take stock of the situation in order to understand exactly what the state of the art is. In order to emerge from a crisis aggravated by the cost of energy, the cost of raw materials and unfair competition, as you yourself pointed out, strong action is needed. We must prevent the multiple cases of relocation such as that of the Austrian Voestalpine, we also need to convene the high-level group as soon as possible to talk about the problems of sites that are subject to major restructuring – I am thinking of Florange in France, U.S. Steel in Slovakia, Galați in Romania, Liège in Belgium, Dbrowa Górnicza in Poland, the Ilva , Piombino and Terni in Italy.  And with regard to Terni: it all stems from a Commission decision linked to the application of the competition rules. The time has come, Commissioner, to open a debate on precisely these rules. Today they are outdated. In the face of globalisation, we need to give ourselves new and more modern rules that will enable European industries to compete in the world. The present ones are from 1957 and apply only affect our companies. That is the real crux of the matter if we are to save the steel sector in the long term. I hope that your colleague who is responsible for competition will follow her commitment and really start a new season with regard to competition policy as well.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, after years of post-industrial hangover, the steel plan was certainly a step forward by recognising the crucial role of basic industry and steel in a strategy for the reindustrialisation of the continent. But we believe that this is not enough and that we must go beyond the action plan.  The case to which Mr Tajani of the Terni special industries also referred demonstrates in an emblematic way the limits of the policy framework (competition, State aid, trade), the inadequacy of this policy framework to support the competitiveness of the European steel industry in the world. And so we must build a new set, a new organic framework, understanding, for example, that market shares in the case of the steel industries must be calculated on a global basis, not only on a European basis, that all the instruments provided for in the current rules of trade policies must be applied consistently, that industrial policy must be seriously implemented.  We hope that the negotiations under way in Terni will be brought to a successful conclusion, that the second furnace will be guaranteed, that there will be a future for such a strong and competitive industry. But we believe that the new Commission must go beyond the old steel plan and make a qualitative leap forward in the definition of industrial policies that are equal to the challenges of the global world.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the global economic crisis has seriously affected the steel industry in the European Union. The stagnation of industrial production and the collapse of the construction sector in the European Union now make the future of the steel industry uncertain. This is particularly true in the European south, where thousands of redundancies are being made and the steel works are closing down. Specifically in Greece, domestic demand for products in the sector has returned to 1962 levels and redundancies are on the agenda, as was the case in the Greek steel industry. Hellenic Steel SA in Thessaloniki is in danger of being closed and wound up following the decision of the Italian parent company, which has been placed under the supervision of the Italian Government. This demonstrates, friends of Italian MEPs, the economic interdependence within the European Union and the need to establish a single platform for the countries of the European south.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President. Good night, Commissioner. From the Basque Country we want to applaud this commitment to industry, because it is the main agent of the real economy and the sector most capable of offering stable and quality jobs, an antidote to unemployment and the best guarantee for our social model. Steel is, together with energy, one of the keys to this process for its horizontal presence in all industrial productions. I ask you to remember that steel is and needs knowledge, because the labor cost differential is not a good argument to compete. The future is in our technological and management capacity. In short, the progress of the steel industry is based on people and their knowledge and innovation. Steel is and needs wisdom. Our legislation must assume that we compete in a global market and cannot allow third-party social or environmental gaps to help them place their products here. Steel is and needs stability and that means energy, financing and assurance on an equal footing for all. The competitiveness that some countries gain with innovation, effort and knowledge disappears because there is no equality in access to basic resources. A real medium- and long-term plan for infrastructure investments is also essential. Steel is and ultimately needs consistency. The 'LuxLeaks' earthquake must banish domestic tax competition, which harms public resources available in Europe. The European Finances must use their margins of action in order to stimulate innovation. This is much fairer and more profitable for everyone. Let us hope that with this plan and the plan presented by Mr Juncker we can, among all, move forward on these objectives.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner, although I must honestly say that I do not believe that her report fully realises the dramatic situation of steel production on this continent.  This debate also stems from the oral question we have presented on the industrial and employment prospects of the iron and steel sector in the European Union and we consider an initiative by Parliament, the Italian Presidency and the Commission to combat the loss of jobs and strategic production such as steel in the Member States to be urgently needed. I think it should be stressed that in Italy the situation really is that of dismantling a strategic production axis. We are talking about plants such as piombino, such as taranto, such as terni, which I would like to focus on in particular this evening. Because it is a dispute that we are following with particular concern, because it is an emblematic dispute of the contradictions we face. Firstly, the contradiction between the right to work and the principle of competition. We believe that the right to work must come before a principle of competition, of competition rules which, as has been said, must be radically reviewed, which are obsolete, which are an obstacle to the maintenance of productive assets as well as jobs, rules which, moreover, do not prevent very serious forms of social dumping.  ThyssenKrupp chooses solidarity contracts in Germany and license in Italy, dismantling a production plant with historical roots. So we are asking – and I am only really going to take a few seconds away from you – for a new and different European steel plan. We strongly demand that the most important products, the more specialized ones such as that of the AST in Terni, which, moreover, being an integrated cycle plant with a low environmental impact, also have a high production specialization. We call on the Commission and the Member States to work to ensure that a strategic production axis is not dismantled.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome you, Commissioner Bieńkowska, to this Parliament, and I thank you for your overview regarding the state of play for the European steel industry. I must say, however, that I was a bit surprised that you did not at all mention the present situation on international steel markets, because I believe that has a major impact on the situation in Europe. The United States, as you know, is presently taking anti-dumping measures. Is there a need to take similar measures in Europe too? Maybe you can answer that in your response. This Parliament is pondering – not for the first time – how we could help the steel industry to hold on to the future that it should have. Here I agree with you, Commissioner: steel must have a future in Europe. There is no way of ignoring the advice that the famous baseball philosopher ‘Yogi’ Berra gave to everybody: when you come to a fork in the road, take it! And the fork in the road that we have to decide upon is whether we want to develop the future of our steel industry following an innovation-based competitiveness strategy, or whether we want a dumping-oriented, never-catch-up strategy. The European steel lobby is, unfortunately, focusing its own efforts not on pursuing an innovation agenda but on resorting to a strategy composed of calls for subsidies, calls for protectionism and calls for social and environmental dumping strategies. I have a leaflet here distributed by Eurofair. In seven points it outlines what the industry is asking for from Parliament. All seven points have just one message: give up any meaningful climate and energy transition policy in Europe and we might be thankful. Not a single word about innovation. I believe that competitiveness can only be built on the basis of technology leadership. Voestalpine is competitive and ThyssenKrupp is competitive again. If we want to have a competitive European steel industry, that is where we have to go.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us restore some order of data: we are talking about estimates. The estimates for 2014 of steel production are positive: they predict a +8% which is equal to 1 594 million tons. The highest increase is in Latin America and Africa. Another significant increase is the one scored by Asia and Oceania with a +6%.  Of course, Europe is lagging behind. The trend is confirmed by the interest of multinationals outside the European Union for Ilva and Lucchini di Piombino. But not only that: the Terni AST will most likely also be put back on the market by ThyssenKrupp. Guess who you think will buy it? Do we open their eyes? Shall we try to open our eyes? We are witnessing the liquidation of European steel. Let us try to ensure that the asset transfers that are looming on the horizon do not hide a further reduction in EU production to the benefit of non-EU production. At the same time, we are guaranteeing environmental plans for the reclamation of all European steel sites without neglecting, in particular, the Italian steel sites, which are devastated. We Italians should also ensure that ThyssenKrupp does not try to divest AST steel in favour of German and Finnish steel. Italian colleagues, the AST issue represents a battle of the war that is being waged for the economic sovereignty of our country and for the future of our children. It is no longer enough to talk about it, the workers are tired of hearing fine words: strong action is needed both in Europe and in Italy. I wonder what is the point of welcoming the AST workers here in the European Parliament with great pomp if we are then unable to do anything concrete for them.  In the short term, the European Union and Italy will only be able to experience a new development in the medium and long term through a forward-looking industrial policy that points to manufacturing. For industry and at the same time for our workers, the 5-star Movement will fight as our grandparents did in the last century.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 63 years after the ECSC came into force, the situation of the steel industry in Europe is now catastrophic.  This commission statement is just another statement full of good intentions and wishful thinking. Strengthening competitiveness and promoting innovation is an interesting formula, but one that will not be followed by any concrete effect and will not solve the evils that affect the industry.  The European steel industry still employed more than one million people in the early 1970s, and in 2014 it employed only 360,000 people. In France, steel production in the 1980s reached 24 million tonnes; in 2013, it was down by only 13 million, a drop of almost 40%. The European Union is playing the arsonist fireman who tries to put out, with a half-full sewing dice, the fire that she herself lit, that is the truth. Even as analyses and studies predict that global steel demand is expected to increase by 2.3 billion tonnes by 2025, the European steel industry has collapsed. Our production sites close one after the other, leaving millions of workers every year, as in my region, Lorraine, this week, where politicians came to see the crime scene. The cause of this cataclysm: ultra-liberal economic policy, the disappearance of national borders and the free and undistorted competition demanded by Brussels. Thanks to you, China and India can rub their hands. How, in fact, could France compete with these low-cost countries? It is now clear that this technocratic European Union, subject to the financial markets and the dogmas of the single currency, does not want France to be re-industrialised at all.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Thank you for the floor, Mr. President. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. As the Commissioner referred to, we discussed the steel report earlier this year. I was a rapporteur for that dossier at the time, and I think it is important now to emphasise some long-term priorities for industry initiatives.  Improving the business environment and creating competitive industry frameworks is the key to boosting Steel demand in Europe. In order to achieve this objective, two areas need to change: lower energy prices and falling regulatory costs, otherwise competitiveness will remain a mere dream.  Firstly, as far as the reduction in energy prices is concerned, energy costs in the steel sector account for a significant part of the cost of production. In order to reduce energy prices, it is essential to achieve a single European energy market as soon as possible, to build missing infrastructures, to remove bottlenecks in cross-border capacities and to ensure competitive energy sources. The implementation of these measures is a priority for the Council and the Member States.  Secondly, reducing regulatory costs for industry. Europe must continue to play a leading role in the areas of sustainability, the green economy and climate protection. However, the risk of carbon leakage and the competitiveness of the steel industry must be avoided.  In reforming the EU ETS, we cannot allow the best performing companies in the steel industry to suffer.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Without these measures, the disappointing steel employment trend of recent years and the continued decline in the number of jobs in many European countries, including Hungary, would continue. I believe that European measures to protect jobs are still not enough, but I hope that the EUR 300 billion Juncker plan can also become part of the solution in this area. The re-industrialisation of the European economy can only be achieved as a result of coordinated measures. Thank you for the floor, Mr. President. (The speaker agreed to answer a question marked with a blue card in accordance with Article 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the My question relates to the further development of the steel industry. We now see that the Council, for example, wants to reduce research subsidies. Horizon 2020 is to be shortened. On the other hand, we see double taxation through the ETS system, because, on the one hand, electricity has to pay taxes and, secondly, it is quite clear that heat also costs accordingly. How can we counteract the fact that in future the basis for the best production in the world in Europe will be renewed?

name: András GYÜRK
text: Blue card answer. – Thank you very much to Mr Rübig for his question, which has shed light on an important problem. And the answer lies in the old wisdom that the right hand must know what the left is doing. So there is also a need for concerted action here in this area. A concept that bearing in mind all the aspects that were included in the report I quoted at the time, the report on the steel industry, some of which has since gone on the road to realise, and others that are before us as a task to be accomplished. Thank you for the word.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Commissioner, and I believe that this first contact we have with her on the subject of steel can be a commitment, we will remember this prime evening devoted to such an important subject. I would therefore ask you to be able to give concrete form to the statement that you have made and that we are all convinced that there can be no industrial development without the capacity of the European steel industry if we are not to be totally dependent on production outside Europe.  So if this is, please, give concrete shape to the consequent commitments, among other things in the continuity of the steel plan, which was a strategic plan, a good intuition, a good job and which, in my opinion, must be carried out not by inertia, by continuity, so as to allow things to go forward, but with conviction, even updating it, completing it.  We talked about competition profiles, we talked about research profiles, we talked about trade policies. Many things can be done and we ask you to do them. But Europe has a special duty. This Commission, this Parliament, has a special duty in the case of Terni, because you are well aware that the application of our rules was one of the factors that certainly contributed to that critical situation. So we ask you: how can we not monitor the situation that has arisen there?  We all remember that the European Commission, when it authorised ThyssenKrupp's reacquisition of the Terni site, had the reassurance that all the rules would be respected there and that a site would be built where there would be very strong production, the specific production capacities of stainless steel and export capacity would also be guaranteed. But that has not happened, and then there must be monitoring. ThyssenKrupp has not fulfilled its commitments to the European Commission under those competition rules. We must be vigilant, we must call on the duty of that respect, on qualified production continuity and on respect for employment. Well, we expect this from you: a Commission that with its head held high summons the entrepreneur who has not respected the agreements made with the Commission. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Laura AGEA
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to ask whether Mrs Toia can tell me what was promised to the workers' delegation that had come from Terni here in Brussels with a document that disappeared within two days and was then completely overturned. We cannot be surprised if the Commission is doing the cheating if the demands of the workers who arrived here in Brussels in a stroke of the sponge have been turned upside down and changed.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Mr President, I am very sorry about two things. Firstly, that colleagues that I respect and think are always documented and prepared are, on the other hand, so care less attentive and aware of the documents and the facts – but this is a matter of personal seriousness. Secondly, that we want to make a small, all-national polemic here.  We didn't make any documents disappear. We signed a workers' document, the political forces present here, and then that document remained in our work and in our commitment, so much so that we had deposited it for this session – we will do so for the next time by adhering to a request that you have also made by changing the title, and we have accepted it and with our votes it has passed. We have prepared a whole question, a very detailed, very precise question, which takes up those commitments that the workers have asked us to make, because we share them, for this simple reason of competence of the problems and of personal and political coherence.  So no strange invention of documents that come and go. We have signed that document brought to us by the workers and we are developing it with subsequent documents and with our political action.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her You have not said much wrong today, perhaps because you have not said much overall and, above all, relatively little concrete. We have an economic crisis. We have a drastic reduction in world steel consumption. We have massive competition from non-European countries. We have additional burdens due to high environmental standards as well as certificate trading and relatively high wages by international comparison. All this has led to dramatic distortions of competition in the global market. Unfortunately, to the detriment of the European steel industry, with 65 000 jobs lost in Europe in recent years. And other locations are at risk. There must be cause for the European Union when such companies are at risk, if other sites are at risk, not to interfere in business decisions. Because if companies want and need to restructure in order to adapt to market changes, they must be able to do so. In this situation, we are called upon to support companies in this. In order to safeguard jobs, we would be better advised to give the European steel industry a better framework, to strengthen its competitiveness and not to continue investing in carbon leakage measures. Let us stop falling into bureaucracy! Let us simplify the regulatory framework and thus secure Europe as a steel location – with its modern environmentally friendly plants and efficient process technology – and its jobs! Sustainable, medium and long term! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – In my constituency, North-East England, the steel industry is in serious trouble. Jobs have been lost in Teesside and 40% of the cost of that industry lies in the cost of energy. High energy prices are putting people out of work. I also know people who sell scrap metal, and they now sell it to India because they can sell it at higher prices to India than they can to the UK. Do you accept that something desperately needs to be done about high energy prices in order to save the steel industry?

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. You mean the Tata Steel plant. It is astonishing that there are still steel works in britain. There is not so much left. The mass of it has long since been broken.
