And, as you rightly say, this has a great deal to do with high energy costs, and this has to do above all with emissions trading, because there are other locations in the world where emissions trading is all a little looser. In the end, the steel industry is just going out of Europe to other continents, without any positive effect on the global climate, without any positive effect on the world's carbon footprint.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, one of the hits we hear all the time is the reindustrialization of Europe. But how do we specifically reindustrialise Europe? We're certainly losing the steelmaking game. India, China, Japan become major producers with raw materials from Australia and Brazil.  By the sea they built steelworks, but by the sea they built shipyards. Europe was one of the largest, if not the largest, actually the largest ship manufacturer at one time. Today we produce about 2% of shipwrecks in the world. To be competent in the world, we need to respond seriously to the process of globalization and protect our industry in some way.  One of the steel markets is certainly the shipbuilding industry, which today buys steel outside the European Union. So here we really go around in circles in a way, and I wonder if the reindustrialism of Europe also means a return to what we know. We know how to build sophisticated and expensive ships. We don't have to encourage just those, so to speak, standard ships that transport more air than other.  Today we have sophisticated shipbuilding in Europe and let's try to stimulate such shipbuilding in some way, because then we have innovations, because then we have research, because we have additional development here, because we have additional jobs here, because we have additional competitiveness there and that is certainly what is definitely something for Europe that is a way out of this situation. (Speaker agreed to answer the question "blue card" (Article 149(8) of the E.S. regulation)).

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, can you explain to me how we want to win the global race for competitiveness when the most energy-efficient steelworks can no longer be found in Europe but in China?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I would love to answer you in my native language, in German, but here, I will not. I want to make it clear that when we talk about industry stimulation, I am not saying that we have to go all the way and we can compete to the end neither China, Korea, Japan, nor India in steel production. But we can in those products that follow later, especially those that need a large amount of steel, which we can rightly protect and protect on the global market. So, we are not just talking about steel production, but everything that thanks to steel we produce in Europe.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Mr President, European steelmaking has problems which require a common action plan: high energy costs, which are the result of liberalisation favourable to private oligopolies, as well as the challenges arising from ecological adaptation and which emissions markets cannot solve. But these problems must be placed in their true context, that of the disappearance of industrial policy under the cloak of competition policy. When the European Coal and Steel Community was born, it does so to coordinate production and investment between States, to improve the well-being of workers and the autonomy of the European economy. It was a successful approach that inspired many of europe's dream. What's left of that today? The European Commission uses its competition policy to strengthen market trends rather than exercise control over them, forcing workers and states to compete with each other to reduce wages and social standards, deindustrializing entire regions along the way. That's how it happened with steelmaking and other sectors in my country, Spain. This is not the way, Commissioner. If we are to return to the European dream, competition policy must be subordinated to productive convergence and quality employment, a source of rights.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Mr President, unlike most British Government politicians, I actually worked for a living before I had the honour of being elected. I worked for 20 years in the steel industry in the UK. During that time I saw it change from when we had state-of-the-art service centres that were absolutely fantastic. They were well ahead of their time – it was the 1990s – and were superb. We were using mainly European steel. I was in the stainless sector. Over the period of my career in that industry, I saw it change. The stainless steel that we were using was coming from Taiwan and the Far East and the service centres – mostly the ones with technical details – moved to Germany. What has happened is very straightforward. We have a situation in the UK where a company I know of is collecting scrap metal. It drives round in a truck and picks up the scrap metal, takes it to its furnaces and makes ingots. It then takes them back out and sells them. The same trucks go round the area and collect the scrap metal and put it on a container to China. It comes back on a container from China, comes on a truck into our area and is sold for half the price. The reason is very simple. It is not lack of skill or technical ability. It is entirely to do with the constriction of regulation and carbon emission controls which are being applied and which are stopping our people from trading fairly. There is a very simple answer. Steel and stainless steel goes really well into a form of energy production – and it is not windmills, folks. What it is – and I will whisper it – is nuclear: nuclear power stations, a new generation of them, across the UK making cheap, effective clean energy with British and European steel producing them. What a great solution. What a boost for industry and what a way forward. We can actually compete again rather than shipping all of our industry to the Far East.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, what is generally the case is also true in the steel industry: the European Union has only one objective, to make capital raising a reality in order to make its monopolies even stronger in global competition. The restructuring of the sector is being victimized by workers whose wages are falling and who are being laid off by the thousands in Greece, Italy, Belgium, France and elsewhere, because steel mills are being shut down by intra-sectoral competition or moving factories to countries with cheaper labour. In Greece, the Greek steel industry closes in Thessaloniki but the European Commission, when asked by the Communist Party of Greece (C.K.E.), responds provocatively that it does not interfere in business decisions. However, it intervenes to give subsidies, tax exemptions, cheap electricity to the steel industry, when thousands of households do not have domestic electricity because they cannot pay it, when steelworkers in Greece are condemned for being late to pay their wages. The Greek government and the Troika, bearing in mind the benefit of the monopolies that concentrate production, are closing the ELVO defence industry in Thessaloniki, an industry of strategic importance for the country's defence at a particularly critical time.  There is no solution within the European Union as long as monopolies are at the helm of the economy. The steelworkers and the working class must take the lead in the fight against them, so that the wealth they generate of popular property can be made.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to wish the kind Commissioner well, to whom I asked a question about the steel industry at the time of the hearings a short time ago. Well, we are here again and we are talking about a great subject which, as Mr Toia and Mr Tajani have mentioned, certainly concerns my country, Italy, a great deal. The first point I would like to make concerns – as some of my fellow Members have also mentioned – the worrying fact of China's increase in steel production. Over the past ten years, steel produced in China has increased from 23 % of the world total to as much as 50 %. At the same time, in my country, Italy, which has historically been linked to the steel industry, there has been a 24 % fall in steel production. There are reasons, precise reasons for which we must be vigilant, especially at the moment, trying to balance, as has been said, the reasons for large industry with the reasons for the right ecological concern. But with the concern that ecological concern should not turn into an ecological obsession and therefore produce anti-industrial attitudes, because the anti-industrial attitudes we know have the only great effect of reducing work on our continent. As far as the Italian case is concerned, in particular the case of Terni, it had a first major setback ten years ago when the production of magnetic sheet moved to Germany. In ten years this has led to a serious reduction in the strength of that production site. Today we have another major industrial problem, which has rightly been mentioned, because during 2014 the reacquisition of AST was done with reassurance about the technological and industrial centrality of that site. To become today, as one would like to do, cold rolling from hot rolling would lead to a reduction in the industrial centrality of that site, and therefore a contradiction with the promise made. That is why the call is right for you to be able to work with my colleague The Commissioner for Competition, Mrs Vestager, to ensure that this emergency for the European steel industry is monitored from an industrial point of view. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to ask my colleague whether he is aware of the Taranto emergency, whether he knows how many deaths there are in Taranto, how many neoplasms, how many infertility, how many sufferers of endometriosis, whether he knows the mussel farmers what happened to them, the shepherds who have ended up, the farmers who have ended up. Do not give us the environmentalists, the madmen, the Taliban, extremists, because we are talking about an extreme emergency, not only economic, but environmental and health.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Mr President, I agree with my colleague's concern. He made statements using terms that I did not use, so he probably referred to speeches by other Colleagues. I did not mention the Taliban, I did not talk about fools, I simply spoke of the need for there to be – try to listen again to the recording of my speech – an adequate balance between the needs of the industrial power of our countries and the just, legitimate ecological concern, so that ecological concern does not turn into an ecological obsession and therefore into anti-industrial behaviour.  Our concern is that the two requirements converge towards a single major objective, which is that of development and work.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: Mr President, the steel sector faces many challenges in Europe. One is emissions rights management, because we must continue to lead the fight against climate change, but we have to fight for competitive prices for the industry in order to deliver a stable future to the sector. Another central problem, which has to do with the antyerior, is the costs of electricity supply. Steel, like much of the industry, is energy intensive, and the electricity price has reached unsustainable levels in many Member States. It is vital, along with climate change policy and security of supply, to offer energy prices, competitive electricity prices to industry that are not insatiable. In this sense, in my country in recent days we have seen the result of a new mechanism for fixing electricity prices for the energy-intensive industry. One of these companies, Alcoa, has announced that the result of this new system may entail the closure of its plants in Spain, Asturias and Galicia. And we cannot assume that there are industries that have to leave Europe because of mis regulations that are poorly designed. We ourselves expel much of the industry from Europe. I therefore take this debate to say that I will not leave alcoa workers alone, in Avilés, Lugo and A Coruña, and that we will give the battle for the revision of this new system of fixing electricity prices for the intensive industry. I hope that Parliament will support all the initiatives I will take in the coming days.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Union is protecting small local agricultural products, committing thousands of billions to bailing out banks and is doing nothing against the destruction of the industrial culture that is our first wealth. AST steelworks are a glorious story. There is a lot of talk here about figures – there are also daily existences, stories. In Terni steelworks have existed for one hundred and threety years, they are part of the landscape, of the culture of a territory and above all of the life of a population that from generation to generation has accumulated a unique wisdom in the world in the production of high quality steel. These factories are a moral property of the people of Terni long before a legal property of this or that acronym. Then comes a multinational company, ThyssenKrupp, which, in breach of commitments already made, decides that steel will no longer be made in Terni. It is true that the Italian Government has serious responsibilities, but the Commission has nonetheless made a mistake in applying outdated competition rules, which have had unfair effects.  We must correct this error and force the multinationals to respect the rules we have all set ourselves.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul When it comes down to it, no one in this House supports europe, because when it comes, everyone acts in the best way to protect their own country and their own economy. Look, for example, at France and Germany with their huge car industry in Peugeot, Renault and Volkswagen – they do not care specifically about European laws, it is about protecting their own industry and economy. They support their own industry and their own countries 100%. I fully understand them, because if you are going to compete with the big international companies, it is a prerequisite to take much better care of your own country's economy. Companies in, for example, England, Holland and Finland have found themselves in situations where factories have had to be shut down due to EU legislation. It has had to pay an unreasonable share in energy costs to finance renewable energy. I do not think this is fair. I am not opposed to renewable energy, but it must be fair. The consequence of this is, of course, that production is preferable to be located in other countries with a different cost picture. As a result, a lot of workers lose their jobs. Since 2007, 60 000 workers in the EU have lost their jobs due to unfair competition. What will that figure look like in the future if we continue like this?  Protecting workers is not really a problem on this issue, but the fact that we have to protect workers is a consequence of European legislation in this House. It is quite clear to me that Sweden and Finland – with our very important steel industry – must also follow the examples of France and Germany, with their car industry.  The mining and steel industry has a long and traditional history in Sweden. Between 90 and 95 percent of all steel production is exported and Europe remains Sweden's largest export market. The steel industry is very important for me, for us and for my own country to support in order to maintain employment and welfare in my own country, Sweden.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this debate is largely becoming an Italian debate, not least because recent news reports, even at this time, draw everyone's attention, especially those representing our country, to a serious issue, that of Thyssen, that is, a historic place of high-quality steel production.  We are not dealing here with companies to be rescued, we are faced with the unsused closure of a sector that is important for our economic sovereignty but also for European production, being of the highest level, moved without the Commission intervening despite the fact that it had to intervene, without there being any control by the European Commission for obligations that had to be respected precisely according to the rules that are often imposed on us. A European and global market that is sharply downsizing, with China struggling with oversupply, ready to invade our market with its products. In the euro cage, the price lists of steel companies are coming out and they are imposing on us this workers' exit, the loss of our companies, a very serious loss for the European steel industry and for the Economy of Europe. You've told us a lot of stories and you haven't defended our businesses with your rules on austerity and lack of state aid. This is the sinking of European industry.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Bieńkowska, you mentioned that you will be moving in relation to the European steel plan and that steel still has a future. Well, it is crucial, however, that this plan, Commissioner, is not only declared but is equipped with instruments that are immediately operational and, above all, a priority and moves in a coherent line, aimed at employment and energy-environmental innovation in all the international contexts in which the Union is committed.  Europe needs to do more, and we hope, Commissioner, that you will do more specifically to really support the future of steel, starting with the crises that are taking place in Europe and particularly in Italy, as all my Italian colleagues have said, and of course starting with the AST in Terni, which is currently meeting with the government to resolve this issue. I hope. However, we would like to know from you whether your commitment will be consistent in this respect and what space steel and steel will have in the plan, for example, that Juncker presented today for investment.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we in Europe have long since exhausted the continent's cheap energy and mineral resources, but we have been able to maintain our industry thanks to political, economic and technological supremacy which has continued through inertia for decades and which is now over, let us make a point of doing so. Today the centre of the world is elsewhere, in places where other nations are redeeming themselves, where energy costs less, minerals are cheaper, labour costs less. Products manufactured in Europe incorporate many additional costs not only for the above-mentioned imports but also for the sacrosanct costs of European standards on the environment, emissions, social protection and workers' rights.  Elsewhere, these costs do not exist, because they are outsourced throughout the planet, to the whole of mankind, to the dignity of individual people. It is the globalised free market that allows this. We will be able to save those steelworks in Europe which are less dependent on imports of raw materials, because they are able to process recycled scrap on the spot, or which are special because they produce special steels. But we cannot close all the steel works on the continent and become dependent on a material, an asset, which is still indispensable. We must therefore have the courage to impose not only on the Member States but also on those who export steel to Europe a new form of social and environmental taxation, which is not an anachronistic form of duty but which is ethically and thermodynamically coherent and at least allows us to play on an equal footing. European taxation, therefore, incorporating energy consumption, emissions, environmental and health externalities for mineral extraction and transport into the final prices, and the deficit in the social and trade union rights of workers outside Europe. So those products that will be manufactured outside Europe and imported with lower ethical and thermodynamic standards than Those in Europe will have higher costs, those with better standards will cost less and this will push us forward. This is one of the revolutions we expect from this Europe, but it takes the courage and strength to discuss the rules of competition and state aid from European states to the renewable energy transition.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, if we are to be fair and effective in the extent that we will be in favour of a successful European steel sector, we must be clear among ourselves on the diagnosis.  European steelmakers have closed more than 42 million tonnes of capacity since 2008, representing 40,000 direct job losses and more than 100,000 indirect jobs and subcontractors at a rate of ten employees per million tonnes. We are not overcapacity. Of our current 170 million tonnes of capacity, our trade surplus is only five million. In other words, if economic activity starts up again — it seems to me that we share the same objective — then we will become a net importer. We must therefore react, and quickly, because this sector, which is so structuring in a majority of European countries, is more than ever in a structural crisis which manifests itself in chronic underinvestment in equipment as well as in the training of employees.  This is the purpose of the report that I will have the honour of defending on the sustainable development of the European base metals industry, including steel. European producers must be on an equal footing with their non-European competitors, who are often subject to less ambitious social and environmental standards. But there is no question of encouraging a levelling down that would involve the unraveling of our social rights or the denial of our health and climate objectives. Should we call him back? We have only one health and one planet. On the contrary, we must initiate a virtuous circle and, at this stage, I see only border adjustment as a way to put our producers back in the game while encouraging others to raise their standards. That will be one of the areas that I will try to make credible. In any case, I am pleased that this subject is attracting the interest of my colleagues and the Commission and I am telling you very soon because there is an urgency. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, do you not think that the ultraliberal dogma imposed by the European Union and supported in France by the UMP and Socialist governments is indeed the source of the collapse of the steel industry in France?

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I see that after the Italian-Italian debate, it is the Franco-French debate. I understand that here we are in the European Parliament, that the steel crisis is European and that we therefore need European measures. If you have listened to me well, but apparently it is not, I am advocating a border adjustment, precisely to prevent the sacrosanct savage liberalism you are talking about from doing even more damage.  Madam, I was a steelmaker not so long ago, and for 32 years.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, do we want qualitative development? Do we want sustainable development? Well, but I come from Taranto, a city sadly famous for the Ilva steelworks, one of the largest in Europe, responsible for the pollution of air, land and surrounding lands, which has severely compromised health and the local economy.  There are thirty-six deaths a year among the population, one hundred and four in eleven years among employees, not to mention malformations, infertility, cardiorespiratory diseases and neoplasms. All in clear violation of Article 191 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union, which aims at a high level of protection based on the principles of precaution and preventive action and the 'polluter pays' principle, and also in breach of Directive 2010/75/EU, article 8 of which states: 'Where breach of the authorisation conditions presents an immediate danger to health or ...] the [...], the exercise of the installation [...] or its interested party is suspended". The lower cost and maximisation of profit has been pursued, thanks to the complacency of the controllers and the exclusion of business ethics. The responsibilities of the political class in Europe too are enormous. That is why I call on Parliament and the Commission to establish industrial conversion plans that guarantee safety, workers' health and the environment where, as in Taranto, we need to divest polluting industrial sites and plans for environmental rehabilitation and the rights of neighbouring territories.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr. President! I would like to thank you for this debate, because it is very important for all of us to see that, on the one hand, criticism can and must be criticised, but it is far more important to develop alternatives that will enable us to have a positive strategy in Europe again and put new, well-paid jobs back in the centre of attention in Europe. That is why I would also like to express my sincere thanks to Commissioner Bie-kowska, because the positive approach to this issue is very important for all of us and, of course, the issue of taxation also plays a major role in this area, because energy costs naturally depend to a large extent on taxation and therefore the role of the emission trading system in the steel industry plays a corresponding role and we cannot therefore accept a double burden on the steel industry. Here in the case of regulations from 2020 onwards, we need to find ways of resettling the cleanest and most sustainable industry in the world. What ideas will the Commission put forward to ensure that the best and most sustainable steel industry is given a new framework in Europe? In addition to many other areas, such as aluminium, paper and glass, it would of course be important to get this heat-intensive industry back to Europe.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for all of your remarks, suggestions and opinions. I really want to stress that I take them all very seriously, and I will elaborate on them later on. I see the steel sector as one of the main pillars in the reindustrialisation agenda. The strength of this sector must lie in quality, know-how and skills. That is why, when talking about the steel industry, we have to take into account industry and employees. I intend to continue the work of the high-level expert group. I think that, as regards turning, which was mentioned by many of you, this will provide a reliable sounding board to discuss the situation in the stainless steel sector in Europe. I also, in this case, duly report to Commissioner Vestager, who is responsible for competition, and Commissioner Thyssen of course. We must protect the competitiveness of the steel sector in Europe. You were rightly in saying that the EU is confronted with strong dumping measures, but it has to be said that there are currently ten ongoing anti-dumping investigations and 37 measures in force related to steel. It also has to be said that we have the Waste Shipment Regulation to prevent illegal scrap from leaving Europe. This debate shows that we are going, hand in hand, in the same direction. We must have the courage to defend modern, innovative European steel. We have to do it not only at the European level but at the national and regional levels. In conclusion, you can count on me in this; you can count on my strong, direct and personal involvement in solving this issue, and I hope that this is only the very beginning of our fruitful cooperation.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: : - Thank you very much Commissioner. We are pleased that you have spent this evening with us. Thank you for your statement.  I close the debate. The vote will take place during the next part-session of the European Parliament. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This statement by the Commission on the EU steel industry will not change the current dire situation and will, at most, add up to the declarations of intent of other institutions and bodies. For this text is in fact only a list of wishful thinking that will never be followed by effective measures and for good reason... For decades, the European steel industry has seen its steel production collapse, its production sites close one after the other, leading to massive layoffs. This is the concrete result of significant structural changes in the steel sector. For example, European production of crude steel from the casting continued to decline (-13.4% between 2006 and 2011). This drop is directly related to the decline in demand from the automotive sector or the construction sector. Faced with direct competition from low-cost countries (led by China and India), 280,000 people lost their jobs in the European metallurgical industry between 2008 and 2013.  By establishing the ultraliberal economic model and free and undistorted competition, and by removing national borders, the European Union is fully responsible for the collapse of the European and French steel industry.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. What a sad irony to consider today, in the face of the disaster in the steel sector, the objectives set out by the EU's forerunner, the Coal and Steel Community! Europe destroyed even the foundations of the industry that it had received as its mission to promote its creation. Yet global demand for steel around the world continues to grow. It is therefore the ultra-liberal ideology that blindly rejects all protectionism and any border that alone can explain the total collapse of the steel industry. The measures proposed by the Commission, as well as those taken at national level by President Hollande, whose emptiness I was able to personally measure in Lorraine in Florange last Monday, are only a wooden leg laid by those who decided to amputate. To return to the path of growth and employment, we must radically change policy, renouncing a single currency that is undermining the economy and protecting us from unfair competition from emerging countries whose social and environmental standards are far from ours. Giving a few billion to ward off some of the effects does not change the causes and therefore does not solve the problem.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – The European siderurgy must be seen in the context of the need to reindustrialise European economies, and those who accuse supporters of European steel of nostalgia and retrograde attitude would do well to study those analyses which demonstrate very clearly that, without industrial and technological support, society risks losing its capacity for innovation and technical progress. Siderurgy is not only of symbolic importance to those who think of the birth of the EU as a coal and steel community, but also of as much importance as a support sector for most industries, including high-tech industries.  Looking for ways to reinvigorate steel in Europe, we are not just thinking about the 360,000 jobs, of which 20 000 in Romania, which this industry provides today, but we are thinking about the competitiveness of the European economy, which would suffer if Europe forgets about this industrial sector. Environmental objectives can be achieved without assassinating the steel industry. The EC must pay attention to reducing the administrative burden associated with European programmes and, above all, we need courage to create a common energy policy at European level that will bring the energy price back to the level required by global competition.
